hom.sense: The sixteenth letter of the alphabet; called TaMCN [and TaA]; the A of which is reduced to I [as its radical letter]: when you spell it, you make its final letter quiescent; but when you apply an epithet to it, and make it a noun, you decline it as a noun, saying, [for instance,] hecihi TaMCN TawiylapN [This is a tall T]: it is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only]; and of the letters termed niToEiy-ap, like t and d, because originating from the niToE [q. v.] of the roof of the mouth. (TA.) It is substituted for the t in the measure AifotaEala and the forms inflected therefrom, and [sometimes] for the pronominal t, when immediately following any of the palatal letters [S and D and T and Z]; (MF, TA;) as in [AiSoTabara and AiDoTaraba and AiT-abaEa and AiZoTalama, for AiSotabara and AiDotaraba and UiTotabaEa and AiZotalama; and in] faHaSoTu and HiDoTu and xabaT-u and HafiZoTu, for faHaSotu and HiDotu and xabaTotu and HafiZotu; but some of the grammarians say that this [latter] substitution is not to be made invariably; [nor is it common;] and it is said to be a dialectal peculiarity of some of the Benoo-Temeem. (TA.) It is also substituted for d: thus Yaạḳoob mentions, on the authority of Aṣ, maT-a AlHuruwfa, for mad-a AlHuruwfa: and AO, AlmaboTaOu, for AlmabodaOu: and Aboo-ʼAmr Ez-Záhid, in the Yawákeet, maA OaboEada TaAraka, for maA OaboEada daAraka. (TA.)
[As a numeral, it denotes Nine.]

entry.sense: R. Q. 1. TaOoTaOa, inf. n. TaOoTaOapN, He lowered, or depressed, a thing. (TA.) You say, TOTO raOosahu He lowered his head; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and so taTaOoTaOa↓, alone. (TA.) And TOTO Eani AlX-aIoCi He lowered his head from the thing. (TA.) And taTaOoTaOotu↓ lahumo taTaOuTuWa Ald-ulaApi, (Ṣ, TA,) occurring in a trad. of ʼOthmán, (TA,) I stooped, or lowered myself, [or bent myself down,] to them, like as do the drawers of water with the bucket. (Ṣ, TA.) And taTaOoTaOo↓ lahaA tuxoTiYoka, a prov., (Meyd, TA,) meaning Stoop thy head to it, i. e. to an accident, or a calamity, and it will [miss thee, or] pass by thee: applied in relation to the abstaining from exposing oneself to evil. (Meyd.) And TaOoTaOato sitorahaA ‡ She (a woman) lowered her veil, or curtain. (TA.) And TOTO yadahu biAlEinaAni He lowered his hand with the rein, for the purpose of [the horse's] running and hastening. (Ḳ,* TA.) And [hence, perhaps,] TOTO farasahu He struck his horse with his thighs, to make him go quickly. (Ḳ,* TA.) And TOTO mino fulaAnK † He lowered the reputation, or estimation, or dignity, of such a one. (TA.)

He hastened, or was quick. (TA.) You say, TOTO fiI maAlihi He hastened, and exceeded the usual bounds, in the expenditure of his property. (A, Ḳ, TA.) And TOTO fiI qatolihimo He hastened, and exceeded the usual bounds, in their slaughter. (TA.)
And He filled up a hollow, or cavity, dug in the ground. (TA.)

R. Q. 2. taTaOoTaOa It was, or became, low, or depressed. (Ṣ, O.) It (the head) was, or became, lowered. (Ḳ.) See also the first paragraph, in three places. One says also, taTaAwala EalaI-a fataTaOoTaOotu minohu [app. meaning † He domineered over me, or exalted himself above me, and I humbled, or abased, myself to him: see TOoTaOa mino fulaAnK, above]. (TA.)
TaOoTaMCN A low, or depressed, place, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) of the ground, that conceals him who is within it: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, a narrow, depressed place; also called SaAEN and miEFI. (TA.)
And A short, short-necked, camel. (O, Ḳ.)

1. Tab-a, aor. _u {yaTobubu}, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) agreeably with analogy in the case of a trans. reduplicative verb [like this], (TA,) and _i, (Ḳ, TA,) which is irregular, (TA,) inf. n. Tab-N (O,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA) [and app. Tib-N and Tub-N also accord. to the O and Ḳ, but, accord. to the Mṣb, Tib-N is the subst. from this verb, and app. Tub-N is likewise a simple subst.], He treated medically, therapeutically, or curatively, (O,* Mṣb, Ḳ,*) another person (O, Mṣb) [or the body, and in like manner the soul: see Tib-N, below].

And Tabyota, with kesr, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and Tababota, with fet-ḥ, (O, Ḳ,) [third pers. of each Tab-a, and, accord. to analogy, the aor. of the former is _a, and of the latter _i, but from what follows it seems probable that one says also Tabubota in the same sense,, aor. _u {yaTobubu}, unless Tababota have taTut-u as an irreg. aor.,] Thou wast, or becamest a Tabiyt [or physician], not having been such. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) One says, Uino kunota caA Tub-K faTub-a liEayonayoka, (Ṣ, O, and so in copies of the Ḳ,) or liEayonika, (so in other copies of the Ḳ,) or linafosika, (ISk, TA,) and cA Tab-K, and cA Tib-K, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and faTab-a, and faTib-a; (Ḳ;) [i. e. If thou be a possessor of the art, or science, of physic, be a physician to thine eyes, or thine eye, or thyself;] meaning, begin by rectifying thyself. (ISk, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 902.])

And [hence] Tab-a signifies also † He acted with skill, or expertness: [and in this sense likewise the second pers. is probably Tabibota and Tababota and Tabubota, of which last the inf. n. is app. TabaAbapN, occurring in one of the phrases here following:] so in the saying, AiSonaEohu SanoEapa mano Tab-a limano Hab-a i. e. † Do thou it in the manner of him who acts with skill, or expertness, for him whom he loves: a prov., relating to the accomplishing an object of want skilfully and well. (El-Aḥmar, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 717.]) One says also, AiEomalo fiI hecaA Eamala mano Tab-a limano Hab-a † [Do thou, in this, the deed of him who acts with skill, or expertness, for him whom he loves]. (M, Mṣb,* TA.) And mano Hab-a Tab-a, (Meyd,) or mano OaHab-a Tab-a, (Ḳ,) † He who loves is skilful, or intelligent, and exercises art, or ingenuity, for him whom he loves: (Meyd:) or † he who loves executes affairs with deliberateness and gentleness. (Ḳ.) [That one says Tabubota, as well as Tabibota and Tababota, seems to be indicated by the fact that TabaAbapN↓, as an inf. n., is thus written, in a copy of the KL in my possession, and expl. as meaning The medical art: Golius, however, appears to have found it written, in a copy of the same work, TibaAbapN↓, which is agreeable with analogy as inf. n. of a verb of the measure faEala significant of an art, and is probably correct: Freytag mentions the pl. TabaAYibu as signifying medical arts, on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees.]
Tab-ahu also signifies † He enchanted him, or fascinated him: (O:) and Tub-a ‡ he (a man, Ṣ, A) was enchanted, or fascinated. (Ṣ, A, O. [See also Tib-N, below.])

Tab-a Als-iqaMCa, aor. _u {yaTobubu}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. Tab-N; (Ḳ, TA;) and Tb-bhu↓, with teshdeed to denote muchness, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. tTobiybN; (Ḳ, TA;) He covered the seams of the water-skin, or milk-skin, with a TibaAbap [q. v.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:) and Tab-a Alxuraza he covered the seams with a TibaAbap: (TA) [and] Tab-abati↓ AlmazaAdap she (a girl, or young woman,) put [or sewed] a piece of skin called TibaAbN↓ and TibaAbapN↓, upon the place of junction [of each] of the two extremities of the loop-shaped handles of the mzAdp [or leathern water-bag]; as though she rectified the mzAdp thereby. (A.)
2: see the last sentence above {1}, in two places.

taTobiybN also signifies The inserting a baniyqap [or gore] for the purpose of widening diybaAj [or silk brocade]: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as in the A, one says of a tailor, Tb-bi Alv-awoba, meaning he added, in the garment, a baniyqap [or gore], in order that it might become [more] wide. (TA.)

Also The hanging a siqaMC [or milk-skin] (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) to a pole (Eamuwd, Ṣ, this is the right word, not Euwd [as in copies of the Ḳ], TA) of the tent, (Ṣ,) and then agitating it to produce the butter: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) but Az says, I have not heard tTbyb explained in this sense except on the authority of Lth, and I think that it is tTnyb. (TA.)

3. muTaAb-apN signifies ‡ The seeking, or labouring, to find the means of accomplishment [of an affair, like as the physician seeks to find the means of curing a disease]; syn. mudaAwarapN. (Ḳ, TA.) One says, OanaA OuTaAb-u hecaA AlOamora munocu HiynK kaIo Oabolugahu ‡ [I have been seeking, or labouring, to find the means of accomplishing this affair, that I might attain to it]. (A, TA.)
4. maA OaTab-ahumo How [knowing, or] skilful, or expert, are they! (Meyd, in explaining a prov. cited below, voce Tab-N.)

5. tTb-b He applied himself to the science of physic: (TA:) [or he applied himself to the science of physic but did not know it well: (see the part. n., below:)] or he practised physic: and he professed physic. (KL.)
And tTb-b lahu He inquired of [or consulted] the physicians for him. (TA.)
10. AstTb- liwajaEihi He asked, or sought, a medical prescription for his pain, or disease. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And jaMCa yasotaTib-u lUibilihi ‡ He came asking, or seeking, for his she-camels, a gentle stallion, that would not injure them. (A.)

hom.sense:
R. Q. 1. TaboTaba, (Lth, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. TaboTabapN, (Lth, TA,) said of a valley, or water-course, (Lth, Ḳ, TA,) It flowed with water so that one heard it to make a sound like Tabo Tabo: (Lth, TA:) or it made a sound (Ḳ, TA) with the water. (TA.) TaboTabapN signifies The sounding of water (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) when in a state of commotion and collision, (IAạr, TA,) and of the like, (Ṣ, TA,) and of the dashing of a torrent. (Ḳ.) And taTaboTaba↓ It made a sound, or noise, [like Tabo Tabo,] said of water and the like, (Ṣ,) and of a woman's breast: (TA:) a poet says,
UicaA TaHanato duroniy-apN liEiyaAlihaA
taTaboTaba vadoyaAhaA faTaAra TaHiynuhaA
[When a woman of Durnà grinds for her family, her breasts make a sound by their collision, and her flour flies away]. (Ṣ, TA.)
TaboTaba AlmaMCa He put the water into a state of commotion. (TA.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. taTaboTaba: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: Tab-N: see Tib-N.
It is also an inf. n. used as an epithet: see TabiybN. (Mṣb.)

And, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as such, i. e. an inf. n. used as an epithet, or by original application, but the former is app. the case, and some have mentioned likewise Tb-N↓ and Tub-N↓, (MF, TA,) ‡ Knowing, or possessing knowledge, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA,) respecting a thing, or of a thing; (A, Mṣb, TA;) and so TabiybN↓: (TA:) and (TA) † skilful, or expert; (T, Ḳ;) as also TabiybN↓: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and ‡ gentle; (Nh, TA;) and so too TabiybN↓. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN Tab-N bikacaA † Such a one is knowing with regard to, or is one possessing knowledge of, such a thing. (TA.) And Alqawomu Tab-uwna, or, as some relate it, Alqawomu maA OaTab-uwna↓, is a prov.: the former means † The people, or party, are knowing, or skilful, or expert: and [Meyd says,] I know not any way in which the latter is explainable unless OaTab-u↓ be syn. with Tab-N, like OaxoXanu and xaXinN, &c., and mA a connective. (Meyd.) To a man who offered to cure the [so-called] seal, or stamp, of the prophetic office between the Prophet's shoulder-blades, asserting himself to be a Tabiyb [or physician], the Prophet replied, TabiybuhaA↓ Al-ac-iI xalaqahaA, meaning † He who has knowledge respecting it is He who created it. (TA.) And El-Marrár El-Fak'asee says,
tadiynu limazoruwrK UilaI janobi HaloqapK
mina AlX-ibohi saw-aAhaA birifoqK TabiybuhaA↓
† [She obeys a plaited nose-rein attached to the side of a ring of brass, the skilful maker of which has fashioned it with gentleness]: (Ṣ, L:) i. e. the she-camel of which he speaks obeys her rein that is tied to her nose-ring of brass. (L.) [Hence,] faHolN Tab-N † A stallion [camel] expert in covering, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) as also TabiybN↓; (Mṣb;) that knows the she-camel that is pregnant from her that is not, and her that desires the stallion from her that is covered without desire, and the motion of the fœtus in the womb,, &c.: (TA:) or ‡ that is gentle, and does not injure the female that he covers. (A, TA.) And baEiyrN Tab-N ‡ A camel that is mindful, or careful, as to the place of his foot, (A, Ḳ, TA,) where to tread with it: or that does not place his foot save where he sees. (TA.)
Tub-N: see the next paragraph:
and see also Tab-N.

Tib-N (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Tab-N↓ and Tub-N↓ (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) Medical, therapeutical, or curative, treatment, (A,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ,*) of the body, [i. e. the physicking thereof,] (A, Ḳ,) and likewise of the soul. (Ḳ.)

[And Knowledge]. qaruba Tib-N [Knowledge is near], or, as some relate it, qaruba Tib-FA, (Meyd, O, Ḳ, TA,) with the noun in the accus. case, as a specificative, (TA,) like the phrase niEoma rajulFA, (Meyd, O, TA,) is a prove.: originally said by a woman to a man who asked her an indecent question which he was himself about to resolve: (Meyd, O, Ḳ, TA:) it is like the saying, Oanota EalaI Almujar-abi [q. v.]: (Meyd, TA:) and is related on the authority of Ibn-Háni. (TA.)
And Skill, or expertness. (T, ISd, Meyd, TA.) This is said in the T to be the primary signification. (TA. [But see TabiybN.])
And ‡ Gentleness; gentle treatment or conduct. (Ḳ, TA.)
And ‡ Enchantment, or fascination: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA: but only Tib-N is mentioned in this sense in the Ṣ and O:) used in this sense as ominating cure. (AO, O,* TA.)
And Tib-N signifies also Desire, or appetence; syn. XahowapN: and will, or wish; syn. UiraAdapN. (Ḳ.)

And ‡ State, condition, or case; syn. XaOonN, (Ḳ, TA,) and daOobN: (A, TA:) [or by the latter of these two words may be meant what here follows:] custom, habit, or wont. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) One says, maAcaAka biTib-iI ‡ That is not my custom, habit, or wont. (Ṣ, A, TA.) [See also another ex., in a verse (added here in the Ṣ and TA) which I have cited voce Uino, page 107, col. iii.]
See also Tab-N.

entry.sense: Tub-apN: see TibaAbapN, in two places.

Tib-apN An oblong piece, or portion, of a garment, or of a piece of cloth, (Ṣ, A, TA,) as also TabiybapN↓; (A;) and likewise of skin: or a square piece of the latter: and a round piece in a mazaAdap and a suforap and the like: (TA:) pl. TibabN: (Ṣ:) and, as also TibaAbapN↓, (Aṣ, Ṣ, TA,) † a streak in sand and clouds, (Aṣ, TA,) or a streak of sand or clouds: (Ṣ:) or Tib-apN and TibaAbapN↓ and TabiybapN↓ signify an oblong piece, or portion, of a garment or piece of cloth, and of skin, and † of land or ground, and † of clouds: (Ḳ:) or, all three words, a long strip of a garment or piece of cloth, and of skin, and † of sand, and † of clouds: (TA:) and † a long and narrow tract of land abounding with plants or herbage: (AḤn, TA; and A in explanation of the first word:)
pl. [of the first] TibabN and [of the same, or of the third, or a coll. gen. n. of which the second word is the n. un.,] TibaAbN↓. (Ḳ.) And sometimes Tib-apN is applied to The piece that is sewed upon the edge of the leathern bucket and upon that of the suforap: and the pl. is TibabN and TibaAbN↓. (M, TA.) Tibabu XuEaAEi AlX-amosi (Aṣ, Ṣ, TA) and AlT-ibaAbu↓, (Aṣ, TA,) or Tibabu AlX-amosi and TibaAbuhaA↓, (A, TA,) signify ‡ The streaks that are seen in the rays, or beams, of the sun when it rises. (Aṣ, Ṣ, A,* TA.)

Also ‡ i. q. naAHiyapN [i. e. A side; or a region, quarter, or tract;, &c.]: (so in a copy of the A:) or i. q. naASiyapN [i. e. a forelock;, &c.]. (So in the TA.) [One of these two explanations is app. a mistranscription for the other.]
And one says, Uin-aka lataloqaI fulaAnFA EalaI TibabK muxotalifapK, meaning, EalaI OalowaAnK ‡ [i. e. Verily thou wilt find such a one to be of various moods, dispositions, or characters]. (A, TA.)

hom.sense: TibaAbN [like EilaAjN] A thing that is used for medical, or curative, treatment: so in the saying, caA TibaAbu hecihi AlEil-api [This, or that, is what is used for the medical, or curative, treatment of this disease]. (A, TA.)
See also Tib-apN, latter half, in four places. And see TibaAbapN, in five places: and 1, last sentence.

entry.sense: TabiybN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and Tab-N↓ (Mṣb, TA) [A physician;] one skilled in AlT-ib- [i. e. medical, therapeutical, or curative, treatment]; (Ṣ, TA;) or one who practises medical, therapeutical, or curative, treatment; (Mṣb;) and mutaTab-ibN↓ signifies [likewise one who practises physic: and a professor of physic: (see its verb:) or] one who applies himself to the science of physic: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or one who applies himself to that science but does not know it well: (Nh, TA:) it has been said that the Tabiyb is so called from the same epithet as signifying “skilful, or expert;” but this is not a valid assertion: (TA:) the pl. (of pauc., Ṣ) is OaTib-apN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and (of mult., Ṣ) OaTib-aMCu. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

The first of these words (Tbyb) occurs in a trad. as meaning ‡ A judge; being metonymically thus used, because the office of him who judges between litigants is like that of the Tbyb who cures diseases of the body. (TA.) [And hence, Tabiybu AlEarabi: see faqiyhu AlEarabi, in art. fqh.] See also Tab-N, in six places.
TabaAbapN: see 1, latter half.

hom.sense: TibaAbapN: see 1, latter half.

Also A piece of skin with which the seams of a siqaMC are covered, extending across, [so I render muEotariDapN, app. meaning from side to side, for one edge of the skin beneath overlaps the other,] like the finger [in breadth], doubled [but see what is said below on the authority of AZ] over the place of the sewing: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] TibaAbN↓: (Aṣ, Ṣ, TA:) or that which is put over the place where the two edges of the skin meet, when it is sewed, in the lower part of the qirobap and of the siqaMC and of the UidaAwap: so says Aṣ: or, as also TibaAbN↓, the piece of skin that is put over the two edges of the skin, in these things, when it is laid flat and then sewed, without being doubled: (TA:) accord. to AZ, when the [piece of] skin, in the lower parts of these things, is doubled, and then sewed, it is called EiraAqN; and when it is laid flat and then sewed, without being doubled, it is called TibaAbN↓: (TA; and the like is said in the Ṣ in art. Erq:) or TibaAbapN and EiraAqN both signify, accord. to Aṣ, a piece of skin with which the punctures of the seams are covered: (Ṣ in art. Erq:) or a TibaAbap is a wide strip of skin, in which is the sewing: and the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] is TibaAbN↓: (M, TA:) or, accord. to the Ḳ, a strip of skin that is in the lower part of a qirobap, between the two seams; as also Tub-apN↓: but in this explanation, its author has confounded the words of Lth, who says that TibaAbapN signifies the strip of the skin that is between the two seams; and Tub-apN↓, the strip of skin that is in the lower part of the qirobap, and that contracts the seams [so I render yqArb Alxrz, but the meaning of this phrase is not, to me, clear]. (TA.) See also 1, last sentence.
And see Tib-apN, in two places.

Also, and TibaAbN↓, (Ḳ, TA, in the CK TabAb and TabAbp,) [or the latter is a coll. gen. n.,] † A streak, or narrow elongated tract, of the sky: (Ḳ, TA:) [and app. any portion of the sky not of large extent:] an ex. of the latter word occurs in a verse cited voce maraAkidu: and in another verse, a man in a prison is described as seeing only a TibaAbap of the sky like a shield; i. e. a round portion thereof. (Az, TA.)

entry.sense: TabiybapN, see Tib-apN, in two places.
Tib-iI-N Medical, therapeutical, or curative; of, or relating to, medical, therapeutical, or curative, treatment. (Mṣb.)
TaboTabapN A certain broad thing, one part of which is struck with another part thereof. (TA.)
TaboTabiy-apN A [kind of whip, or scourge, such as is called] dir-ap [q. v.]: (Ḳ, TA:) because the sound that is made by its fall is like Tabo Tabo. (TA.)
TaboTaAbN A certain bird, or flying thing, (TaAYirN,) having large ears. (Ḳ.)
TaboTaAbapN, or TiboTaAbapN, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) A broad piece of wood, with which one plays with the ball, (Ḳ, TA,) or with which the horseman plays with the ball. (T, TA.)
AlT-abaATibu The Eajam [i. e. Persians, or foreigners]. (L, TA.)
maTobuwbN ‡ A man enchanted, or fascinated. (Ṣ, A.)
mutaTab-ibN: see TabiybN.

TabaAhajN, (so in some copies of the Ḳ, and so in the Ṣ voce kabaAbN,) or TabaAhajapN, (so in other copies of the Ḳ,) with fet-ḥ to the T and the h, (TA,) [the latter app. a n. un.,] Flesh-meat cut into thin slices and broiled: (Ḳ,* TA:) or a food composed of flesh-meat and eggs: (MA; in which the word is written TabaAhijap:) [or, accord. to Golius, as on the authority of J and El-Haleemee, a food of pieces of flesh-meat, eggs, onion, and water: but I do not find that J has explained it otherwise than by what here follows:] i. q. kabaAbN: (Ṣ voce kabaAbN:) or a kind of fry of flesh-meat: (L:) arabicized from [the Pers.] tabaAhaho. (Ḳ.) [See also De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed. i. 175.]

hom.sense: 1. Tabaxa, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yaTobuxu} (L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _a {yaTobaxu}, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. TaboxN; (L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AiT-abaxa↓, (Sb, L;) He cooked (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) flesh-meat, (Ṣ, A, L,), &c., (L,) either in a cookingpot [by boiling or stewing or the like] or by roasting or broiling or frying; (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ;) the former verb [accord. to some] said of one who cooks for himself or for others; and the latter, of one who cooks only for himself: (L: [but see an ex. in what follows, of this paragraph; and see also the latter verb below:]) or the former signifies he cooked flesh-meat with broth or gravy. (Az, Mṣb.) And you say also Tabaxa Alqidora He cooked [the contents of] the cooking-pot. (Ṣ, L.) And Tabaxa Almaraqa [He cooked the broth]. (A.)
And Tabaxa He (a dyer) decocted Brazil-wood (baq-am), &c. (A. [See TubaAxapN.])

And He baked bread, and wheat, and bricks [and clay and pottery]. (L.) One says, hecihi xubozapN jay-idapu AlT-aboxi This is a cake of bread well baked [in the hot ashes]. (Ṣ, A,* L, Mṣb.) And hecihi Mjur-apN xay-idapu AlT-aboxi This is a brick well baked. (L, Mṣb.) And AiT-abixuwA↓ lanaA quroSFA [Bake ye for us (app. meaning for us including yourselves) a round cake of bread]. (Ṣ.)

Also † It (the heat) ripened the fruit. (TA.) And Tabaxatohumu AlhawaAjiru ‡ [The vehement midday-heats fevered them]. (A.) And Tabaxahu AljudariI-u ‡ [The small-pox affected him with a hot, or burning, fever]: and in like manner one says of the HaSobap [i. e. measles, or spotted fever: see TaAbixN]. (A.)
[And † He dressed silk: see the pass. part. n., below.]

[Tabixa, aor. _a {yaTobaxu}, inf. n. TabaxN, accord. to the L, seems to signify He was, or became, confirmed in stupidity: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned: and this is doubtful: see OaTobaxu.]

entry.sense: 2. Tb-x, inf. n. taTobiyxN, It (a Hisol [or young lizard of the species called Dab-]) grew big; syn. kabira. (Ṣ. [See muTab-ixN.])
And He (a boy) became active, and grew up, or became a young man; (L, Ḳ;) grew big; syn. kabira; (Ḳ;) and became intelligent. (L.)
5. tTb-x He (a man) ate Tib-iyx [or melons, or water-melons; as also tbT-x]. (A.)

7. AnTbH, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AiT-abaxa↓, (Ḳ, [but this latter seems to be a mistake, occasioned by a misunderstanding of the word AiXotawaI, one of the words by which it is expl. in several of the lexicons,]) It (flesh-meat, Ṣ, A, L, and the same is said of other things, L) was, or became, cooked, either in a cooking-pot [by boiling or stewing or the like] or by roasting or broiling or frying: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or it (flesh-meat) was, or became, cooked with broth, or gravy. (Az, Mṣb.) And you say also, AnTbxt Alqidoru [The contents of] the cooking-pot became cooked. (Ṣ, L.) And AnTbx Almaraqu [The broth became cooked]. (A.)
[Said of bread, and wheat, and bricks and clay and pottery, It was, or they were, or became, baked. (See 1.)]

8. AiT-abaxa He prepared, or prepared for himself, Tabiyx [i. e. flesh-meat cooked in a pot,, &c.], syn. Ait-axaca TabiyxFA, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) or qadiyr, [which signifies flesh-meat cooked in a pot, with, or without, seeds to season it, such as pepper and cumin-seeds and the like, as expl. below, voce TabiyxN]; (TA;) [it is said that] it particularly signifies he cooked for himself alone, [or it signifies for himself with others,] thus differing from Tabaxa, as expl. above: (L:) see 1, in two places; and see also 7: ISk says that AiT-ibaAxN signifies the cooking in a pot and by roasting or broiling or frying. (Ṣ.)
[Also, probably, He prepared, or prepared for himself, the beverage called Tabiyx.]
TiboxN: see TabiyxN.
TaboxapN: see OaTobaxu.

TabaAxN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) thus in the handwriting of El-Iyádee, (L,) and TubaAxN, (Ḳ,) thus in the handwriting of Az, (L,) † Firmness, or soundness; (Ḳ;) strength, and fatness. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) One says, maA bihi TabaAxN ‡ There is not in it, or him, strength [nor fatness]: originally said of lean flesh-meat, that yields no benefit to him who cooks it. (A.) And rajulN layosa bihi TabaAxN † A man in whom is no strength nor fatness. (Ṣ.) And laA TabaAxa lahu † He has no intelligence, nor does he possess any good: and † he has no companion remaining to him. (L.) And fiI kalaAmihi TabaAxN † In his speech is soundness. (TA.) And maA fiI kalaAmihi TabaAxN ‡ There is no profit in his speech. (A.)

TabiyxN, of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN [i. e. i. q. maTobuwxN↓ Cooked;, &c.; but accord. to general usage, it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, signifying cooked flesh-meat]: accord. to some, flesh-meat cooked with broth or gravy; what is cooked without broth or gravy not being thus termed: (Mṣb:) or, as El-Karkhee says, what has broth, or gravy, and contains flesh or fat; dry fried meat, and the like, not being thus termed: (Mgh:) or i. q. qadiyrN [which signifies either flesh-meat cooked in a pot, or flesh-meat cooked in a pot with seeds to season it such as pepper and cumin-seeds and the like]: or qdyr is applied to that which is with seeds to season it, and Tabiyx is that which is not seasoned with seeds such as pepper and cumin-seeds and the like: (L, TA:) [pl. OaTobixapN:] and cooked flesh-meat is also called TiboxN↓. (L.)
[Also A decoction: used in this sense in medical and other books. (See also TubaAxapN.)]
And A sort of munaS-af [i. e. wine, or beverage, cooked until half of it has evaporated]. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.)

And Gypsum: and baked bricks. (Ḳ.) These are said to be meant by the last word in the following trad., UicaA OaraAda Qll-ehu biEabodK suwoCFA jaEala maAlahu fiI AlT-abiyxayoni [When God desires evil to befall a man (lit. a servant), He makes his property to consist in gypsum and baked bricks]. (L.)
TubaAxapN The froth, or foam, that boils over from a cooking-pot. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And A decoction of anything; the extracted juice, thereof, that is taken after coction; such as that of Brazil-wood (baq-am), and the like: (L:) what one takes, of that which he requires [for use], of that which is cooked; such as bq-m; of which one takes the TbAxp for dyeing, and throws away the rest. (T.) [See also TabiyxN.]
TibaAxapN The art, or business, of cooking. (Ḳ.)

Tabiyxapu AlHar-i, (A, L,) pl. TabaAYixu, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) ‡ Hot wind (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ) blowing at midday in the season of vehement heat. (A, L.) One says, xarajuwA fiI Tabiyxapi AlHar-i, and fI TabaAYixihi, ‡ They went forth during the hot wind, &c., and during the hot winds, &c. (A.)

AimoraOupN TabaAxiyapN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and TubaAxiy-apN, (Ḳ,) A young woman, (L, Ḳ,) full, [or plump,] (L,) compact in flesh: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or the latter, (L,) or both, (Ḳ,) an intelligent and beautiful woman. (L, Ḳ.)
Tab-aAxN A cook. (Ḳ.)

Tib-iyxN, (A, L, Ḳ,) written by Aboo-Bekr Tab-iyx, with fet-ḥ to the T, (L,) i. q. biT-iyxN [The melon; or particularly the water-melon]: (L, Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, (L,) or of El-Medeeneh. (A.) [Freytag says that, accord. to some, but he does not not name his authority, it is a large, round melon, rough to the touch, and without a neck, different from the bTyx, which is a small melon.]
TaAbixN [act. part. n. of Tabaxa:]
[and hence,] sing. of Tub-axN, which signifies † The angels of punishment [who roast the damned in Hell]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Hum-aI TaAbixN, (A,) ‡ A [hot, or burning,] fever, such as is termed SaAlibN. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
TaAbixapN ‡ i. q. haAjirapN [i. e. Midday when the heat is vehement; or midday in summer, or in the hot season;, &c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

maTobaxN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and miTobaxN↓, (Mgh, Mṣb,) sometimes called by the latter name as being likened to an instrument, (Mṣb,) and this latter is the only form mentioned in the A, and is said by Sb to be not a noun of place, but a subst. like mirobadN, (TA,) A place of cooking; a place in which cooking is performed; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a cook's house or room; a kitchen. (T.) [See also muT-abaxN.] One says, huwa OaboyaDu AlmaTobaxi ‡ [lit. He is one whose kitchen, or cooking-place, is white; meaning he is inhospitable; like as one says in the contrary case, huwa kaviyru Alr-amaAdi]: and in like manner, humo biyDu AlmaTaAbixi. (A.)
miTobaxN An implement for cooking: or a cooking-pot. (Ḳ.)
See also the next preceding paragraph.

muTab-ixu A young [lizard of the species called] Dab- [in a certain stage of its growth]: in its first stage it is called HisolN; then, gayodaAqN; then, muTab-ixN; then, xuDarimN; and then, Dab-N: (Ṣ, L:) or one that has nearly attained to the size of its parent: or one in its fullest state: (ISd, L:) or the first of the offspring of the Dab- (Oaw-alu waladi AlD-ab-i). (Ḳ. [But this is evidently a mistake, as is observed in the TḲ.])

And A young man that is full [or plump]: (Ḳ:) a child when born is called raDiyEN, and TifolN; then faTiymN; then, daArijN; then, jaforN; then, yaAfiEN; then XadaxN; then, muTab-ixN; and then, kawokabN. (IAạr, TA.)
maTobuwxN: see TabyxN.
UiboriysamN maTobuwxN [Dressed silk]. (Mgh and Mṣb voce HariyrN.)

muT-abaxN A place in which people cook their food. (JK,) One says, hecaA muT-abaxu Alqawomi wahecaA muXotawaAhumo [This is the people's place of cooking their food, and this is the place of their roasting or broiling or frying]. (Ṣ.) [See also maTobaxN.]

TabarozacN, an arabicized word, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from the Pers. tabarozado, (L,) as though pieces were chipped from its sides with an axe, or a hatchet, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) tabaro in Pers. signifying “an axe or a hatchet,” (L,) [and zado “he struck,”] originally meaning “what is chipped, or cut, or hewn, with an axe or a hatchet;” (Shifá el-Ghaleel;) [Sugar-candy; called in the present day Tabarozad and qanod and qanodap: see qanodN:] or excellent sugar: (MF, voce burotN:) or sugar: (L, Ḳ:)
as also suk-arN TabarozaciI-N↓; (Mṣb;) and TabarozalN and TabarozanN: (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and Yaạḳoob says TabarozudN and TabarozulN and TabarozunN: but ISd remarks upon these forms as being unknown to him. (L.)
TabarozaciI-N: see the preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. TabaEa, aor. _a {yaTobaEu}, inf. n. TaboEN, He sealed, stamped, imprinted, or impressed; syn. xatama: (Mṣb:) [and, as now used, he printed a book or the like:] taboEN and xatomN both signify the making an impression in, or upon, clay and the like: (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ:) or, as Er-Rághib says, the impressing a thing with the engraving of the signet and stamp: (TA in this art. and in art. xtm: [see more in the first paragraph of the latter art:]) and he says also that TaboEN signifies the figuring a thing with some particular figure; as in the case of the TaboE of the die for stamping coins, and the TaboE of coins [themselves]: but that it is more general in signification than xatomN, and more particular than naqoXN; as will be shown by what follows: accord. to Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ the Grammarian, TaboEN and xatomN both signify the covering over a thing, and securing oneself from a thing's entering it: and IAth says [in like manner] that they held TaboEN to be syn. with rayonN [inf. n. of raAna]: but Mujáhid says that rayonN denotes less than TaboEN; and TaboEN, less than UiqofaAlN [or the “closing with a lock:” this he says with reference to a phrase in the Ḳur xlvii. 26]. (TA.) You say, TabaEa AlkitaAba, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and TabaEa EalaI AlkitaAbi, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) He sealed (xatama, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the writing, or letter. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.) And TabaEa He branded, or otherwise marked, the sheep, or goat. (O. [See TaAbaEN.]) And TabaEa Qll-ehu EalaI qalobihi ‡ God sealed [or set a seal upon] his [i. e. an unbeliever's] heart, so that he should not heed admonition, nor be disposed to that which is good; (Mgh;) or so that belief should not enter it: (O:) [and in like manner, xatama Ealayohi, q. v.:] in this, regard is had to the TaboE, and the TabiyEap, which is the natural constitution or disposition; for it denotes the characterizing of the soul with some particular quality or qualities, either by creation or by habit, and more especially by creation. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

Also He began to make, or manufacture, a thing: and he made [a thing] as in instances here following. (Mgh.) You say, TabaEa mina AlT-iyni jar-apF He made, [or fashioned, or moulded,] of the clay, a jar. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And TabaEa All-abina, (Mgh, TA,) and Als-ayofa, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ,) and Ald-irohamu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) He made (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ) [the crude bricks, and the sword, and the dirhem]: or TabaEa Ald-araAhima he struck (Mgh, Mṣb) with the die (Mṣb) [i. e. coined, or minted,] the dirhems, or money. (Mgh, Mṣb.) And [hence] one says, Tabaqahu Qll-ehu EalaI AlOamori, aor. and inf. n. as above, † God created him with an adaptation, or a disposition, to the thing, affair, state, condition, or case; or adapted him, or disposed him, by creation, [or nature], thereto. (TA.) And TubiEa EalaI AlX-aIoCi † He (a man, O, TA) was created with an adaptation, or a disposition, to the thing; or was adapted, or disposed, by creation [or nature], thereto; syn. jubila, (IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA,) or fuTira. (Lḥ, TA.)

Also, (aor. as above, TA, and so the inf. n., O, TA,) He filled (Er-Rághib, O, Ḳ, TA) a measure for corn or the like, (Er-Rághib, TA,) or a leathern bucket, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and a skin, (O, TA,), &c.; (O;) and so Tb-E↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. taTobiyEN: (Ṣ, O:) because the quantity that fills it is a sign that prevents the taking a portion of what is in it [without the act's being discovered]. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

And TabaEa qafaAhu, (IAạr, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (IAạr, O,) He struck the back of his neck with his hand; (IAạr, O, Ḳ;) i. e. the back of the neck of a boy: if with the ends of the fingers, one says, qac-a qafaAhu. (IAạr, O.)
maA OadoriI mino Oayona TabaEa means I know not whence he came forth; syn. TalaEa. (TA.)

TabiEa, [aor. _a {yaTobaEu},] inf. n. TabaEN, said of a sword, It was, or became, rusty, or overspread with rust: (Ṣ:) or very rusty, or overspread with much rust. (Ḳ, TA: from an explanation of the aor.: but this is written in the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, and in the O, yuTobaEu. [An explanation of TabaEN in the O and Ḳ confirms the reading yaTobaEu; and another confirmation thereof will be found in what follows in this paragraph.])

Said of a thing, (Mṣb,) or of a garment, or piece of cloth, (TA,) inf. n. TabaEN, It was, or became, dirty; (Mṣb, TA;) and tT-bE↓ is likewise said [in the same sense] of a garment, or piece of cloth. (M and TA voce raAna, in art. ryn.)

Said of a man, † He was or became, filthy or foul [in character]. (Ṣ.) And † He was, or became, sluggish, lazy, or indolent. (Ṣ.) One says of a man, yaTobaEu, (O, Ḳ,) like yaforaHu, (Ḳ,) meaning † He has no penetrative energy, sharpness, or effectiveness, in the affairs that are the means, or causes, of attaining honour, like the sword that is overspread with much rust. (O, Ḳ.)

TubiEa, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. TaboEN, (O,) said of a man, † He was rendered [or pronounced] filthy or foul [in character]; (O, Ḳ;) on the authority of Sh; (O;) and so TabiEa, like fariHa; (TA as on the authority of Sh; [but this I think doubtful;]) and disgraced, or dishonoured: (Ḳ:) and Tub-iEa↓, (O, TA,) inf. n. taTobiyEN, (TA,) he was rendered [or pronounced] filthy or foul [in character], (O, TA,) and blamed, or discommended. (O.)
2. Tb-E, inf. n. taTobiyEN, He sealed well [or much, or he sealed a number of writings, &c.]. (KL: in which only the inf. n. is mentioned.)
And He loaded [a beast heavily, or] well. (KL.)
See also 1, a little after the middle.
taTobiyEN signifies also The rendering unclean, dirty, filthy, or impure. (O, Ḳ.)
See 1, last sentence.

entry.sense: 5. tTb-E † He affected what was not in his natural disposition. (Ḥar p. 236.) You say, tTb-E biTibaAEihi ‡ He affected, or feigned, his [i. e. another's] natural dispositions. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

Also It (a vessel) became full or filled: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) quasi-pass. of Tb-Ehu. (Ṣ.) And tTb-E biAlmaMCi It (a river, or rivulet,) overflowed its sides with the water, and poured it forth abundantly. (TA.)
See also 1, last quarter.

7. yacuwbu wayanoTabiEu, a phrase of Es-Sarakhsee, meaning [It melts, and then] it admits of being sealed, stamped, imprinted, or impressed, is allowable on the ground of analogy, though we have not heard it [as transmitted from the Arabs of pure speech]. (Mgh.)

[Golius has erroneously expl. AnTbE as meaning “Mansuetus, edoctus, obsequens fuit;” on the authority of the KL; evidently in consequence of his having found its inf. n. (AinoTibaAEN) written in a copy of that work for AinoTiyAEN, the reading in my own copy.]
8. AlAiT-ibaAEu for AlAiDoTibaAEu see in art DbE.

TaboEN, originally an inf. n., (Ṣ,) signifies † A nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like; or an idiosyncrasy; syn. sajiy-apN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) or jibil-apN (Mṣb) and xaliyqapN; (TA;) to which a man is adapted by creation; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) [as though it were stamped, or impressed, upon him;] as also TabiyEapN↓; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) or this signifies his mizaAj [i. e. constitution, or temperament, or aggregate natural constituents], composed of the [four] humours; (Mṣb; [see mizaAjN;]) and TibaAEN↓; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) or this last signifies, (Ḳ,) or signifies also, (O,) with the article Al prefixed to it, what is, or are, constituted in us in consequence of food and drink, &c. (maA ruk-iba fiynaA mina AlmaToEami waAlmaXorabi wagoyari celika [in which mTEm and mXrb are evidently used as inf. ns. agreeably with general analogy]), (O, Ḳ, TA,) by gyr clk being meant such as straitness and ampleness [of circumstances], and niggardliness and liberality, (TA,) of the natural dispositions that are inseparable from us; (O, Ḳ, TA;) and this word is fem., (O, TA,) like TabiyEapN, as is said in the M; or it is sing. and masc. accord. to Abu-l-Kásim Ez-Zejjájee; and it is also pl. of TaboEN, as it is said to be by Az; (TA;) [and those who have asserted it to be fem. may have held it to be a pl.;] and TaAbiEN↓ is syn. with TibaAEN [as a sing.]; (Ḳ, TA;) or, as Lḥ says, it is syn. with TabiyEapN↓; of which the pl. is TabaAYiEu. (TA.)

Also † Model, make, fashion, or mould: as in the saying, AiDoribohu EalaI TaboEi hecaA † [Make thou it, fashion it, or mould it, according to the model, make, fashion, or mould, of this]. (IAạr, O, L, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: And i. q. magiyDu maMCK [i. e. A place where water sinks, or goes away, into the earth; or where water enters into the earth; and where it collects]: (O, Ḳ:) pl. OaTobaAEN. (O, TA.)

And The quantity sufficient for the filling of a measure for corn or the like, and of a skin, (O, Ḳ, TA, [wAls-iqMCu in the CK being a mistake for waAls-iqaMCi,]) such as does not admit of any addition: and the quantity that a vessel holds, of water. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph, in two places.

entry.sense: TabaEN Dirtiness, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or dirt: (Ṣ:) or, as also TiboEN↓, rustiness, or rust, (O, Ḳ, TA,) upon iron; (TA;) and dirtiness, or dirt, (O, Ḳ, TA,) covering the sword: (TA:) or the former signifies much dirtiness or dirt, from rust: (Lth, O, Ḳ:) pl. OaTobaAEN. (Ḳ. [See TabiEa, of which TabaEN is the inf. n.])

Also ‡ Disgrace, or dishonour; (AʼObeyd, O, Ḳ, TA;) and so TiyoEN↓; (TA;) it is in religion, or in respect of worldly things. (AʼObeyd, TA.) Thábit-Kutneh says, in a verse ascribed by Et-Tanookhee to 'Orweh Ibn-Udheyneh,
laA xayora fiI TamaEK yahodiI UilaI TabaEK
waguf-apN mino qiwaAmi AlEayoXi takofiyniI
[There is no good in coveting, or covetousness, that leads to disgrace: and a sufficiency of the means of subsistence contents me]: (O, TA:) yahodiI in this case means yuWad-iI. (O.)
TabiEN Rusty; applied to a sword. (TA.)
Dirty. (Mṣb.)
Applied to a man, (O,) ‡ Filthy, or foul, base, ignoble, mean, or sordid, in disposition; that will not be ashamed of an evil action or saying. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
And † Sluggish, lazy, or indolent. (TA.)
TuboEaAnu AlOamiyri The clay with which the prince, or governor, seals. (O, Ḳ.)
TibaAEN, as a sing. and a pl.: see TiboEN.
TibaAEapN The art, or craft, of the Tab-aAE, or manufacturer of swords, (O, Ḳ, TA,) or of knives, or of spear-heads, or the like. (TA.)
[Also, as used in the present day, The art of printing.]

TabiyEapN: see TaboEN, in two places. [It generally signifies] The mizaAj [or nature, as meaning the constitution, or temperament, or aggregate natural constituents, of an animal body, or any other thing, for instance,] of medicine, and of fire, which God has rendered subservient [to some purpose or purposes]. (TA.) [Hence the phrase yabasato TabiyEatuhu, meaning He became costive. And AlT-abaAYiEu AlOarobaEu The four humours of the body: see xiloTN and mizaAjN.]

TabiyEiI-N Natural; i. e. of, or relating to, the natural, native, or innate, disposition, or temper, or other quality or property; like jibil-iI-N; meaning essential; resulting from the Creator's ordering of the natural disposition in the body. (Mṣb in art. jbl.) [Hence, AlEilomu AlT-abiyEiI-u Natural, or physical, science.]
Tab-aAEN A manufacturer of swords, (O, Ḳ, TA,) or of knives, or of spear-heads, or the like. (TA.)

Tab-uwEN A certain venomous duwayob-ap [or insect]: (El-Jáhidh, O, Ḳ, TA:) or, (Ḳ,) as said to Az by a man of Egypt, an insect (duwayob-ap) (O) of the same kind as the qirodaAn [or ticks], (O, Ḳ,) but (O) the bite of which occasions intense pain; (O, Ḳ;) and sometimes, or often, he that is bitten by it becomes swollen [app. in the part bitten], and is relieved by sweet things: Az says that it is with the Arabs [called, or what is called,] the nibor [which is expl. as meaning the tick; or an insect resembling the tick, which, when it creeps upon the camel, causes the track along which it creeps to swell; or as being smaller than the tick, that bites, and causes the place of its bite to swell;, &c.]: (O:) [accord. to Dmr, as stated by Freytag, i. q. qamoqaAmapN, which is expl. as applied to a small tick; and a species of louse, that clings tightly to the roots of the hair, app. meaning a crab-louse:] what is known thereof [or by this appellation] now is a thing of the form of a small emaciated tick, that sticks to the body of a man, and is hardly, or not at all, severed, except by the application of mercury. (TA.)

Tib-iyEN The heart (lub-) of the TaloE [as meaning the spathe of the palm-tree]; (O, Ḳ;) so called because of its fulness; expl. in a trad. of El-Ḥasan El-Basree as meaning the TaloE [i. e., in this case, agreeably with general usage, the spadix of the palm-tree] in its kufur-aI [i. e. spathe], the kufur-uI being the envelope of the TaloE. (O, TA.)

TaAbaEN and TaAbiEN↓ (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) i. q. xaAtamN (Ṣ, O) and xaAtimN (O) [meaning A signet, seal, or stamp; i. e.] a thing with which one seals, stamps, imprints, or impresses: (Mṣb, TA:) [and also a seal, or stamp, as meaning a piece of clay or wax or the like, or a place in a paper, &c., impressed, or imprinted, with the instrument thus called:] and accord. to ISh, the former, (O,) or each, (Ḳ,) signifies the miysam [which means the instrument for the branding or otherwise marking, and the brand or other mark,] of the faraAYiD [or beasts that are to be given in payment of the poor-rate: see TabaEa AlX-aApa]. (O, Ḳ.) One says, AlT-aAbiEu TaAbiEN↓ [The signet,, &c., is a thing that seals,, &c.]; which is like the attribution of the act to the instrument. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And kalaAmN Ealayohi TaAbaEu AlfaSaAHapi ‡ [Language upon which is the stamp of chasteness, or perspicuity,, &c.]. (TA.)
TaAbiEN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places:
and see also TaboEN.
[maTobaEN A place where anything is sealed, stamped, imprinted, or impressed. And, as used in the present day, A printing-house; as also maTobaEapN.]
muTobaEapN, applied to a she-camel: see the next paragraph.
muTab-aEN Filled: so its fem. in the phrase qirobapN muTab-aEapN TaEaAmFA [A skin filled with food]. (TA.)
And muTab-aEapN applied to a she-camel, Filled with fat and flesh, so as to be rendered firm in make: (Az, TA:) or [simply] fat. (Z, TA.)
And, (TA,) so applied, Heavily laden; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) and [in like manner] muTobaEapN↓ a she-camel heavily burdened by her load. (TA.)
And muhorN muTab-aEN A colt trained, or rendered tractable or manageable. (TA.)
muTobuwEN [pass. part. n. of TabaEa in all its senses].
You say, huwa maTobuwEN EalaI Alkarami ‡ [He is created with an adaptation, or a disposition, to generosity]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. [Tabaqahu, aor. _i {yaTobiqu}, accord. to Freytag, is expl. in the Ḳ as syn. with OaTobaqahu in the first of the senses assigned to this latter below: but I find no authority for this in the Ḳ nor in any other lexicon.]

Tabiqato yaduhu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) aor. _a {yaTobaqu}; and Tabaqabo, aor. _u {yaTobuqu}; (TA;) inf. n. (of the former, Ṣ, TA) TabaqN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) and (of the latter, TA) TaboqN; (Ḳ, TA;) † His arm would not be stretched forth; (Ṣ, O;) or ‡ stuck to his side, (Ḳ, TA,) and would not be stretched forth. (TA.)
Tabiqa yafoEalu biI kacaA i. q. Tafiqa [i. e. He set about, or began,, &c., doing with me such a thing]. (O, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: 2. Tb-qhu, inf. n. taTobiyqN: see 4.

[Hence,] Tb-q Als-aHaAbu Aljaw-a The clouds covered the mid-air between the heaven and the earth: (Ḳ:) and OaTobaqa↓ Algayomu Als-amaMCa and Tab-aqahaA [The clouds covered the sky]: (Mgh, TA:) both signify the same. (TA.) And Tb-q AlmaMCu wajoha AlOaroDi The water covered the face of the earth, or land. (Ḳ.)

And Tb-q AlX-aIoCu, inf. n. as above, i. q. Eam-a [The thing was, or became, common, or general, in its relation or relations, operation or operations, effect or effects,, &c.]. (Ḳ.) And as syn. with Eam-a it is trans.: so in the phrase, hecaA maTarN Tab-aqa AlOaroDa [This is rain that has included the general extent of the land within the compass of its fall]. (TA.) And one says also, Tb-q Algayomu, (Ṣ, O, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) The clouds rained upon the whole of the land; (Ṣ, O;) or made their rain common, or general, (Ḳ, TA,) to the land. (TA.)
taTobiyqN also signifies The making a thing to suit, match, tally, conform, correspond, or agree, with another thing. (KL.)
[And Tb-q bayona AlX-ayoYayoni He put the two things together, face to face. (See also 3.)]

[Hence,] Alt-aTobiyqu in the divinely-appointed act of prayer is The putting the hands [together, palm to palm,] between the thighs in the act of bowing oneself; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and in like manner in the act termed Alt-aXah-ud [q. v.]. (El-Ḥarbee, TA.) One says of a person bowing himself in prayer, Tb-q, and likewise ATbq↓, (TA,) or Tb-q kaf-ayohi, (Mgh,) or Tb-q bayona kaf-ayohi vum-a waDaEahumaA bayona faxicayohi, (O,) He put his hands [together, palm to palm, ana then put them] between his thighs. (Mgh.) The doing thus is forbidden; (Mgh, O;) for the hands should be placed upon the knees. (O.)

Also The horse's raising his fore feet together and putting them down together in running: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Aṣ, the leaping of a camel, or of a she-camel, and then alighting so that the legs fall upon the ground together; the doing of which is not approved. (TA.)
And Tb-qt AlUibilu AlT-ariyqa ‡ The camels travelled the road without declining from the right direction. (TA. [The verb is there written without any syll. sings; but is evidently thus.])

And Tb-q Als-ayofu, (Ṣ, O, TA,) [i. e. Tb-q Als-ayofu AlmafoSila,] inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) The sword hit the joint (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) and severed the limb: (Ṣ, O, TA:) or fell between two bones. (TA.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely, El-Farezdaḳ, praising El-Hajjáj, and likening him to a sword, (O,)
yuSam-imu OaHoyaAnFA waHiynFA yuTab-iqu
[expl. in art. Sm]. (Ṣ, O.) Hence, yuTab-iqu AlmafoSila means † He hits aright the argument, proof, or evidence: (Ṣ, O:) and this is also said of an eloquent man. (AZ, TA voce qaAlabN, q. v.) Hence also, Tab-aqa alone, † He hit upon the right mode of judicial decision: (O, TA:) and the text of the tradition. (TA.)

3. muTaAbaqapN signifies The putting a thing upon, or above, or over, another thing commensurate therewith: whence the phrase, TaAbaqotu Aln-aEola [i. e., as expl. in Bḍ lxvii. 3, I sewed another sole upon the sole or sandal]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [Hence] one says also, TaAbaqotu bayona AlX-ayoYayoni I made the two things commensurate, and stuck them together. (Ṣ, O. [See also 2.]) And TAbq bayona qamiySayoni He put on, or attired himself with, two shirts, one over, or outside, the other; (Ḳ, TA;) and in like manner SaAfaqa bayonahumaA, and TaAraqa, (TA,) and ZaAhara. (A, &c. in art. Zhr.)

And TAbqhu, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. muTaAbaqapN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) and TibaAqN, (Ḳ, TA,) It suited, matched, tallied, conformed, corresponded, or agreed, with it; (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ, TA;) and was equal to it; or was like it in measure, size, quantity, or the like. (TA.)
[Hence,] one says, hecaA jawaAbN yuTaAbiqu Als-uWaAla [This is an answer, or a reply, that is suitable to the question]. (TA.)
And TAbqt zawojahaA She (a woman) complied with [the desire of] her husband: and TAbqt said of a she-camel, and of a woman, She was, or became, submissive to him who desired her. (TA.)
And TAbq liI biHaq-iI He obeyed me with respect to my right, or due, and hastened to render it; or he acknowledged to me my right, or due, willingly. (TA.)
And TAbqhu EalaI AlOamori He combined with him, and aided him, to do the thing: or [simply] he aided him to do it. (TA.)
And TAbq EalaI AlEamali He became accustomed, habituated, or inured, to the work. (Ṣ,* O,* TA.)

muTaAbaqapN, of a horse, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) in his running, (Ṣ, O,) and in like manner of a camel, as in the A, (TA,) means His putting his hind feet in the places that were those of his fore feet. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And (hence, TA) ‡ The walking as one shackled; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) i. e., with short steps. (TA.) [See an ex. voce HijolN.]

hom.sense: 4. ATbqhu He covered it; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also Tb-qhu↓, inf. n. taTobiyqN; (Ḳ;) [i. e.] he made it to be covered; (Ṣ, O;) he put the Tabaq, i. e. cover, upon it, namely, a jar [or the like]. (Mgh. [And the like is said in several other arts. in other lexicons.]) And ATbqtu Alr-aHaI I put the upper mill-stone upon the lower. (TA.)

See also 2, second sentence. [This last ex. shows that ATbqhu signifies sometimes It covered it as meaning it became a cover, or like a cover, to it; and ATbq Ealayohi likewise has this meaning; as also AnTbq↓ Elyh, and tTb-q↓ Elyh.]

[Hence,] one says, ATbq Ealayohi Aljunuwnu (Mṣb, TA) † Insanity covered [i. e. veiled, or wholly obscured,] his reason, or intellect. (TA.) And ATbqt Ealayohi AlHum-aI (Mgh, O, TA) ‡ The fever was, or became, continual upon him, not quitting him night nor day. (TA.)
ATbqwA EalaI AlOamori means ‡ They combined consentaneously, or agreed together, respecting, or to do, the thing, or affair; (Ṣ,* Mgh,* O,* Mṣb, TA;*) and so tTAbqwA↓ Ealayohi. (MA.)
And ATbqwA Ealayohi They came round about him. (MA.)
[And ATbqt Ealayohi AlHay-apu The serpent wound itself round upon him. (See TabaqN, last sentence.)]
And ATbqt Aln-ujuwmu The stars appeared, and were numerous; (O, Ḳ, TA;) [as though they were like a cover; or] as though they were stage above stage (TabaqapN fawoqa TabaqapK). (TA.)

[ATbqhu Ealayohi signifies He made it to cover it; i. e., to be a cover, or like a cover, upon it.] You say, OaTobaqa EalaI maxoraji AlHarofi mina All-isaAni maA HaAcaAhu mina AlHanaki [He made to cover the part of the tongue which was the place of utterance of the letter what was opposite to it of the palate; i. e. he put that part of his tongue close beneath the opposite part of the palate]. (O.)

[Hence,] OaTobaqa Ealayohimu AlEacaAba, said of God, ‡ He made punishment to fall, or come, upon them in common, or universally, [as though He made it to cover them,] so that none of them escaped. (Jel in xci. 14.)

And OaTobaqa Qll-ehu Ealayohi AlHum-aI, and Aljunuwna, † God made the fever to be continual upon him, and in like manner insanity: the verb being used as intrans. and trans. (Mṣb. [But its author adds that he had not found this: meaning that he had not found any classical authority for the trans. use of the verb in this and similar senses.])

One says also, ATbq AlbaAba [He closed the door]. (Mṣb and Ḳ in art. wSd;, &c.) And OaTobiqo Xafatayoka [Close thy lips;] i. e. † be thou silent. (TA.) [And ATbq AlkitaAba He closed, or shut, the book. And ATbq Alv-awoba He folded together the garment, or piece of cloth.] See also 2, in the middle of the paragraph.
maA OaTobaqahu How skilful is he (O, Ḳ) likacaA [for the performance of such a thing]! (O) is form Tab-aqa AlmafoSila. (JK.)

entry.sense: 5. tTb-q: see 7.
tTb-q Ealayohi: see 4. [Hence,] one says, lawo taTab-aqati Als-amaMCu EalaI AlOaroDi maA faEalotu kacaA [If the heaven became as a cover upon the earth, I would not do such a thing]. (Ṣ, O.)

6. tTAbq AlX-ayoMni The two things suited, matched, tallied, conformed, corresponded, or agreed, each with the other; (Ṣ,* O,* TA;) and were equal, each to the other; or were like each other in measure, size, quantity, or the like. (TA.) And tTAbqwA EalaI AlOamori: see 4.
7. AnTbq It was, or became, covered; (O, Ḳ;) [i. e.] it was made to be covered; [or it had the Tabaq, i. e. cover, put upon it;] quasi-pass. of OaTobaqahu; (O;) and so tTb-q↓. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
[And It became closed; said of a door, &c.]
[Hence,] yanoTabiqu Ealayohi AlkalaAmu i. q. yanogaliqu † [Speech is as though it were closed against him; i. e. he is impeded in his speech, unable to speak, or tonguetied]. (O.)
See also 4.
[Hence one says of a rule, yanoTabiqu EalaI kacaA wakacaA † It applies to such and such things or subjects.]

hom.sense: TaboqN: see an ex. of the accus. case, in the phrase waladati Alganamu TaboqFA, voce TabaqN, last quarter.
TaboqN is also expl., by IAạr, as meaning The doing wrong, or injuring, by false pretence or false allegation. (TA.)
TiboqN: see TabaqN, in the latter part of the former half.
Tiboqu AlOaroDi: see TibaAqN.

hecaA AlX-aIoCu Tiboqu hecaA, (IAạr, O, Ḳ,*) and Tabaquhu↓, and TibaAquhu↓, (IAạr,* O,* Ḳ,) and Tabiyquhu↓, (IAạr, O, Ḳ,) and TaAbaquhu↓, and muTobaquhu↓, (IAạr, O, TA,) i. q. muTaAbiquhu↓ [i. e. This thing is the match of this; or what suits, matches, tallies, conforms, corresponds, or agrees, with this; what is equal to this; or the like of this in measure, size, quantity, or the like]. (IAạr, O, Ḳ, TA.)

TiboqN signifies also A space, or period, (saAEapN,) of the day; and so TiboqapN↓: and TabiyqN↓ signifies the same of the night: (Ḳ:) you say, Oaqamotu Einodahu TiboqFA mina Aln-ahaAri, and TiboqapF↓, I remained at his abode during a space, or period, (saAEapF,) of the day: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O:) and TiboqFA, (Ḳ, TA,) with kesr, (TA,) or TabaqFA↓, (so in the O,) and TabiyqFA↓, i. e. a while, or a long time, syn. maliy-FA: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:)
or, accord. to the L, one says, OataAnaA baEoda TiboqK mina All-ayoli, and Tabiyq↓, he came to us after a space, or period, (HiynK,) of the night; and in like manner, mina Aln-ahaAri of the day: (TA:) the pl. of TabiyqN is TuboqN. (Ḳ.) [See also TabaqN, in, or near, the middle of the paragraph.]
And Snares for birds, or things with which birds are caught; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O;) like fixaAx; as also TibaqN; of which [latter] the sing is TiboqapN↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
Also A road, or way:
and i. q. dasotuwr [as a Pers. word, generally meaning Permission, or leave, as expl. by Golius in this instance]. (KL. [But for these two significations I have not found any other authority.])

entry.sense: TabaqN A thing that is the equal of another thing (Mṣb, Ḳ) of any kind (Ḳ) in its measure so that it covers the whole extent of the latter like the lid: this is its primary signification: (Mṣb:) [whence] one says, hecaA AlX-aIoCu Tabaqu hecaA, like Tiboquhu, q. v.: (IAạr, O, Ḳ:) and [hence] it signifies The cover, or lid, (Mgh, Ḳ,) of a jar, (Mgh,) or of anything: (Ḳ:) pl. OaTobaAqN (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ) [and TibaAqN, mentioned in the Mṣb as a pl. of TabaqN in another, but similar, sense, which will be found in what follows, but better known as a pl. of TabaqapN], and OaTobiqapN is added as another pl. in the Ḳ, but [SM says] this is strange; I have not found it in the [other] lexicons; and it may be that the right reading is waOaTobaqahu, as syn. with what immediately there follows it, i. e. waTab-aqahu. (TA.) waAfaqa Xan-N Tabaqaho is [a prov.] expl. (O, Ḳ, TA) by Aṣ (O, TA) as said of a company of men who had a receptacle of skin [i. e. a water-skin] that had become old and worn out, wherefore they made a Tabaq [or cover] for it: (O, Ḳ, TA:) [so that the meaning is, A water-skin that had become old and worn out suited its cover:] or Xan-N and TabaqN [in the O Tbqh] were two tribes; (Ṣ,* O, Ḳ * TA;) and, as ISd says, Xan-N does not here mean a water-skin, for this has no Tabaq: (TA:) or [TabaqahN is for Tabaqapa, and] Tabaqapu was an intelligent woman, whom an intelligent man took as his wife. (O, Ḳ, TA. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 800.])

Also A certain household utensil; (Mṣb;) [i. e. a dish, or plate; perhaps thus called because the cover of a cooking-vessel is often used as a dish or plate;] the thing upon which one eats, (Ḳ, TA,) and in which one eats; and the thing upon which fruit is placed [i. e. a dish, or plate, used for that purpose; and likewise a round tray, and the like]: (TA:) pl. OaTobaAqN and TibaAqN. (Mṣb.)

‡ The surface of the earth [considered as a cover]. (Ḳ, TA.) [And in like manner applied to A layer, or stratum, of earth. dafanotu AlX-aIoCa is expl. in the Mṣb as meaning Oaxofayotuhu taHota OaTobaAqi Alt-uraAbi I concealed it beneath the layers, or strata, of the earth, or dust. See also TabaqapN.]
‡ The exterior part of the pudendum muliebre [considered as a cover]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ, TA.)
A fold, a ply, or an overlapping part, of a thing. (PṢ. [See HafivN.])
[And hence, app., ‡ A roller of the sea: see MciI-N.]

A thin bone [or cartilage] that forms a division between any two vertebræ: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) what is between any two vertebræ of a horse [&c.]: pl. OaTobaAqN: (Kr:) and some say, the vertebræ altogether: and some say, a vertebra, in any part. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting the day of resurrection, taboqaI OaSolaAbu AlmunaAfiqiyna TabaqFA waAHidFA, meaning [The backbones of the hypocrites shall be (lit. continue to be) as though they were] one vertebra: or, as some say, TabaqapF↓; and [they say that] TabaqN is the pl. [or coll. gen. n.]. (O. [See also 1 in art. Eqm.])
[And Any of the successively-superimposed cartilages of the windpipe: pl. OaTobaAqN. (See HanojarapN, in art. Hjr; and see also HuloquwmN.)]

Any of the stages of Hell [whereof every one except the lowest is imagined to be like a cover over another]. (TA.) [And in like manner, Any of the Seven Heavens:] one says, Als-amewaAtu TibaAqN, meaning The Heavens are [composed of stages] one above another; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;*) every heaven [except the lowest] being like a Tbq to another: (Mṣb:) or this is said because of their being conformable, one with another: (Ḳ:) and it is said in the Ḳur lxvii. 3, Aal-aciI xalaqa saboEa samewaAtK TibaAqFA, meaning [Who hath created seven heavens] placed one above another; TbAqA being the inf. n. of TaAbaqotu Aln-aEola [q. v.], used as an epithet; or for Tuwbiqato TibaAqFA; or caAta TibaAqK, pl. of TabaqN or of TabaqapN↓. (Bḍ.)

[Any of the bones of the head; because they compose a covering: or] OaTobaAqu Alr-aOosi means the bones of the head because they suit one another and have certain parts of them inserted and infixed into other parts. (TA. [See 8 in art. Xjr.])
Any joint of a limb: pl. OaTobaAqN. (Aṣ, TA.)

A collective number of men, and of locusts; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also TiboqN↓, (Ḳ,) which is thus expl. by Aṣ in relation to men: (TA:) or a multitude of men, and of locusts: (Ḳ:) [app. considered as covering a space of ground:] or a company of men that are equal with a company like them. (ISd, TA.)

A generation of mankind; or the people of one time; syn. qaronN and EaAlamN; as in the saying of El-ʼAbbás,
UicaA maDaI EaAlamN badaA Tabaqu
[metre munosariH] i. e. UicaA maDaI qaronN badaA qaronN [When a generation passes away, a generation appears in its place]: the qaron being called Tabaq because they are a Tabaq [i. e. cover] to the earth: then they pass away and another Tabq comes: (O, TA:) or, as IAạr says, TabaqN signifies a people after a people. (TA.) And (TA) A qaron [i. e. generation] of time: or twenty years: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as in the book of El-Hejeree, on the authority of I’Ab, TabaqapN↓ has this latter meaning. (TA.)

‡ A rain such as fills and covers the earth, or land; (TA;) or such as is general, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and of wide extent; termed by a poet (namely, Imra-el-Ḳeys, O, TA) Tabaqu AlOaroDi: (Ṣ, O, TA:) or a lasting rain, consecutive in its falls. (Mṣb.) And OaSobaHati AlOaroDu TabaqFA waAHidFA means † [The land became, or became in the morning,] covered with water over its surface. (TA.)

A main portion of the night and of the day: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or, accord. to the Mufradát [of Er-Rághib], Tabaqu All-ayoli waAln-ahaAri signifies saAEaAtuhu AlmTAbqp [app. a mistranscription for AlmutaTaAbiqapu, and meaning the commensurate, or similar, or equal, portions of the night and of the day]. (TA.) See also TiboqN.

And A state, or condition; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) as also TabaqapN↓, of which the pl. is TibaAqN: the pl. of the former in this sense is OaTobaAqN. (TA.) Hence the phrase, latarokabun-a TabaqFA Eano TabaqK, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) in the Ḳur [lxxxiv. 19], meaning [Ye shall assuredly enter upon] state after state, (Ṣ,* O, TA,) and predicament after predicament; as in the A; (TA;) on the day of resurrection; (Ṣ;) the state being termed Tabaq because it will fill the hearts [as though the dread thereof covered them], or will be near to doing so; (O, TA;) and Eano being put in this instance, as it is in many others, in the place of baEoda: (TA:) or the meaning is, one after another of similar states of hardship: or it may be, degrees of hardship after degrees thereof; TabaqN accord. to this rendering being regarded as pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of TabaqapN↓: (Ksh and Bḍ:) or [ye shall assuredly mount upon] the heaven in one state after another state; for it (the heaven) shall be like muhol [i. e. molten brass or iron, &c., as is said in the Ḳur lxx. 8,] and then successively in other states: (O, TA:) so says Aboo-Bekr: accord. to Er-Rághib, it points to the various successive states of man in the present world from his creation, and in the world to come until his resting in one of the two abodes [Paradise or Hell]: or, accord. to Ibn-Abi-l- Hadeed, it means [ye shall assuredly enter upon] difficulty after difficulty; as is related by MF; and the same is said by Az on the authority of I’Ab: (TA:) some read latarokaban-a, meaning thou, O Moḥammad, shalt assuredly mount upon stage after stage of the stages (OaTobaAq) of heaven; and I’Ab and Ibn-Mes-ood read latarokabin-a, with kesr to the b, which is accord. to the dial. of Temeem, and Keys and Asad and Rabee'ah pronounce the first letter of the future with kesr except when it is I: ʼOmar read layarokaban-a, either as relating to the Prophet or as referring to him who is mentioned in verses 10-15 of the same chapter. (O, TA.) One says also, baAta yaroEaI Tabaqa Aln-ujuwmi, meaning ‡ [He passed the night watching] the state of the stars in their course: (TA:)
or Tabaqu Aln-ujuwmi means the falling [or app. setting] of stars after [other] stars: or, accord. to Es-Sadoosee, the rising of a star and the setting of another: and a collective number thereof after a collective number [of others]: and such, he says, are termed TabaqaAtN↓ mina Aln-ujuwmi. (O.)

jaMCati AlUibilu TabaqFA waAHidFA means EalaI xuf-K waAHidK [i. e. The camels came following one another, in a single line: see art. xf]. (TA.) And one says, waladati Alganamu TabaqFA and TaboqFA↓, meaning The sheep, or goats, brought forth one after another: (L:) El-Umawee says, when they do thus, one says, waladatohaA Alr-ujayolaMCi and waladatohaA TabaqFA and TabaqapF↓ [They brought them forth (i. e. their young ones) one after another]. (Ṣ, O.)

[The pl.] AlOaTobaAqu also signifies Those who are remote, and those who are remotely connected: so in a trad. respecting the signs of the resurrection, or of the time thereof; in which it is said, yuwoSalu AlOaTobaAqu wayuqoTaEu AlOaroHaAmu [Those who are remote, and those who are remotely related, shall be brought into close connection, and the ties of relationship shall be severed]. (TA.)

binotu TabaqK is an appellation of A female tortoise, [app. because of the cover of her back,] which, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) as the Arabs assert, (Ṣ, O,) lays ninety-nine eggs, all of them [eventually] tortoises, and lays one egg which discloses (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) a serpent (Ḳ) [or a serpent such as is termed] an Oasowad; (Ṣ, O;) or, accord. to Az, sixty-nine [eggs], and the seventieth is [eventually] a viper. (So in a marg. note in one of my copies of the Ṣ; in which, also, the appellation is written binotu Tabaqa, instead of binotu TabaqK.) Hence the phrase UiHodaI banaAti TabaqK, meaning ‡ A calamity; (Ṣ, O, TA;) as also binotu TabaqK: (TA:) banaAtu TabaqK meaning calamities [like muTobiqaAtN]: as well as tortoises: and serpents: (Ḳ:) and Oum-u TabaqK [in like manner] means calamity: (TA in art. Trq:) or, accord. to EthTha'álibee, Tabaqu [thus, imperfectly decl., as written in the L,] signifies a yellow serpent: (L, TA:) and Oum-u TabaqK and binotu TabaqK are said to signify the serpent, because of its coiling itself round: or banaAtu TabaqK is an appellation applied to serpents because of their winding themselves round (lUiTobaAqihaA) upon him whom they bite; or, as some say, because the Haw-aMC [q. v.] confines them beneath the lids (OaTobaAq) of the baskets (OasofaAT) covered with leather; or, as Z says, because they resemble the Tabaq [i. e. cover, or dish, or plate,] when they coil themselves round. (TA.)

hom.sense: TiboqapN: see TiboqN, former half, in two places:
and also near the end of the same paragraph.

entry.sense: TabaqapN [generally signifying Any one of two or more things that are placed, or situate, one above another; a stage, story, or floor; a layer, or stratum; or the like: pl. TabaqaAtN and TibaAqN]: see TabaqN, in seven places.
[Hence, TabaqaAtu AlEayoni The coats, or tunics, of the eye. (See julayodapN.)]
[Hence also,] TabaqaAtu Aln-aAsi The degrees, ranks, orders, or classes, of men. (Ṣ,* O,* TA.) [Thus, TabaqaAtu AlX-uEaraMCi means The orders, or classes, of the poets.]
kutubuhu UilaI-a TabaqapN is a phrase mentioned by Ibn-ʼAbbád as meaning His letters, or epistles, to me are consecutive. (O, TA.)
A Tabaqap of land is [A portion] like a maXaArap [expl. in art. Xwr]. (TA.)
yadN TabiqapN An arm that will not be stretched forth; (Ṣ, O, TA;) sticking to the side. (Ḳ, TA.)
TibaAqN [a pl. of TabaqapN, and said to be also a pl. of TabaqN].

TibaAqu AlOaroDi means What is upon the earth: (Ṣ, O:) or what fills, or would fill, the earth, extending over it in general, or in common, (O, TA,) as though it were a Tabaq [or cover] to it. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting Kureysh, Eilomu EaAlimihimo TibaAqu AlOaroDi i. e. The knowledge of the knowing of them is as though it extended over the earth in general, or in common, and were a cover to it; (O,* TA;) or, as some relate it, Tiboqu↓ AlOaroDi. (TA.)
See also TiboqN.
And see muTobiqN.
TabiyqN: see TiboqN, in five places.
TabaAqaMCu ‡ A camel (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) that will not cover; (Ṣ, O;) lacking strength, or ability, to cover. (Ḳ, TA.)

And, applied to a man, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) † Impeded in his speech; unable to speak; or tonguetied: (O, Ḳ,* TA:) or that will not perform the act of coïtus: (TA:) or heavy, covering the woman (yuTobiqu EalaI AlmaroOapi, in the CK [erroneously] yaTobiqu, and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ yuTab-iq AlmrOpa,) with his breast by reason of his heaviness: (Ḳ, TA:) or impotent; syn. EiyiI-N: (Ṣ, O:) or impotent (EayiI-N), heavy, covering her whom he compresses, or the woman, with his breast, by reason of his littleness, or immature age: accord. to Aṣ, stupid, foolish, impotent in speech or actions, dull, or heavy: accord. to IAạr, whose reason is veiled, or wholly obscured, (muTobaqN↓ Ealayohi, [see OaTobaqa Ealayohi Aljunuwnu,]) by stupidity, or foolishness: or, as some say, whose affairs are veiled to him [so that he sees not how to accomplish them]: or who lacks ability to speak, his lips being closed. (TA.)
taHal-abuwA EalaI celika AlUinosaAni TabaAqaMCa means They collected themselves together against that man, all of them. (ISh, O.)

Tub-aAqN A species of tree, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) growing upon the mountains of Mekkeh; (Ḳ;) described to AḤn by some one or more of Azd-es-Saráh as being about the stature of a man in height, growing near one another, scarcely ever or never seen singly, having long, slender, green leaves, which slip [between the fingers] when squeezed, applied as a dressing to a fracture, which, remaining upon it, they consolidate; it has a clustered yellow flower; is not eaten by the camels, but by the sheep or goats; and grows among the rocks, with the EaroEar; the bees eat from its flowers, and the mountain-goats also feed upon it: (O:) it is beneficial as an antidote against poisons, taken internally and applied as a dressing, and as a remedy for the mange, or scab, and the itch, and fevers of long continuance, and colic, and jaundice, and obstructions of the liver; and is very healing. (Ḳ.) [TubaAqN, thus written by Golius, without teshdeed, is said by him to be Ocimum agreste; as on the authority of Meyd; but he has not given the syn. by which Meyd has explained it.] bayona Xav-K waTub-aAqK, in a trad. of Moḥammad Ibn-El-Hanafeeyeh, means in the places where grow these two species of trees; (O;) i. e. in the tracts of the mountains of Mekkeh. (TA.)

hom.sense: TaAbaqN: see TiboqN.

Also, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ,) and TaAbiqN, (Ḳ,) both mentioned by Ks and Lḥ, [and both in one of my copies of the Ṣ,] (TA,) and TaAbaAqN↓, (Fr, O, Ḳ,) A large brick: (Mgh:) or a large baked brick: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) [or a large tile, or flat piece of baked clay:] and a large [piece of] glass: (Mgh:) arabicized, (Ṣ, Mgh, O,) from the Pers., (Ṣ, O,) i. e. from taAbaho: (Mgh, O:) [and particularly a large flat piece of baked clay, or of stone, &c., that is used for a trapdoor:] whence, bayotu AlT-aAbaqi [the chamber that has a trap-door]: (Mgh: [see also muTobiqN:]) pl. TawaAbiqu and TawaAbiyqu; (Mgh, O, Ḳ;) the former being pl. of TAbq, and the latter of TAbAq. (O.)

And in like manner the TaAbaq of iron [is from the Pers. taAbaho]: (O:) [i. e.] TaAbaqN signifies also, (Ḳ, TA,) and TaAbiqN likewise, (accord. to the Ḳ,) A certain vessel in which one cooks, (Ḳ, TA,) [meaning a frying-pan,] of iron or of copper: (TA:) arabicized from taAbaho. (Ḳ, TA.)
[And A plate, or flat piece, of metal.]
biYorN caAtu TaAbaqK means A well in which are projecting edges. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)

And TaAbaqN and TaAbiqN signify also A limb, or member, (Th, O,* Ḳ, TA,) of a human being, such as the arm, or hand, and the leg, or foot, and the like: (Th, TA:) applied in a trad. to the hand of a thief, which is to be cut off: (TA:) [see TaAYifN, in art. Twf:] or they signify [or signify also] the half of a sheep, or goat: (Ḳ, TA:) or as much thereof as two persons, or three, eat. (TA.)

entry.sense: AlEim-apu AlT-aAbiqiy-apu The mode of disposing the turban without winding [a portion thereof] beneath the chin: (O, Ḳ:) a mode which is forbidden. (O.) jaMCa fulaAnN mutaEam-imFA TaAbiqiy-KA means Such a one came having his turban disposed in the manner above described. (IAạr, O.)
maTobaqN: see muTobiqN.
muTobaqN [pass. part. n. of 4, Covered;, &c.].

AlHuruwfu AlmuTobaqapu are The letters S, D, T, and Z: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) the part of the tongue which is the place of their utterance being [closely] covered [in their utterance] by what is opposite to it of the palate. (O, TA.)

And muTobaqN is used by the vulgar for muTobaqN Ealayohi, [which is for muTobaqN Ealayohi Aljunuwnu,] meaning † Upon whom insanity is made to be continual: (Mṣb: see also TabaAqaMCu [where muTobaqN Ealoyahi is in my opinion better rendered]:) and you say majonuwnapN muTobaqN EalayohaA [in like manner, for muTobaqN EalayohaA Aljunuwnu † an insane female whose reason insanity has veiled, or wholly obscured]. (Mgh, O.)
muTobaqN Ealayohi signifies also Affected with a swooning, or a fit of insensibility. (TA.)
bayotN muTobaqN means † A verse of which the former hemistich ends in the middle of a word. (Z, TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
And see TiboqN.
muTobiqN Covering. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
Hence, (Ḳ, TA,) junuwnN muTobiqN (Mgh, O, Ḳ, TA) † Insanity that covers [i. e. veils, or wholly obscures,] the reason, or intellect. (TA.)
Hum-aI muTobiqapN (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) ‡ A continual fever, not quitting night nor day. (Ṣ, Mṣb,* TA.)
muTobiqapN [for sanapN muTobiqapN] means ‡ A hard, or severe, year. (TA.) And muTobiqaAtN means † Calamities [like banaAtu TabaqK]. (TA.)
And muTobiqN may have the same meaning as muTobaqN↓. (TA. [But in what sense the latter is here used is not specified.])
muTab-aqN: see TiboqN, last quarter.
jaraAdN muTab-iqN Locusts extending in common or universally [over a tract or region]. (TA.) And saHaAbapN muTab-iqapN A cloud raining upon the whole of a land. (Ṣ, O.)
muTab-iqN signifies also [A sword hitting the joint, and severing the limb: or falling between two bones.]
[And hence,] ‡ One who takes the right course in affairs by his [good] judgment. (Ḳ, TA.)
muTaAbiqN: see an ex. voce TiboqN

1. Tabala, (Lth, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaTobulu} (Lth, O, Mṣb) and _i {yaTobilu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. TabolN, He beat the Tabol [or drum; he drummed]; (Lth, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Tb-l↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taTobiylN, (O, Mṣb,) signifies the same; (O,* Ḳ;) or the latter verb signifies he did so much. (Mṣb.)
2: see the preceding paragraph {1}.

hom.sense: TabolN [A drum;] a certain thing with which one beats, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) [or rather upon which one beats,] well known, (Mṣb,) having a single face, and having two faces: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. [of mult.] TubuwlN (O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OaTobaAlN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) [Hence] one says, huwa TabolN cuw wajohayoni [lit. He is a double-faced drum]; meaning ‡ he is of ill-omened, or hard, aspect. (TA.) And fulaAnN yaDoribu AlT-abola taHota AlkisaMCi [lit. Such a one beats the drum beneath the garment called ksAC; meaning, † strives to conceal what is notorious: similar to the Pers. saying Tabol daro ziyri Giliym zadano]. (TA.)

Also A raboEap [or small round basket, covered with leather,] for perfumes. (TA.) And A sal-ap [or round basket] for food, [app. shallow, resembling a round tray, for it is said to be] like the xiwaAn; also called Taboliy-apN↓, of which the pl. is TabaAlK. (TA. [See also sad-N, last sentence.]) [And A kind of tray, of wood, used for counting money, &c.; also called TabolapN↓: this is app. what is meant by the saying in the Ṣ, Tabolu Ald-araAhimi wagayorihaA maEoruwfN; and by the saying in the O, Tabolapu Ald-aArahimi maEoruwfN.]

And A certain sort of garments, or cloths, (Lth, IDrd, O, Ḳ,*) upon which is the form of the Tabol [or drum], (Lth, O, Ḳ,) or figured with the like of Tubuwl [or drums], (T, TA,) of the fabric of El-Yemen, or of Egypt, (Ḳ,) or brought from Egypt, and called also AlT-aboliy-apu↓ and Oarodiyapu AlT-aboli: (Lth, O:) which last appellation is expl. in the A as meaning [garments of the kind called] buruwd, worn by the lords, or principal personages, of Egypt. (TA.)

And The [tax called] xaraAj: (IAạr, O, Ḳ:) [or an instalment thereof; for] one says, Oad-aI Oaholu miSora TabolFA mina AlxaraAji and Tabolayoni and TubuwlFA The people of Egypt payed an instalment of the xrAj [and two instalments and several instalments]; so called after the Tabol [or drum] of the bunodaAr [app. meaning the farmer-general of the tax, who, it seems from this, announced his coming by the beating of a drum]: (A, TA:) [and probably syn. with xaraAjN as meaning revenue in a general sense; for it is added,] hence [the saying] huwa yuHib-u AlT-aboliy-apa↓ (O, Ḳ [in the CK taHota is erroneously put for yuHib-u]) i. e. He loves the xaraAj, (O,) or the money of the xaraAj, (Ḳ,) without fatigue. (O.)

AlT-abolu signifies also Alxaloqu and Aln-aAsu [i. e. The created beings in general and mankind in particular]: one says, maA OadoriI OaI-u AlT-aboli huwa i. e. [I know not] what one of mankind he is: (Ṣ, O:) and so OaI-u AlT-aboni huwa. (TA.)

entry.sense: TabolapN [A wooden tray; generally round: like TalobahN in Persian. And such is app. meant by what here follows:] A certain thing of wood, which women take for their use. (TA.) See also TabolN.
Taboliy-apN: see TabolN, in three places.
TibaAlapN The art, or occupation, of beating the Tbol [or drum]. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Tab-aAlN [A drummer;] a beater of the Tabol. (O, Ḳ.*)
Tab-aAlapN [fem. of Tab-aAlN:]
[and] i. q. TuwbaAlapN, q. v.

TuwbaAlapN A ewe; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also Tab-aAlapN↓: (TA:) pl. of the former TuwbaAlaAtN: a ram is not to be called TuwbaAlN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Tarafeh says,
naEaAniI HanaAnapu TuwbaAlapF
tasaf-u yabisFA mina AlEiXoriqi
[Hanáneh announced to me death (app. meaning predicted my death, for otherwise it should be naEaI liI): a ewe that eats dry 'ishrik]: (Ṣ, O, TA:) [in explanation of which it is said,] naEaAniI means OaxobaraniI biAlmawoti: and HanaAnap is the name of a pastor: and TwbAlp is put in the accus. case as a term of revilement, as though the poet said OaEoniI TuwbaAlapF. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Tabina lahu, aor. _a {yaTobanu}, inf. n. TabanN [accord. to the CK TabonN, which is wrong]; and Tabana lh, aor. _i {yaTobinu}, inf. n. TabaAnapN and TabaAniyapN and TubuwnapN; He understood it; or knew it; or had knowledge, or was cognizant, of it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) some say that TabanN relates to good, and tabanN to evil; but AO says that TabaAnapN and tabaAnapN are one, meaning the being very intelligent or knowing; and Lḥ says that TabaAnapN and TabaAniyapN, and tabaAnapN and tabaAniyapN, and laqaAnapN and laqaAniyapN, and lahaAnapN and lahaAniyapN [app. mistranscriptions for kahaAnapN and kahaAniyapN], are one [in meaning]. (TA. [See more in the first paragraph {1} of art. tbn.])

Tabina lahaA, in which the pronoun refers to a woman, a phrase occurring in a trad., is expl. as meaning He apprehended what was the state, or disposition, of her mind, and that she was one who would comply with the endeavour to seduce her: or, accord. to Sh, it is Tabana lahaA, like Daraba, and means he deceived her, or corrupted her, and beguiled her: accord. to Az, Tabinotu bihi, aor. _a {yaTobanu}, inf. n. TabinN; and Tabanotu, aor. _i {yaTobinu}, inf. n. TabaAnapN; signify I deceived him, or deluded him. (TA.)
And TabaAniyapN, accord. to IB, signifies also A man's looking at his wife, and either debarring her from appearing or being angry and jealous. (TA.)
Tabana Aln-aAra, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaTobinu} (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK _a,]) inf. n. TabonN, (Ḳ,) He covered the fire [in a hollow] in the earth, in order that it might not become extinguished. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And TaAbana Zahorahu He lowered, or bent down, his back; syn. TaAmanahu. (TA.)
And TaAbanahu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muTaAbanapN and TibaAnN, (TA,) He, or it, agreed, or accorded, with him, or it. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Q. Q. 4. AiTobaOan-a i. q. AiTomaOan-a; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) formed from the latter by substitution [of b for m]. (Ṣ in art. Tmn.) So in the phrase AiTobaOan-a qalobuhu, meaning His heart became quiet, at rest, at ease, or tranquil. (TA.)

hom.sense: TabonN A numerous collection or body (Ḳ, TA) of men; (TA;) as also TabanN↓. (Ḳ, TA.
