(Ṣ.)

And The skin [meaning sole] of a sandal, (Lth, O, Ḳ,) when the [thong, or strap, called] XiraAk has been removed from it. (Lth, O.) El-Hárith Ibn-Hillizeh [in the 13th verse of his Mo'allakah, using it in a pl. sense,] applies it to the Soles that are attached to the feet of camels: (TA:) or he there means by it the marks left by the TrAq of a she-camel. (EM p. 259.) And A piece of skin cut in a round form, of the size of a shield, and attached thereto, and sewed. (O, Ḳ.)
And Anything made to match, or correspond with, another thing. (Lth, O, Ḳ.)

Iron that is expanded, and then rounded, and made into a helmet (Lth, O, Ḳ) or a [kind of armlet called] saAEid (Lth, O) and the like. (Lth, O, Ḳ.) And Any qabiylap [i. e. plate, likened to a qbylp of the head,] of a helmet, by itself. (Lth, O.) And Plates, of a helmet, one above another. (TA)
riyXN TiraAqN Feathers overlying one another. (Ṣ.) And TaAYirN TiraAqu Alr-iyXi A bird whose feathers overlie one another. (TA.)

Also A brand made upon the middle of the ear of a ewe, (En-Naḍr, O, Ḳ,) externally; being a white line, made with fire, resembling a track of a road: (En-Naḍr, O:) there are two such brands, called TiraAqaAni. (TA.)
See also Tir-iyqapN.

TariyqN A road, way, or path; syn. sabiylN; (Ṣ;) [i. e. a beaten track, being of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; and applied to any place of passage;] and TuroqapN↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ:) [see also musotaToraqN:] it is masc. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ *) in the dial. of Nejd, and so in the Ḳur xx. 79; (Mṣb;) and fem. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) in the dial. of El-Ḥijáz: (Mṣb:) the latter accord. to general usage: (MF:) [see zuqaAqN:]
the pl. [of pauc.] is OaToriqapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) with those who make the sing. masc. (Mṣb) and OaToruqN (O, Ḳ) with those who make the sing. fem. (TA) and [of mult.] TuruqN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TuroqN [of which see an ex. voce dilaAlapN] (Ḳ) and OaToriqaMCu, (O, Ḳ,) and TuruqaAtN is a pl. pl. (Mṣb, Ḳ) i. e. pl. of TuruqN. (Mṣb, TA.)

In the saying banuw fulaAnK yaTaWuhumu AlT-ariyqu, accord. to Sb, AlT-ariyqu is for Oaholu AlT-alriyqi: [the meaning therefore is, † The sons of such a one sojourn, or encamp, where the people of the road tread upon them, i. e., become their guests: (see more in art. wTO:)] or, as some say, AlTryq here means the wayfarers without any suppression. (TA.)

Haq-u AlT-ariyqi [The duty relating to the road] is the lowering of the eyes; the putting away, or aside, what is hurtful, or annoying; the returning of salutations; the enjoining of that which is good; and the forbidding of that which is evil. (El-Jámiʼ es- Sagheer. See jalasa.)

qaTaEa AlT-ariyqa [He intercepted the road] means he made the road to be feared, relying upon his strength, robbing, and slaying men [or passengers]. (Mṣb in art. qTE.) [And OaSaAba AlT-ariyqa means the same; or, as expl. by Freytag, on the authority of Meyd, He was, or became, a robber.]
[Hence,] Aibonu AlT-ariyqi means † The robber [on the highway]. (T in art. bnI.)
[But Oaholu Tariyqi Qll-ehi means † The devotees.]

Oum-u TariyqK, thus correctly in the ʼEyn, [and shown to be so by a verse there cited, q. v. voce EasobN,] † The hyena: erroneously written by Ṣgh, Am- Tur-ayoqK↓; and the author of the Ḳ has copied him in this instance accord. to his usual custom. (TA.)
See also Oum-u AlT-ariyqi and Oum-apu AlT-ariyqi in art. Am.
banaAtu AlT-ariyqi means † The branches of the road, that vary, and lead in any, or every, direction. (TA.)
TariyqN signifies also The space between two rows of palm-trees; as being likened to the Tariyq [commonly so called] in extension. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
Oaxaca fulaAnN fiI AlT-ariyqi means the same as Oaxaca fiI Alt-aToriyqi [expl. before: see 2, near the end]. (TA.)
TariyqN as syn. with TariyqapN: see the latter word, first sentence.

[biAlT-ariyqi AlOawolaI is a phrase of frequent occurrence, app. post-classical; lit. By the fitter way; meaning with the stronger reason; à fortiori: see an ex. in Beyd xlii. 3, and De Sacy's Anthol. Gr. Ar. p. 467.]
Also A sort of palm-tree. (TA.)
See also TariyqapN (of which it is said to be a pl.), last sentence.

entry.sense: TurayoqN: see OuTayoriqN.

TaruwqapN A she-camel covered by the stallion; of the measure faEuwlapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN. (Mṣb.) Taruwqapu AlfaHoli means The female of the stallion [camel]. (Ṣ, O.) And (Ṣ, O) A she-camel that has attained to the fit age for her being covered by the stallion: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it is not a condition of the application of the term that he has already covered her: (Mṣb:) or a young, or youthful, she-camel that has attained to that age and kept to the stallion and been chosen by him. (TA.) And one says to a husband, kayofa Taruwqatuka, meaning † How is thy wife? (TA:) every wife is termed Taruwqapu zawojihaA, (O,) or Trwqp baEolihaA, (Mṣb,) or Trwqp faHolihaA; (Ḳ,* TA;) which is thought by ISd to be metaphorical. (TA.)

One says also, naw-axa Qll-ehu AlOaroDa TaruwqapF lilomaMCi i. e. † God made, or may God make, the land capable of receiving the water [of the rains so as to be impregnated, or fertilized, or soaked, thereby]; expl. by jaEalahaA mim-aA tuTiyquhu. (Ṣ in art. nwx.) [See also a verse cited in art. sfd, conj. 4.]

TariyqapN A way, course, rule, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like, (syn. macohabN, Ṣ, TA, and siyrapN, and masolakN, TA,) of a man, (Ṣ, TA,) whether it be approved or disapproved; (TA;) as also TariyqN↓, which is metaphorically used in this sense: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [like macohabN, often relating to the doctrines and practices of religion: and often used in post-classical times as meaning the rule of a religious order or sect:] and meaning also a manner of being; a state, or condition; (syn. HaAlapN, Ṣ, or HaAlN, O, Ḳ;) as in the saying, maA zaAla fulaAnN EalaI TariyqapK waAHidapK [Such a one ceased not to be in one state, or condition]; (Ṣ;) and it is applied to such as is good and to such as is evil. (O.) One says also, huwa EalaI Tariyqatihi [He is following his own way, or course]. (TA voce jadiy-apN.) lawi QsotaqaAmuwA EalaI AlT-ariyqapi, in the Ḳur [lxxii. 16], means, accord. to Fr, [If they had gone on undeviating in the way] of polytheism: but accord. to others, of the right direction. (O.) [The pl. is TaraAYiqu.]

[It is also used for Oaholu TariyqapK: and in like manner the pl., for Oaholu TaraAYiqa. Thus,] kun-aA TaraAYiqa qidadFA, in the Ḳur [lxxii. 11], means † We were sects differing in our desires. (Fr, Ṣ, O. [See also qid-apN.]) And Tariyqapu Alqawomi means ‡ The most excel-lent, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and the best, (Ṣ, O,) and the eminent, or noble, persons, (Ḳ, TA,) of the people: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) and you say, hecaA rajulN Tariyqapu qawomihi ‡ [This is a man the most excellent,, &c., of his people]: and heWulaMCi Tariyqapu qawomihimo and TaraAYiqu qawomihimo ‡ These are [the most excellent,, &c., or] the eminent, or noble, persons of their people: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,* TA:) so says Yaạḳoob, on the authority of Fr. (Ṣ, O, TA.) wayacohabaA biTariyqatikumu AlmuvolaI, in the Ḳur [xx. 66], means [And that they may take away] your most excellent body of people: (O:) or your eminent, or noble, body of people who should be made examples to be followed: and Zj thinks that bTryqtkm is for biOaholi Tariyqatikum: (TA:) or, accord. to Akh, the meaning is, your established rule or usage, and your religion, or system of religious ordinances. (O, TA.)
[Also † The way, or course, of an event: and hence,] TaraAYiqu Ald-ahori means † The vicissitudes of time or fortune. (TA.)
[And † The air of a song, &c.: but this is probably post-classical.]

Also A line, streak, or stripe, in a thing: (Ḳ, TA:) [and a crease, or wrinkle; often used in this sense:] and [its pl.] TaraAYiqu signifies the lines, or streaks, that are called Hubuk, of a helmet. (TA.) The Tariyqap [or line] that is in the upper part of the back: and the line, or streak, that extends upon [i. e. along] the back of the ass. (TA.) [A vein, or seam, in a rock or the like. A track in stony or rugged land, &c. A narrow strip of ground or land, and of herbage.] An extended piece or portion [i. e. a strip] of sand; and likewise of fat; and [likewise of flesh; or] an oblong piece of flesh. (TA.)
[Hence, app.,] vawobN TaraAYiqu A garment old and worn out [as though reduced to strips or shreds]. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

caAtu TaraAYiqa and fiyhaA TaraAYiqu are phrases used, the latter by Dhu-r-Rummeh, in describing a spear-shaft (qanaAp) shrunk by dryness [app. meaning Having lines, or what resemble wrinkles, caused by shrinking]. (TA.)
And TaraAYiqu signifies also The last remains of the soft and best portions of pasturage. (TA.)

And The stages of Heaven; so called because they lie one above another: (TA:) [for] Als-amewaAtu saboEu TaraAYiqa baEoDuhaA fawoqa baEoDK [The Heavens are seven stages, one above another]; (Lth, O, TA:) and they have mentioned [likewise] the stages of the earth [as seven in number: and of hell also: see darakN]. (TA.) See also TaraqapN.

Accord. to Lth, (O, TA,) TariyqapN signifies also Any OuHoduwrap, (so in the O and in copies of the Ḳ and accord. to the TA, and thus also in the JK,) or Ouxoduwdap, (thus accord. to the CK,) [neither of which words have I found in any but this passage, nor do I know any words nearly resembling them except OuHoduwr and Ouxoduwd, of which they may be mistranscriptions, or perhaps dial. vars., the former signifying a declivity, slope, or place of descent, and the latter a furrow, trench, or channel,] of the earth or ground: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or [any] border, or side, (Sanifap,) of a garment, or piece of cloth; or of a thing of which one part is stuck upon another, or of which the several portions are stuck one upon another; and in like manner of colours [similarly disposed]. (O, TA.)

And A web, or thing woven, of wool, or of [goats'] hair, a cubit in breadth, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) or less, (Ṣ, O, TA,) and in length four cubits, or eight cubits, (TA,) [or] proportioned to the size of the tent (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) in its length, (Ṣ, O,) which is sewed in the place where the XiqaAq [or oblong pieces of cloth that compose the main covering of the tent] meet, from the kisor [q. v.] to the kisor; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) [it is app. sewed beneath the middle of the tent-covering, half of its breadth being sewed to one Xuq-ap and the other half thereof to the other middle Xuq-ap; (see Burckhardt's “Bedouins and Wahábys,” p. 38 of the 8vo ed.;) and sometimes, it seems, there are three TaraAYiq, one in the middle and one towards each side; for it is added,] and in them are the heads of the tentpoles, [these generally consisting of three rows, three in each row,] between which and the TrAYq are pieces of felt, in which are the nozzles (Ounuwf) of the tent-poles, in order that these may not rend the TrAYq. (TA.)

Also A tent pole; any one of the poles of a tent: a xibaMC has one Tryqp: a bayot has two and three and four [and more]: and the part between two poles is called matonN: (AZ, TA in art. zbE:) or the pole of a [large tent such as is called] miZal-ap, (Ḳ, TA,) and of a xibaMC. (TA.)

And A tall palm-tree: (Ḳ:) or the tallest of palm-trees: so called in the dial. of El-Yemámeh: (AA, ISk, Ṣ, O:) or a smooth palmtree: or a palm-tree [the head of] which may be reached by the hand: (TA:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] TariyqN↓. (AA, ISk, Ṣ, O.)
Tir-aAqN: see TiroyaAqN.
Oum-u Tur-ayoqK: see TariyqN, latter part.

Tir-iyqN means kaviyru AlUiToraAqi [i. e. One who lowers his eyes, looking towards the ground, much, or often; or who keeps silence much, or often]; (Lth, O, Ḳ;) applied to a man: (Lth, O:) and miToraAqN↓ signifies [the same, or] one who keeps silence much, or often; as also muToriqN↓ [except that this does not imply muchness or frequency]. (TA.)
And The male of the [bird called] karawaAn; (Lth, O, Ḳ;) because, when it sees a man, it falls upon the ground and is silent. (Lth, O.) [See 4.]
OaroDN Tir-iyqapN Soft, or plain, land or ground; (O, Ḳ;) as though beaten so as to be rendered even, or easy to be travelled, and trodden with the feet. (TA.)

hom.sense: Tir-iyqapN [fem. of Tir-iyqN: see what next precedes.]

[And also a subst., signifying] Gentleness and submissiveness: (Ṣ, O:) or softness, or flaccidity, and gentleness: (O, Ḳ:) and softness, or flaccidity, and languor, or affected languor, and weakness, in a man; as also TaroqapN↓ and TiraAqN↓. (TA.) One says, taHota Tir-iyqatika laEinodaOowapN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) i. e. Beneath thy gentleness and submissiveness is occasionally somewhat of hardness: (Ṣ, O, TA:) or beneath thy silence is impetuosity, and refractoriness: (TA:) or beneath thy silence is deceit, or guile. (Ḳ, voce EinodaOowapN, q. v.)

entry.sense: TiroyaAqN i. q. tiroyaAqN [q. v.], (O, Ḳ,) as also diroyaAqN; (O;) and so Tir-aAqN↓. (O, Ḳ.)

TaAriqN [act. part. n. of Taraqa; and, as such, generally meaning] Coming, or a comer, (Ṣ,) [i. e.] anything coming, (O, Mṣb,) by night: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) one who comes by night being thus called because of his [generally] needing to knock at the door: in the Mufradát [of Er-Rághib] said to signify a wayfarer (saAlikN lilT-ariyqi): but in the common conventional language particularly applied to the comer by night: its pl. is OaToraAqN, like OanoSaArN pl. of naASirN, [and app., as in a sense hereafter mentioned, Tur-aAqN also, agreeably with analogy,] and the pl. of [its fem.] TaAriqapN is TawaAriqu. (TA.) [TaAriqu AlmanaAyaA, like daAEiI AlmanaAyaA, means The summoner of death, lit., of deaths; because death makes known its arrival or approach suddenly, like a person knocking at the door in the night.]

Hence AlT-aAriqu, mentioned in the Ḳur [lxxxvi. 1 and 2], The star that appears in the night: (Er-Rághib, O:) or the morning-star; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) because it comes [or appears] in [the end of] the night. (O.)

Hence the saying of Hind (Ṣ, O) the daughter of 'Otbeh the son of Rabee'ah, on the day [of the battle] of Ohud, quoting proverbially what was said by Ez-Zarkà El-Iyádeeyeh when Kisrà warred with Iyád, (O,)
naHonu banaAtu TaAriqi
laA nanovaniI liwaAmiqi
namoXiI EalaI Aln-amaAriqi
† [We are the daughters of one like a star, or a morning-star: we bend not to a lover: we walk upon the pillows]: (Ṣ,* O,* TA:) meaning we are the daughters of a chief; likening him to the star in elevation; (O, TA;) i. e. our father is, in respect of elevation, like the shining star: (Ṣ:) or banaAtu TaAriqK means † The daughters of the kings. (T and TA in art. bnI.)

And TaAriqN signifies also [A diviner: and particularly, by means of pebbles; a practiser of pessomancy: or] one who is nearly a kaAhin; possessing more knowledge than such as is termed HaAzK: (ISh, TA in art. HzI:) Tur-aAqN [is its p., and] signifies practisers of divination: and TawaAriqu [is pl. of TaAriqapN, and thus] signifies female practisers of divination: Lebeed says,
laEamoruka maA tadoriI AlT-awaAriqu biAlHaSaI
walaA zaAjiraAtu AlT-ayori maA Qll-ehu SaAniEu
[By thy life, or by thy religion, the diviners with pebbles know not, nor the diviners by the flight of birds, what God is doing]. (Ṣ, O.)

hom.sense: TaAriqapN [a subst. from TaAriqN, made so by the affix p, † An event occurring, or coming to pass, in the night: pl. TawaAriqu]. One says, naEuwcu biQll-ahi mino TawaAriqi Als-awoCi ‡ [We seek protection by God from] the nocturnal events or accidents or casualties [that are occasions of that which is evil]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And TaAriqapN occurring in a trad. of ʼAlee is expl. as signifying Taraqato bixayorK [app. meaning An event that has occurred in the night bringing good, or good fortune]. (TA.)
Also A man's [small sub-tribe such as is called] EaXiyrap, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and [such as is called] faxic. (Ṣ, O.)
And A small couch, (IDrd, O, Ḳ,) of a size sufficient for one person: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (IDrd, O.)

[El-Makreezee mentions the custom of attaching TawaAriq Harobiy-ap upon the gates of Cairo and upon the entrances of the houses of the OumaraMC; and De Sacy approves of the opinion of A. Schultens and of M. Reinaud that the meaning is Cuirasses, from the Greek θώραξ: (see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., vol. i. pp. 274-5:) but I think that the meaning is more probably large maces; for such maces, each with a head like a cannon-ball, may still be seen, if they have not been removed within the last few years, upon several of the gates of Cairo; and if so, TawaAriq in this case is app. from Taraqa “he beat:” see also EamuwdN.]

entry.sense: TaAriqiy-apN A qilaAdap [i. e. collar, or necklace]: (Ḳ:) [or rather] a sort of qalaAYid [pl. of qilaAdap]. (Lth, O.)

OaToraqu A camel having the affection termed TaraqN, inf. n. of Tariqa [q. v.]: fem. TaroqaMCu: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and the latter is said by Lth to be applied to the hind leg as meaning having the crookedness termed TaraqN in its saAq. (O.)

OuTayoriqN and TurayoqN↓ A sort of palm-tree of El-Ḥijáz, (AḤn, O, Ḳ,) that is early in bearing, before the other palm-trees; the ripening and ripe dates of which are yellow: (O:) AḤn also says, in one place, the ATyrq is a species of palm-trees, the earliest in bearing of all the palm-trees of El-Ḥijáz; and by certain of the poets such are called AlT-urayoquwna and AlOuTayoriquwna. (TA.)

turosN muToraqN [A shield having another sewed upon it: or covered with skin and sinews]: (Ṣ:) and majaAn-u muToraqapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or muTar-aqapN↓, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Shields sewed one upon another; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) formed of two skins, one of them sewed upon the other; (Mṣb;) like naEolN muToraqapN a sole having another sole sewed upon it; as also muTaAraqapN↓: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or shields clad [i. e. covered] with skin and sinews. (Ṣ, O.) kaOan-a wujuwhahumu AlmajaAn-u AlmuToraqapu, or AlmuTar-aqapu↓, occurring in a trad., (Mṣb, TA,) i. e. [As though their faces were] shields clad with sinews one above another, (TA,) means † having rough, or coarse, and broad, faces. (Mṣb, TA.)
And riyXN muToraqN Feathers overlying one another. (TA.)

hom.sense: muToriqN Having a natural laxness of the eye [or rather of the eyelids, and a consequent lowering of the eye towards the ground]: (Ṣ, O:) [or bending down the head: or lowering the eyes, looking towards the ground; either naturally or otherwise: (see its verb, 4:)] and silent, or keeping silence. (TA. See also Tir-iyqN.)

It is also applied as an epithet to a stallion-camel: and to a [she-camel such as is termed] jumaAliy-ap [i. e. one resembling a he-camel in greatness of make], and, thus applied, [and app. likewise when applied to a stallion-camel,] it may mean That does not utter a grumbling cry, nor vociferate: or, accord. to Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, [quick in pace, for he says that] it is from TaroqN signifying “quickness of going.” (Sh, TA.)
See also miToraAqN, last sentence.
And, applied to a man, ‡ Low, ignoble, or mean, (Ḳ, TA,) in race, or parentage, or in the grounds of pretension to respect or honour. (TA.)
Also An enemy: from OaToraqa fulaAnN lifulaAnK expl. above [see 4, last sentence]. (TA.)

entry.sense: miToraqN: see the next paragraph.

miToraqapN The rod, or stick, with which wool is beaten, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) to loosen it, or separate it; (Ṣ,* O,* TA;) as also miToraqN↓. (O, Ḳ, TA.) And A rod, or stick, or small staff, with which one is beaten: pl. maTaAriqu: one says, Darabahu biAlmaTaAriqi He beat him with the rods,, &c. (TA.)
And The implement [i. e. hammer] (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb) of the blacksmith, (Ṣ, O,) with which the iron is beaten. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
cahabN muTar-aqN Stamped, or minted, gold; syn. masokuwkN. (TA.)
And naAqapN muTar-aqapN [like maToruwqapN (q. v.)] † A she-camel rendered tractable, submissive, or manageable. (TA.)
And jul-N muTar-aqN [A horse-cloth] in which are [various] colours [app. forming TaraAYiq, i. e. lines, streaks, or stripes]. (O.)
See also muToraqN, in two places.
qaTaApN muTar-iqN [thus without p] A bird of the species called qaTFA that has arrived at the time of her egg's coming forth. (Ṣ.) [See also muEaD-ilN.]

hom.sense: miToraAqN: see Tir-iyqN.
Also A she-camel recently covered by the stallion. (O, TA.)

And pl. of maTaAriyq in the saying jaMCati AlUibilu maTaAriyqa (TA) which means The camels came in one Tariyq [i. e. road, or way]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the camels came following one another (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,* TA) when drawing near to the water. (O, Ḳ, TA. [See also a similar phrase voce TaraqN.])

[Hence,] miToraAqu AlX-aIoCi signifies That which follows the thing; and the like of the thing: (Ḳ:) one says, hecaA miToraAqu hecaA This is what follows this; and the like of this: (Ṣ, O:) and the pl. is maTaAriyqu. (Ṣ.)

And maTaAriyqu signifies also Persons going on foot: (Ḳ:) one says, xaraja Alqawomu maTaAriyqa The people, or party, went forth going on foot; having no beasts: and the sing. is miToraAqN, (O,) or muToriqN↓, (ʼEyn, L,* TA,*) accord. to AʼObeyd; the latter, if correct, extr. (TA.)

entry.sense: maToruwqN [pass. part. n. of Taraqa; Beaten,, &c.]. huwa maToruwqN means He is one whom every one beats or slaps (yaToruquhu kul-u OaHadK). (TA.)

And ‡ A man in whom is softness, or flaccidity, (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and weakness: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or weakness and softness: (TA:) or softness and flaccidity: from the saying huwa maToruwqN i. e. ASAbth HAdvp ktfth [which, if we should read katafatohu, seems to mean he is smitten by an event, or accident, that has disabled him as though it bound his arms behind his back; but I think it probable that ktfth is a mistranscription]: or because he is mSrwf [app. a mistake for maDoruwb], like as one says maqoruwE and madaw-ax [app. meaning beaten and subdued, or rendered submissive]: or as being likened, in abjectness, to a she-camel that is termed maToruwqapN [like maTar-aqapN (q. v.)]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) maToruwqapN applied to a woman means [app. Soft and feminine;] that does not make herself like a man. (TA.) [See also a reading of a verse cited voce maToruwfN.]
Also ‡ Weak in intellect, (Ḳ, TA,) and soft. (TA.)
Applied to herbage, Smitten by the rain after its having dried up. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, L, Ḳ.)
See also TaroqN, latter half. Applied to a ewe, maToruwqapN signifies Branded with the mark called TiraAq upon the middle of her ear. (ISh, O, Ḳ.)
muTaAraqN: see its fem., with p {muTaAraqapN}, voce muToraqN.
musotaToraqN ‡ i. q. sik-apN [app. as meaning A road, like TariyqN; or a highway]. (TA.)
munoTariqaAtN Mineral substances. (TA.)

Q. 1. TaromaHa He made his building long; (Ṣ, Ḳ; in the former in art. TrH;) like Tar-aHa: (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. TrH:) or he made it long and high: (A, TA:) accord. to J, the m is augmentative. (TA.) A poet says, describing camels which herbage produced by the nawoC [here meaning the rain of the auroral setting] of the constellation Leo had filled with fat,
TaromaHa OaqoTaArahaA OaHowaI liwaAlidapK
SaHomaMCa waAlfaHolu lilD-irogaAmi yanotasibu
[Dark green herbage, the offspring of a mother (meaning, as is said in the TA, of a cloud) of a yellowish black hue, the stallion (meaning the star or asterism supposed to be the cause of its giving rain) tracing his origin to the lion, extended, or stretched out, their sides]. (Ṣ and TA, the former in art. TrH.)
TaromaHN One who takes, or walks with, long steps: (Ḳ, TA:) accord. to IḲṭṭ, the m is augmentative. (TA.)
TaromaHaAniy-apN Pride. (Ḳ.)
miXoyapN TaromaHaAniy-apN A proud walk or gait. (TA.)
TuromuwHN (Ḳ, TA) and Tirim-aAHN↓, as also TuroHuwmN, which last is thought by IDrd to be formed by transposition, (TA,) Long, or tall. (Ḳ, TA.)

Tirim-aAHN, of the very rare measure fiEil-aAlN, of which there can hardly, or cannot at all, be found any other example, except sinim-aArN, a foreign word, and sijil-aATN, also said to be of foreign origin, (TA,) A man of high ancestry or family, and celebrated; (Ḳ, TA;) of high renown. (TA.)
And One who goes, or penetrates, far, or deeply, into an affair. (AZ, Ḳ, TA.)
And accord. to Abu-l-ʼOmeythil El-Aạrábee, One who elevates his head in pride. (TA.)
See also TuromuwHN.

Q. 1. Taromaca, inf. n. TaromacapN, He gloried, or boasted, vainly, and praised himself for that which was not in him: (AHeyth, L:) Th says, in his “Amálee,” that TaromacapN is a genuine Arabic word; (L;) and so says El-Ḳálee: (TA:) but in the Ṣ it is said to be not of the language of the people of the desert. (L, TA.) [See this word below.]
Taromaca Ealayohi He gloried over him, and praised himself for that which he did not possess. (L, Ḳ.)
fiyhi TaromacapN In him is pride: (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, L:) [or vain-glorying: see 1.]
TiromicapN: see the last paragraph below.
TiromicaAnN and TaromacaArN: see the next paragraph.

TiromaAcN One who glories, or boasts, vainly, and praises himself for that which is not in him; (L, Ḳ;) as also TiromicaAnN↓, (L, Ḳ,) and TiromicaArN, (L,) or TaromacaArN, (Ḳ, in which it is mentioned in a separate art.,) but TrmcAr is said to have been unknown by IAạr: (TA:) or one who boasts of abundance which he does not possess; as also the last of the above-mentioned epithets, which also signifies one who boasts of that which he does not perform. (L.)
Also A horse of generous breed. (Th, L.)

muTaromicN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and TiromicapN↓ (Ḳ) A man who says but does not act, or perform; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and who does not act seriously, or in earnest, (laA yuHaq-iqu,) in affairs: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, who does not verify things. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Taruwa, [aor. yaToruw,] (Ḳṭr, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and TariIa, [aor. yaToraI,] (Ḳṭr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. TaraAwapN (Ḳṭr, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TaraMCapN (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and TaraApN, (TA, and so in some copies of the Ṣ and of the Ḳ,) like HaSaApN, (TA,) and TaraMCN, (so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or TarFA, (TA as from the Ḳ,) with the shortened alif, (TA,) [the last agreeable with analogy as inf. n. of TariIa,] said of a thing, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or of flesh-meat, (Ḳṭr, Ṣ,) It was, or became, fresh, juicy, or moist: (Ḳṭr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and TaruWa signifies the same; (Mgh, Mṣb;) but Taruwa is more common. (TA in art. TrO.)
And TariIa signifies also tajad-ada [It became new; was newly made or done; or was renewed]. (TA.)

TaraA, [aor. yaToruw,] inf. n. Turuw-N, (Ḳ,) or, as written in the M, TarowN, (TA,) He came from a distant place: (Ḳ:) you say TaraA Ealayohimo he came, or, accord. to Lth, he came forth, upon them from a distant place: or, accord. to AZ, he came upon them without their knowledge: it is a dial. var. of TaraOa [q. v.]. (TA.)
And TaraA signifies also maDaI [He went, or went away,, &c.]. (TA.)

And TariIa, aor. yaToraI, (IAạr, Ḳ,) in which, accord. to the Ḳ, the last radical letter is I, [not w changed into I by reason of the kesreh before it,] but ISd says that there in no word of which the radical letters are T and r and I, (TA,) He advanced, or came forward: or he passed, passed by, went, or went away. (IAạr, Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Tr-Ahu, inf. n. taToriyapN, He rendered it fresh, juicy, or moist. (Ḳ.) You say, Tar-ayotu Alv-awoba inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) [app. meaning I refreshed, or I moistened, the garment, or piece of cloth.]

And Tr-I, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He rendered perfume fragrant [as though he refreshed it] by admixtures; (Ḳ, TA;) and aloes-wood with [other] perfume, or ambergris, or some other thing: (Az, TA:) and in like manner, food, (Ḳ, TA,) by mixing it with aromatics. (TA.)
And He plastered, or coated, a building with clay, or mud: of the dial. of Mekkeh. (Z, TA.)

4. ATrAhu He praised him; thus in the Ṣ, and in like manner expl. by Zbd and IḲṭṭ; (TA;) and thus ATrOhu [with C] is expl. by Es-Sarakustee: (Mṣb:) he eulogized, or commended, him; (Ḳ;) thus in the M; (TA;) and thus it is expl. by Es-Sarakustee: (Mṣb:) or he praised him renewing the mention of him: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or he praised him exceedingly: (AA, TA:) or he praised him for the best of the qualities that he possessed; (Mṣb, TA;) thus expl. by IF, and in like manner by Z: (TA:) or he praised him for that which was not in him: (Az, TA:) or he praised him greatly, or extravagantly; exceeded the just, or usual, bounds in praising him: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to Hr and IAth, he exceeded the just, or usual bounds in praising him, and lied therein. (TA.)
And ATrI AlEasala He made the honey to thicken, or coagulate. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)

12. AiToraworaI, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. AiToriyraMCN, (TA,) He suffered from indigestion, or heaviness of the stomach, (Ḳ, TA,) in consequence of much eating, (TA,) and became inflated in his belly: (Ḳ, TA:) and so AiZoraworaI: thus correctly; but mentioned by J and IḲṭṭ as with D. (TA.) [See also Q. Q. 3 in art. Tr.]

AlT-araA [without the article TarFA] What is not of the nature of the earth; (Ḳ;) or whatever is upon the surface of the earth, of such things as are not of the nature of the earth, consisting of pebbles; or small pebbles; [and the like;] and dust and the like: (TA:) and, (Ḳ, TA,) as some say, (TA,) the sorts of created things whereof the number cannot be reckoned; (Ḳ, TA;) or any created things whereof the number and the sorts cannot be reckoned. (TA.) One says, humo Oakovaru mina AlT-araI waAlv-araI [or AlT-araA wAlav-araA i. e. They are more in number, or quantity, than the pebbles,, &c., and than the moist earth]. (TA.)

TariI-N Fresh, juicy, or moist: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) and TariIoCN is a dial. var. thereof. (Mṣb.) It is expl. as meaning thus in the Ḳur [xvi. 44 and] xxxv. 13 [as an epithet applied to the flesh of fish]. (TA.) And AlT-ariy-aAni [used as a subst.] means Fish and fresh ripe dates. (A, TA.)

Also Strange, or a stranger; syn. gariybN: and AA has mentioned rajulN TaAriI-N↓, [said to be] with teshdeed, [otherwise I should think it might be a mistranscription for TaAriYN,] as meaning a man that is a stranger. (TA.)

Tiriy-aAnN, with two kesrehs, and with the I musheddedeh, The xiwaAn [or table] upon which one eats; thus accord. to ISk: or, accord. to IAạr, the Tabaq [i. e. dish, or plate]: occurring in a trad.; as some relate it, thus; and as others relate it, Tir-iyaAn, with the r musheddedeh, like Sil-iyaAn; [and thus it is mentioned in the O and Ḳ in art. Tr;] but Fr says that this latter is of the dial. of the vulgar. (TA.)
TaAriI-N: see TariI-N.

UiToriyapN A sort of food, called in Pers. laA xiXaho; (Ṣ;) [i. e.] a certain food, like threads, made of flour; (Ḳ, TA;) an explanation necessarily implying that it is what is called in Egypt gazolu AlbanaAti: accord. to Sh, a thing made of softened starch; and said by Lth to be a food made by the people of Syria; a word having no n. un.; and what these two say indicates that it is what is called kunaAfap: Lth and Z mention the word as pronounced also with fet-ḥ; but Az says that the pronunciation with fet-ḥ is incorrect. (TA.)

OuToruwaAnN The first stage, and the quickness, (gulawaMC, in the CK [erroneously] guluw-,) of youth: (Ḳ, TA:) like EunofuwaAnN in measure and in meaning. (TA.) One says also, likul-i XaIoCK OuToruwaAniy-apN↓ i. e. [To everything there is] a state of youthfulness. (TA.)
OuToruwaAniy-apN: see what next precedes.

EuwdN muTar-FI [Aloes-wood] such as is termed muTay-arN, with which one fumigates himself: (Ṣ, TA:) and OalowapN muTar-aApN [signifies the same, i. e. aloes-wood] rendered fragrant [as though refreshed] by the admixture of [other] perfume, or of ambergris, or some other thing: AlmuTar-aApu is said by Lth to mean a sort of perfume. (TA.) And gisolapN muTar-aApN A preparation for washing the head or hand, compounded with aromatics. (Ṣ, TA.)
And one says, huwa muTar-FI fiI nafosihi, meaning mutajab-irN [i. e. † He is restored to a good state, or condition, of body, or of property]. (TA.)

Tas-N and Tas-apN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and Tis-apN↓ (M, Ḳ) i. q. TasotN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is expl. in its proper place: (TA:) [see art. Tst: or] Tas-apN is the original of TasotN: (Lth, TA:) the pl. (of Tas-N, M) is OaTosaAsN [a pl. of pauc.] (M) and TusuwsN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and TasiysN (M, Ḳ) [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.] and (of Tas-apN and Tis-apN, M) TisaAsN and [of Tas-apN also] Tas-aAtN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Tis-apN may also have for its pl. TisasN, accord. to rule. (M.) The dim. [of Tas-N] is TusayosN; (Ṣ in art. Tst;) and [of Tas-apN and Tis-apN,] TusayosapN. (IḲt and Mṣb in art. Tst.)
Tas-apN: see the preceding paragraph.
Tis-apN: see the preceding paragraph.
TisaAsapN The trade of selling, (M,) or the art of making, (Ḳ,) [the kind of basins called] Tusuws [pl. of Tas-N]. (M, Ḳ.*)
Tas-aAsN A seller, (M,) or maker, (Ḳ,) of [the kind of basins called] Tusuws, (M, Ḳ.*)

TasotN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.) A kind of vessel of Sufor [or brass]: (M, TA:) [generally pronounced in the present day TiXot and TaXot: and mostly applied to a kind of basin of tinned copper, or of brass, or of silver, used for washing the hands, &c., figured and described in my work on the Modern Egyptians:] i. q. Tas-N, [q. v.,] (IḲt, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is [said to be] arabicized from Tasot, the latter being a foreign word; (Mgh;) [but it is from the Pers., TaXot;] it is of the dial. of Teiyi; (Ṣ;) and [said to be] formed from Tas-N, one of the two s being changed into t, (IḲt, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) because they are deemed difficult of pronunciation; (IḲt, Ṣ, Mṣb;) but in forming the pl. and the dim., the second s is restored, because separated from the former; (Ṣ;) for (IḲt, Ṣ, Mṣb) the pl. is TisaAsN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) and TusuwsN, though it has also for its pl. TusuwtN, (IḲt, Mgh, Mṣb,) or, accord. to Zj, TisaAtN; (Mṣb;) and the dim. is TusayosN, (Ṣ,) or TusayosapN: (IḲt, Mṣb:) it is also pronounced TisotN; (MF;) and TaXotN also has been mentioned; (Ḳ;) but some say that this is a mistake; and others, that TaXot is the original word from which TasotN is arabicized: (TA:) Zj says that, with most of the Arabs, (Mṣb,) it is fem.: (Mgh, Mṣb:) sometimes it is masc.: (Lḥ, M:) IAmb says, on the authority of Fr, that the word used by the Arabs was Tas-apN, save that some said Tas-N, without p; and that the tribe of Teiyi said TasotN, like as they said liSotN for liS-N: Es-Sijistánee says that it is a foreign word arabicized: and Az, that it is a word adopted into the Arabic language, because T and t do not both occur in an Arabic word. (Mṣb.)

TasoqN, incorrectly pronounced by the people of Baghdád TisoqN, (O, Ḳ,) A certain measure of capacity, (Lth, M, O, Ḳ,) well known: (M:) and (Lth, M, O, in the Ḳ “or”) the portion of the [tax called] xaraAj that is levied on the [quantities of land termed] jurobaAn, (Lth, M, O, Ḳ,) pl. of jariybN: (TA:) an assessed rate (waZiyfapN) of the land-tax: (Ṣ:) it is like the xaraAj, having a certain amount: (Az, TA:) or it is like an impost of a certain amount: (O, Ḳ:) not a pure Arabic word: (Az, O:) app. post-classical: (Ḳ:) or (Ḳ) a Pers. word (Ṣ) arabicized: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) from the Pers. taXah [or taX-aho] originally signifying “an oil-measure:” (TḲ:) it occurs in a letter of ʼOmar to ʼOthmán. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

Tas-uwjN A certain weight; (T, TA;) two grains, i. e. grains of barley; (Hab-atani;) (Ṣ;) the quarter of a daAniq; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. the twenty-fourth part of a diroham; the dAnq being the sixth of a drhm: (TA:) pl. TasaAsiyju: (Ṣ:) an arabicized word [from the Pers. tasuw]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Also i. q. naAHiyapN [as meaning A district, or province, or the like]; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) such as a qaroyap [here app. meaning township], and the like: for instance, Ardabeel is of the TasaAsiyj of Hulwán: (Mgh:) one of the TasaAsiyj of the Sawád: (T, TA:) the TsAsyj of the people of El-Ahwáz are like the maxaAliyf of the people of El-Yemen and the OajonaAd of the people of Syria and the kuwar of the people of El-'Irák and the rasaAtiyq of the people of El-Jibál: (IB voce mixolaAfN:) in this sense likewise (Ṣ) an arabicized word. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.*)
[Hence,] TaX-a [as meaning † He sprinkled the moisture from his nose like fine rain] is said of one affected with the malady termed TuX-ap, when he blows his nose. (O.)
And TuX-a, (O, Ḳ,) with damm, (Ḳ,) He (a man) was, or became, affected with the malady termed TuX-ap: (O, Ḳ:) but Az says that the [better] known word is TuXiYa. (TA.)
4: see the preceding paragraph {1}.

TaX-N and TaXiyXN↓ Weak [or fine] rain, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) but exceeding what is termed racaAcN: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or the former is less than racaAc: (El-Khaṭṭábee, and Suh in TA art. rc:) or rain exceeding what is termed rik-N, but less than what is termed qiToqiTN: (TA:) or the first of rain; (L, TA;) next to which is what is termed raX-N: (L:) [but see these other terms for rain: TiXaAXN and TuXuwXN are pls. of TaX-N; both mentioned in the O, though not there said to be pls. of TaX-N:] one says, OaSaAbanaA TiXaAXN wariXaAXN [Rains such as are termed TXAX and rXAX fell upon us]. (O.)

TuX-apN and TuXaAXN↓, both with damm, A malady like the [rheum termed] zukaAm, (O, Ḳ,) incident to human beings: said by El-Ḳutabee to be termed TuX-ap because when he who is affected with it blows his nose he sprinkles the moisture from it like fine rain (UicaA Qsotanovara TaX-a): but the [better] known word is TuXoOapN (O.) [See also the next paragraph.]

TiX-ap is said in the Ḳ to signify A young child; its author having app. understood a young child to be meant thereby in a trad. respecting the [plant called] HazaAp, in which it is said, yaXotariyhaA OakaAyiysu AlS-iboyaAni lilT-iX-api [evidently meaning, Intelligent children purchase it for the malady termed TiX-ap, this word being doubtless either a dial. var. of TuX-ap, or a mistranscription]: that TX-p here denotes children is refuted by another relation of the trad., yaXorabuhaA OakaAyiysu Aln-isaMCi lilTuX-api [i. e. intelligent women drink a preparation of it for the TuX-ap]. (TA.)
TaXaAXN i. q. raXaAXN [i. e. Such as is sprinkled, or scattered,] (Ḳ, TA) of rain: or such as is weak. (TA.) [Not to be mistaken for the pls. TiXaAXN and riXaAXN: see TaX-N.]
And hence, app., and, if so, tropical, Weakness of sight: whence the prov., AlT-aXaAXu walaA AlEamaI [Weakness of sight, and not blindness]. (TA.)
TuXaAXN: see TuX-apN.
TaXiyXN: see TaX-N.
OaroDN maToXuwXapN Land upon which has fallen rain such as is termed TaX-N. (Ṣ, A, O.)
And rajulN maToXuwXN A man affected with the malady termed TuX-ap. (TA.)
TaXotN: see TasotN.

1. TaEimahu, aor. _a {yaToEamu}, inf. n. TaEomN and TaEaAmN, He ate it; namely, food: (Ḳ,* TA:) and TaEima, aor. as above, inf. n. TuEomN, with damm, he tasted [a thing]: (Ḳ:) or TaEima, aor. as above, (Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb,) inf. n. TuEomN, with damm, (Ṣ,) or TaEomN, with fet-ḥ, (Mṣb,) or both, (Mgh,) and maToEamN also is an inf. n. of the same verb, (TA,) signifies he ate, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,*) a thing, (Mgh,) and [app. also he swallowed, for it is said that] it applies to anything that is swallowed easily or agreeably, even to water: (Mṣb:) and he tasted (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) a thing; (Mgh, Mṣb;) as also tTE-m↓; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) [i. e.] this latter verb signifies he tasted food in order that he might know its flavour; and so AstTEm↓: (Mṣb:) and TaEima as meaning he tasted may be used in relation to that which is eaten and to that which is drunk. (L.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xxxiii. 53], faUicaA TaEimotumo faQnotaXiruwA And when ye shall have eaten [disperse yourselves]. (Ṣ,* TA.) And you say, fulaAnN qal-a TuEomuhu, meaning [Such a one,] his eating [was, or became, little]. (Ṣ.) The saying in the Ḳur [ii. 250], wamano lamo yaToEamohu faUin-ahu min-iI means But whoso does not taste it, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* TA,) he is of my followers, (Bḍ, Jel,) or is at one, or in union, with me: (Bḍ:) or, accord. to Zj, the meaning is, lamo yataTaE-amo↓ bihi [app. meaning does not refresh himself with it as though with food]: (TA:) or, as some say, the passage in which it occurs denotes a prohibition to take aught save as much as is laded out with the hand; and when water has with it something that is chewed, one says of it yuToEamu. (Er-Rághib, TA.) taTaE-amo↓ taToEamo i. e. Taste thou, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) then thou wilt have desire, or appetence, (Mgh,) or so that thou mayest have desire, or appetence, and mayest eat; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or taste thou the food, for it will induce thee to eat it; (IB, TA;) is a prov., (IB, Mgh, TA,) said to him who refrains from an affair; meaning, commence it, for thy doing so will invite thee to finish it. (IB, TA.)
AlT-aEomu signifies also The eating with the central incisors: one says, Uin-ahu layaToEamu TaEomFA HasanFA [Verily he eats well with the central incisors]. (TA.)
maA yaToEamu Mkilu hecaA AlT-aEaAmi, (Ḳ,* TA,) a phrase mentioned by ISh, (TA,) means ‡ The eater of this food does not become satisfied in stomach. (Ḳ,* TA.)
TaEima said of a branch, or shoot, ‡ It received ingraftment. (ISh, Ḳ, TA.)
And [hence, perhaps,] TaEimato Eayonuhu † [His eye had a mote cast into it: see 4]. (TA.)

TaEima Ealayohi, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. TuEomN, (Ḳ,* TA,) which, in the Ḳ, is improperly disjoined from its verb, [as though it were a simple subst.,] (TA,) i. q. qadara [i. e. He had power over him, or it; or he had power, or ability, to do it,, &c.]. (Ḳ, TA.)
2: see 4, in three places.

TE-m, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. taToEiymN, (TA,) said of a bone, means † It had, or contained, marrow. (Ḳ, TA.) [Used in this sense, it may be regarded as a trans. v. of which the objective complement is understood; as though signifying It fed.]
3. TaAEamotuhu I ate with him. (TA.)
And [hence] TaAEamaA, said of two pigeons, ‡ They billed; the male bird inserting his mouth [or bill] into that of his female; as also taTaAEamaA↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
4. ATEmhu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or ATEmhu AlT-aEaAma, (Ṣ,) [inf. n. UiToEaAmN,] He fed him; or gave him to eat, or gave him food; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) [and so, accord. to modern usage, TE-mhu↓.]

And [hence] ATEmhu signifies also ‡ He supplied him with the means of subsistence: whence, in the Ḳur [li. 57], wamaA Ouriydu Oano yaToEimuwni i. e. ‡ And I desire not that [they, meaning] any of my servants should supply me with the means of subsistence; for I am the supplier of the means of subsistence. (TA.)

And OaToEamotuka hecihi AlOaroDa † I have assigned to thee as a TuEomap [q. v.] this land. (TA.) It is said of the Prophet, OaToEamahumo TuEomapF † [He assigned to them, or gave them, a TEmp]: accord. to Aboo-Ḥaneefeh, AlUiToEaAmu signifies peculiarly † the lending of land for cultivation: but it is said on the authority of Mo'áwiyeh, Uin-ahu OaToEama EamorFA xaraAja miSora, meaning † that he gave ʼAmr as a TuEomap the xrAj [or land-tax] of Egypt. (Mgh.)
See also 10.

ATEm AlguSona, (ISh, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiToEaAmN, (TA,) ‡ He ingrafted upon the branch, or shoot, a branch, or shoot, of another tree; (ISh, Ḳ, TA;) as also TE-mhu↓, [which is more commonly used in this sense,] (Ḳ,) inf. n. taToEiymN. (TA.) [And TE-mhu↓ is now used as meaning also † He inoculated him.]
And OaToEamotu Eayonahu qacFI † [I cast a mote into his eye]. (TA.)
[See also a verse cited voce EiqobapN.]

ATEm Aln-axolu ‡ The palm-trees had ripe fruit, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) such as might be eaten: or bore fruit: (TA:) or ATEmt AlX-ajarapu the tree had ripe fruit: (Mṣb:) or ATEmt Alv-ayarapu the fruit became ripe. (Mgh.)
5: see 1, in three places: and see also an ex. voce DaArK, in art. Drw and DrI.

6. tTAEywA They (a party on a journey) ate with, or at the tent of, [meaning, of the food of,] this man on one occasion of alighting, and another man on another occasion of alighting; each one of them having his turn to supply the food of one day: like tnAwbwA and tnAzlwA. (ISh, TA in art. nwb.)
See also 3.
[Hence,] one says of two persons in conformity, taTaAEamaA, meaning † They acted as do the two [billing] pigeons. (TA.)
8. AT-Em Albusoru, (Ḳ,) or AT-Emt Albusorapu, (Ṣ,) † The ripening dates, or the ripening date, acquired flavour, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and became ripe, so as to be eaten. (TA.)

[Hence,] one says, huwa rajulN laA yaT-aEimu ‡ He is a man who will not become well disciplined, in whom that which should improve him will not produce an effect, (Ḳ,* TA,) and who will not become intelligent. (TA.)
10. AstTEmhu He asked him to feed him. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.)
[Hence,] AisotaToEamatuhu AlHadiyva † I asked him to relate to me the narrative, or tradition: or to make me to taste the savour of his discourse. (TA.)

And UicaA QsotaToEamakumu AlUimaAmu faOaToEimuwhu↓ ‡ When the AmAm [or leader in prayer] desires you to tell him what he should say, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) being unable to proceed (Mgh, TA) in reciting the prayer, (TA,) do ye tell him what he should say, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) and prompt him, as though putting the recitation into his mouth like as food is put in: (TA:) a saying of ʼAlee. (Ḳ.)
And AisotaToEamotu Alfarasa † I desired the horse's running. (TA.)
See also 1, first sentence.
TaEomN [as an inf. n.: see 1.]

[As a simple subst.,] Taste, flavour, or savour; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) sweetness, and bitterness, and a quality [of any kind] between these two, in food and in beverage: pl. TuEuwmN. (Ḳ.) One says, TaEomuhu mur-N [Its taste is bitter], (Ṣ, TA,) and HulowN [sweet], (Mṣb, TA,) and HaAmiDN [acid]: and tagay-ara TaEomuhu Its taste became altered from its natural quality. (Mṣb.)

And [Relish, i. e.] a desired quality of food. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One says, layosa lahu TaEomN [It has no relish]: (Ṣ:) and layosa lilogav-i [What is lean has no relish]: and TaEamN↓ signifies the same in the dial. of Kiláb. (Mṣb.)

[Hence, † An approvable quality in a man.] One says rajulN cuw TaEomN † A man possessing intelligence, and prudence, or discretion: and maA bifulaAnK TaEomN walaA nawiySN † There is not in such a one intelligence nor activity: and layosa limaA yafoEalu fulaAnN TaEomN † There appertains not to what such a one does any pleasing quality, nor any place of honour in the heart, or mind: and it is said in a trad., maA qatalonaA OaHadFA bihi TaEomN maA qatalonaA Uil-aA EajaAYiza SuloEFA † We slew not any one of account, any known person, or any one of rank, or station; [we slew not any but bald-headed old women;] and one may also say in this case TuEomN↓, with damm. (TA.)

Also A thing that is swallowed easily or agreeably, whether solid, as grains [&c.], or liquid, as expressed juice and oil and vinegar [&c.]; differing from TuEomN, which does not apply to liquids. (Mṣb.)
TuEomN [as an inf. n.: see 1:]
as a subst.: see TaEaAmN.
Also Grain that is thrown to birds. (T, Mṣb, TA.) And A bait that is thrown to fish. (TA.)

TaEaAmu TuEomK means Food that satisfies the stomach of its eater: (ISh, Ḳ, TA:) and is said by MF to be for TaEaAmu XaIoCK TuEomK. (TA.) The Prophet said of the well Zemzem, Uin-ahaA TaEaAmu TuEomK, meaning Verily it is a satisfier of the stomach of man, (ISh, Mṣb, TA,) like as is food. (TA.)
See also TaEomN.
TaEamN; see TaEomN.
TaEimN: see TaAEimN.

TuEomapN i. q. maOokalapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or rizoqN; (Mgh;) i. e. † An assigned, or appointed, means of subsistence; such as a grant of a tract of land; [an allodium so granted;] and a tax, or a portion of a tax or of taxes; and the like: (Mgh, TA:) pl. TuEamN. (Mgh, Ḳ.) One says, jaEalotu hecihi AlD-ayoEapa TuEomapF lifulaAnK † [I have assigned this estate as a means of subsistence to such a one]. (Ṣ.) [For other exs., see 4.] And it is said in a trad. respecting the inheritance of the grandfather, Uin-a Als-udosa AlMxara TuEomapN lahu i. e. † The other sixth is a surplus for him beyond his [regular] due. (TA.)
Also An invitation to food. (Ḳ.)

And ‡ A mode, or manner, of gain; (Ṣ, Ḳ, Ta;) as also TiEomapN↓: (TA:) it is like HirofapN. (A, TA.) One says, fulaAnN Eafiyfu AlT-uEomapi ‡ [Such a one is uncorrupt in respect of the mode of gain]: and xabiyvu AlT-uEomapi i. e. corrupt in respect of the means of gain. (Ṣ, TA.)

TiEomapN A way, mode, or manner, of eating: (Ḳ, TA:) Lḥ explains it as meaning a way, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct, without saying in eating or in any other thing. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN Hasanu AlT-iEomapi waAlX-irobapi [Such a one is good, or comely, in respect of the way, mode, or manner, of eating and of drinking]. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, TA.) And fulaAnN Tay-ibu AlT-iEomapi ‡ [Such a one is accustomed to eat nothing but what is lawful], and xabiyvu AlT-iEomapi accustomed to eat nothing but what is unlawful. (TA.) See also TuEomapN.
TaEaAmN [as an inf. n.: see 1.]

[As a subst.,] Food, (Ṣ, Nh, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of any kind; (Nh, TA;) like as XaraAbN signifies beverage [of any kind]: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and especially wheat, (Ṣ, Nh, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) to which it is applied by the people of El-Ḥijáz; (Mṣb, TA;) and barley; (Nh, TA;) [and corn in general; thus applied to millet in the present day in some parts of Arabia, as, for instance, in El-Yemen; (see miyrapN;)] and dates, (Nh, Mgh, TA,) when said not to mean wheat; (Mgh, TA;) &c.: (Nh, TA:) and in the Expos. of the “Shifè,” it is said to be applied to ‡ other than food tropically: (TA:) and TuEomN↓ signifies the same; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also maToEamN↓; (Ḥam p. 166, and Ḳ;*) of which the pl. is maTaAEimu: (Ḥam ubi suprà:) one says, huwa yaHotakiru AlmaTaAEima, meaning [He collects and withholds] wheat [waiting for a time of scarcity and dearness]: (A, TA:) the pl. of TaEaAmN is OaToEimapN, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and pl. pl. OaToEimaAtN. (Ḳ.) [It often means A meal, or repast.] TaEaAmu AlbaHori means That from which the water [of the sea, or of the great river,] has receded, leaving it, so that it is taken without fishing: or, as some say, anything that is irrigated by the water of the bHr [i. e. great river], and consequently vegetates: so says Zj. (TA. [See the Ḳur v. 97.])

TaEuwmN and TaEiymN↓, applied to a slaughtered camel or she-camel, † Such as is between the lean and the fat: (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the former, so applied, signifies fat: and each, applied to a sheep or goat (XAp), having somewhat of fat: (TA:) and the former, as also muTaE-imN↓ and muT-aEimN↓ [in the CK muT-aEamN], signifies ‡ thus, applied to a he-camel and to a she-camel, (Ḳ,* TA,) as also TaEiymN↓: or a she-camel having in her a little marrow: or in the flesh of which is found the flavour of fat, by reason of her fatness. (TA.) Accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed, one says, laka gav-u hecaA waTaEuwmuhu i. e. † [Thine is, or shall be, the lean of this] and the fat thereof. (TA.) And mux-N TaEuwmN means † Marrow in which is found the flavour of fatness. (TA.)
TaEiymN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
Also, applied to water, i. q. XaruwbN [q. v.]. (TA in art. Xrb.)
TaEuwmapN A sheep, or goat (XAp) that is confined to be eaten. (Ḳ.)
TaEaAmiI-N A seller of TaEaAm [app. as meaning wheat, or corn]. (TA.)
TaAEimN Eating: and tasting. (Ṣ.)
OanaA TaAEimN Eano TaEaAmikumo, thus in the A and Ḳ, but in the L gayora TEAmkm, (TA,) means ‡ I am in no need of your food. (Ḳ, TA.)
maToEamN [as an inf. n.: see 1.]
[As a subst.,] A place of eating: (Ḥar p. 345:) [and a time thereof:] syn. maOokalN. (TA.)
See also TaEaAmN.
And see also musotaToEamN.
muToEamN [Fed.]
[And hence,] ‡ Supplied with the means of subsistence. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
[Hence,] one says, Uin-aka muToEamN mawad-atiI, meaning marozuwqN mawad-atiI [i. e. ‡ Verily thou art gifted with my love, or affection]. (TA.)

miToEamN That eats vehemently: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) fem. with p {miToEamapN}: (Ḳ:) the former applied to a man; (Ṣ, TA;) and the latter, to a woman, and extr., [said to be] the only instance of the kind except miSak-apN. (TA.)
muToEamapN or miToEamapN: see the next paragraph, each in two places.

muToEimapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like muHosinapN, (Ḳ,) [i. e.] with kesr to the E, accord. to IAạr, (Ṣ,) and like mukoramapN, (Ḳ, [i. e. muToEamapN↓, but I think it most probable that it is correctly miToEamapN↓, like mikosaHapN, &c., as being the name of an instrument, agreeably with a remark respecting it in what follows,]) ‡ A bow: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) called by the former appellation because it feeds its owner with the game: (IAạr, Ṣ, TA:) and by the latter appellation because one takes the game by means of it, and often shoots with it. (TA.)

And AlmuToEimapu, (Ḳ, TA,) or, as written by Z, with fet-ḥ, [i. e. AlmuToEamapu↓, or, as I think more probable, AlmiToEamapu↓,] ‡ The galoSamap [or epiglottis; because it is said to throw the meat and drink into the gullet]. (Ḳ, TA.) And ‡ [The place thereof; i. e.] the Haloq [or fauces; or upper part of the throat]: so in the saying, Oaxaca fulaAnN bimTEmp fulaAnK i. e. ‡ Such a one seized the Haloq of such a one, squeezing it; said only in a case of throttling and fighting. (AZ, TA.)
And AlmuToEimataAnK ‡ The two corresponding anterior toes of a bird; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. the two talons with which the bird seizes the flesh-meat. (TA.)
muTaE-imN: see TaEuwmN.
Also † Milk that has acquired in the skin a flavour and a pleasant odour: (AḤát, Ḳ, TA:) and muT-aEimN↓ signifies [the same, or] milk that has acquired the flavour of the skin. (TA.)
muT-aEimN: see TaEuwmN:
and see also muTaE-imN.

miToEaAmN One who feeds others much, (Ṣ,) or who has many guests, (Ḳ,) and who entertains guests much; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a man, (Ṣ, TA,) and to a woman: (TA:) [and app. one who eats much: for] qawomN maTaAEiymu signifies a people, or party, that eat much: or that feed others much. (TA.)
muTaAEamu Alxaloqi i. q. mutaAbaEu Alxaloqi [app. † Sound, or free from defect, in make]. (TA.)

musotaToEamN The lips of the horse: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) Aṣ says that thinness of the mstTEm of the horse is approved: (Ṣ, TA:) but some say that it is the part beneath the marosin [or place of the halter] of the horse, extending to the extremities of his lips: and mTEm [thus in my original, app. maToEamN↓, as being the “place of eating,”] signifies the same. (TA.)

1. TaEanahu biAlr-umoHi, aor. _u {yaToEunu} and _a {yaToEanu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter allowed by Fr as aor. of the verb in all its senses, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) because of the faucial letter, (Mṣb,) and heard by him as aor. of the verb in this phrase, but not by Ks in this case nor in relation to the grounds of pretension to respect or honour, (TA,) inf. n. TaEonN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and maToEanN, (Mṣb,) and Lth authorizes TaEanaAnN also in this case as well as in the case of TaEana biAlqawoli, (TA,) He smote him and pierced him, or he smote him and he pierced him, [for it does not always signify the causing the weapon to enter,] with the spear; (Ḳ;) he pierced him, smote him, or wounded him, with the spear: (MA:) [sometimes TaEanahu means he pierced, stabbed, stuck, or gored, him with a spear, &c.; and sometimes, he thrust, goaded, or poked, him:] you say, TaEana Ald-aAb-apa biEuwdK Oawo naHowihi [He goaded the beast with a stich or the like]. (Mgh and Mṣb in art. nxs.)
[Hence,] TuEina ‡ He was smitten by the TaAEuwn i. e. plague, or pestilence; (Z, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) said of a man, (Mṣb, TA,) and of a camel. (TA.)

And TaEana fiyhi biAlqawoli, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Ealayohi, (Mṣb, TA,) and TaEanahu bilisaAnihi, (TA,) [and TaEana fiI EiroDihi,] aor. _u {yaToEunu}, (Lth, TA,) or, accord. to some, in this case _a, (TA,) or both, (Mṣb,) inf. n. TaEonN and TaEanaAnN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA, [the latter in the CK, erroneously, TaEonaAn, but expressly said in the TA to be biAlt-aHoriyk,]) ‡ [He wounded him, or attacked him, with words, and with his tongue; and wounded, or attacked, his reputation;] he blamed, censured, or reproached, him; attributed or imputed to him, charged him with, or accused him of, a vice, fault, or the like; or spoke against him. (Mṣb, TA.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely, Aboo-Zubeyd, (TA,)
waOabiI ZaAhiru AlX-anaMCapi Uil-aA
TaEanaAnFA waqawola maA laA yuqaAlN
[And my father is one in whom hatred is manifest, (or, as in the TA, AlmuZohiru AlEadaAwapa, he who manifests enmity,) except in censuring, and saying what should not be said]. (Ṣ.) TaEanaAnN is of a measure of inf. ns. of verbs denoting that in which is prolongation and perseverance; and aptly applies to deviation from the right course. (TA.)
TaEana UilaI Oum-ihi is said of a child, meaning He raised his head [or thrust with it] towards the breast of his mother. (L.)
And TaEana fiI Ald-aAri, said of a branch of a tree, (L, Mṣb,) means It inclined into, or against, the house, rising: (L:) or it inclined towards the house, extending sideways. (Mṣb.)

TaEanato fiI Alxidori, said, in a trad., of any one of the Prophet's daughters, when demanded in marriage, as denoting her disapproval, means † She entered within the xidor [or curtain]: or, as some say, she struck the xdr with her hand. (TA in art. xdr.)

And you say, TaEana fiI AlmafaAzapi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaToEunu} and _a {yaToEanu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. TaEonN, (Mṣb,) ‡ He went away in, or into, the desert, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) penetrated into it, (TA,) and traversed it. (So in a copy of the Ṣ.)

And TaEana All-ayola ‡ He journeyed throughout the whole of the night. (Ḳ, TA.) One says, xaraja yaToEunu All-ayola ‡ He went forth journeying in the night. (TA.) And TaEana biAlqawomi † He journeyed by night with the people, or party. (TA.)
And TaEana fiI Als-in-i, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaToEunu}, (Ṣ,) † He became old, or advanced [or far-advanced] in age: (Mṣb:) or he rose (XaxaSa) in age. (TA.)

And TaEana fiyhi means also † He began it, or entered upon it, namely, a thing, (Mṣb, TA,) or an affair, of any kind. (Mṣb.) Hence one says of a woman, TaEanato fiI AlHayoDapi, for TEnt fI Oay-aAmi AlHayoDapi i. e. † She entered upon the days of the menstruation. (Mṣb.)

TaEana fiI AlEinaAni, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaToEunu}, (Ṣ,) said of a horse, means ‡ He strained the rein [by thrusting forward his head], and hastened, or was quick, (tanaX-aTa, so in copies of the Ṣ, in the Ḳ tabas-aTa,) in going, or pace. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

And TuEina fiI jinaAzatihi means † He died; (Lth and Mgh and TA in art. jnz;) [lit. he was thrust into his bier:] or he was at the point of death: and TuEina fiI nayoTihi signifies the same. (TA in the present art.)
3: see 6.
AlT-iEaAnu is metonymically used as meaning AlmujaAmaEapu. (Ḥar p. 601.)

6. taTaAEanuwA fiI AlHarobi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taTaAEunN, (Ḳ, TA,) and accord. to the Ḳ TEnAn, app. TaEanaAnN, [in the CK with the E quiescent,] but correctly TiEin-aAnN↓, with two kesrehs and with a sheddeh to the n, which is anomalous; and to this the Ḳ adds TiEaAnN, with kesr, [in the CK written with fet-ḥ,] but this is the inf. n. of TaAEanuwA↓, not of tTAEnwA, as also muTaAEanapN; (TA;) and AiT-aEanuwA↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the measure AifotaEaluwA; (Ṣ;) [They pierced, or thrust, one another in war:] Az says that Alt-afaAEulu and AlAifotiEaAlu scarcely ever signify otherwise than the participation of two agents. (TA.)
8: see the next preceding paragraph {6}.
TaEonN: see what next follows.

TaEonapN [as an inf. n. of un., A single act of piercing or thrusting; i. e. a piercing thrust or a stab, or simply a thrust; with a spear or the like: and a wound made by piercing or thrusting with a spear or the like; i. e.] the effect of AlT-aEon: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] TaEonN↓, thus used by a Hudhalee poet in the phrase TaEonN jawaAYifu [spear-wounds penetrating into the interior of the body, or into a vital part]. (TA.)
[It is also an inf. n. of un. in other senses.]

[Golius assigns also to this word and to TiEonapN and TuEonapN, as from the Ḳ, the meaning of A woman of evil disposition: but this is evidently a mistake, and taken from an art, (next after the present one) in the Ḳ, in which AlT-aEovanapu, there said to be biAlmuhomalapi waAlmuval-avapi, is expl. as meaning “the woman evil in disposition.”]
TiEin-aAnN an anomalous inf. n. of 6, q. v. (TA.)
TaEiynN: see maToEuwnN, in two places.

TaE-aAnN, (Ṣ, TA,) occurring in a trad., (Ṣ,) means Wont [to wound, or attack, the reputations of men;] to attack men with blame, censure, or reproach, and with backbiting, and the like: (TA:) it is for TaE-aAnN fiI OaEoraADi Aln-aAsi [a phrase mentioned in the Mṣb]. (Ṣ, TA.*)
TiE-iynN Skilled in piercing, or thrusting, [with the spear,] in war. (TA.)

TaAEuwnN ‡ An epidemic disease; (TA;) [i. e.] plague, or pestilence, syn. wabaO or wabaMC, (Ḳ, TA,) by reason of which the air is vitiated, and by it the constitutions and the bodies are vitiated: (TA:) or the kind of wabaO with which men are smitten by the jinn, or genii: (TA voce wabaON, q. v.:) or a mortality in consequence of wabaO: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. TawaAEiynu: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it is a tropical term from AlT-aEonu, because the TawaAEiyn are called by them rimaAHu Aljin-i [the spears of the jinn, or genii]. (Z, TA.)

maToEanN is a noun of place [signifying A place of piercing or thrusting, &c.]; as well as an inf. n. (Mṣb.) maA fiyhi maToEanN means † There is not in him anything [for which his reputation is to be wounded, or attacked, or] for which he is to be blamed, censured, or spoken against: (TA in art. gmz:) and you say, lahu fiyhi maToEanN † [He has (meaning he finds) in him something for which his reputation may be wounded,, &c.]: pl. maTaAEinu. (TA in the present art.)
miToEanN: see what next follows.
miToEaAnN One who pierces, or thrusts, the enemy much; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also miToEanN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former maTaAEiynu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and of the latter maTaAEinu. (Ḳ.)
Also ‡ Smitten by the TaAEuwn [i. e. plague, or pestilence]; (Mṣb, TA;) and so TaEiynN↓. (TA.)
5. tTg-m [in Freytag's Lex. taTaAgama] He feigned ignorance (Ḳ, TA) Eilayohi [to him]; as though he did as do the TagaAm. (TA.)
TagamN A sea. (Ḳ.) And Much water. (Ḳ.)

TagaAmN Low, ignoble, mean, or sordid, and weak, persons, such as serve for the food of their bellies; or stupid, weak in intellect, low, ignoble, mean, or sordid: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and applied to a single person as well as to a pl. number. (Ṣ, TA.)

And The inferior, or meaner, sorts of birds, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) [contr. of EitaAqu AlT-ayori,] and some add, and of beasts, or birds, of prey: (TA:) n. un. with p {TagaAmapN}; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to the male and the female. (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ.) It has no verb; and its derivation is not known. (Ṣ.)

yaA TagaAma AlOaHolaAmi, said by ʼAlee to the people of El-'Irák, is a phrase of the same class as UiXofaI Almirofaqi, [i. e. an instance of a subst. used as an epithet,] as though he said yaA DiEaAfa AlOaHolaAmi [O ye weak in respect of the qualities of forbearance]. (TA.)
TagaAmu AlkalaAmi means ‡ Low, or vile, speech: one says, kalaAmu AlT-agaAmi TagaAmu AlkalaAmi ‡ [The speech of the low, ignoble,, &c., is low, or vile, speech]. (TA.)
TagaAmapN Foolish; stupid; or having little, or no, intellect or understanding; (Az, Ḳ;) as also dagaAmapN. (Az, TA.)
[See also TagaAmN, of which it is a n. un.]
TuguwmapN and Tuguwmiy-apN Foolishness; stupidity; or paucity, or want, of intellect or understanding: and lowness, ignobleness, or meanness. (Ḳ.)

1. TagaI, aor. yaTogaI; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, TA, &c.;) not mentioned in the Ḳ [in art. TgI, but in some copies thereof mentioned in art Tgw]; perhaps dropped by the copyist; (TA;) and TagaA, aor. yaToguw; and TagiIa, aor. yaTogaI; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) inf. n. TagoIN, which is of the first, though mentioned in the Ḳ as being of the last; (TA;) and TugoyaAnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is also of the first, and second, (Ṣ,) or of the last, as also TigoyaAnN, (Ḳ,) mentioned by Ks as from some of the tribe of Kelb; (TA;) or TugoyaAnN is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) and TagoyaA, mentioned by Az as an inf. n. [app. of the first]; (TA;) and the inf. n. of the second is TagowN, (Mṣb,) or Tuguw-N, (Ḳ accord. to the TA,) like Euluw-N, (TA,) or TagowaI, (so in some copies of the Ḳ,) and TagowaI, mentioned as an inf. n. by Az, (TA,) and TugowaAnN; (Ḳ, and mentioned in the Ṣ as syn. with TugoyaAnN;) and the inf. n. of TagiIa is TagFI; (Mṣb, TA;) He exceeded the just, or common, limit or measure; was excessive, immoderate, inordinate, or exorbitant; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) [and particularly] in disobedience: (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* TA:) he exalted himself, and was inordinate in infidelity: he was extravagant in acts of disobedience and in wrongdoing: (Ḳ:) accord. to El-Harállee, AlT-ugoyaAnu signifies the acting wrongfully in respect of the limits of things and the measures thereof. (TA.)

[Hence,] TagaI, in the Ḳ TagiIa, but the former is the right, (TA,) or TagaA, (Mṣb,) said of a torrent, (Mṣb,) or of water, (Ḳ, TA,) ‡ It rose high, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) so as to exceed the ordinary limit in copiousness: (Mṣb:) or TagaI or TagaA, (accord. to different copies of the Ṣ,) said of a torrent, † it brought much water: and, said of the sea, † its waves became raised, or in a state of commotion: and, said of the blood, † it became roused, or excited. (Ṣ.) [Hence also the phrase TagaA miroqamuka † Thy pen has exceeded its due limit: see art. rqm.]
Tagati Albaqarapu, (Ḳ,) aor. _a, (TA,) means The baqarap [i. e. the bovine antelope called baqarapu AlwaHoXi (see TagoyaA)] uttered a cry or cries. (Ḳ.)
4. ATgAhu It, (i. e. wealth, Ṣ,) or he, (a man, Mṣb,) made him to exceed the just, or common, limit or measure; to be excessive, immoderate, inordinate, or exorbitant. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
6. tTAgI Almawoju [app. The waves conflicted, or dashed together, with excessive vehemence]: a phrase mentioned by Z. (TA.)
TagFA: see what next follows.

TagoIN; accord. to the copies of the Ḳ TagFA↓, but this is incorrect; A sound, or voice; of the dial. of Hudheyl: one says, samiEotu TagoIa fulaAnK I heard the sound, or voice, of such a one: and, as in the “Nawádir,” samiEotu TagoIa Alqawomi, and Tahoyahumo, and dagoyahumo, I heard the sound, or voice, [or voices,] of the people, or party. (TA.)
TagowapN: see what next follows.

TagoyapN The top, or upper part, of a mountain: (Ṣ, TA:) and any high, or elevated, place; as also TagowapN↓. (TA as from the Ṣ: but only the latter word is mentioned in this sense in my copies of the Ṣ.)
And (Ṣ) A small quantity (nubocapN) of anything: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) so says AZ. (Ṣ. [In this sense, and in the two senses following, erroneously written in the CK Tagiy-ap.])
And A smooth stone or rock. (Ḳ.)

And, accord. to the copies of the Ḳ, AlT-agoyapu signifies AlmusotaSoEabu mina Aljabali [as though meaning What is deemed, or found, difficult, of the mountain]: but [SM says, though I think this doubtful,] it is correctly mina Alxayoli [meaning what is refractory, or untractable, of horses], as in the M. (TA.)

TagowaI a subst. from the verb TagaA, (Ḳ, TA,) [and] so is TugoyaAnN↓, (Mṣb,) or the latter is an inf. n., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and, accord. to Az, so is TagowaI, and so too is TagoyaA↓, which latter is said by Zj to be the original of TagowaI: (TA:) it is like TugowaAnN and TugoyaAnN. (Ṣ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xci. 11], kac-abato vamuwdu biTagowaAhaA [Thamood disbelieved by reason of their exorbitance]; (Ḳ,* TA;) meaning that they did not believe when they were threatened with the punishment of their TugoyaAn: or, as is said in the Expos. of Bkh, the meaning is, by reason of their acts of disobedience. (TA.)

hom.sense: TagoyaA: see the next preceding paragraph.

It is also a proper name for [The bovine antelope called] baqarapu AlwaHoXi; (Ḳ, TA;) from Tagati Albaqarapu [expl. above: see 1, last sentence]: (TA:) [or, as it appears from a citation in the TA, partly mistranscribed so as to be unintelligible, TagoyaA or TugoyaA↓ signifies, accord. to IAạr, a baqarap uttering a cry or cries, or a loud cry or loud cries:]
or TugoyaA↓ with damm accord. to Aṣ, or TagoyaA with fet-ḥ accord. to Th, signifies a youngling of the baqar AlwaHoX. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: TugoyaA: see what next precedes, in two places.
TugoyaAnN: see TagowaI.
TaAgK Any exceeding his, or its, just limit [in an absolute sense or] in disobedience. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

TaAgiyapN i. q. jab-aArN [i. e. Insolent, tyrannical,, &c.]; (Ḳ, TA;) who deviates from the right way or course, or trangresses the just limit: (TA:) and stupid, or foolish; proud; (Ḳ, TA;) wrongful, unjust, or injurious, in conduct: (TA:) or one who cares not what he does, devouring [the property of] men, and oppressing them, and who is not turned from his course by a disposition to shun sin or crime, nor by fear. (Sh, TA.) [Hence,] AlT-aAgiyapu is an appellation of The king of the ruwm [or Greeks of the Lower Empire]; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) applied to him as a surname because of his much exorbitance, and corrupt conduct. (TA.)
And A thunderbolt; syn. SaAEiqapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And The cry of punishment; by which Thamood were destroyed, as mentioned in the Ḳur [lxix. 5]: (Ṣ, TA:) or, accord. to Zj, it there means their TugoyaAn [or exorbitance]; being a subst. like EaAfiyapN and EaAqibapN. (TA.)
Also The flood denoted by the words of the Ḳur [lxix. 11] Uin-aA lam-aA TagaI AlmaMCu. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

TaAguwtN is of the measure falaEuwtN, from Tagawotu; (M, Ḳ;) formed by transposition, though like laAhuwtN which is not so formed: (Ṣ:) it is originally of the measure faEaluwtN, which is changed to falaEuwtN, so that it becomes TawaguwtN, and this is then altered to TaAguwtN: (Mṣb, TA:) it is held to be altered from Tawaguwt rather than from Tagayuwt because the transposition of w is more common than that of I, as in XaAkK, &c.: (M, TA:) or, as some say, the t is a substitute for w, and the measure is faAEuwlN: and some say that the measure is faAEaluwtN, and that it is originally TaAgayuwtN: (TA:) the pl. is TawaAgiytu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and TawaAgK, (Ḳ,) the latter mentioned by ISd. (TA.) It signifies A devil; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) thus expl. by Abu-l- ʼÁliyeh and others, and said to be on the authority of ʼOmar: (TA:) or one that is exorbitant in pride or corruptness or disbelief or disobedience, of the jinn, or genii: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or AlT-aAguwtu means [the idol called] All-aAt and [that called] AlEuz-aI; (Ḳ;) or thus some expl. Aljibot and AlT-aAguwt [together, in the Ḳur iv. 54]: (TA:) or whatever is worshipped instead, or to the exclusion, of God; (Zj, Ḳ, TA;) as also Aljibotu: (Zj, TA:) and the idols [in general]: (Ḳ:) or it is of the idols, and of the jinn, or genii, and of mankind: (Akh, TA:) or he who turns from the good way: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and the diviner: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and the enchanter: thus expl. by ʼIkrimeh; and said to mean thus in the Ḳur iv. 63: and so Aljibotu accord. to Zj: (TA:) and any head, or leader, of error: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the exorbitant in pride or corruptness or disbelief or disobedience, of the people of the Scripture: (Ḳ:) it is used as a sing., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as in the Ḳur iv. 63; (Ṣ;) and as a pl., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as in the Ḳur ii. 259; (Ṣ;) and masc. and fem., (Mṣb, TA,) as fem. in the Ḳur xxxix. 19: (TA:) or by Aljibot is meant Hoyeí Ibn-Akhtab; and by AlT-aAguwt, Kaab Ibn-El-Ashraf: (I’Ab, Ḳ:) and [the pls.] TawaAgiytu and TawaAgK signify [sometimes] idol temples: so says El-Háfidh in the preface to the “Fet-ḥ” [i. e. his celebrated work entitled “Fet-ḥ el-Bári”]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Taf-a, (Aṣ, O, Ḳ,) [aor., app., _i,] inf. n. Taf-N, (TḲ, [or, accord. to Freytag TufuwfN, which see in what follows,]) It (a thing) was, or became, near. (Aṣ, O, Ḳ.) You say, Oaxacotu mino mataAEiI maA xaf-a waTaf-a i. e. [I took, of my goods,] what [was light, and] was near to me. (Aṣ, O.) And Taf-a AlX-aIoCu mina AlX-aIoCi The thing was, or became, near to the thing. (O, Ḳ.*) And xuco maA Taf-a laka, and QsotaTaf-a↓ laka, (Ṣ, Meyd, O, Ḳ,) and OaTaf-a↓ laka, (Meyd, O, TA,) Take thou what has risen to thee, and become within thy power or reach, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and become attainable [to thee], or prepared [for thee], (AZ, Meyd, TA,) and become near to thee: (Ḳ, TA:) or what has risen to view, and has appeared, [to thee,] to be taken: (TA:) [for] Taf-a, inf. n. TufuwfN, signifies it rose [app. so as to become visible]: and it was, or became, little in quantity: the saying is a prov., relating to a man's being content with a part of that which he wants: (Meyd:) and in like manner one says, xuco maA daf-a laka, and Qsotadaf-a: (AZ, Meyd, TA:) and Ks mentions, in relation to a man's being content with a part of that which he wants, the saying, xuco maA Taf-a laka wadaEo maA QsotaTaf-a↓ laka [app. meaning, if the saying be correctly thus related, Take what is within thy power, or reach, and leave what has risen to thy view so as to invite approach]; i. e. be content with what is within thy power. (TA.)
Taf-ati AlX-amosu:
and Taf-a said of a bird: see 2.
mar-ayaTf-u [app. yaTif-N] He passed by hastening, or going quickly. (O.)
Taf-a Aln-aAqapa, (O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaTofufu}, (O, TA,) inf. n. Taf-N, (TA,) He (a man, O) bound the legs of the she-camel, (O, Ḳ,) all of them. (O.)

Taf-ahu He (a man, O) raised it (i. e. a thing, O) with his leg or foot, or with his arm or hand. (O, Ḳ.) And Taf-a bifulaAnK mawoDiEa kacaA He raised such a one to such a place; and made him to be on a level with it. (TA.)
And Taf-a AlHaAYiTa, inf. n. Taf-N, He mounted upon the wall. (TA.)

2. Tf-f He made defective, or deficient. (TA.) You say, Tf-f, (Ḳ,) or Tf-f AlmikoyaAla, and AlmiyzaAna, (Mṣb,) inf. n. taTofiyfN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) He gave short measure, and short weight; (Mṣb;) he made the contents of the measure to be defective, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and in like manner, of the balance; (Mṣb;) not filling the former to its uppermost parts: (Ṣ, TA:) i. e. he did thus, cheating his companion in measure or in weight. (TA.) [Hence,] Tf-f EalaI EiyaAlihi ‡ He scanted his household, stinted them, or was niggardly or parsimonious towards them, in expenditure. (TA.) And Tf-f EalaI Alr-ajuli † He gave to the man less than he had taken from him. (TA.) And Tf-f AlUinaMCa He took what was upon [or above] the vessel [i. e. its TufaAf, or TufaAfap]. (TA. [See also 4, last sentence.])
Also He made full, or complete. (TA.) [Thus it has two contr. significations.]

Tf-ft AlX-amosu ‡ The sun drew near to setting: (TA:) [but this may be a mistranscription for Taf-at↓, mentioned by Golius in this sense on the authority of Z: or each may be correct: that the latter is correct, and that TafaAfN↓ or TifaAfN↓ is its inf. n., seems to be indicated by the fact that SM adds immediately after the explanation of the former phrase,] OataAnaA Einoda TfAfi AlX-amosi means ‡ [He came to us] at the sun's drawing near to setting. (TA.)

Tf-f, said of a bird, [or Taf-a↓, mentioned by Freytag from Hamaker's Specim. catal. p. 49, 1. 4, of the Arabic text, or both may be correct,] The bird expanded his wings: (O, Ḳ:) so says Ibn-ʼAbbád. (O.)

And Tf-f bihi Alfarasu ‡ The horse leaped with him. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ. [Golius has omitted this; and has assigned to Tf-f, followed by b with the person who is the object, as on the authority of the Ṣ and Ḳ, the signification of AdnA (properly OadonaI), meaning “prope admovit,” a signification belonging to OaTaf-a, but not assigned to either of these verbs in the Ṣ nor in the Ḳ.]) Taf-afa biIa Alfarasu masojida baniI zurayoqK, in a saying of Ibn-ʼOmar respecting a horse-race, means ‡ The horse leaped with me (Ṣ, O, TA) so that he passed beyond the mosque of the Sons of Zureyk. (O, TA.)
4. xuco maA OaTaf-a laka: see 1.
And ATf- lahu He had knowledge of it, i. e. an affair; (Lth, O, Ḳ;) and of him, i. e. a person. (O.)
And He desired to deceive him: (O, Ḳ:) or he had knowledge of him, and desired to deceive him. (O.)

And ATf- Ealayohi i. q. OaXorafa (O, Ḳ) i. e. OaXorafa Ealayohi [meaning He looked upon it, looked upon it from above, looked down upon it, got a view of it, saw it, or got knowledge of it]; namely, a thing; as also OaTal-a Ealayohi. (O.)

And, (AZ, O, Ḳ, TA,) as also OaTal-a Ealayohi, (AZ, TA,) He got possession of it, (AZ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and took it away, or went away with it; (AZ, O, TA;) namely, the property of another person. (AZ, TA.)
ATf- Ealayohi biHajarK He reached, or hit, him, or it, (tanaAwalahu,) with a stone. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
ATf-t Aln-aAqapu The she-camel cast, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O,) or brought forth, (Ḳ,) her young one in an imperfect state. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

ATf-h He put it, or brought it, near: 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd says, [using the verb in this sense,]
OaTaf-a liOanofihi AlmuwsaI qaSiyrN
[Kaseer put the razor near to his nose]: (Ḥam p. 436:) or this means Kaseer put the razor near to his nose and cut it off. (TA.)

And i. q. mak-anahu. (TA.) [You say, mak-anahu mina AlX-aIoCi, and app., in like manner, ATf-hu mina AlX-aIoCi, i. e. He made him to have power over the thing; or to have the thing within his power or reach; and so, perhaps, ATf-hu lilX-aIoCa.]
And ATf- lahu Als-ayofa He held forth the sword towards him, and struck him with it. (TA.)
And ATf- Alkayola He made the contents of the measure to reach to its uppermost parts: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as some say, he took what was upon [or above] the measure. (TA. [See also Taf-afa AlUinaMCa.])

entry.sense: 10. AstTf-, said of a camel's hump, It rose, or became high. (TA.)
And AstTf-t HaAjatuhu The thing that he wanted became prepared, and easy of attainment. (TA.) See also 1, in two places.
R. Q. 1. TafoTafa He (a man, TA) became lax [or weak] (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ) in the hands of his adversary (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O) or in the hand of his adversary. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: Taf-N The side (O, Ḳ) of a thing: (O:) [like daf-N:] and the bank, or shore, (O, Ḳ,) of a great river or a sea; (O;) as also TafoTaAfN↓: (O, Ḳ:) accord. to Lth, of the Euphrates: (O:) or, as some say, the elevated part of the side of the Euphrates. (TA.) And AlT-af-u is applied to The part of the land of the Arabs that overlooks the cultivated region of El-'Irák: (IDrd, O, Ḳ:) said by Aṣ to be so called because it is near to the cultivated region: (O:) or it is a place in the district of El-Koofeh. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.*)
And The exterior court or yard of a house. (TA.)
See also TafaAf, in two places.
And see Taf-aAfN.

entry.sense: TafafN: see TafaAf.
TafafapN: see TufaAfapN.

hom.sense: TafaAfu Almak-uwki (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,* Ḳ) and AlUinaMCi, (Ḳ,) and TifaAfuhu↓, (Ṣ, Mgh,* O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Taf-uhu↓, and Tafafahu↓, (Ṣ, Mgh,* O, Ḳ,) The quantity sufficing for the filling (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) of the [measure called] mk-wk (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and of the vessel (Ḳ) to its uppermost parts: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or what remains in it after the wiping off of the head thereof: (M, Ḳ: [the measure being generally in the form of a truncated cone, much smaller at the top than at the base, the quantity rising above the top is not much:]) or the jimaAm or jamaAm or jumaAm (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ [generally meaning the quantity that rises above the top after the filling]) thereof: or the quantity sufficing for the filling thereof: (Ḳ:) or the quantity nearly sufficing for the filling thereof: (TA: [and the like explanation is given of the third word in the Ṣ, &c., as will be shown by what follows:]) or the quantity that falls short of the filling thereof. (Mgh. [See also TufaAfapN.]) It is said in a trad. (Ṣ, Mgh, O) of the Prophet, (Mgh, O,) kul-ukumo banuw Mdama Taf-a↓ AlS-aAEi, (Ṣ, O,) or Taf-u AlS-aAEi, (so in my copy of the Mgh,) All of you, sons of Adam, are like the quantity nearly sufficing for the filling of the SAE; (Ṣ,* Mgh, O;) i. e. ye are all nearly alike; so says Az: (Mgh:) meaning, all of you, in being related to one father, are in one predicament in respect of defectiveness, like the thing measured that falls short of filling the measure: (IAth, Mgh, O:) the Prophet then proceeded to inform them that there is no excellence of one above another except by piety. (O.)
TafaAfN signifies also The blackness of night; (O, Ḳ;) and so TifaAfN↓. (Ḳ.)
See also 2.

entry.sense: TufaAfN: see TufaAfapN, in two places.
TifaAfN: see TafaAf, in two places:
and see 2.
TafiyfN Little in quantity: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and incomplete: (IDrd, O, Ḳ:) applied to a thing in this sense, (IDrd, O,) and in the former sense. (TA.) [See tifolN.]
Also Low, base, vile, mean, paltry, or contemptible. (TA.)

TufaAfapN The quantity that is above the measure; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also TufaAfN↓ (Ṣ) or TafafapN↓: (O, Ḳ:) or the quantity that falls short of filling the vessel, (IDrd, O, Ḳ,) of beverage or wine, &c. (IDrd, O. [See also TafaAf.]) And Somewhat, little in quantity, remaining in a vessel. (TA.)
And TufaAfapu AlUinaMCi and TufaAfuhu↓ The uppermost part of the vessel. (Ḳ.)

Taf-aAfN (O, Ḳ) and Taf-N↓ (Ḳ) and xaf-N and daf-N, as epithets applied to a horse, are alike (O, Ḳ) in meaning (Ḳ) [app. signifying Light, brisk, or quick: (see Taf-afa bihi Alfarasu:) in the TḲ, and hence by Freytag, expl. as meaning thus, but as an epithet applied to a man].
[UinaMCN Taf-aAnu in the CK Taf-AnN] A vessel in which the measuring [or thing measured] has reached its uppermost parts: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) [or] a full vessel. (IAạr, TA.)
AlT-aAf-apu What is between mountains and plains. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
And TaAf-apu AlbusotaAni What surrounds the garden: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:) pl. TawaAf-u. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)
