TafoTafapN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and TifoTifapN, (O, Ḳ,) the latter mentioned on the authority of AZ, (O,) The xaASirap [or flank]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or any quivering flesh: (Az, O, Ḳ: [see XidoqN:]) or the flaccid flesh of the soft parts of the belly; (O, Ḳ;) thus the former word is expl. by IDrd: (O:) or the extremities of the side, adjoining the ribs: (Ḳ:) and said to mean the soft part of the liver; the pl. being used by Dhu-r-Rummeh in relation to the liver: (L, TA:) the pl. is TafaATifu. (O, Ḳ.)
TafoTaAfN The extremities of trees: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or the soft, or tender, and succulent, of plants, or herbage: or, accord. to El-Mufaddal, the leaves of the branches. (TA.)
See also Taf-N.

muTaf-ifN One who gives short measure, and short weight, (Zj, Mṣb, TA,) thus cheating his companion; but this epithet is not applied unrestrictedly except in the case of exorbitant deficiency: [or] accord. to Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ [i. e. Zj], the mTf-f is thus called because he seldom or never steals from the measure or balance save what is paltry, i. e. Tafiyf; for it is from Taf-u AlX-aIoCi, meaning “the side of the thing:” the pl. occurs in the Ḳur lxxxiii. 1. (TA.)

1. TafiYati Aln-aAru, aor. _a {yaTofaOu}, inf. n. TufuwoCN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TafaON; (TA;) and AnTfOt↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) The fire became extinguished, or quenched: (Mṣb:) or ceased to flame: (Ḳ, TA:) [or rather, ceased to flame and its live coals became cool; for] when the flame of the fire has become allayed but its coals still burn, it is said to be xaAmidap; and when its flame is extinct and its coals have become cool, it is said to be haAmidap and TaAfiYap↓. (TA.)

4. ATfO Aln-aAra He extinguished, or quenched, the fire. (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA.) Hence, ATfO AlHaroba ‡ He extinguished the fire of the war. (TA.) And OaTofaOotu Alfitonapa ‡ I allayed the sedition, or conflict and faction, or the like. (Mṣb.)
7: see the first paragraph {1}.
naArN TaAfiYapN [Fire becoming, or become, extinguished]: see 1.

muTofiYu Aljamori [The extinguisher of the live coals;] one of the [seven] days called Oay-aAmu AlEajuwzi; (Ṣ, O;) the fifth of those days; (Ḳ;) so in the M, &c.: (TA:) or the fourth thereof: (O, Ḳ:) or the last thereof. (Ḥar p. 295.) [Accord. to modern Egyptian almanacs, it is the fourth of those days on which the last of the three jamaraAt becomes extinct: see jamorapN: and see also EajuwzN]

muTofiYapu Alr-aDofi (so in the M and O and L and in some copies of the Ḳ, in other copies of the Ḳ muTofiYu, TA) A piece of fat which, when it falls upon the raDof [or heated stones], melts, and quenches them. (Lth, O, Ḳ.) And in the M and L, it is said to signify A lean sheep or goat: the Arabs, as is related by Lḥ, used to say, Hadasa lahumo bimuTofiYapi Alr-aDofi (TA) i. e. He slaughtered for them a lean sheep or goat, which extinguished the fire and did not become thoroughly cooked: (M and L and Ḳ in art. Hds:) or a fat sheep or goat, (AO and T, TA in that art.,) which quenched the raDof by its fat. (T, TA ibid. [See also damaga.])

Also A serpent, the poison of which, as it passes by the raDof, extinguishes their fire: (O, Ḳ:) in a verse of El-Kumeyt, [for the sake of the metre,] the former word is [altered to] muTaf-iYap↓. (O.)
And ‡ A calamity, or misfortune: (O, Ḳ, TA:) said by AO to mean originally such as has made one to forget that which was before it, and extinguished its heat. (O, TA.)
muTaf-iYapu Alr-aDofi: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. TafaHa, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaTofaHu}, (TA,) inf. n. TufuwHN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and TafoHN, (Ḳ,) It (a vessel, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, and a river, A, TA, and a wateringtrough, or tank, A) was, or became, full, so as to overflow: (Ṣ, A:) was, or became, full, and high [in its contents], (Ḳ, TA,) so as to overflow. (TA.) [See also miroqamN.]
TafaHa said of one intoxicated, ‡ He was full of wine. (T, Ṣ, TA.)

TafaHato biAlOawolaAdi ‡ She (a woman) brought forth children abundantly; brought forth many children: (A:) [or] TafaHato biAlwaladi she brought forth the child at the full period of gestation, or fully formed. (Ḳ.)
TafaHa Eaqoluhu † His understanding, or intellect, became eminent [or, app., exuberant]. (TA.)
TafaHa, aor. as above, also signifies † He ran. (Aṣ, TA.)
And one says, AiTofaHo Ean-iI, meaning † Go thou away, or depart, from me. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
TafaHa as trans.: see 4.
TafaHati Alr-iyHu AlquTonapa The wind raised, or carried up, the portion of cotton: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and in like manner, a similar thing. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 2: see the next paragraph {4}.

4. ATfHhu; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and Tf-Hhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taTofiyHN; (Ṣ;) and TafaHahu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. TafoHN; (TA;) He filled it so that it overflowed: (Ṣ, A:) or he filled it so that it became high [in its contents]: (Ḳ:) namely, a vessel, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and a river, or rivulet, and a watering-trough, or tank. (A.)
8. AiT-afaHa Alqidora (Ṣ, Ḳ, in the CK [erroneously] Alqidoru) He took off the TufaAHap (i. e. scum) of the cooking-pot. (Ṣ.)
TafoHaAnu; fem. TafoHaI: see TaAfiHN.

TifaAHu AlOaroDi What would fill the earth (T in art. THf, and Ḳ,) so that it would overflow: (T:) so in the saying, in a trad., waUno kaAna Ealayohi TifaAHu AlOroDi cunuwbAF [Though there be upon him, or imputable to him, what would fill the earth so that it would overflow, of sins, or crimes]. (T.)
TufaAHapF What has come forth upon the surface of a thing, such as the scum of the cooking-pot, (Ṣ,) which is termed TufaAHapu Alqidori. (A, Ḳ.)
Taf-aAHu AlqawaAYimi ‡ A horse that runs much. (A.) And Taf-aAHapu AlqawaAYimi ‡ A she-camel having swift legs. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: TaAfiHN Full, so as to overflow; applied to [a vessel, and] a river, and a watering-trough, or tank: (A, TA:) or full: and full and high. (AʼObeyd, T, TA.) And UinaMCN TafoHaAnu↓, and qaSoEapN TafoHaI A vessel, and a bowl, of which the contents flow over the sides. (Ḳ.)
Applied to one intoxicated, ‡ Full of wine. (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
And † Running, or one that runs. (Aṣ, TA.)
And [the fem.] TaAfiHapN signifies Dry, or tough, or rigid: whence the phrase rukobapN TaAfiHapN meaning A knee which he to whom it belongs cannot grasp with his hand. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: miTofaHapN A skimmer, or ladle with which the scum of the cooking-pot is taken off; (Ḳ;) called in Pers. kafoGiyr. (TA.)

1. Tafara, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _i {yaTofiru}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. TufuwrN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TaforN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) or TaforapN, (Ḳ,) [but] this has a more particular signification than TaforN, (Mṣb,) [being an inf. n. un.,] He leaped: (Ṣ:) or he leaped upwards, (Lth, T, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as when one leaps over a wall to what is behind it. (Lth, T, Mgh, Mṣb.) One says, Tafara AlHaAYiTa, (TA,) or Tafara AlHaAYiTa UilaI maA waraMCahu, (A,) He leaped over the wall to what was behind it. (TA.) And Tafara Alfarasu Aln-ahora [The horse leaped over the river, or rivulet]. (A, TA.)
2. Tf-r Alfarasa Aln-ahora He made the horse to leap over the river, or rivulet. (A, TA.)

8. AiT-afara farasahu, inf. n. AiT-ifaArN; (O, TA;) accord. to the Ḳ, OaTofara, inf. n. UiTofaArN, but the former is the right; (TA;) He thrust his feet into the groins of his horse: the doing of which is a fault in the rider. (O, Ḳ, TA.) And in like manner one says of a man when he makes his camel to run: (O, TA:) i. e. AiT-afara baEiyrahu, inf. n. AiT-ifaArN, He thrust his feet into the groins of his camel. (L.) [It seems to be tropical, from what here follows.]

AiT-afara Alr-ajulu, meaning He stuck his nails [into a thing] is originally AiZ-afara; (TA; [in which it is said to be tropical; but for this I see no reason;]) as also AiT-afarahu he stuck his nail into it. (TA in art. Zfr.)

TaforapN A leap: (Ṣ:) or a leap upwards, (T, A,* Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) as when one leaps over a wall; (T, Mgh, Mṣb;) said to be thus distinguished from wavobapN, which is downwards. (Mgh, Mṣb.) Hence Taforapu Aln-iZaAmi [app. meaning An overleaping the right order, or method: I have not found any explanation of it]. (A.)
huwa Taf-aAru AlOanohaAri [He is the leaper over rivers, or rivulets]. (A.)
TinofisapN and its variations: see art Tnfs.

1. Tafiqa yafoEalu kacaA, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaTofaqu}; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Tafaqa, aor. _i {yaTofiqu}, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) mentioned by Akh, (Ṣ, ISd, O,) and by Zj, (ISd, TA,) as said by some, (Ṣ, O,) but pronounced by Lth to be bad; (TA;) inf. n. TaqaqN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, [in some copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, TafoqN,]) of the former verb; (Ṣ, TA;) and TufuwqN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) of the latter verb; (Ṣ, O;) He set about, began, commenced, took to, or betook himself to, doing such a thing: (Ṣ, Mgh, O, TA:) expl. in the Ḳ as meaning he continued uninterruptedly the doing of such a thing (waASala AlfiEola [or in some copies waSala AlfiEola]), and by El-Háfidh Ibn-Hajar, in the “Fet-ḥ el-Bári,” as meaning he entered upon, began, or commenced, and went on continually, doing such a thing; but it denotes the entering upon the doing of a thing irrespectively of the going on continually or not, and therefore it is not allowable to prefix Oano to its predicate: (MF, TA:) it is followed by a future [or an aor., as in the ex. above]: the saying faTafiqa masoHFA biQls-uwqi waQloOaEonaAqi, in the Ḳur [xxxviii. 32], (TA,) i. e. He took to severing with the sword [the thighs and the necks], or, as some say, to wiping [or stroking] with his hand [the thighs and the necks], (Bḍ,) is for Tafiqa yamosaHu masoHFA: (Bḍ,* TA:) the verb is used only in an affirmative phrase: they do not say maA Tafiqa. (IDrd, O, Ḳ.)
Tafiqa fulaAnN bimaA OaraAda, (Aboo-Saʼeed, O, Ḳ,*) a phrase of the Arabs of the desert, (Aboo-Saʼeed, O,) means Such a one attained that which he desired. (Aboo-Saʼeed, O, Ḳ.*)
And one says Tafiqa AlmawoDiEa, aor. _a {yaTofaqu}, He kept, or clave, to the place. (ISd, Ḳ.)

4. ATfqhu Qll-ehu bihi God caused him to attain him, or it. (Aboo-Saʼeed, O, Ḳ.) One says, laYino OaTofaqaniI Qll-ehu bihi laOafoEalan-a bihi [Verily if God cause me to attain him, or it, I will assuredly do something with him, or it]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Tafula, aor. _u {yaTofulu}, inf. n. TafaAlapN and TufuwlapN, It (anything) was, or became, soft, or tender; [as though resembling a Tifol;] (Ḳ, TA;) syn. raxuSa. (TA.)
Tafalat said of a she-camel: see 2.
Tafala, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. TufuwlN, said of a man, (TA,) He entered upon the [time called] Tafal, (Ḳ, TA,) which has two contr. meanings; (TA;) as also ATfl↓. (Ḳ.)
And Tafalati AlX-amosu The sun rose: (O, Ḳ:) so says Fr in his “Nawádir.” (O.)

And, (O, Ḳ,) accord. to Zj, (O,) The sun became red on the occasion of setting; and so OaTofalat↓: (O, Ḳ:) thus the former has two contr. meanings: (Ḳ:)
and Tf-lt↓ AlX-amos, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Tf-lt liloguruwbi, (Ṣ,) inf. n. taTofiylN, (Ṣ, O,) The sun inclined to setting: (Ṣ, O:) or approached the setting; as also Tafalat, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. _u {yaTofulu}, inf. n. TufuwlN. (TA.)
Tafalati AlHumuru AlEuXoba The asses depastured the herbs so as to raise the dust upon them. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)

And Tafila Aln-abotu; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ;) and Tufila; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA;) or, accord. to the Ḳ, Tuf-ila↓, inf. n. taTofiylN; (TA;) The herbage became soiled by dust, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ, TA,) and thereby marred, or injured. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA.)

2. Tf-lt Aln-aAqapu i. q. raXaHato TifolahaA or raX-aHatohu [i. e. The she-camel rubbed the root of her young one's tail, and pushed him on with her head; and went before him, and waited for him until he overtook her; and sometimes gently urged him on, and followed him]; (Ḳ accord. to different copies; [but both of these verbs signify the same, as expl. in the L;]) and so Tafalat↓, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. _u {yaTofulu}, inf. n. TufuwlN. (TA.)
Tf-lt AlX-amosu: see 1.
Tf-l All-ayolu The night began to be dark: (Ṣ, O:) or drew near. (Ḳ.)
Tf-l AlUibila, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. taTofiylN, (Ṣ, O,) He treated the camels gently, in journeying, in order that their young ones (OaTofaAluhaA) might come up to them. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

And Tf-l AlkalaAma, ‡ He considered, or forecast, the results of the speech, or saying; he looked to what would, or might, be its result; or he thought, or meditated, upon it, and endeavoured to understand it; syn. tadab-arahu; (Ḳ, TA;) and (TA) so ATflhu↓. (O, TA.)
See also 1, last sentence.
And see 5, in two places.

4. ATflt, said of a woman, (Ṣ, O, TA,) and of a girl, or young woman, (Sbyp, [but this, I doubt not, is a mistranscription for Zaboyap, i. e. a doe-gazelle,]) and of a she-camel, (TA,) or of any female, (Mṣb,) She had a Tifol [or young one of tender age]: (Ṣ, O, TA:) or she brought forth. (Mṣb.)
See also 1, in two places.
And see 2.

entry.sense: 5. tTf-l He was, or became, an intruder at feasts, uninvited; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Tf-l↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taTofiylN: (TA:) or he imitated Tufeyl: (Ḥar p. 179: [see TufayoliI-N:]) and Tf-l↓ Ealayohi and tTf-l Elyh he intruded upon him at a feast, uninvited. (TA.) It is of the speech of the people of El-'Irák. (Lth, Mṣb.)

hom.sense:
TafolN Soft, or tender; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) applied to anything, (Ḳ:) fem, with p {TafolapN}; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) applied to a girl, or young woman, (Ṣ,) or to a woman: (O:) and pl. TifaAlN and TufuwlN, (Ḳ.) One says banaAnN TafolN [Soft, or tender, fingers, or ends of fingers]; this being allowable, though bnAn is a [kind of] pl. and Tfl is a sing., because every pl. [of the kind] that differs not from its sing. save in the p [affixed to the latter] is made sing. and masc. [as well as fem.]: and therefore Homeyd says,
falam-aA kaXafona All-ibosa Eanohu masaHonahu
biOaToraAfi TafolK zaAna gayolFA muwaX-amFA
[And when they (referring to females) removed from over him the clothing, they wiped him with the extremities of soft, or tender, fingers, that adorned a plump fore arm, tattooed]; meaning, biOaToraAfi binaAnK TafolK. (Ṣ, O.)

Also [Fullers' earth, which is used for scouring cloths, and is sometimes used in the bath, instead of soap;] a certain yellow [or rather yellowish, and sometimes white, or whitish,] earth, well known in Egypt, with which cloths are dyed [or rather scoured]; (TA;) also called bayoluwnN. (Esh-Shiháb El-'Ajamee, TA in art. bln.)

TifolN A young one, or youngling, or the young, (Mṣb, Ḳ,*) of anything, (Ḳ,) [or] of a human being and of a beast: (Mṣb:) or (Ḳ) a new-born child, or young infant: and also a young one, or the young, of any wild animal: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or it is applied to a child until he discriminates; (Mṣb, TA;) after which he is called SabiI-; thus some say, (Mṣb,) [and] thus says El-Munáwee: (TA:) or, accord. to Az, (Mṣb, TA,) on the authority of AHeyth, (TA,) a child from the time of his birth (Mgh, TA) until he attains to puberty: (Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) fem. TifolapN: (Zj, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) and pl. OaTofaAlN: (Zj, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA:) but TifolN is also used as fem., (Zj, Mgh, O, Mṣb, TA,) and dual, (Zj, TA,) and pl., (Zj, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA,) occurring as pl. in the Ḳur xxiv. 31, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) and [xxii. 5 and] xl. 69: (Zj, TA:) and TifoyalN↓ signifies the same as TifolN; (Ḳ, TA;) used in this sense by a rájiz; but accord. to some, by poetic license, for the dim. TufayolN↓. (TA.)
[Hence,] † Any part or portion of anything, whether a substance or an accident: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. OaTofaAlN: whence they say Tifolu Alham-i and AlHub-i † [The portion of anxiety and of love]. (TA.)

‡ A falling spark or portion (siqoT [in the CK saqaT]) of fire: (M, Ḳ, TA:) or a live coal: (A, TA:) or fire when just struck; as also TifolapN: (T, TA: [but this latter is the n. un.:]) and the pl. is OaTofaAlN: one says, taTaAyarato OaTofaAlu Aln-aAri, meaning ‡ The sparks of the fire [became scattered]. (TA.)
† Small clouds: so in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb. (TA.)
‡ An object of want: (Ḳ:) or a small object of want. (TA.) One says, huwa yasoEaI fiI OaTofaAli AlHawaAYiji i. e. [‡ He labours in the accomplishment of] small objects of want. (A, TA.)
‡ Night: (Ḳ, TA:) or the first part thereof. (A, TA.)
And † The sun when near to the setting. (ISd, Ḳ, TA.)
TafalN: see Tufuwliy-apN.

Also The period [next] after sunrise: from TifolN signifying “a young one” or “youngling:” (O:) or Tafalu AlgadaApi signifies the period from that when the sun is about to rise, or appear, until its light has ascendancy over the earth: (T, TA:) or when the sun is about to rise, or appear, and has not yet ascendancy in, or upon, the earth: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the period from the rising, or appearing, of the sun, until its having ascendancy [for UilaI QsotikomaAlihaA in a copy of the M, and AstkmAnhA and AstknAnhA in different copies of the Ḳ, I read AlI QsotimokaAnihaA, agreeably with the explanation in the the T and with that of Er-Rághib, in both of which the verb used is yasotamokin,] in, or upon, the earth. (M, Ḳ.) And (O) The period after [that called] the EaSor [q. v.] when the sun inclines to the setting: (Ṣ, O:) or Tafalu AlEaXiI-i signifies the last part of the afternoon, at sunset, (Ḳ, TA,) and at the time of the sun's becoming yellow, when it is about to set. (TA.) One says, Oatayotuhu TafalFA [I came to him at one of the periods termed Tafal]. (Ṣ, O.)
Also The coming of the night with its darkness. (TA.)
And The darkness itself. (O, Ḳ.)

Also Rain: so in the phrase Tafalu Alv-uray-aA [The rain of the auroral setting of the Pleiades]. (Ṣ, O.) [Or A shower of rain: for] one says, waqaEato OaTofaAlu AlwasomiI-i The showers of the [rain called] wsmI- [q. v.] fell: and jaAdahu TafalN mino maTarK [A shower of rain descended copiously upon him, or it]. (A, TA.)
And riyHN TafalN A wind that blows gently, or softly. (TA.)

entry.sense: TafilN Herbage that does not become tall (TA.)
TufaAlN and TafaAlN Dry clay: (Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

TafiylN, like OamiyrN, (Ḳ,) or, accord. to the L, TifoYilN↓, mentioned in the L in art. TfOl, (TA,) Turbid water remaining in a watering-trough: (Ḳ, TA:) n. un. with p {TafiylapN}; (Ḳ;) accord. to the L, TifoYilapN; meaning a portion thereof. (TA.)
TifoYilN: see TafiylN.
TifoyalN: see TifolN.
TafaAlapN: see what next follows.
TufuwlapN: see what next follows.

Tufuwliy-apN, mentioned by ISd and the expositors of the Fṣ and others, as well as in the Ḳ, and also pronounced without teshdeed, [i. e. TufuwliyapN,] which shows, as do several other reasons, that the I therein is not that which is the characteristic of rel. ns., though it has been asserted to be so, (MF, TA,) The state, or condition, of the Tifol; [i. e. early infancy: or, in a larger sense, childhood;] as also TufuwlapN↓ and TafaAlapN↓ and TafalN↓; (Ḳ;) [inf. ns.] having no verb [corresponding to them]. (TA.)

TufayoliI-N One who intrudes at feasts, uninvited; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also TifoliylN↓: (Ḳ:) the former is a rel. n. from TufayolN, the name of a certain man of El-Koofeh, (ISk, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) who used to intrude at feasts, uninvited, (ISk, Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) and who was called Tufayolu AlOaEoraAsi and Tufayolu AlEaraAYisi: (ISk, Ṣ, O: [two other derivations are mentioned in the TA; but they are too far-fetched to deserve notice:]) such the Arabs [in their proper language] called waAriXN. (ISk, Ṣ, O, Mṣb.)
Taf-aAlN One who sells Tafol [or fullers' earth]. (TA.)
TifoliylN: see TufayoliI-N.

[TaAfilapN, which Golius explains as meaning “i. q. faAyidapN et xayorN, utilitas, bonum,” referring to the KL as his authority, is evidently a mistake for TaAYilN, expl. as meaning faAYidapN and xayorN in my copy of the KL, which does not mention TaAfilapN in any sense.]

OaTofalu [More, or most, like to the TufayoliI-: and hence, more, and most, intrusive, uninvited]. OaTofalu mino layolK EalaI nahaArK [More intrusive, uninvited, than night upon day], and mino XayobK EalaI XabaAbK [than hoariness upon youthfulness], and mino cubaAbK [than flies], are proverbs. (Meyd.)

muTofilN, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and muTofilapN also, (TA,) applied to a female, of human beings and of wild animals, (Ḳ, TA,) and of camels, (AʼObeyd, TA,) i. q. caAtu TifolK [Having a young one, or youngling,, &c.], (AʼObeyd, Ḳ, TA,) with her: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or applied to a she-gazelle and camel, (Ṣ, O,) or to any female, (Mṣb,) that has recently brought forth: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:*) pl. maTaAfilu and maTaAfiylu. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) [See also EaAYicN, in art. Ewc.] saArato qurayoXN biAlEuwci AlmaTaAfiyli i. e. Kureysh journeyed with the camels that had recently brought forth having with them their young ones, occurring in a trad., means, † with their collective company, their old and their young. (TA.) [See, again, EaAYicN.]
[It is also said by Freytag to be applied in the Deewán of the Hudhalees to clouds followed by small ones.]
And layolapN muTofilN means A night that kills the young ones by its cold. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. TafaA fawoqa AlmaMCi, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaTofuw, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. Tufuw-N (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TafowN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It (a thing, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) floated upon the water, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and did not sink. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
[Hence,] one says, AlZ-uEunu taTofuw watarosubu fiI Als-araAbi † [The women's camel-vehicles appear, as though floating, and disappear, as though sinking, in the mirage]. (TA.)
And Tafati AlxuwSapu fawoqa AlX-ajari ‡ [The leaf of the date-palm, or of the Theban palm,, &c.,] appeared [above the trees]. (Ḳ, TA.)
And TafaA said of a bull, (Ḳ,) or of a wild bull, (TA,) ‡ He mounted upon the hills (Ḳ, TA) and upon the sands. (TA. [In the CK, ElI AlAakami is erroneously put for EalaA AlOakama.])

And Tafawotu fawoqahu † I leaped upon it. (TA.) The saying
EabodN UicaA maA rasaba Alqawomu TafaA
is expl. by IAạr as meaning [A slave] who, when the people are grave, leaps by reason of his ignorance. (TA.)
And TafaA AlmaMCu [not a mistranscription for TagaA] † The water rose, or became high. (TA voce TuwfaAnN, q. v.)

And TafaA said of a gazelle, † He ran vehemently. (Ḳ.) One says of a gazelle, mar-a yaTofuw, meaning ‡ He passed by, or along, or away, going lightly, or briskly, upon the ground, and running vehemently. (Ṣ, TA.)
And, said of a man, (Ḳ, TA,) by way of comparison [to a floating fish], (TA,) ‡ He died. (Ḳ, TA.)

And † He (i. e. a man) entered into [or upon] an affair: (Ḳ, TA:) [or,] accord. to the “Nawádir,” one says, TafaA fiI AlOaroDi he entered into the earth, either waAgilFA [app. as meaning penetrating, and becoming concealed], or raAsixFA [app. as meaning becoming firmly fixed therein]. (TA.)
[TafaA is made trans. by means of bi: see an ex. voce Oarosaba.]

entry.sense: 4. ATfI He kept continually, or constantly, to the eating of fish found floating upon the water. (TA.)
TufoIN: see TufoyapN.
TafowapN, (Ḳ,) thus it should app. be accord. to the Ḳ, but in copies of the M, TufowapN↓, with damm, (TA,) A thin, or slender, plant. (Ḳ.)
TufowapN: see what next precedes:
and see also the paragraph next following.

TufoyapN The leaf of the muqol [or Theban palm]; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so TufowapN↓: (Aṣ, TA:) pl. TufoIN↓ (Ṣ,* TA) or [rather this is a coll. gen. n., and the pl. properly so termed is] TufFI, (Mṣb,) which is [also] pl. of TufowapN. (Aṣ, TA.) [Accord. to Forskål (Flora Ægypt. Arab., p. cxxvi.), the Theban palm itself, which he terms “borassus flabelliformis,” is called TfI, as well as dwm.]

And [hence] AlT-ufoyapu, (Ḳ,) or cuw AlT-ufoyatayoni, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) is the name of † A serpent (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of a foul, or malignant, sort, (Ḳ,) having upon its back two lines, or stripes, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which are black, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) resembling two leaves such as are termed TufoyataAni: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and sometimes it is termed TufoyapN, meaning caAtu TufoyapK: and AlT-ufaI is used as the pl., meaning cawaAtu AlT-ufaI. (Ṣ.)
TufaAwapN The floating froth or scum (Ḳ, TA) and grease (TA) of the cooking-pot. (Ḳ, TA.)
And A halo around the sun, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and also around the moon [like haAlapN]: (Ḳ:) the former accord. to Fr, and the latter accord. to AḤát. (TA.)
And one says, OaSabonaA TufaAwapF mina Alr-abiyEi meaning XayoYFA minohu [i. e. We obtained somewhat of the herbage, or perhaps of the rain, of the season called rabiyE]. (Ṣ, TA.)
samakN TaAfK Fish floating upon the surface of the water, having died therein. (Mgh, Mṣb, TA.)
[Hence,] farasN TaAfK † A horse elevating his head. (TA.)
kaOan-a Eayonahu EinabapN TaAfiyapN [As though his eye were a floating grape], in a trad. respecting Ed-Dejjál, is expl. by Th as meaning his eye's being prominent and conspicuous. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. TaqoTaqa [He caused a thing to make a sound such as is termed TaqoTaqapN]. (Ḳ voce karaba.)

Taqo a word imitative of a sound; and sometimes they said TaqoTaqapN↓: (IDrd, O, TA:) or the former is a word imitative of The sound of stones; and ↓the latter is its noun: (Ḳ:) one says, samiEotu TaqoTaqapa↓ AlHijaArapi I heard [the sound of] the falling of the stones, one upon another, when they rolled down from a mountain: (IDrd, O:) or Taqo is a word imitative of the sound of the stone and of the solid hoof; and TaqoTaqapN↓ signifies the action thereof: (M, TA:) or this latter is a word imitative of the sound of the successive falling of stones, one upon another: (IDrd, O:) or this word signifies the sound of the legs of horses upon the hard ground; (IAạr, TA;) [or] sometimes it signifies also the sound of the solid hoofs upon the ground; (IDrd, O;) or the sounds of the hoofs of horses or similar beasts [with quick reiteration]; like daqodaqapN; and sometimes they said HabaTiqoTiqo↓, of which El-Mázinee cites an ex.; (Ṣ, O;) but [J says] I have not seen this except in his book: (Ṣ:) another ex. of it, however, is cited by Lth. (TA.)
Tiqo The sound of a frog leaping from the margin of a river or rivulet. (M, Ḳ.) One says, laA yusaAwiI Tiqo [It is not, or will not be, equal to the sound of a frog, &c.]. (M.)
TaqoTaqapN: see Taqo, in four places.
In the language of the common people, it means Lightness, or promptness, in speech. (TA.)
And † The death that results from the jinn's piercing or thrusting [i. e. from the TaAEuwn]. (TA.)
TuqoTuwqN and muTaqoTiqN↓ in the language of the common people, Light in person; and light, or prompt, in speech. (TA.)
muTaqoTiqN: see what next precedes.
HabaTiqoTiqo: see Taqo.

hom.sense:
1. Tal-ati Als-amaMCu AlOaroDa, [aor. _u {yaTolulu},] inf. n. Tal-N, The sky rained small rain upon the earth, or land. (MA.) And Tul-ati AlOaroDu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) [meaning, as is implied in the Ṣ and O, The earth, or land, was rained upon by the weakest of rain; or was rained upon, or bedewed, by the Tal-, q. v.; or] the Tal- descended upon the earth, or land: (Ḳ:) and Tal-ahaA Aln-adaI [The rain, or dew, moistened it]: (Ṣ, O, TA:) and Tal-at, with fet-ḥ, signifies [accord. to some] It became moist, or moistened:
one says, Tul-ato bilaAduka, and Tal-ato; the former meaning May thy countries, or tracts of country, be rained upon; and the latter, become moist, or moistened: or, accord. to Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, [i. e. Zj,] Tul-ato only, with damm; [and he adds,] one says, raHubato bilaAduka waTul-ato, with damm, [i. e. May thy tracts of country be spacious to thee, and be moistened by the Tal-, (or, as in art. rHb in the TA, OaroHabato Ealayoka waTul-ato)], not Tal-ato; because the Tal- is not from them, [i. e. it is not from the tracts of country,] but they are the objects thereof. (TA.) [Golius mentions, among the significations of Tal-a, as on the authority of Z, i. q. rHb, said of land, or the earth, and followed by ElI relating to a person: but I think it most probable that he inferred this signification from his finding, in a copy of the A, the phrase raHubato Ealayoka AlOaroSu waTal-ato (for waTul-ato), without any explanation. And Freytag mentions OuTil-a↓ as meaning It was watered by fine rain; from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.] And [it is said that] Tal-ati Als-amaMCu signifies AiXotad-a waqoEuhaA [i. e. The rain fell vehemently]. (TA.)

Tal-a damahu, (AZ, Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) said of God, (Ṣ,) or of the ruling power, (Mṣb,) first pers. Talalotuhu, (Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yaTolulu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. Tal-N (Mṣb, Ḳ) and TuluwlN, (Ḳ,) He made his blood to go for nought, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct; made it to be of no account: (AZ, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) or held it to be of little account, as though it were but [the rain, or dew, termed] Tal-, in its result; this, accord. to Er-Rághib, being the proper meaning: (TA:) and ATl-hu↓ signifies the same. (AZ, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And Tul-a damuhu His blood was made to go for nought,, &c.; (AZ, Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also OuTil-a↓ damuhu: (AZ, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and Tal-a damuhu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with fet-ḥ, accord. to Ks and AO, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaTolulu} [contr. to analogy], (Mṣb,) or _i [agreeably with analogy]; (Ḳ;) and Tal-a, originally Talila, (Mṣb, Ḳ,*) aor. _a {yaTolalu}; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) [his blood went for nought,, &c.;] but this is disallowed by AZ; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) and it is more commonly with damm. (Ḳ.)

And Tal-ahu Haq-ahu, aor. _u {yaTolulu}, He diminished, or impaired, to him his right, or due; or deprived, or defrauded him of it, partly, or wholly: (Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, (TA,) he denied him, or refused him, his right, or due; (Ḳ, TA;) and withheld it [from him]: (TA:) and he annulled it; or made it to go for nought, as a thing of no account, or as a thing that had perished or become lost. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, Tal-uwA fulaAnFA Haq-ahu, aor. _u {yaTolulu}, inf. n. Tal-N, They denied, or refused, such a one his right, or due: so says Khálid Ibn-Jembeh. (O.)
And Tal-a gariymahu, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaTolulu}, (TA,) inf. n. Tal-N, (O, Ḳ,) He delayed, or deferred, with his creditor, or put him off, by promising time after time to pay him. (O,* Ḳ.)
And Tal-N signifies also The driving of camels roughly, or rigorously. (Ḳ.) You say, Tal-a AlUibila, inf. n. Tal-N, He drove the camels roughly, or rigorously! (TḲ.)

Tal-a, [sec. pers. Talilota, aor. _a {yaTolalu},] inf. n. TalaAlapN; like mal-a, [sec. pers. malilota, aor. _a {yaTolalu},] (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. malaAlapN; (TA;) [accord. to Freytag, followed by lahu, and in the Deewán of the Hudhalees by Uilayohi; and so, accord. to him, AstTl-↓, followed by lahu;] He, or it, was, or became, pleasing, (Ḳ, TA,) and goodly. (TA.)
And Tal-ahu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. Tal-N, (TA,) is also syn. with TalaAhu: (Ḳ:) so in the phrase Tal-ahu biAlwarosi [He smeared it, or rubbed it over, with wrs, q. v.]; namely, a thing. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)
4: see 1, former half:
and the same {1}, latter half, in two places.

ATl- Ealayohi He (a man, Mṣb) looked upon it, looked upon it from above, looked down upon it, got a view of it, or saw it; syn. OaXorafa, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) [i. e.] OaXorafa Ealayohi, (Mṣb,) or OawofaI Elyh; (Ḥam p. 208;) properly OawofaI Ealayohi biTalalihi, i. e. biXaxoSihi [meaning he looked upon it,, &c., with his body; not in imagination]; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and AstTl-↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ:) and so OaTaf-a Elyh. (O in art. Tf.) [See also 6.] Hence, in a trad., the saying of Safeeyeh the daughter of ʼAbd-El-Muttalib, faOaTal-a EalayonaA yahuwdiI-N faqumotu faDarabotu raOosahu biAls-ayofi vum-a ramayotu bihi Ealayohimo [And a Jew looked upon us, and I arose, and smote off his head with the sword, then cast it upon them]. (O.)
[Hence, perhaps,] ATl- Alz-amaAnu † The time drew near. (Mṣb.)
And ATl- EalaI Haq-iI facahaba bihi † He got possession of my right, or due, and took it away, or went away with it. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.) [See also OaTaf-a.]

And ATl- Ealayohi ‡ He importuned him, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA,) Hat-aI galabahu [so that, or until, he overcame him]. (TA.) And ATl- fulaAnN EalaI fulaAnK biAlOacaI † Such a one kept continually, or constantly, to the annoying, or molesting, or hurting, of such a one. (TA.)
An Arab woman of the desert is related to have said, maA OaTal-a XiEora jamiylK waOaHolaAhu [How pleasing is the poetry of Jemeel, and how sweet is it!]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. hecihi AlOaroDu qado taTal-alato This land has produced herbage, and become replete, [for taxay-arato (to which I cannot assign any apposite meaning), in my original, I read taHay-arato,] and has not been trodden by any one: so says AA. (O.)

6. taTaAl-a (Ṣ, O, in the Ḳ in art. Twl written taTaAlala,) UilaI AlX-aIoCi (O) He stretched out his neck, looking at the thing, it being far from him: (Ṣ, O:) or he stretched out his neck to look: (TA in art. dmx:) or taTaAlalotu signifies I stood upon my toes, and stretched my stature, to look at a thing, (taTaAwalotu, Ḳ, TA, both of these verbs meaning thus, TA in art. Twl,) and looked: (Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to AA, Alt-aTaAl-u signifies the looking from above a place, or from a curtain or the like. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. Xrf, conj. 10: and see also 4 in the present art.]

hom.sense: AstTl- Alfarasu bicanabihi is expl. by Ibn-ʼAbbád as signifying mar-amuTil-FA bihi UicaA naASabahu fiI Als-amaMCi [app. meaning The horse went along raising his tail toward the sky: for I think that UicaA naASabahu should be UicaA kaAna naASibahu or OaIo naASibahu]. (O.)
See also 1, last sentence but one.

entry.sense: R. Q. 1. TaloTalahu He moved him, agitated him, shook him, or put him into a state of motion or commotion; (Ḳ, TA;) like talotalahu: (TA:) [or,] accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, AlT-aloTalapu signifies the moving about the arms in walking. (O.)

hom.sense: Tal-N Light, (Mṣb,) or weak, (Ḳ,) [i. e. drizzling,] rain: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the lightest, (Ḳ,) or weakest, of rain: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or dew (nadFI, Ḳ, TA) that descends from the sky in cloudless weather: (TA:) or above nadFI and less than maTarN: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, rain that has little effect; and so in the Ḳur ii. 267: (TA:) pl. TilaAlN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and TilalN, (O, Ḳ,) the latter mentioned by Fr, and said by him to be the only instance of the kind that has been heard except HirafN pl. of HarofN as meaning the Harof of a mountain; (O;) [or] TalalN is a contraction of TilaAlN: in a saying of a poet, cited by IAạr, (TA,) AlT-alal↓ occurs for AlT-al- [in the CK AlT-ul-]: or in this instance, as some relate it, the word is AlT-ilal. (Ḳ, TA.)

And Milk: (Ḳ:) or so Tul-N↓, with damm, in the saying maA biAln-aAqapi Tul-N [There is not in the she-camel any milk], as Yaạḳoob says, and as is related on the authority of AA, (Ṣ,) and thus in the saying maA biAld-aAri Tul-N [There is not in the house any milk]: (O:) or Tul-N signifies thus: or blood. (Ḳ. [But see this word below.])
And Paucity of milk of a camel; as also Tul-N↓. (Ḳ.)

And Fat, or fatness; syn. TiroqN [in the CK TaraqN, and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ TuroqN]: thus in the saying maA biAln-aAqapi Tal-N [There is not in the she-camel any fat, or fatness]. (M, Ḳ, TA: in the CK Tul-N.)

[It is also used as an epithet.] You say yawomN Tal-N, meaning cuw Tal-K, i. e. [A day having drizzling rain, or dew; or] moist, or humid. (TA.) And OaroDN Tal-apN Land moistened by dew [or by drizzling rain]; (TA;) as also maToluwlapN↓: (Ṣ, TA:) and [in like manner] Tal-apN signifies a meadow (rawoDapN) moistened by Tal-. (Ḳ.) And Tal-N signifies Anything moist. (TA.)

[Hence, app.,] Goodly, or good, or beautiful, and pleasing: thus applied to a night, and to poetry (XiEor [in the CK XaEar]), and to water, &c.: (Ḳ, TA:) applied to these as meaning good, or beautiful; and so to discourse; (TA;) and thus TaliylapN↓ applied to a xuTobap. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA.) And AimoraOapN Tal-apN means A beautiful, elegant, or graceful, woman. (TA,) And xamorN Tal-apN Pleasant, or delicious, wine: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:*) or, as some say, such as descends easily [or pleasantly down the throat]. (TA.)
And Tal-apN applied to an odour (raAYiHapN, Ḳ, TA, or ray-aA, TA) likewise signifies Pleasant, or delicious. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also An aged man: (Kr, Ḳ:) and Tal-apN signifies an old woman: (Ḳ, TA:) and a woman foul, unseemly, or obscene, in tongue; (Ḳ,* TA;) annoying, or molesting. (TA.)
And A serpent; (Ḳ;) thus accord. to IAạr: (O:) and so Til-N↓; (Ḳ;) thus accord. to AA; (O;) like TiloEN. (TA in art. TlE.)

entry.sense: Tul-N: see Tal-N, in two places. [But the signification of “blood” there mentioned requires consideration; for Ṣgh adds immediately after explaining the saying maA biAld-aAri Tul-N what here follows.]

cahaba damuhu Tul-FA and Til-FA↓ means hadarFA [i. e. His blood went for nought, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O. [Then follows immediately in the O AlT-ul-aMCu, expl. as below.])

hom.sense: Til-N: see Tal-N, last sentence:
and see also Tul-N.
Tal-apN [fem. of Tal-N, q. v.]
[And also used as a subst.: signifying] A wife. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And Daintiness, or delicacy, in food and clothing. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, Aln-iEomapu is erroneously put for Aln-aEomapu.])
Tul-apN The neck. (Ḳ.)
And A draught of milk; (Az, Ḳ, TA;) as also Tul-aI↓: (Az, TA:) pl. of the former TulalN. (Ḳ.)

TalalN A portion still standing of the remains of a dwelling or house; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) as also TalaAlapN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. OaTolaAlN and TuluwlN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter pl. sometimes used: (Mṣb:) what cleaves to the ground is termed rasomN: (TA:) the people of the towns or villages apply the term OaTolaAlN to the remains of walls and of places of worship; and the people of the tents to [the remains of] places of eating and of drinking and of sleeping: (Ḥam p. 541:) [and] as pl. of TalalN it signifies elevated places: one says, raOayotu Talala Alqaroyapi, meaning I saw what was elevated of the land of the town, or village. (Ḥar p. 139.)

And The XaxoS [or body, or bodily or corporeal form or figure or substance, such as one sees from a distance,] of a thing, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) whatever it be; as also TalaAlapN↓: pl. of the former as above: (Ḳ:) the XaxoS [as meaning body, or person,] of a man; as also TalaAlapN↓: (Ṣ, O:) or, of a man, the erect XaxoS. (Mṣb voce juv-apN.) And ZalaAlapN, with Z, signifies the same. (O and Ḳ in art. Zl.) One says, Hay-aA Qll-ehu Talalaka and TalaAlataka↓, meaning [May God preserve, or save,] thy XaxoS [i. e. body, or person]. (Ṣ, O.) And Hay-aA Qll-ehu Talalaka and OaTolaAlaka, meaning maA XaxaSa mino jasadika [i. e. May God preserve, or save, what has risen into view of thy body, or person]. (TA.)

Also A place in the SaHon [or court] of a house, prepared for the household to sit upon: ADk says that there was a place on which to eat and drink in the finaMC [or yard] of every house, called the Talal: (Az, TA:) accord. to ISd, (TA,) the Talal of a house is, or was, like the [kind of wide bench, of stone or brick, &c., generally built against a wall, called] duk-aAnap [or duk-aAn], upon which to sit. (Ḳ, TA.)

And The jilaAl [or deck] of a ship or boat; (M, Mgh, O, Ḳ;) i. e. (Mgh) the covering thereof, which is like the roof (Mgh, Mṣb) of a house or chamber: (Mgh:) pl. OaTolaAlN. (Mgh, Mṣb, TA.) [In the TA it is said to mean the XiraAE of a ship or boat; which is a mistake, as is sufficiently shown by its being there immediately added, “hence the trad. of Aboo-Bekr, that he used to pray upon the ATlAl of the ship or boat.”]

[Hence, app.,] one says, (of a man, Ibn-ʼAbbád, O,) maXaI EalaI Talali AlmaMCi i. e. ElI Zahorihi, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,) which, Z says, means ElI wajohihi [i. e. ‡ He walked, or went along, upon the surface of the water: but whether this relates to a pretended miracle or to sliding upon ice, I know not]: and he adds that it is a tropical phrase. (TA.)
Also Anything fresh, or juicy, or [like Tal-N] moist; syn. TariI-N. (Ḳ.)
See also Tal-N, first sentence.
TaliylN: see maToluwlN.

Also Sweet; syn. HulowN: (so accord. to the O and some copies of the Ḳ: accord. to other copies of the Ḳ, i. q. xilq; i. e., accord. to some of these copies, xaloqN; accord. to some, xalaqN; and accord. to some, xaliqN:) thus expl. by Ibn-ʼAbbád; and said by him to be of the dial. of Hudheyl. (O.) [The explanation in the O is, I doubt not, the right: and hence]
TaliylapN applied to a xuTobap: see Tal-N, latter part.

Also A mat; syn. HaSiyrN: (IAạr, O, Ḳ:) or such as is woven of [the leaves of the] dawom [or Theban palm-tree]; or of the leaves of the date-palm; or of the quXuwr [app. meaning the peels of the branches] thereof: (Ḳ, TA:) so in the M: in the T it is said that TaliylapN↓ means, accord. to AA, a [mat of the kind called] buwriyaMC; and accord. to Aṣ, a baAriI- [which signifies the same as bwryM]: (TA:) pl. OaTil-apN and Til-apN and TululN. (Ḳ.)

TalaAlapN [an inf. n.: see 1, last sentence but one. And, as a simple subst.,] A good, or goodly, state or condition; and a beautiful aspect, appearance, mien, or guise. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.) And Beauty, or beauty of colour, or brightness: (O, Ḳ:) so in the saying, EalaI manoTiqihi TalaAlapu AlHusoni [Upon his diction is the glow of beauty]. (O.) Accord. to Aṣ, i. q. HusonN and maMCN [i. e. Goodliness, or beauty, and, app., lustre]. (TA.)
Also, (AA, O, Ḳ,) and some say TulaAlapN↓, (AA, O,) Joy, gladness, or happiness. (AA, O, Ḳ.)
See also TalalN, in four places.
[Hence,] one says farasN Hasanu AlT-alaAlapi, meaning [A horse goodly, or beautiful,] in what is high, or elevated, of his frame, or make. (TA.)

entry.sense: TulaAlapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
TaliylapN: see TaliylN.
Tul-aI: see Tul-apN.

Tul-aMCN, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,) like sul-aMCN, (Ḳ, TA,) [in the CK, Tal-AC, like sal-AC, and] in some copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, Til-aMC, (TA,) Blood, itself: and some say, a pellicle upon the surface thereof: (O:) [and in like manner Tul-aMC is expl. in the Ḳ in art. TlO:] or blood that has been made to go for nought, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct: (Ḳ: [and from the context in the O, it seems that this is probably meant by Ibn-ʼAbbád: see Tul-N:]) accord. to AAF, (TA,) the C in this word is originally l. (Ḳ, TA.)
TuloTulN A chronic, or permanent, disease. (IAạr, Az, Ḳ.)
TulaTilN: see TulaATilapN.
TulaTilapN: see TulaATilapN: each in two places.
TalaATilu: see TulaATilapN: each in two places.
TulaATilN: see the next paragraph, in three places.
TulaATilapN A calamity, or misfortune; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also TulaTilapN↓ [in the CK TaloTalap] and TulaTilN↓ [in the CK TaloTal]. (Ḳ, TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, O,) or TulaATilN↓, (M, Ḳ,) A disease that wearies the physicians, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) for which there is no remedy: (Ṣ, O:) and said in the M to be a pain in the back. (TA.) And the former, A disease that attacks a man in his belly; as also TulaTilapN↓. (O.) And A disease in the backs of asses, that breaks their backs; (Ḳ,* TA;) so in the M; (TA;) as also TilATl with damm and fet-ḥ [i. e. TulaATilN↓ and TalaATilu↓]. (Ḳ.)

And A certain piece of flesh in the fauces: (ISd, Ḳ, TA:) or the piece of flesh extending downwards upon [the upper extremity of] the musotaraT [or masoraT, i. e. the gullet]; (Aṣ, Az, O, Ḳ,* TA;) [meaning] the lahaAp [or uvula]: (TA:) or, (O, Ḳ,) accord. to AHeyth, (O,) the falling of the lahaAp [or uvula], so that neither food nor beverage passes the fauces easily by reason of it. (O, Ḳ.)

OaTolaAlu is the name of a certain mare, (O, Ḳ,) or of a she-camel, (Ḳ,) which, in reply to her rider's commanding her to leap a river, on the day of El-Kádiseeyeh, is asserted to have spoken, saying, wavobN wasuwrapi Albaqarapi [A leap, by the Chapter of the Cow!]. (O, Ḳ.) [Freytag has erroneously said, as on the authority of the Ḳ, that it is a name of the chapter of the Ḳur-án otherwise called bqrp.]
muTal-N: see maToluwlN.

OamorN muTil-N An affair not settled, or not established. (So accord. to some copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ, expl. by the words layosa bimusotaqir-K: in other copies of both, and in the O, lys bimusofirK [to which I am unable to assign any probable meaning].)
muTal-ilN i. q. DabaAbN [Mist; or moisture like clouds, or like dust, covering the earth in the early mornings; or thin clouds, like smoke;, &c.: see art. Db]. (TA.)
maToluwlN: see its fem., with p {maToluwlapN}, voce Tal-N.
Also Blood made to go for nought, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and so TaliylN↓ and muTal-N↓. (Ḳ.)

Also [or labanN maToluwlN] Pure milk with froth upon it, upon which water has been poured, and which one imagines to be good, or pleasant, whereas there is no goodness in it; and so maToluwlapN↓: or this latter, some say, signifies a piece of skin soaked and softened [for mawozuwnapN in my original, which I think a mistranscription, I read mawoduwnapN,] with pure milk, which they eat [app. in a time of scarcity].
maToluwlapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. Talabahu, (Ṣ, A, O, &c.,) aor. _u {yaTolubu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. TalabN (Ṣ, A, MA, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and maTolabN (A, MA, Mṣb) and TilaAbN and TilaAbapN (A, MA) and TalibapN (MA) and taTolaAbN [which is of a measure denoting intensiveness]; (TA;) and AiT-alabahu↓; (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and tTl-bhu↓; (A, Ḳ;) [but see this last below;] He sought it, desired it, demanded it, or asked for it; (MA;) [he pursued it, pursued after it, or prosecuted it;] he sought, desired, or endeavoured, to find it and to get or take it: (A, Ḳ, TA:) and Talaba is also expl. as signifying AtbE [i. e. OatobaEa he followed in pursuit,, &c.]. (TA.) One says, AuTolubo liI XayoYFA Seek thou,, &c., for me, a thing. (Lḥ, TA.) And Talabahu minohu and Uilayohi, inf. n. as above, He sought it, desired it, demanded it, or asked for it, of him. (MA.) And Talaba UilaI-a means ragiba [i. e. He petitioned me, or made petition to me,, &c.]: (Ḳ, TA:) or Talaba Uilayohi means saOalahu [he asked him]: or [it means] Talabahu raAgibFA Uilayohi [he sought him, petitioning him]; for it is generally held that Talaba is not trans. by means of a prep., therefore they explain the like of this phrase as implicative. (MF, TA.) See also 4, in two places: and see 5. You say also, Talabahu biHaq-K, meaning TaAlabahu, q. v. (Ḳ.) And Talaba bivaOorihi and bicaHolihi [He sought to obtain his blood-revenge, or retaliation; and in like manner, Talaba bidamihi]. (Ṣ and Mṣb in art. cHl.)
[Hence,] one says also, Als-iraAju yaTolubu Oano yanoTafiYa ‡ [The lamp, or lighted wick, is near, or about, to become extinguished]; like as one says, jidaArN yuriydu Oano yanoqaD-a. (A.)
Taliba, aor. _a {yaTolabu}, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. TalabN, (TḲ,) He, or it, [accord. to the TḲ said of a man,] was, or became, distant, or remote. (O, Ḳ. [See also 4.])

entry.sense: 2: see 5.

3. TAlbhu, inf. n. muTaAlabapN and TilaAbN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He sought or demanded of him a thing [as being due to him; i. e. he sued or prosecuted him for it]; (Mṣb;) i. q. Talabahu↓ biHaq-K [he sought or demanded of him,, &c., a right, or due]: (Ḳ:) and you say, TAlbhu biHaq-K lahu Ealayohi [he sought or demanded of him,, &c., a thing due to him on his part]. (A.) muTaAlabapN is used in relation to a real thing: [but it does not necessarily imply the justice of the act:] one says, TAlb zayodN EamorFA biAld-araAhimi [Zeyd sought or demanded of ʼAmr, or sued or prosecuted him for, the money]. (Kull p. 349.) And TAlbhu biAld-ayoni He sought or demanded of him [&c.] the debt. (MA.) And TAlbhu bikacaA, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. muTaAlabapN, (Ṣ,) [He sought or demanded of him,, &c., such a thing; or he prosecuted him for such a thing, as, for instance, blood, or mutilation, or a wound: see exs. voce xabolN.]

4. ATlbhu He performed, or accomplished, for him, (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, TA,) that which he sought, or demanded, (Ṣ, A,* O, Mṣb,) or the object of his want: (TA:) or he gave him that which he sought, or demanded. (Ḳ.) A man said to the Prophet, AuTolubo↓ UilaI-a TalibapF faUin-iI OuHib-u Oano OuTolibakahaA i. e. [Ask thou of me] an object of want, [for I love] to perform it, or accomplish it, for thee. (TA.) And one says, Talaba↓ UilaI-a faOaTolabotuhu i. e. [He asked of me a thing] and I performed, or accomplished, for him that which he sought, or demanded. (TA.) And ATlbhu AlX-aIoCa He aided him, or helped him, to seek the thing. (TA.) And OaToliboniI Aid thou me to seek. (Lḥ, TA.)
Also He, or it, (said of a man, Mṣb, and of poverty, A,) necessitated his seeking, or demanding. (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Thus it has two contr. significations. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

And hence, (Ṣ, O,) OaTolaba said of water, and of pasture, or herbage, (Ṣ, A, O,), &c., (Ṣ, O,) It was distant, or remote, (Ṣ, A, O,) so as to be not attainable but by seeking, (Ṣ, O,) or so that it was sought. (A.)

5. tTl-bhu He sought it, or demanded it, repeatedly, or time after time: (Ṣ, O:) [he made repeated, or successive, endeavours to obtain it, or to attain it: he prosecuted a search after it:] or he sought it diligently, studiously, sedulously, or earnestly; syn. AibotagaAhu: (Mṣb:) or he sought, desired, or endeavoured, leisurely, to find it and to get or take it; (O, TA;) and (TA) so Tl-bhu↓, inf. n. taToliybN; (Ḳ, TA;) and Talabahu↓; (TA;) from [various] places. (O, TA.)
See also 1, first sentence.

7. AnTlb lahu is quasi-pass. of Talabahu, and means It (an action [&c.]) was, or became, suitable to him; or fit, meet, or proper, for him: [as though it were sought, or desired, or desirable:] but they have been content to use AinobagaI in the place of this verb. (Zj, TA in art. bgI. [yanobagiI, in the Ḳur xix. 93, is expl. by yanoTalibu in the Ksh and in the Expos. of Bḍ.])
8: see 1, first sentence.
TilobN: see TalibapN, in two places:
and TaAlib.
TalabN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, A, &c.)
See also TaAlibN, in two places.
And see TalibapN.
TulobapN A far-extending journey: (O, Ḳ:) and so safarN TaluwbN↓. (A.)
TilobapN [A mode, or manner, of seeking, &c.: an inf. n. of modality, like jilosapN, &c.]
[And] a subst from TaAlabahu: (Ḳ:) see TalibapN, in three places.
Oum-u Tilobapa The eagle. (O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: TalibapN an inf. n. of Talabahu [q. v.]. (MA.)

[It generally signifies] A thing that one seeks, desires, demands, or asks for; a thing that one seeks, desires, or endeavours, to find and to get or take; an object of quest, or desire; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also TilaAbN↓, which is originally an inf. n. of TaAlabahu; (Mṣb;) and so TilobN↓; (Ḥar p. 560;) and TilobapN↓ and TalabN↓ are substs. from TaAlabahu, (Ḳ,) signifying [the same, or] a right, or due, sought, or demanded: (TḲ:) and TalibapN signifies also an object of want, or need; a needful thing: (TA:) its pl. is TalibaAtN. (Mṣb.) One says, liI Einodahu TilobapN↓ [or TalibapN] I have an object of quest, or desire, or of want, or a right, or due, necessary to be sought, or demanded, of him. (A.) And hiIa Tilobu↓ fulaAnK She is the object of love of such a one; as also Tilobatuhu↓: (A, Ḳ:) or the former, (O,) or each, the latter mentioned by Lḥ, (TA,) means she is the object of quest, or desire, and the object of love, of such a one. (O, TA.)
And it is said on the authority of IAạr that Tlbp [app., accord. to the context, TalibapN] signifies A company, or an assembly, of men. (TA.)

entry.sense: TilaAbN: see the next preceding paragraph.

TaluwbN, of which the pl. is TulubN, (Ḳ, TA,) and, as is said in the Mṣb, [but not in my copy of it,] TulobN; (TA;) and Tal-aAbN↓, of which the pl. is Tal-aAbuwna; and TaliybN↓, of which the pl. is TulabaMCu; Seeking, desiring, or demanding; or seeking, desiring, or endeavouring, to find and to get or take; (Ḳ, TA;) much, or often; all are intensive in signification. (TA.)
And biYorN TaluwbN (O, TA) [and] TaliybN↓ (thus in a copy of the A) A well of which the water is remote: (A, O, TA:) pl. of the former OaboMrN TulubN. (O, TA.) See also TulobapN.
TaliybN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
Tal-aAbN: see TaluwbN.

TaAlibN Seeking, desiring, or demanding; or seeking, desiring, or endeavouring, to find and to get or take; or a seeker,, &c.: (Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA:) [and used for TaAlibu EilomK a student of science or knowledge:] pl. Tul-aAbN and TalabapN (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and Tul-abN (Ḳ) and TaAlibuwna (Mṣb) and OaTolaAbN [a pl. of pauc., like OaSoHaAbN,] (A)
and TalabN↓, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) or this last, as is said in the M, is [properly speaking] a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) or, (Mgh, TA,) as IAth says, (TA,) it is either a pl. of TaAlibN or an inf. n. used as such, (Mgh, TA,) for Oaholu AlT-alabi: (TA:) fem., applied to a woman, TaAlibapN; of which the pl. is TaAlibaAtN and TawaAlibu. (Mṣb.) You say, huwa TaAlibN lilX-aIoCi He is a seeker,, &c., of the thing. (TA.) And heWulaMCi Talabu↓ OaEodaAYihimo and OaTolaAbuhumo These are the troops that are the seekers [or pursuers] of their enemies. (A.) And huwa Tilobu↓ nisaMCK, (A, Ḳ,) with kesr, (Ḳ,) He is a seeker, or desirer, of women: (A, Ḳ:) pl. OaTolaAbN and TilabapN. (Ḳ.)

maTolabN A place, (Mṣb, KL,) or time, (KL,) of seeking: (Mṣb, KL:) [and so muT-alabN↓:] pl. maTaAlibu. (KL.) [And particularly applied to A place in which treasure is buried and sought. And A place where anything remarkable is to be sought, or looked for, in a book.]
[And hence, † A person from whom one seeks a thing.] layosa liI maTolabN siwaAka † [I have none from whom to seek the accomplishment of my desires but Thee] occurs in a trad. respecting prayer. (TA.)
See also maToluwbN.
It is also an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (A, MA, Mṣb.)

muTolibN, applied to water, and to pasture, or herbage, Distant, or remote, (Ṣ, A, O,) so as not to be attainable but by seeking, (Ṣ, O,) or so that it is sought: (A:) or, applied to pasture, or herbage, distant, or remote: and, applied to water, distant, or remote, from the pasture or herbage: or between which and the pasture, or herbage, is twice the space termed a miyl, (Ḳ, TA,) or thrice that space, the myl being the space from one Ealam [or sign of the way] to another; (TA;) or a day, or two days, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. a day's journey, or two days' journey; in the latter case being termed muTolibu UibilK [i. e. distant to be sought of camels]. (TA.) It is also applied to other things: a poet says,
OahaAjaka baroqN Mxira All-ayoli muTolibu
[Has distant lightning, in the latter part of the night, excited thee?]. (Ṣ, O.)
maToluwbN Sought, desired, or demanded; and so maTolabN↓ [but app. as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, and used in the sense of TalibapN]. (KL.)
muT-alabN: see maTolabN.

hom.sense: 1. TaliHati AlUibilu, (Ṣ, A,) [aor. _a {yaTolaHu},] inf. n. TalaHN, (TA,) The camels had a complaint (Ṣ, A) of their bellies (Ṣ) from eating of the trees called TaloH. (Ṣ, A. [But see UibilN.])
And TaliHa, aor. _a {yaTolaHu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TḲ,) He (a man, TḲ,) was, or became, empty, or void of food, in his belly; as also TuliHa, like EuniIa. (Ḳ.)

TalaHa, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaTolaHu}, inf. n. TaloHN and TalaAHapN, (M, Ḳ,) said of a camel, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) He was, or became, lean, or emaciated, by reason of fatigue, or of disease: (A:) or fatigued, or wearied: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or injured, or hurt, by fatigue: (AZ, T, TA:) or he was, or became, fatigued, and fell down by reason of travel: (M, TA:) or TaliHa, aor. _a {yaTolaHu}, inf. n. TalaHN; and TalaHa, aor. _a {yaTolaHu}, inf. n. TaloHN; he was, or became, fatigued: or lean, by reason of fatigue, or of disease. (MA.)
And TalaHa, inf. n. TalaAHN, ‡ He (a man) was, or became, bad, corrupt, or vicious. (A, L. [See TalaAHN below.])

entry.sense: 2: see the last sentence above {1}.
[Hence, app.,] Tl-H Ealayohi, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. taToliyHN, (Ḳ,) ‡ He importuned him, (A, Ḳ,) i. e., his debtor, so that he wearied him. (A.)
4: see 1, last sentence.

hom.sense: TaloHN, [a coll. gen. n.,] (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) and TilaAHN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) the latter said to be pl. of TaloHapN, (TA,) which is the n. un. of TaloHN, (Ṣ,) or, accord. to Sb, the pl. of TaloHapN is TuluwHN, like as SuxuwrN is pl. of SaxorapN; and TilaAHN also; and the pl. of TaloHN is OaTolaAHN; (M;) [The acacia, or mimosa, gummifera; an appellation applicable also to the sanoT, which produces the gum-arabic: (see SamogN:) the former tree is termed by Forskål (Flora Ægypt. Arab. p. cxxiv.) “mimosa gummifera;” but it is more commonly termed an “acacia:” its pods are termed Eul-afN, q. v.:] a species of large trees, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the kind called EiDaAhN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) growing in El-Ḥijáz [and Egypt and Nubia and other countries]; the fruit of which is like that of the samurap; having curved thorns: the places in which it grows are the interiors of valleys; and it is that species of the EDAh which is the largest in its thorns, and the hardest in respect of its wood, and the best in respect of its gum: Lth describes it as above, and says that it is the same as the Oum-u gayolaAna [and the like is said in the A]: ISh says that it is a tall tree, affording a shade in which men and camels repose, with few leaves, long and large branches, with many thorns, [more] than the prickles of the palm-tree, and a great trunk, which a man's arm cannot embrace; the same as the Am- gylAn; and grows in the mountains: AḤn says that it is, of the trees called EDAh, the largest, and that which has most leaves, and the greenest, and has thick and long thorns, but these are of the least hurtful of thorns, producing no heat in the foot; it has a fruit (baramapN) of pleasant odour; and there is not among the trees called EDAh any that produces more gum than it, nor any more bulky; and it grows only in rugged, hard, fertile ground. (TA.) By TaloH in the Ḳur lvi. 28 may be meant the trees called Am- gylAn, because they have a blossom of a very pleasant odour. (Zj.) [But see below.]

TaloHN signifies also Banana-trees; syn. Xajaru Almawozi; and is said [by some] to have this meaning in the Ḳur lvi. 28: (Zj, T, TA:) or i. q. mawozN [which some expl. as meaning the trees above-mentioned; but others as meaning the fruit of those trees]: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) this, however, is said to be unknown in the [classical] language. (TA.)

And i. q. TaloEN [generally meaning The spadix of the palmtree; but sometimes the spathe thereof]: (Ḳ:) a dial. var. of the latter word: (Ṣ:) mentioned by ISk among words formed by the substitution of one letter for another: and this meaning, also, it is said [by some] to have in the Ḳur lvi. 28. (TA.)
And Remains of turbid water in a watering-trough or tank. (Ḳ.)
And Having the belly void of food. (Ḳ.)
See also TaliyHN.

entry.sense: TiloHN The tick; syn. quraAdN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) sometimes applied thereto; (Ṣ;) as also TaliyHN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a large tick. (TA. [See HamonaAnN.])

[Hence,] TiloHu maAlK ‡ One who keeps to camels, or cattle, and to the care of them, like as cleaves the TiloH, i. e. tick: (A:) a manager, tender, or superintendent, of camels, or cattle; or a good pastor thereof. (Ḳ.)
And TiloHu nisaMCi ‡ One who follows, or goes after, women (Ḳ, TA) much, or often. (TA.)

And TiloHN is also expl. as signifying A pastor fatigued, or wearied: (Ḳ, TA:) and [its pl.] TuluHN, as signifying [simply] pastors. (L.) El-Hotei-ah says, after mentioning certain camels and their pastors,
UicaA naAma TiloHN OaXoEavu Alr-aOosi xalofahaA
hadaAhu lahaA OanofaAsuhaA wazafiyruhaA
When a pastor, dusty and shaggy or matted in the hair of the head, sleeps behind them, [and they become lost to him,] their breathing and their vehement respiration occasioned by the fulness of their bellies guides him to them, so that he finds them, even if they be distant. (Ṣ,* L.)
See also TaliyHN, in four places.
TalaHN (thus correctly written, not TaloHN as in [some of the copies of] the Ṣ, TA) Enjoyment of a life of ease and plenty. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

TaliHN an epithet applied to a camel. (A.) You say UibilN TaliHapN and TalaAHaI [the latter being the pl.] Camels having a complaint (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) of their bellies (Ṣ, Ḳ) from eating of the trees called TaloH: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:)
but [the meaning seems to be, from eating thereof immoderately, for] Aboo-Saʼeed disapproves of the phrase Abl TlAHI as meaning camels that have eaten of the TlH [and become disordered thereby, though it appears from what is said in art. EDh that camels are sometimes disordered by eating of any of the trees called EiDaAh], asserting it to signify camels that are fatigued, or wearied; for [he says that] the TlH do not disorder camels, but are wholesome food for them. (TA.) See also TaliyHN, in two places.
And OaroDN TaliHapN Land abounding with the trees called TaloH. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: TaloHapN n. un. of TaloHN [q. v.]. (Ṣ.)
Oum-u TaloHapu The louse. (TA.)

entry.sense: TaloHiy-apN meaning A piece of paper is a post-classical word. (Ḳ.)
TalaAHN, as an attribute of a man, ‡ Badness, corruptness, or viciousness: (A:) contr. of SalaAHN. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: TaliyHN, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) Rendered lean, or emaciated, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) applied to a camel; (A, Mṣb;) as also TaliHN↓, (A,) or TiloHN↓, (Ḳ,) and TaAliHN↓, so applied, by reason of fatigue, or of disease. (A.) Also, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) applied to a camel, and TiloHN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latter, (Ṣ, MF,) and the former likewise, (MF,) applied to the male and to the female of camels and of other animals, (Ṣ, MF,) and TaloHN↓, (Ḳ,) and TaliHN↓, (L, TA,) Fatigued: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner, applied to a she-camel, TaliyHapN and TiloHapN↓, (Ḳ, in the CK TaloHpN,) but the forms commonly known of these two epithets thus applied are without p, because each has the signification of a pass. part. n., (MF,) and TaAliHN↓: (IAạr, Ḳ:) the pls. are Tul-aHN and TalaAYiHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [both pls. of TaliyHN,] meaning fatigued, or jaded, and rendered lean, by travel, (Ṣ,) and TaloHaI, which last is [said by SM to be] anomalous, because [he holds that] it has the meaning of an act. part. n., [app. on the ground that some expl. TaliyHN as syn. with muEoIK and taEibN,] (TA,) and TuluHN is another pl., [app. of the second and third and fourth of the sings. mentioned above,] signifying fatigued: (L, TA;) and OaTolaAHN is pl. [of pauc.] of TiloHN. (Ṣ.) One says naAqapN TaliyHu OasofaArK meaning A she-camel jaded, and rendered lean, by journeys: (T, Ṣ:) and TaliyHu safarK, and TaloHu↓ safarK. (IAạr, TA.) raAkibu Aln-aAqapi TaliyHaAni means The rider of the she-camel and the she-camel are both fatigued, or jaded: (L, Ḳ:) for raAkibu Aln-aAqapi waAln-aAqapu TaliyHaAni: or for raAkibu AlnaAqapi OaHadu AlT-alyHayoni. (L.)
See also TiloHN.

entry.sense: UibilN TilaAHiy-apN and TulaAHiy-apN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latter anomalous, (Ṣ,) or the latter is a dial. var. of the former, which is not a rel. n. from the pl. TilaAHN, because, when a rel. n. is formed from a pl., the pl. is reduced to its sing. form, unless it is used as a name of a particular thing, (from a marginal note in copies of the Ṣ, [see also Ḥam pp. 791-2,]) Camels feeding upon the trees called TilaAH [or TaloH]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
TaAliHN: see TaliyHN, in two places.
Also, as an epithet applied to a man, ‡ Bad, corrupt, or vicious; (A, L;) in whom is no good: (L:) contr. of SaAliHN. (Ṣ, L.)
muTal-iHN † One who acts wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously, fiI AlmaAli [with respect to property, or camels, or cattle]. (Az, L.)

And, accord. to Az, One who breathes hard, or emits the voice with a moaning sound, fiI AlkalaAmi [in speaking]; syn. nah-aAtN [but the first letter in this word is written in the L without any diacritical point; so that the word may perhaps be bah-aAtN, meaning a great, or frequent, calumniator, slanderer, or false-accuser: see art. bht]. (L, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Talasahu, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaTolisu} (Ḳ, MṢ, O, TA, but in a copy of the A, _u,) inf. n. TalosN; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) and Tl-shu↓, (M, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. taToliysN; (A;) He obliterated it, or effaced it, namely, a writing; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) i. q. Tar-asahu: (M:) or he obliterated it, or effaced it, namely a writing, [so far as] to mar, or spoil, its characters; thus differing from Tr-shu, which signifies “he obliterated it, or effaced it, well.” (T, A.)
[Hence,] Talasa baSarahu ‡ He took away, or destroyed, his sight: (A, TA:) in the Ḳ [and O] Talasa baSaruhu his sight went away, or became destroyed; on the authority of Ibn-ʼAbbád. (TA.)
Talisa, aor. _a {yaTolasu}, inf. n. TalasN, It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was, or became, old and worn-out. (IḲṭṭ.)

Talisa, aor. _a {yaTolasu}, inf. n. TalasN; and Talusa, aor. _u {yaTolusu}, inf. n. TulosapN; He, or it, was, or became, of a dusty colour, inclining to black. (IḲṭṭ: the inf. ns., only, are mentioned in the M.)

entry.sense: 2: see above {1}, first sentence.

hom.sense: 5. tTl-s It (a writing) became obliterated, or effaced. (Ṣ.) [See also 7.]

tTl-s biTayolasaAnK, and taTayolasa↓, He clad, or attired, himself with a TayolasaAn. (M, TA.) [The former verb is used by El-Hemedhánee transitively, as meaning, He put on, or made use of, a napkin as a TylsAn: (see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., vol. iii., p. 90 of the Arabic text:) but perhaps this usage is only post-classical.]

entry.sense: 7. AnTls Oavaruhu His trace, or track, or footsteps, became concealed, or unapparent: said of a beast: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TṢ, O, TA:) Oamoruhu, in the copies of the Ḳ, is a mistake. (TA.) [See also 5.]
Q. Q. 2. taTayolasa: see 5.

hom.sense: TilosN i. q. TirosN: (Ṣ in art. Trs, M, Mṣb, TA:) i. e., (TA,) A written paper or the like; syn. SaHiyfapN: (Ḳ, TA:) or one of which the writing has been obliterated, or effaced, (A, Ḳ, TA,) but not well obliterated; thus differing from TirosN, accord. to the T: (TA:) pl. TuluwsN. (Mṣb, TA.) See TirosN.
Also The skin of the thigh of the camel (T, M, Ḳ) when the hair has fallen off. (T, Ḳ.)
See also OaTolasu, in three places.

entry.sense: TaliysN, of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, † Having the eye blinded: in the O and Ḳ erroneously said to be Til-iys, like sik-iyt: but in the Tekmileh, correctly, Taliys, like Oamiyr. (TA.)
Tal-aAsapN A piece of rag with which one wipes a tablet (A, Ḳ, TA) upon which is writing, and with which the writing is obliterated, or effaced. (A, TA.)
TayolasN: see TayolasaAnN.
TaAlasaAnN: see TayolasaAnN.

hom.sense:
TayolasaAnN (El-Fárábee, Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TayolisaAnN, (M, O, Ḳ,) the latter form used by some, (El-Fárábee, Mṣb,) or by the vulgar, (Ṣ,) and disallowed by Aṣ, (M, Mṣb,) and TayolusaAnN, all these three forms being mentioned by ʼIyáḍ and others, (Ḳ,) [accord. to the TA, following Lth; but the words of Lth, as cited in the TA, and in the O, rather signify that, if, instead of TayolisaAnN, with kesr to the l, one said TayolusaAnN, with damm to the l, like xayozuraAnN and HayosumaAnN, it would be more agreeable with analogy; and the like is said in the Mṣb, as on the authority of Az;] and TayolasN↓ (M, Mgh, O, Ḳ) and TaAlasaAnN↓; (M, TA;) arabicized words, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from the Pers., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) originally taAlasaAno, (as in some copies of the Ḳ,) or taAlaXaAno; (as in other copies of the Ḳ, and in some copies of the T, and thus written by El-Urmawee, as is said in the TA, and thus written also in the Mgh;) differently expl. by different persons; (TA;) [app. accord. to the fashions of different times and countries;] accord. to some, (TA,) A certain kind of kisaMC: (M, TA:) or a certain article of apparel worn by the Eajam [Persians or other foreigners], (Mgh, Mṣb,) of a round form, and black; accord. to the “Jema et-Tefáreek,” having its woof and warp both of wool: (Mgh:) or a kisaMC, of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, (OaxoDar,) worn by persons of distinction: (EshShereeshee, in Ḥar, p. 238:)
[see also bat-N, and saAjN: El-Makreezee mentions a kind of TylsAn having a round piece cut out from the middle of it (muqaw-arN) worn by the Egyptian Wezeer, and called, in his time, (the 14th and 15th centuries of our era,) TaroHapN: (see this word: and see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., ii. 267-269; and Dozy's Dict. des Noms des Vêtements chez les Arabes, 278-90:) it seems to have resembled our academic hood, of which it was perhaps the original: the term TylsAn is now commonly applied to an oblong piece of drapery, or a scarf, or an oblong shawl, worn in such a manner that one end hangs down upon the side of the bosom, the middle part being turned over the head and under the chin, and the other end being thrown over the shoulder, and hanging down upon the back: this is worn by many of the professional learned men in winter, in Arabian countries: it is also used in the sense of the word EacabapN, meaning an end of a turban, when made to hang down between the shoulders: see EacabN:] the pl. (of TayolasaAnN and TayolisaAnN and TayolasN, M) is TayaAlisapN, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in which the p is added because it is a foreign word, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and TayaAlisu; (M, A;) or the latter is pl. of TayolasN: (TA:) I do not know (says ISd) any pl. of TaAlasaAnN: (M, TA:) it is not allowable to form an abbreviation of TayolisaAnN, with kesr to the l, as a compellation, because there is no instance of the measure fayoEilN, with kesr to the E, except in infirm words such as say-idN and may-itN. (Ṣ.) Hence the expression, (Mgh,) yaA Qbona AlT-ayolasaAni, [lit., O son of the teylesán,] meaning, O 'Ajamee, (A, Mgh,) or Aajamee, (Ḳ,) [i. e., Persian, or foreigner,] used in reviling another; (Mgh, Ḳ;) for the Eajam are those who [most commonly] attire themselves with the TylsAn. (TA.)
See also TalosN.

OaTolasu Old and worn-out; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) applied to a garment, or piece of cloth: (M, Ḳ:) as also TilosN↓; pl. OaTolaAsN. (Ṣ.) You say, rajulN OaTolasu Alv-awobi A man whose garment is old and worn-out. (Ṣ.)
A dirhem [of which the impression is obliterated;] having no impression. (Mṣb, voce masiyHN.)

A wolf whose hair has fallen off by degrees; (Az, TA;) as also TilosN↓: (IAạr, A, Ḳ:) or a wolf of a dusty colour inclining to blackness; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) and anything of that colour; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) whether a garment or any other thing: (TA:) fem. TalosaMCu: (M:) pl. TulosN. (A.)
A man having little hair upon the side of the cheek; pl. TulosN: or i. q. kawosajN [q. v.]: of the the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)
Dirty, or filthy; as also TilosN↓: (Ḳ:) the latter applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (Ḳ, TA,) in the colour of which is a dusty hue: (TA:) and TalosaMCu a dirty rag. (O.)
A man ‡ dirty, or filthy, in apparel: likened to a wolf in respect of the dusty hue of his clothes: (M:) or black and dirty. (O.)
[Hence,] † A man who is accused of foul, or evil, conduct; (Sh, O, Ḳ;) and so OaTolasu Alv-awobayoni, an expression used by Ows Ibn-Hajar. (Sh, O.)
‡ Black, as an Abyssinian and the like: (O, Ḳ:) as being likened in colour to a wolf. (TA.) [See also TalosN.]
‡ A thief: (O, Ḳ:) because of his evil nature, (TA,) being likened to a wolf. (O, TA.)
[Satin; so called in the present day;] a garment, or piece of cloth, of woven silk: [app. because of its smoothness:] but this is not [of the classical] Arabic: pl. TulosN. (TA.)
falaku AlOaTolasi: see OaviyrN, last sentence.

Q. 1. Talosama He (a man) made his face to be displeasing, or odious; (M, L, TA;) he contracted it; or made it austere, or morose: and so Taromasa, and Talomasa, (L, TA,) and Tarosama. (TA in art. Tlms.)
And He (a man) bent down his head; or lowered his eyes, looking towards the ground; or was, or became, silent; syn. OaToraqa: and so Tarosama. (Ṣ in art. Trsm; and TA.)

[And, accord. to Golius, He receded, or drew back, from fight; followed by Eano: (one of the significations assigned in the Ḳ to Tarosama:) he mentions this as on the authority of J: perhaps he found it in a copy of the Ṣ in art. Trms (in which AlT-aromasapu is expl. as meaning AlAinoqibaADu and Aln-ukuwSu), or in some other art. of that work in which I do not remember to have seen it.]
[Also He sculptured, engraved, or inscribed, a thing with talismanic devices or characters. And He charmed, or guarded, or preserved, by means of a talisman. See what follows.]

entry.sense: TilasomN, or, accord. to MF, Til-asomN, [also written TalisomN, and TilisomN, and Til-isomN, and TalosamN, and TalosimN, and TilosamN,] said by MF to be a Pers., or foreign, word; [perhaps from a late usage of the Greek τέλεσμα;] but [SM says] in my opinion it is Arabic; a name for A concealed secret; [i. e. a mystery: hence our word talisman: accord. to common modern usage, it signifies mystical devices or characters, astrological or of some other magical kind: and a seal, an image, or some other thing, upon which such devices, or characters, are engraved or inscribed; contrived for the purpose of preserving from enchantment or from a particular accident or from a variety of evils, or to protect a treasure with which it is deposited, or (generally by its being rubbed) to procure the presence and services of a Jinnee,, &c.:] pl. TalaAsimu (TA) [and TilasomaAtN or Til-asomaAtN, &c.].

1. TalaEati AlX-amosu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaToluEu} [notwithstanding the faucial letter], (Mṣb, JM, TA,) inf. n. TuluwEN and maTolaEN and maToliEN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the second and third both used as inf. ns., and also as ns. of place [and of time], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) but the former of them is preferable on the ground of analogy as an inf. n., and the latter as a n. of place (Fr, O) or of time, (Zj, O,) The sun rose, (MA,) or appeared; (Ḳ;) and in like manner TalaEa is said of the moon, (TA,) and of a star, or an asterism; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and so AiT-alaEa↓; (Ḳ;) [and OaTolaEa↓, for] OaTolaEati Alv-uray-aA means TalaEat [i. e. The Pleiades rose], as in a verse of El-Kumeyt [in which, however, the verb may, consistently with the metre, be a mistranscription for AT-alaEat]; (IB, TA); and OaTolaEa is syn. with TalaEa in the saying of Ru-beh,
kaOan-ahu kawokabu gayomK OaTolaEaA
[As though it, or he, were a star in the midst of clouds, that had risen]. (TA.) One says also, Mtiyka kul-a yawomK TalaEatohu AlX-amosu, meaning TalaEato fiyhi [i. e. I will come to thee every day in which the sun rises]: and it is said in a prayer, TalaEati AlX-amosu walaA taToluEu binafosi OaHadK min-aA [meaning The sun has risen, and may it not have risen with the soul of any one of us]; i. e., may not any one of us have died with its rising: the future being put in the place of the preterite. (TA.)

And TalaEa is said of anything that appears to one from the upper part [of a thing, or that comes up out of a thing and appears]. (Mgh, Mṣb.) It is said in the Ksh that AlT-uluwEu signifies The appearing by rising, or by becoming elevated. (TA.) One says, TalaEato sin-u AlS-abiI-i ‡ The tooth of the child showed its point. (Ḳ, TA.) And TalaEa Alz-aroEu, [aor. _u {yaToluEu},] inf. n. TuluwEN, ‡ The seed-produce began to come up, and showed its sprouting forth: (T, TA:) and OaTolaEa↓ Alz-aroEu ‡ The seed-produce appeared: (TA:) and OaTolaEa↓ nabotu AlOaroDi † The plants, or herbage, of the earth, or land, came forth: (Mgh:) and OaTolaEa↓ AlX-ajaru ‡ The trees put forth their leaves. (TA.) And TalaEa Aln-axolu, (O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaToluEu}, inf. n. TuluwEN; (TA;) and (O, Ḳ) OaTolaEa↓; (Zj, Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ;) or OaTolaEati Aln-axolapu; (Mṣb;) † The palm-trees, or -tree, put forth the TaloE [q. v.]; (Zj, Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Tl-E↓, (L, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. taToliyEN. (L, TA. [These verbs, in this sense, are app. derived from the subst. TaloEN; but this is obviously from TalaEa.])

One says also, malaOotu lahu AlqadaHa Hat-aI yakaAda yaToluEu mino nawaAHiyhi [I filled for him the drinking-vessel until it nearly overflowed from its sides]. (TA.) And taTal-aEa↓ AlmaMCu fiI AlUinaMCi † The water in the vessel poured forth [or overflowed] from its sides. (TA.)

And TalaEa Aljabala, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaToluEu}, (TA,) inf. n. TuluwEN, (Mṣb, TA,) ‡ He ascended upon the mountain; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) the prep. [EalaI] being suppressed; (Mgh;) as also TaliEa, with kesr; (Ḳ;) and AiT-alaEa↓ Aljabala signifies the same as TalaEahu: (TA: [see also muDoTaliEN, in art. DlE:]) accord. to ISk, one says, TaliEotu Aljabala, with kesr, meaning † I ascended upon the mountain; (Ṣ, O;) but others say, TalaEotu, with fet-ḥ. (O.)
And ‡ He ascended the mountain: (TA:) [or] TalaEotu fiI Aljabali means † I ascended the mountain. (Mṣb. [See also another explanation of this latter phrase in what follows.])

And TalaEa EalayonaA, aor. _a {yaTolaEu} and _u {yaToluEu}; and AiT-alaEa↓; † He (a man) came to us; (Ḳ;) and came upon us suddenly, or at unawares: (TA:) and TalaEa Eanohumo he became absent, or absented himself, or departed, from them: (Ḳ:) or TalaEa EalaI Alqawomi he came forth upon the people, or party: and he looked upon them: (MA:) accord. to ISk, TalaEotu EalaI Alqawomi means I came to the people, or party: and TalaEotu Eanohumo I became absent, or absented myself, or departed, from them: (Ṣ, O:) and OaTolaEotu↓ Ealayohimo signifies the same as TalaEotu: (O:) and TalaEotu Eanohumo has the same meaning [also] as TalaEotu Eanohumo expl. above, accord. to ISk; EalaI being put in the place of En: accord. to AZ [likewise], TalaEotu EalaI Alqawomi, inf. n. TuluwEN, means I became absent from the people, or party, so that they did not see me: and also I advanced, or approached, towards them, so that they saw me: thus having two contr. meanings: and accord. to Az, the Arabs said, TalaEotu fiI Aljabali, inf. n. TuluwEN, as meaning I retired, or went back, into the mountain, so that my companion did not see me: [see another explanation of this phrase in what precedes:] and TalaEotu Eano SaAHibiI, inf. n. TuluwEN, I retired, or went back, from my companion: and TalaEotu Eano SaAHibiI [in which Eano seems to be evidently a mistranscription for EalaI] I advanced, or approached, towards my companion. (TA.) [In all of these phrases, TalaEa and TalaEotu may be correctly rendered He, and I, came forth, or went forth. And hence,] it is said in a prov., hecihi yamiynN qado TalaEato fiI AlmaxaArimi [expl. in art. xrm, voce maxorimN]. (AZ, TA.)
For another meaning of TalaEa followed by EalaI, see AiT-alaEa [which is more common as having that meaning].

TalaEa is also syn. with qaSada: so in the phrase TalaEa bilaAdahu ‡ [He tended, repaired, betook himself, or went, to, or towards, his country]: (Ḳ, TA:) and so in the saying, in a trad., hecaA busorN qado TalaEa Alyamana, (so in the O,) or hcA bur-N, (so in the TA,) ‡ [These are ripening dates, or this is wheat, that have, or has, gone to, or towards, El-Yemen,] meaning from Nejd. (TA.)

And syn. with balaga; as also AiT-alaEa↓: (O, Ḳ:) so the former in the saying, TalaEa OaroDahumo ‡ [He reached, or arrived at, their land]; (Ḳ, TA;) and mataI TalaEota OaroDanaA ‡ [When didst thou reach, or arrive at, our land?]: (O, TA:) and so the latter verb in the saying, AT-lE↓ hecihi AlOaroDa [He reached, or arrived at, this land]: (O, Ḳ:) and hence, (TA,) Ql-atiI taT-aliEu↓ EalaI AlOafoYidapi, in the Ḳur [civ. 7], means † Whereof the pain shall reach the hearts: (Fr, O, TA:) or which shall rise above the hearts, (O, TA,) [or overwhelm them,] and burn them. (TA.)
2. Tl-E said of the palm-tree: see 1, former half.
Tl-Ehu, inf. n. taToliyEN, meaning He put it forth, or produced it, is a vulgar word. (TA.)
Tl-E kayolahu, inf. n. as above, † He filled his measure. (O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 3. TAlEhu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. muTaAlaEapN and TilaAEN, (Ḳ,) i. q. AiT-alaEa Ealayohi; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) i. e., a thing: (Ṣ, O:) Lth says that TilaAEN is syn. with AiT-ilaAEN; but Az disapproves this: (O:) [the verb is correctly explained in what here follows:] one says, TaAlaEotu DayoEatiI, meaning naZarotuhaA waQT-alaEotu EalayohaA ‡ [I inspected, or considered with my eye, my estate, and obtained a knowledge of it, or acquainted myself with its condition]: (TA:) or muTaAlaEapN signifies the inspecting a thing well, in order to obtain a knowledge of it. (KL.) [Hence, muTaAlaEapu Alkutubi † The studying, and perusing, of books.]
See also the next paragraph {4}, latter half, in three places.
4: see 1, former half, in five places.
ATlEt Aln-axolapu signifies also † The palm-tree became tall. (Mṣb.)
And ATlE, also, ‡ He made his arrow to pass above the butt. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.)
And ‡ He vomited. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.)
And ATlEt Als-amaMCu i. q. OaqolaEat [i. e. † The rain cleared away]. (TA.)
ATlE followed by EalaI: see 1, latter half:
and see also 8.
And ATlE as syn. with OaXorafa: see 8, in two places.
ATlE raOosahu † [He raised his head, looking at a thing; or] he looked at a thing from above; syn. OaXorafa EalaI XaIoCK. (TA.)

ATlEhu EalaI kacaA † He made him acquainted with such a thing; acquainted him with it, or made him to know it. (Mṣb.) UiTolaAEN signifies † The making to know, and to see. (KL.) For an ex. [of the latter meaning], in the pass. form of the verb, see 8. You say, ATlEhu EalaI sir-ihi, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) ‡ He made him to know, (TA,) or revealed, or showed, to him, (O, Ḳ, TA,) his secret.
