(O, Ḳ, TA.) [See also 8, last sentence.] And OanaA OuTaAliEuka↓ biHaqiyqapi AlOamori means OuToliEuka Ealayohi ‡ [I will acquaint thee with the truth of the case]. (TA.) And similar to this is the saying, TaAliEoniI↓ bikutubika (TA [and a similar phrase is mentioned without explanation in the Ṣ]) [meaning † Acquaint thou me with thy letters: and also, by means of thy letters; for] one of the meanings of muTaAlaEapN is The making one to know a thing by writing. (KL.) [And in like manner,] one says also, TAlE↓ biAlHaAli, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. muTaAlaEapN and TilaAEN, (TA,) † He showed, exhibited, or manifested, the case. (O, Ḳ.)
You say also, ATlE Uilayohi maEoruwfFA † He did to him, or conferred upon him, a benefit, benefaction, or favour. (O, Ḳ.)
And ATlE fulaAnFA † He made such a one to hasten, or be quick. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
5. tTl-E ‡ It became full [to the top, or so as to overflow]; said of a measure for corn or the like. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
See also 1, former half.

And † He was proud, or self-conceited, [or lofty,] or was quick, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, (zaAfa,) in his gait: (O:) or so tTl-E fiI miXoyatihi: (Ḳ:) app. syn. with tatal-aEa, meaning he advanced his neck, and raised his head. (TA.)

And ‡ He raised his eyes, looking [for a thing, or towards a thing]. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, tTl-E UilaI wuruwdihi ‡ He raised his eyes, looking for its, or his arrival. (Ḳ, TA.) And taTal-aEotu UilaI wuruwdi kitaAbika (Ṣ, O, TA) ‡ I raised my eyes, looking, (TA,) or I looked continually, (PṢ,) for the arrival of thy letter: (TA, PṢ:) or i. q. AinotaZarotu [agreeably with what here follows, and with an explanation of the inf. n. in the KL]. (PṢ.) And tTl-E UilaI liqaAYihi † He looked for the meeting him. (MA.) And [hence] one says, EaAfaI Qll-ehu rajulFA lamo yataTal-aEo fiI famika, meaning ‡ [May God preserve from disease, or harm, a man] who has not sought to find some slip, or fault, in thy speech: (O, Ḳ, TA:) mentioned by AZ, (O, TA,) and by Z. (TA.) [Hence likewise,] Alt-aTal-uEu signifies also AlUiXoraAfu [as meaning ‡ The being eager, or vehemently eager, agreeably with what here follows]. (TA.) And Alt-aTal-uEu UilaI AlX-aIoCi ‡ The inclining of the soul to the love of the thing, and the desiring it so that the man perishes. (TA.) And taTal-uEu Aln-afosi † The desiring, or yearning, or longing, of the soul. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. Sbr.]
tTl-Ehu ‡ He looked at him with a look of love or of hatred. (TA.)
And ‡ He overcame him, and overtook him; namely, a man. (TA.)
See also 6.
And see 8.

entry.sense:
6. taTaAlaEatohu i. q. Taraqatohu [i. e. † She, or it, or they (referring to irrational things), came to him in the night]: Aboo-ʼAlee cites [as an ex.],
taTaAlaEuniI xayaAlaAtN lisalomaI
kamaA yataTaAlaEu Ald-ayona Algariymu
[Apparitions of Selmà come to me in the night, like as the creditor comes in the night to exact the debt]: but accord. to another, or others, it is only yataTal-aEu↓, because tafaAEala is generally intrans.: so that accord. to Aboo-ʼAlee, it is like tafaAwaDonaA AlHadiyva and taEaATayonaA AlkaOosa and tanaAXadonaA AlOaXoEaAra. (IB, TA.)

hom.sense: 8. AiT-alaEa: see 1, first sentence:
and near the middle of the paragraph, in two places:
and last sentence, in three places.

Also † i. q. OaXorafa [meaning as expl. in the next sentence]; as also OaTalaEa↓, of the class of Oakorama. (Mgh.) One says, AiT-alaEotu mino fawoqi Aljabali and OaTolaEotu↓ † [I looked, or looked down, from above the mountain]. (TA.) And AiT-alaEotu Alfajora ‡ I looked at the dawn when it rose. (O, TA.*) And AiT-alaEotu Ealayohi ‡ I looked down, or from above, upon him, or it; syn. OaXorafotu. (TA.)
[Hence,] halo Oanotumo muT-aliEuwna faQT-alaEa, in the Ḳur [xxxvii. 52 and 53], means † Would ye [be of those who] look to see (tuHib-uwna Oano taT-aliEuwA) where is your place of abode among the people of Hell? and he (i. e. the Muslim) shall look (faQT-alaEa Almusolimu) and see his [former] associate in the midst of Hell-fire: but some read hl Antm muToliEuwna faOaToliEa↓ [in the CK fAT-alaEa, but it is expressly said in the O that the hemzeh is with damm and the T quiescent and the l with kesr; the meaning being † Are ye of those who will make me to see? and he shall be made to see; as is indicated in the O and TA]. (Ḳ, O.)

And † He saw. (KL.) You say, AT-lE Ealayohi meaning † He saw it. (MA.) [Hence,] it is said in a prov., baEoda QT-ilaAEK UiynaAsN (O, TA) i. e. † After appearance [or rather sight, is knowledge, or certain knowledge]. (Fr, TA in art. Ans. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 181.])

And AT-lE Ealayohi, (Mṣb, TA,) and AT-lEhu, and tTl-Ehu↓, and TalaEa↓ Elyh, inf. n. TuluwEN, (Ḳ, TA,) and OaTolaEa↓ Elyh, (TA,) ‡ He got, or obtained, sight and knowledge of it: (Mṣb, TA:*) or [simply] he knew it; namely, an affair, or a case, or an event. (Ḳ, TA.) One says, AT-lE EalaI baATinihi, (Ḳ,) or AD-lE EalaI baATini Oamorihi, (Ṣ, O,) ‡ He became acquainted with, or obtained knowledge of, or knew, his inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances, or the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of his affair or case. (Ḳ,* TA.) And-accord. to some, AiT-ilaAEu AlHijaAbi means † The stretching out the head [and looking over the veil of Paradise or of Hell]; for he who examines into a thing stretches out his head to see what is behind the veil, or covering. (TA voce HijaAbN, q. v.) [And one says also, AT-lE fiyhi, meaning † He looked into it: see an ex. voce hadara.]
AiT-alaEatohu EayoniI means ‡ My eye regarded him with contempt. (TA.)
[AiT-alaEa is used sometimes for AiDoTalaEa, as is shown in art. DlE: see muDoTaliEN: and see an instance in the first paragraph {1} of art. Elw.]

And accord. to Kr, AiliA T-laAEu signifies also Aln-ajaApu. (TA. [But I think that both words are mistranscribed, and that Kr explained AlUiTolaAEu as meaning Aln-ijaMCu, i. e. The acquainting with a secret.])

entry.sense: 10. AstTlEhu signifies Talaba TuluwEahu † [He sought, or desired, its, or his, coming forth, or appearance]. (Ḥar p. 47.) [And hence, † He sought, or desired, to elicit, or to discover, it: he sought, or desired, information respecting it, minohu of him: and he asked him to tell him a thing. (See Ḥar pp. 134 and 82.)] You say, AstTlE raOoIa fulaAnK (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) ‡ He looked to see what was the opinion, or advice, of such a one, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and what would be shown to him [thereof] respecting his affair, or case. (O, Ḳ.) It is doubly trans. [as shown above]: you say, AisotaTolaEotu zayodFA raOoyahu; as well as AstTlEt raOoIa zayodK. (Ḥar p. 322.)
And † He took it away, or went away with it. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.) You say, AstTlE maAlahu † He took away, or went away with, his property. (TA.)

hom.sense: TaloEN † The TaloE [i. e. spadix, or spadix in its spathe, and sometimes, the spathe alone,] of the palm-tree: (Ṣ, O:) the UigoriyD [or spadix] of the palm-tree, from over which the kaAfuwr [or spathe] bursts open longitudinally; or the flowers of the palm-tree, while in the kAfwr; (TA;) a thing that comes forth from the palm-tree, as though it were two soles, or sandals, closed together, with the Himol [meaning flowers] compactly disposed between them, and having the extremity pointed; or the vamarap [or produce] of the palm-tree, in the first stage of its appearance, the covering [or spathe] of which is called the kufur-aI (Ḳ, TA) and the kaAfuwr, (TA,) and what is within this the UigoriyD, because of its whiteness; (Ḳ, TA;) or the TaloE is what comes forth from the palm-tree and becomes dates if the tree is female; and if the tree is male it does not become dates, but is eaten in its fresh state, or is left upon the palm-tree a certain number of days until there becomes produced in it a white substance like flour, [i. e. the pollen,] having a strong odour, and with this the female is fecundated; (Mṣb;) or a certain white thing that appears from the kim- [or spathe] of the palm-tree, to the colour of which [that of] the teeth are likened, and to the odour thereof [that of] the sperma: and also, [sometimes,] the kim- [or spathe] that comes forth from the palm-tree, before it bursts open longitudinally: [and this is also called the kufur-aI, for] the phrase TaloEu Alkufuz-aI is an instance of the prefixing of a noun to an explicative thereof: (Mgh:) [or this phrase may mean the spadix of the spathe of a palm-tree: TaloEN, it should be added, is sometimes used as a coll. gen. n.: and its n. un. is with p {TaloEapN}: thus in explanations of UigoriyDN, &c.] In the Ḳur xxxvii. 63, it is applied to ‡ The fruit, or produce, of the tree called Alz-aq-uwm, in the bottom of Hell, metaphorically, because partaking of the form of the TlE of dates, or because coming forth from the tree. (Bḍ.)
Also † i. q. miqodaArN [as meaning Number, or quantity]: (Ḳ, TA:) so in the phrase AljayoXu TaloEu OalofK [The army consists of the number of a thousand]. (Ḳ,* TA).
See also the next paragraph, in three places.

TiloEN ‡ a subst. from AlAiT-ilaAEu: [meaning Knowledge:] whence the saying, AiT-alaEa TiloEa AlEaduw-i ‡ [He learned the knowledge of the enemy; meaning he obtained knowledge of the state, or case, or tidings, or of the secret, or of the inward, or intrinsic, or secret, state or circumstances, of the enemy]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) [for] TiloEa AlEaduw-i means xabarahu, (Mṣb,) or sir-ahu, (PṢ,) or baATina Oamorihimo: (Ḥar p. 82:) and [hence also] one says, OaTolaEotuhu TiloEa OamoriI, meaning ‡ I revealed, or showed, to him my secret. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

Also † An elevated place, above what is around it, from which one looks down (yuT-alaEu [in the CK erroneously yuTolaEu]); as also TaloEN↓. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, Ealawotu TiloEa AlOakamapi, meaning † I ascended upon a part of the hill from which I overlooked what was around it. (IDrd, O, TA.)

And † i. q. naAHiyapN [A side, or an adjacent tract, or a region,, &c.]; as also TaloEN↓. (Ḳ.) One says, kuno biTiloEi AlwaAdiI and TaloEi↓ AlwAdI [i. e. biTaloEi AlwAdI also, meaning, as is indicated in the TA, † Be thou in the side,, &c., of the valley]: (Ṣ, O:) and one says also, fulaAnN TiloE AlwaAdiI, without b [† Such a one is in the side,, &c., of the valley]. (O.)

And † Any depressed piece of ground: or such as has in it a hill: (Ḳ:) [i. e.,] as expl. by Aṣ, any depressed piece of ground having in it a hill from which, when you ascend upon it, you see what is in it. (O.)
Also the serpent: (AA, O, Ḳ:) like Til-N. (TA.)

entry.sense: TaliEN ‡ [Desirous, eager, or vehemently eager]. nafosN TaliEapN and nufuwsN TaliEapN, like fariHapN [in form], mean ‡ A soul, and souls, desirous, eager, or vehemently eager. (TA.) [See also TulaEapN.]

TaloEapN ‡ The aspect; or countenance; syn. ruWoyapN: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) or person and aspect: (L, TA:) or face: (Ḳ:) so in the saying, Hay-aA Qll-ehu TaloEatahu ‡ [May God preserve his aspect,, &c.]. (O, Ḳ.)

nafosN TulaEapN, means nafosN tukoviru Alt-aTal-uEa lilX-aIoCi, (Ṣ, O,) or UilaI AlX-aIoCi, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. ‡ A soul that inclines much to the love of the thing [that it would obtain], and desires it so that the man perishes: and TulaEapN is used also as applied to a pl., so that one says also nufuwsN TulaEapN, (TA,) or OanofusN TulaEapN, meaning souls eager, or vehemently eager, for the objects of their love and appetence. (O.) [See also TaliEN.] And in like manner one says AimoraOahN TulaEapN, (Ṣ,) or AimoraOapN TulaEapN xubaOapN: (TA:) or this latter means ‡ A woman that comes forth (taToluEu [in the CK erroneously taT-aliEu]) at one time (mar-apF [omitted in the CK]) and conceals herself at another: (O, Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner one says AmrOp TulaEapN qubaEapN. (TA.)
TulaEaMCu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) like gulawaMCu [in form], (Ṣ, O,) ‡ Vomit: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) as also TawolaEN↓: (IAạr, O, Ḳ:) or the former signifies a little vomit. (Ḳ voce qanasN.)
TalaAEN, like saHaAbN [in form], the subst. from AlATlAE [app. AlUiTolaAEu, i. e. a subst. syn. with UiTolaAEN; like as SalaAH is with UiSolaAHN, and fasaAdN with UifosaAdN]. (TA.)

TilaAEN ‡ A thing sufficient in quantity, or dimensions, for the filling of another thing, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) accord. to AʼObeyd, so as to overflow [an addition not always agreeable with usage]: (TA:) pl. TuloEN. (Ḳ.)
TilaAEu AlOaroDi cahabFA means ‡ What would suffice for the filling of the earth, of gold: (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, TA:) or, accord. to Lth, what the sun has risen, or appeared, upon, to which Er-Rághib adds and man. (TA.) And you say qawosN TilaAEu Alkaf-i ‡ A bow of which the part that is grasped is sufficient in. size for the filling of the hand. (Ṣ,* O,* TA.) And hecaA TilaAEu hecaA † This is of the quantity, or measure, or size, of this. (TA.)
TaluwEN † Aspiring to, or seeking the means of attaining, lofty things, or eminence. (Ḥam p. 655.)

TaliyEapN, of an army, † [A scout; and a party of scouts;] a man, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and a party of men, (O, Ḳ, TA,) that is sent, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and goes forth, (TA,) to obtain knowledge of the state, or case, or tidings, or of the secret, or of the inward, or intrinsic, or secret, state or circumstances, of the enemy, (liyaT-aliEa TiloEa AlEaduw-i, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) like the jaAsuws; (TA;) a man, (Mgh,) or a party of men, (Mgh, Mṣb,) sent (Mgh, Mṣb) before another party (Mṣb) to acquaint himself, or themselves, with the tidings, or state, or case, of the enemy; (Mgh, Mṣb;) accord. to the ʼEyn, applied to a single man, and to a number of men when they are together; and as used by [the Hanafee Imám] Moḥammad, three, and four; more than these being termed sariy-apN: (Mgh:) pl. TalaAYiEu. (Mgh, O, Mṣb, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
Tal-aAEu Alv-anaAyaA and Tal-aAEu AlOanojudi ‡ [lit. A man wont to ascend mountain-roads; meaning] a man experienced in affairs; wont to surmount them by his knowledge and his experience and his good judgment: or who aspires to lofty things, or the means of attaining eminence: (O, Ḳ, TA: [see also vaniy-apN:]) OanojudN being pl. of najodN; which means “a road in a mountain,” like vaniy-apN [of which vanaAyaA is the pl.]. (TA.) An ex. of the former phrase is presented by a verse of Soheym Ibn-Wetheel cited in art. jlw: and an ex. of the latter by the saying of Moḥammad Ibn-AbeeShihádh Ed-Ḍabbee, said by ISk to be of Ráshid Ibn-Dirwás,
waqado yaqoSuru Alqul-u AlfataI duwna ham-ihi
waqado kaAna lawolaA Alqul-u Tal-aAEa Oanojudi
[Certainly, or sometimes, or often, poverty withholds the young man from attaining his purpose; and certainly, or sometimes, or often, but for poverty, he would be a surmounter of affairs by his knowledge, &c.]. (O, TA.)
qadaHN Tal-aAEN ‡ A full drinking-vessel. (TA.) And EayonN Tal-aAEN [or Tal-aAEapN?] ‡ An eye filled with tears. (TA.)

entry.sense: TaAliEN [Rising, or appearing, as a star, &c.:] anything appearing from the upper part [of a thing, or that comes up out of a thing and appears]: (TA:) [or appearing by rising, or by becoming elevated. (See 1.)]
[Hence,] one says, TaAliEuhu saEiydN, meaning His star [is fortunate]. (TA.)
[Hence also,] AlT-aAliEu means The false dawn: (Ṣ:) or so AlT-aAliEu AlmuSoEidu. (O.)

And The hilaAl [or moon when near the sun, showing a narrow rim of light; probably the new moon, from the sight of which the commencement of the month was reckoned; as appears from what follows]. (O, Ḳ.) maA raOayotuka munocu TaAliEayoni is mentioned as heard from some of the Arabs of the desert, meaning munocu Xahorayoni [i. e. I have not seen thee for two months, or during the period since two new moons]. (O.)

Also The arrow that falls behind the butt: (Az, O, Ḳ:) or that passes beyond the butt, going over it: (TA:) and Ḳṭ says that they used to reckon that falling above the mark as that which hit the butt: pl. TawaAliEu. (O, TA.) It is said of one of the kings, accord. to Ṣgh, [in the O,] kaAna yasojudu lilT-aAliEi, (TA,) meaning as expl. in art. sjd: (O, TA:*) or it may mean that he used to lower himself, or bend himself down, to the rising hilaAl, by way of magnifying God. (O, TA.)
TaAliEapu AlUibili means † The first, or foremost, of the camels. (TA.)
TawolaEN: see TulaEaMCu.

maTolaEN and maToliEN are inf. ns.: and signify also The place [and the time] of rising of the sun [&c.]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ: [see 1, first sentence:]) but by Fr the former is explained as meaning the rising, and the latter as meaning the place of rising: and some of the Basrees say that when one reads Hat-aI maToliEi Alfajori [in the last verse of ch. xcvii. of the Ḳur], with kesr to the l, the meaning is, [until] the time of rising [of the dawn]: (O, TA:) [the pl.] maTaAliEu signifies the places [and the times] of rising of the sun [&c.]. (TA.)

maTolaEu Aljabali means † The place of ascent of the mountain. (TA.) And you say, hecaA laka maTolaEa AlOakamapi, meaning † This is present before thee; i. e. as near to thee as if thou hadst to ascend for it the hill. (TA.)
maTolaEu AlqaSiydapi means ‡ The beginning of the qSydp [or ode]. (TA.)
See also muT-alaEN.
muToliEN † A palm-tree (naxolapN) putting forth its TaloE [q. v.]; and sometimes they said muToliEapN. (Mṣb.)
And the latter, † A palm-tree taller than the other palm-trees [around it or adjacent to it]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

muT-alaEN † [A place to which one ascends: or] a place of ascent from a low spot to a place that overlooks. (Aṣ, TA.) Hence, (TA,) it is said in a trad. (O, Ḳ) of the Prophet, (O,) maAnazala mina AlquroMni MyapN Uil-aA lahaA ZahorN wabaTonN walikul-i HarofK Had-N walikul-i Had-K muT-alaEN i. e. (O, Ḳ) † Not a verse of the Ḳur-án has come down but it has an apparent and known [or exoteric] interpretation and an intrinsic [or esoteric] interpretation, (TA voce ZahorN, where see more,) [and every word has a scope, and every scope has] a place [meaning point] to which the knowledge thereof may ascend, (O, Ḳ, TA,) or, as some say, something that may be violated, God not having forbidden a thing that should be held sacred without his knowing that some one would seek to elicit it. (TA.)

And i. q. maOotFI; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) muT-alaEu AlOamori meaning maOotaAhu; (Ṣ, O, TA;) as also maTolaEu↓ AlOamori; (TA;) i. e. † The way, or manner, of attaining to the doing, or performing, of the affair. (TA.) One says, maAlihecaA AlOamori muT-alaEN † There is no way, or manner, of attaining to the doing, or performing, of this affair. (TA.) And Oayona muT-alaEu hecaA AlOamori i. e. maOotaAhu † [Where is the way of attaining to the doing, or performing, of this affair?]. (Ṣ, O, TA.)

And ‡ An elevated place from which one looks towards a low place. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) To this is likened the scene of the events of the world to come, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) after death, i. e. the station of the day of resurrection, (TA,) in the saying of ʼOmar, lawo Oan-a maA fiI AlOaroDi jamiyEFA laOafotadayotu bihi mino hawoli AlmuT-alaEi ‡ [If all that is in the world belonged to me, assuredly I would ransom myself therewith from the terror of the place whence one will look down on the day of resurrection]: (Ṣ,* O, Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA:) or AlmuT-alaE means that which is looked upon of such hardships as the interrogation of [the angels] Munkar and Nekeer, and the pressure of the grave, and its solitude, and the like; and is [for AlmuT-alaEi Ealayohi, or] originally an inf. n. in the sense of AlAiT-ilaAE: or it may be a noun of time, and thus applied to the day of resurrection. (Ḥar p. 344-5.)

muT-aliEN Strong, or powerful; high, or eminent; one who subdues, or overcomes: (Ḳ:) or strong, or powerful; as also muDoTaliEN: or the latter has this meaning, from AlD-alaAEapu; and the former signifies high, or eminent; one who subdues, or overcomes: (O:) accord. to ISk, one says, huwa muDoTaliEN biHamolihi [“he is one who has strength to bear it”]; but not muT-aliEN bHmlh. (TA.) [See, however, muDoTaliEN, in art. DlE.]

muTaAlaEN [pass. part. n. of 3, q. v.]. One says, AlXr tlqI muTaAlaEa AlAisomi, [thus in my original, app. AlX-ar-a taloqaI Alx,] meaning baArizFA makoXuwfFA [i. e., if I rightly read it, † Evil thou wilt find to be that whereof the name is manifest, or overt; so that, when it is mentioned, it is well known]. (TA.)

2. Tl-f Ealayohi, inf. n. taToliyfN; (O, Ḳ;) and Zl-f is a dial. var. thereof; (TA;) He exceeded it; (O, Ḳ;) [meaning a certain number of years; for] it is like car-afa and ram-ava and Tal-ava. (IAạr, TA in art. Zlf.)

hom.sense: 4. ATlf [He escaped being a victim of his adversary's blood-revenge; expl. as meaning] the blood-revenge of his adversary was ineffectual, or had not effect. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
ATlfhu He made it [i. e. a man's blood] to go for nothing [i. e. unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct]; or to be of no account. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And He gave him (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) a thing (O) as a free gift. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: TalofN: see the next paragraph in two places.

TalafN A thing that goes for nothing; [as blood that is unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct;] that is of no account, ineffectual, or null; syn. hadarN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) [and so TalofN↓, as shown by what follows;] as also TaliyfN↓. (O, Ḳ.) You say, cahaba damuhu TalafFA, (AA, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and TalofFA↓, (AA, O, Ḳ,) and ZalafFA and ZalofFA, (AA, O,) His blood went for nothing; as a thing of no account; ineffectually; or in vain; unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct; syn. hadarFA, (AA, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and baATilFA: and in like manner, maAluhu [his property]. (TA. [See also talafN.]) And Ru-beh says,
kamo mino EidFI OamowaAluhumo Taliyfu↓
[How many enemies are there whose possessions are things that have gone for nought!]. (O, as an ex. of the last word in the sense of hadar.)
And (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) hence (O) A gift; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) a gift freely bestowed, not for any compensation. (Ṣ, TA.)
And A thing that is easy; or of light estimation, paltry, or despicable; [as also ZalafN;] syn. hay-inN. (IF, O, Ḳ.)
And A redundant portion of a thing: (IF, O, Ḳ:) if this be not what is meant by the saying that TalafN is syn. with faDolN, this saying is of no account. (IF, O.)
TaliyfN: see TalafN, in two places.
Also A thing that is taken. (O, Ḳ.*) [And hence, perhaps, the saying of Ru-beh cited above.]
One says also, cahaba fulaAnN biAlmaAli TaliyfFA and ZaliyfFA i. e. Such a one went away with the property without compensation. (Yoo, O.)
And Oakala maAlahu fiI Taliyf He devoured his property in a vain, or an ineffectual, procedure. (O.)

hom.sense: 1. Talaqati Aln-aAqapu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaToluqu}, inf. n. TuluwqN, (Mṣb,) The she-camel was, or became, loosed from her bond, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) or cord, by which her fore shank and her arm had been bound together. (Ṣ, Mgh.) And Talaqati Aln-aAqapu UilaI AlmaMCi [The she-camel was, or became, loosed from her bond to repair to the water]: (Mṣb:) or Talaqati AlUibilu (AZ, Aṣ, Ṣ, TA) UilaI AlmaMCi, (AZ, TA,) aor. as above, (Aṣ, TA,) inf. n. TaloqN (AZ, Aṣ, Ṣ, TA) and TuluwqN, (AZ, Ṣ, TA,) the camels were, or became, loosed to repair to the water, it being distant two days' journeys, (AZ, Aṣ, Ṣ, TA,) and were left to pasture while going thither: and the subst. is TalaqN [q. v.]. (AZ, Ṣ, TA.)

[Hence,] Talaqato, (IAạr, Th, Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb,) or Talaqato mino zawojihaA, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaToluqu}; (Th, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Taluqato also; (IAạr, Th, Mgh, Mṣb;) the latter of which is preferable, but the former is allowable; (IAạr, TA;) or the latter is the more common; (Th, TA;) but accord. to to Akh, the latter is not allowable; (Ṣ, O, TA;) inf. n. TalaAqN, (Th, Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ,) or [properly TaloqN, for it is said that] TalaAqN is the subst., (Mṣb,) [or] TalaAqN is also a subst. syn. with taToliyqN, [as will be expl. below,] as well as inf. n. of Taluqato and Talaqato; (Mgh;) said of a woman; (IAạr, Th, Ṣ, &c.;) ‡ She was, or became, [divorced, or] left to go her way, (O,) or separated from her husband [by a sentence of divorce]. (Ḳ, TA.)
And Taluqa lisaAnuhu, inf. n. TuluwqN and TuluwqapN, † His tongue was, or became, eloquent, or chaste in speech, and sweet therein. (Mṣb. [See also TaloqN: and see 7.])

And Taluqa, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. TalaAqapN, (Ṣ, O,) or TuluwqapN and TuluwqN, (TA,) ‡ He was, or became, laughing, or happy, or cheerful, and bright, (Ḳ, TA,) in face, or countenance: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) or, inf. n. TalaAqapN, † it (the face, or countenance,) was, or became, cheerful, or happy, (MA, Mṣb,) the contr. of frowning or contracted, (Mgh,) displaying openness and pleasantness; (Mṣb;) and tTl-q↓ signifies the same; (MA, Mgh;) as also AnTlq↓; (Mgh;) syn. AnbsT; (Ḳ;) whence the saying, yanobagiI liloqaADiI Oano yunoSifa AlxaSomayoni walaA yanoTaliqu↓ bwajohihi UilaI OaHadihimaA, meaning † [It behooves the judge to treat with equity the two adversaries in litigation, and] he shall not speak to one of them with a cheerful countenance (biwajohK TaloqK) and with sweet speech, not doing this to the other: or it may be from AlAinoTilaAqu signifying “the going away,” and may hence mean, and he shall not turn his face, or pay regard, to one of them [in preference to the other]. (Mgh.)
Taliqa, (O, Ḳ,) with kesr, (O,) like samiEa, (Ḳ,) signifies tabaAEida [He, or it, was, or became, distant, or remote;, &c.]. (O, Ḳ.)
TaloqN is also trans., syn. with OaTolaqa: see the latter verb, former half, in two places.

[Hence,] Tuliqato, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. tuTolaqu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. TaloqN, (Ṣ, Mgh,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) and inf. n. un. TaloqapN, (TA,) † She (a woman, Ṣ, O, Mṣb) was taken with the pains of parturition: (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) a phrase implying a presage of good [i. e. of speedy and safe delivery]. (Mgh.) [And Tuliqato bihi † She was, or became, in labour with him.]

entry.sense: 2. Tl-q naAqatahu He left, left alone, or let go, his she-camel. (TA.) See also 4, second sentence.

[Hence,] Tl-q QmoraOatahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taToliyqN, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb,) from TalaAqN [q. v.]; (O;) and ATlqhA↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UiTolaAqN; (TA;) ‡ [He divorced his wife;] he separated his wife from himself [by a sentence of divorce]. (Ḳ, TA.) [Tl-q in this sense is opposed to raAjaEa: and hence the meanings of these two verbs in a verse of En-Nábighah which I have cited in art. ncr, (see conj. 6 in that art.,) and which is also cited in the Ṣ and O and TA in the present art.]

And Tl-q AlbilaAda ‡ He left, or quitted, the country. (IAạr, TA.) El-'Okeylee, being asked by Ks, OaTal-aqota QmoraOataka [Hast thou quitted thy wife?], answered, naEamo waAlOaroDa mino waraAYihaA † [Yes, and the land behind her]. (IAạr, TA.) And one says, Tal-aqotu Alqawoma † I left, or quitted, the people, or party: and Tl-q AlEiyaAla † He left [or deserted] the household, like as the man leaves [or divorces] the woman, or wife. (TA.) And Tl-q AlEayoru EaAnatahu † The he-ass passed by, or beyond, his she-ass, and then left her: and Tal-aqatohu AlEaAnapu † The she-ass submitted herself [the verb which I thus render has been altered to Anqdt, for which I read QnoqaAdato,] to him, after having been incompliant. (TA.)

And Tul-iqa Als-aliymu † The person bitten by a serpent became rid of the pain: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or recovered himself, and his pain became allayed, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) after the paroxysm: (Ṣ, O:) inf. n. as above. (Ḳ.)
Tal-aqa naxolahu: see 4, last sentence.

4. AlUiTolaAqu signifies The loosing, or setting loose or free, and letting go. (TA.) You say, ATlq Aln-aAqapa mino EiqaAlihaA, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA,) or mina AlEiqaAli, i. e. He loosed the she-camel from the bond, or cord, by which her fore shank and arm were bound together; (Mgh;) as also Tl-qhA↓. (TA.) And ATlq AlOasiyra, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) and ATlq Eanohu, (O, TA,) He let go the captive; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) and set him free; (TA;) he loosed the bond of the captive, and let him go: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and OuToliqa Eanohu UisaAruhu [His bond was loosed from him], namely, the captive. (Ṣ.) And ATlq xayolahu fiI AlHalobapi He made his horses to run [in the race-ground]. (TA.) And ATlq Aln-aAqapa He drove the she-camel to the water: (TA:) or OaTolaqotu Aln-aAqapa UilaI AlmaMCi [I loosed the she-camel from her bond to repair to the water]: (Mṣb:) or OaTolaqotu AlUibila (AZ, Ṣ, O, TA) UilaI AlmaMCi (AZ, Ṣ,* TA) I loosed the camels to repair to the water, it being distant two days' journeys, and left them to pasture while going thither. (AZ, Ṣ, O,* TA.) And ATlq Alqawomu means The people, or party, had their camels loosed to repair to the water, it being distant two days' journeys, and the camels being left to pasture while going thither. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.)
ATlq QmoraOatahu: see 2, third sentence.
ATlq Ald-awaMCu baTonahu The medicine loosened, or relaxed, his belly [or bowels]; (Mṣb;) or moved his belly. (TA.)

[ATlq EinaAnahu He let loose, or slackened, his (a horse's) rein; and so † made him to quicken his pace. (See Ḥar p. 356.)] And ATlq rijolahu † He hastened him; or desired, or required, him to hasten, or be quick; as also AstTlqhu↓. (TA. [Whether the pronoun relate to a beast or a man is not shown. By AstTlqh is not meant AstTlq rijolahu as rijol is fem.])

ATlq yadahu bixayori (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) and fiI xayorK, and bimaAlK and fiI maAlK; (TA;) and TalaqahaA↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaToluqu}, (Ṣ,) or _i, (Ḳ,) but expressly said in the Ṣ to be with damm, inf. n. TaloqN; (TA;) † He opened his hand [freely] with good, (Ḳ, TA,) and with property. (TA.) And ATlq lahu maAlFA † He gave him property: (MA:) and Talaqa↓ † he gave (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ) a thing. (Ḳ.) And ATlq SaAHibu Ald-ayoni kacaM † [The creditor remitted so much of the debt; being asked, or desired, to do so: see 10]. (Mṣb.)

[ATlqh also signifies † He made it allowable, or free, to be done, or taken, &c.] You say, ATlq lahu fiEola kacaA † He permitted him, or gave him permission or leave, to do such a thing; i. q. Oacina lahu fiyhi. (Mṣb in art. Acn.)

[And † He made it to be unrestricted. Hence the saying, ATlq bihimu Als-ayofa † He made the sword to have unrestricted scope with them; i. e. he slew them without restriction.] And OaTolaqotu Albay-inapa † I made the evidence, proof, or voucher, to be without any mention of the date; contr. of Oar-axotuhaA; (Mṣb in art. Arx;) or I gave the evidence without restricting it by a date: from OaTolaqotu AlOasiyra. (Mṣb in the present art.) And hence also OaTolaqotu Alqawola † I made the saying to be unrestricted, and unconditional. (Mṣb.) [And ATlq lafoZFA † He uttered, or mentioned, or used, a word, or an expression, without restriction: and in like manner, ATlq alone is often employed. And † He used, or applied, a word, or an expression, without restriction, EalaI maEonFI to signify a particular meaning: thus in the saying ATlq AlmaSodara EalaI AlfaAEili † He used, or applied, the infinitive noun without restricting it by the prefix cuw, or the like, to signify the active participial noun; as EadolFA to signify EaAdilFA: and thus in the saying ATlq Qsoma EalaI AljuzoCi † He used, or applied, the name of the whole without restricting it by a prefix to signify the part; as AlquroMn to signify AllMyap: and many similar exs. might be added: but this usage of the verb is conventional: see Kull p. 57. Hence also Oalifu AlUiTolaAqi: see art. A, p. 1, col. 3.]

AlUiTolaAqu fiI AlqaAYimapi [in which AlATlAq is inf. n. of the pass. v., OuToliqa,] is † The freedom from [the whiteness termed] waDaH [meaning taHojiyl, q. v.,] in the leg [of a horse]: and some make AlUiTolaAq to signify the having a fore leg and a hind leg in one side with tHjyl; and AlUimosaAku [as inf. n. of Oumosika], the having a fore leg and a hind leg without tHjyl. (TA.)
ATlq Eaduw-ahu † He dosed his enemy with poison. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
And ATlq nxolahu ‡ He fecundated his palm-trees; (IAạr, O, Ḳ, TA;) said when they are tall; (IAạr, O, TA;) as also Tl-qhu↓, (IAạr, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. taToliyqN. (Ḳ.)

5. tTl-q, said of a gazelle, He went along, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or bounded in his running, or ran briskly in one direction, (Aisotan-a fiI Eadowihi,) and went along, (TA,) not pausing nor waiting for anything; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also AstTlq↓. (TA.) And tTl-qt Alxayolu The horses went [or ran] a heat without restraining themselves, to the goal. (TA.)
And, said of a horse, ‡ He staled after running. (AO, O, Ḳ.)
Said of the face: see 1, latter half.

7. AnTlq, inf. n. AinoTilaAqN, of which the dim. is nuTayoliyqN↓, the conjunctive A being rejected, so that it becomes niTolaAqN, (Ṣ, O,) [He was, or became, loosed from his bond: whence,] AinoTilaAqu AlEinaAni [The rein's being let loose, or slackened,] is a phrase metonymically used to denote quickness in going along. (Ḥar pp. 355-6.)

[Hence,] † He (a captive loosed from his bond) went his way: (Mṣb:) or [simply] he went away, or departed: (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ:) or he went removing from his place. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Thus in the Ḳur [lxxvii. 29], AinoTaliquwA UilI maA kunotumo bihi tukac-ibuwna † [Depart ye to that in which ye disbelieved]; (TA;) meaning to the punishment: (Bḍ, Jel:) or, accord. to IAth, [it seems to mean go ye away quickly into the lowest depth of misery or affliction; for he says, app. in explanation of this verse of the Ḳur, that] AlAinoTilaAqu means suroEapu Alc-ahaAbi fiI OaSoli AlmiHonapi. (TA.) And one says also, AnTlq yafoEalu kacaA ‡ He went away doing, or to do, such a thing. (TA.) waQnoTalaqa QlomalaOu minohumo Oani QmoXuwA [in the Ḳur xxxviii. 5 may be expl. in a similar manner; Oan being here used in the place of yaquwluwna: or this] means [And the chief persons of them] broke forth, or launched forth, with their tongues, [saying,] Go ye on, or continue ye, in your course of action, &c. (Mughnee, voce Oano.) And one says, AunoTuliqa bihi, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) meaning He, or it, was taken away; (Ḳ;) like as one says, AunoquTiEa bihi. (Ṣ, O.)
[AnTlq lisaAnuhu means † His tongue was, or became, free from impediment; and hence, eloquent, or chaste in speech. See an ex. in the Ḳur xxvi. 12: and see also Taluqa lisaAnuhu.]
AnTlq said of the face: see 1, latter half, in two places.

8. maA taT-aliqu nafosiI lihecaA AlOamori, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,*) of the measure tafotaEilu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. AiT-ilaAqN, of which the dim. is TutayoliyqN↓, the [latter] T being changed [back] into t because the former T becomes movent, (Ṣ, O,) † My mind does not become free from straitness [for, or with respect to, this thing, or affair]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.*)

hom.sense: 10. AisotiTlaAqN [primarily signifies The desiring to be loosed, unbound, set loose or free, and let go]: its dim. is tuTayoliyqN↓. (Ṣ, O.)
[Hence,] AstTlq baTonuhu † His belly [or bowels] became [unbound,] loosened, or relaxed; (Mṣb, TA;) or became moved; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) and the contents thereof came forth. (TA.)
Said of a gazelle, i. q. tTl-q, q. v. (TA.)
[It is also trans., as such primarily signifying The desiring a person or thing to be loosed, unbound, set loose or free, and let go.]

[Hence,] one says, AstTlq Alr-aAEiI naAqapF linafosihi (Ṣ, O) [meaning The pastor desired a she-camel to be left, or he left a she-camel, for himself, not milking her at the water; as is plainly indicated by what immediately precedes it in the Ṣ: or] the pastor took, (PṢ,) or retained, [which is virtually the same,] a she-camel for himself. (PṢ, TA.)
And AisotaTolaqotu mino SaAHibi Ald-ayoni kacaA † [I desired. or demanded, of the creditor, the remission of so much of the debt]. (Mṣb.)
See also 4, former half.

TaloqN [Loosed from his bond, set loose or free, or], as expl. by IAạr, let go; as also TaliyqN↓ and muTolaqN↓: and a man not having anything upon him, as expl. by Ks: and Taloqu Alyadayoni a camel not having the fore legs bound. (TA.) You say, Hubisa TaloqFA, (so in the CK,) or TalaqFA↓, (Ḳ accord. to the TA, [and this is agreeable with the preceding context in the Ḳ, but it requires confirmation which I do not find,]) and with damm, [i. e. TuloqFA,] accord. to the Ḳ, but correctly with two dammehs, [i. e. TuluqFA↓,] (TA, and thus in the Ṣ,) He was imprisoned without shackle and without bond. (Ḳ, TA) See also TuluqN, first sentence.

[Hence,] Taloqu All-isaAni, and Taliyqu↓ AllsAn, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Tiloqu↓ AllsAn, (Ḳ,) and Tulaqu↓ AllsAn, (TA,) ‡ Eloquent, or chaste, in speech, and sweet therein: (Mṣb:) and munoTaliqu↓ All-isaAni and mutaTal-iquhu↓ ‡ [free from impediment of the tongue; or] eloquent, or chaste in speech. (TA.) And lisaAnN TaloqN caloqN, and TaliyqN↓ caliyqN, and TuluqN↓ culuqN, and TulaqN↓ culaqN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) but the last two of these were unknown to Aṣ, and the latter of them was disallowed by IAạr, (TA,) and TaliqN↓ caliqN, (O, Ḳ,) [expl. in the Ḳ as meaning A tongue having sharpness; but correctly] meaning ‡ a tongue free from impediment, or eloquent, or chaste in speech, (cuw QnoTilaAqK,) and sharp. (O, TA.)

And Taloqu Alyadayoni, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Tuluqu↓ Alydyn, (O, Ḳ,) and Tuloqu↓ Alydyn, (O, TA,) and Taliyqu↓ Alydyn, (L, TA,) ‡ Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) applied to a man: (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb:) and in like manner, a woman: (TA:) [or] a woman is termed Taloqapu Alyadayoni: (Ṣ:) and so, accord to AZ, Taloqu Alwajohi; which [generally] has another meaning, expl. in what follows. (TA.) And yaduhu TaloqN ‡ His hand is liberal; syn. bisoTN; (TA in art. bsT;) and so muTolaqapN↓: (Ṣ and Ḳ and TA in that art.:) or the latter signifies opened; and so maToluwqapN↓. (TA in the present art.)

And Taloqu Alwajohi, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Tiloqu↓ Alwjh, (IAạr, O, Ḳ,) and Tuloqu↓ Alwjh, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and Taliqu↓ Alwjh, (Ḳ,) and Taliyqu↓ Alwjh, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) ‡ Laughing, or happy, or cheerful, and bright, in the face, or countenance: (Ḳ, TA:) or cheerful, or happy, displaying openness and pleasantness, in the face; and so TaloqN alone: (Mṣb:) and Taliyqu↓ Alwjh open and pleasant, and goodly, in countenance: (AZ, TA:)
and TaliyqN alone, joyful, and open or cheerful, in countenance. (TA. [And it is there said that the pl. of TaloqN is TaloqaAt: but this is app. a mistranscription for TuloqaAnN or TiloqaAnN.]) OuwojuhN TawaAliqu↓ is not allowable, except in poetry. (IAạr, TA.)

And yawomN TaloqN, (Lth, Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ,) and layolapN TaloqapN (Lth, Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TaloqN, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) ‡ A day, and a night, in which is neither heat nor cold: (Lth, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or in which is no cold nor anything hurtful: (Ṣ:) or in which is no rain: or in which is no wind: or in which the cold is mild: (TA: [after which is added, mn AyAm TaloqAt: but the last word seems, as in an instance before mentioned, to be mistranscribed, or AyAm (i. e. Oay-aAm) may be a mistake for layaAlK:]) or layolapN TaloqN means a night in which is no cold: (AA, TA:) or in which the wind is still: (O, TA:) and layolapN TaloqapN sometimes means a moon-lit, or a light, or bright, night: (IDrd, O, TA:) and one says also layolapN TaAliqapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) meaning a still, or calm, and light, or bright, night: (TA:) and layaAlK TawaAliqu↓, (Ḳ,* TA,) meaning pleasant nights in which is neither heat nor cold. (TA.) Er-Rá'ee says,
falam-aA Ealatohu AlX-amosu fiI yawomi TaloqapK
meaning yawomi layolapK TaloqapK [And when the sun came upon him, or it,] in a day of a night in which was neither cold nor wind; i. e., in a day after such a night; for the Arabs commence with the night, before the day: and the phrase fiI yawomi TaloqapK occurs in like manner in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh. (Az, TA.)
For the epithet Taloqu Alyadi AlyumonaI, (applied to a horse, accord. to the Ḳ,) see TuluqN.
And for other meanings assigned in the Ḳ to TaloqN, see TuluqN, in two places.
TaloqN signifies also The pain of childbirth. (Ṣ, O.) One says, DarabahaA AlT-aloqu [The pain of childbirth smote her]. (O.) [See also Tuliqat, of which it is the inf. n.]
And [it is said to signify] A sort of medicine. (Ṣ.) See TalaqN, latter half, in two places.

entry.sense: Tuloqu Alyadayoni:
and Tuloqu Alwajohi: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: Tiloqu All-isaAni:
and Tiloqu Alwajohi: see TaloqN.

TiloqN signifies also ‡ Lawful, allowable, or free: (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) or it signifies, (Mṣb, TA,) or signifies also, (Mgh,) muTolaqN↓, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) [i. e.] a thing unrestricted, (TA,) i. e. any affair in which one has power, or authority, to act according to his own judgment or discretion or free will. (Mṣb.) One says, hecaA HalaAlN TiloqN ‡ [This is lawful,, &c., unrestricted; using the latter epithet as a corroborative]: and [in the contr. case] HaraAmN giloqN. (TA.) And huwa laka TiloqFA ‡ [It is thine lawfully, &c.]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.) And AifoEalo hecaA TiloqFA laka † Do thou this as a thing lawful, &c. to thee. (Mṣb.) And OaEoTayotuhu mino Tiloqi maAliI † I gave him of what was lawful, &c., i. e. free to be disposed of by me, of my property: (Mṣb:) or ‡ of what was clear [from any claim or the like], and good, or lawful, of my property. (TA.) And Alxayolu TiloqN, occurring in a trad. as meaning ‡ Horses are allowable to be betted upon. (TA.) And Oanota TiloqN mino hecaA AlOamori ‡ Thou art clear of this affair; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,* TA;*) quit of it, or irresponsible for it. (Ḳ, TA.)
[In consequence of a misplacement in some copies of the Ḳ, several meanings belonging to TalaqN are assigned to TiloqN.]
See also TalaqN, latter half.
TalaqN: see TaloqN, second sentence.

Also the subst. from Talaqati AlUibilu: (AZ, Ṣ, TA: [see 1, second sentence:]) and [as such] signifying The journeying [of camels] during the night to arrive at the water in the next night, there being two nights between them and the water; the first of which nights is termed AlT-alaqu [or layolapu AlT-alaqi (see HawozN)]; the pastor loosing them to repair to the water, [in the CK yajolibuhA is put for yuxal-iyhaA,] and leaving them to pasture while going thither: the camels after the driving, during the first night, are said to be TawaAliqu↓; and in the second night, qawaAribu: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) or AlT-alaqu signifies the first of two days intervening between the camels and the water; and Alqarabu, the second: and layolapu AlT-alaqi, the night in which the faces of the camels are turned towards the water and during which they are left to pasture; and layolapu Alqarabi, the second night: (Aṣ, TA:) but it has been said that layolapu AlT-alaqi means the second of the nights in which the camels repair to the water: Th says that AlT-alaqu signifies the second of two days during which the camels seek the water when it is two days distant from them; and Alqarabu, the first of those days: and it is said that layolapu AlT-alaqi means [the night of] the turning of the faces of the camels towards the water: but this explanation was not pleasing to ISd. (TA.) [See an ex. voce HawozN, in which it is used tropically.]

Also A heat; i. e. a single run, or run at once, to a goal, or limit; syn. XawoTN; (Ṣ, IAth, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) meaning a running, of a horse, without restraining himself, [or without stopping,] to a goal, or limit: (Mṣb:) and the utmost extent to which a horse runs. (TA.) One says of a horse, EadaA TalaqFA or Talaqayoni [He ran a heat or two heats]. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ. [In the CK, erroneously, TaloqFA and Taloqayoni.])
And (hence, TA) ‡ A share, or portion, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, A, O, Ḳ, TA,) of property [&c.]. (A, TA.)
Also A shackle, or pair of shackles, (qayodN,) of skins: (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ, TA:) or a rope strongly twisted, so that it will stand up. (TA.)

And sing. of OaTolaAqN which signifies The [intestines into which the food passes from the stomach, termed the] OamoEaMC, or the OaqotaAb of the belly; (IDrd, O, Ḳ;* [in some copies of the last of which, Alqunobu is erroneously put for Alqitobu as one of the words explaining AlT-alaqu;]) so in one or more of the dialects: AO says, in the belly are OaTolaAq, of which the sing. is TalaqN; (O, TA;) meaning the lines, or streaks, (TaraAYiq,) of the belly: and Talaqu AlbaToni is also expl. [in like manner] as meaning the jud-ap of the belly; pl. as above. (TA.)

Also The [plant called] Xuborum: [but what plant is meant by this is doubtful:] or a plant that is used in dyes: or this is a mistake: (Ḳ:) [or] accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, AlT-aloqu↓ is what is used in dyes; and is said to be the Xuborum: (O, TA:*) and (Ḳ) accord. to Aṣ, (O,) TalaqN signifies a sort of medicament, (O, Ḳ,) which, when one is anointed therewith, (Ḳ,) i. e. with the extract thereof, (TA,) prevents the burning of fire: (Ḳ:) or a species of plant: so says Aṣ: (O:) the appellation by which it is generally known is Taloq↓, with the l quiescent; (O, Ḳ;) or this pronunciation is incorrect: (Ḳ:) and AḤát mentions, (Ḳ, TA,) on the authority of Aṣ, (TA,) its being termed TiloqN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) but it is not a plant: it is of the nature of stones, and of [what are termed] lixaAf [thin white stones]; and probably he [referring to Aṣ] heard that it is called kawokabu AlOaroDi, and therefore supposed it to be a plant; for if it were a plant, fire would burn it; but fire does not burn it, unless by means of artful contrivances: (O, TA:) the word is arabicized, from talako: (Ḳ, TA: in the O written tilk:) [it is the well-known mineral termed talc:] the Ra-ees [Ibn-Seenà, whom we call “Avicenna,”] says, (TA,) it is a brightlyshining stone, that separates, when it is bruised, into several laminæ and split pieces, of which are made maDaAwiI [correctly maDaAwiY, meaning small circular panes which are inserted in apertures to admit light,] for the [cupolas of] hot baths, instead of glass: the best is that of El-Yemen; then that of India; then that of El-Undulus [or El-Andalus]: the art employed in dissolving it consists in putting it into a piece of rag with some pebbles and immersing it in tepid water, then moving it about gently until it becomes dissolved and comes forth from the piece of rag into the water, whereupon the water is strained from it, and it is put in the sun to dry. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: TaliqN caliqN:
and Taliqu Alwajohi: see TaloqN.
Tulaqu All-isaAni: and lisaAnN TulaqN culaqN: see TaloqN.

TuluqN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA,) with two dammehs, (Mṣb, TA,) or TaloqN↓, (Ḳ,) but this requires consideration, (TA,) Not shackled; applied to a she-camel, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA,) and to a he-camel, (Ṣ, O, TA,) and to a person imprisoned; (O, TA;) as also TaAliqN↓ applied to a she-camel; but TuluqN is more common: (Aboo-Naṣr, TA:) the pl. of TuluqN is OaTolaAqN. (Ṣ, TA.) See also TaloqN, second sentence.
[Hence,] lisaAnN TuluqN culuqN:
and Tuluqu Alyadayon: see TaloqN again.

And Tuluqu UiHodaI AalqawaAYimi † A horse having one of the legs without [the whiteness termed] Alt-aHojiyl. (Ṣ.) And Tuluqu Alyadi AlyumonaI, (O,) or Tuloqu↓ Alyd AlymnI, (Ḳ, [in this case again deviating from other authorities,]) ‡ A horse without taHojiyl in the right fore leg; (TA;) i. q. muTolaqu↓ Alyd AlymnI. (O, Ḳ, TA.) And muTolaqa↓ Alyadayoni † A horse having the fore legs free from tHjyl. (Mṣb.)

[As an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] TuluqN, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O,) or TaloqN↓, (Ḳ, [but this, as in the instances above, is questionable,]) signifies † A gazelle: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:) so called because of the quickness of its running: (O,* TA:) pl. OaTolaAqN. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
And † A dog of the chase: (Ḳ:) because he is let loose; or because of the quickness of his running at the chase: (TA:) OaTolaAqN is mentioned by Ibn-ʼAbbád as signifying dogs of the chase. (O.)
TaloqapN [A single divorce: used in this sense in law-books]. (T and Mṣb in art. bt, &c.)
TulaqapN: see miTolaAqN.

TalaAqN is the inf. n. of Talaqat said of a woman: (Th, Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ:) or the subst. therefrom: (Mṣb:) or [rather] it is also a subst. in the sense of taToliyqN; (Mgh;) [whence,] TalaAqu AlmaroOapi signifies † The letting the wife go her way: (Lth, O:) and it has two meanings: one is [the divorcing of the woman; i. e.] the dissolving of the wife's marriage-tie: and the other is the leaving, and dismissing, of the wife [either in an absolute sense or as is done by a single sentence of divorce]. (O, TA.) Some of the lawyers hold that the free woman whose husband is a slave is not separated but by three [sentences, as is the case when both husband and wife are free]; and the female slave whose husband is free, by two: some, that the wife in the former case is separated by two [sentences]; and in the latter case, by not less than three: and some, that when the husband is a slave and the wife is free, or the reverse, or when both are slaves, the wife is separated by two [sentences]. (TA.)
TaliyqN A captive having his bond loosed from him, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and let go. (TA.) See also TaloqN, first sentence.
And † A man freed from slavery; emancipated; i. q. EatiyqN; i. e. who has become free: pl. TulaqaMCu. (TA.)

It is said in a trad., AlT-ulaqaMCu mino qurayoXK waAlEutaqaMCu mino vaqiyfK † [The TulaqaMC are of Kureysh; and the EutaqaMC, of Thakeef]: AlTlqAC being app. applied to Kureysh as it has a more special signification than AlEtqAC: but accord. to Th, AlT-ulaqaMCu signifies those who have been brought within the pale of El-Islám against their will. (TA.)
Taliyqu All-isaAni: and lisaAnN TaliyqN caliyqN:
and Taliyqu Alyadayoni:
and Taliyqu Alwajohi: see TaloqN again; the last in two places.
Taliyqu AlUilehi means ‡ The wind. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
Tal-aAqN: see miTolaAqN.
Til-iyqN: see miTolaAqN.

TaAliqN A she-camel not having having her fore shank and her arm bound together: (TA:) or not having upon her a xiTaAm [or halter]: (IDrd, O, Ḳ:) or repairing to the water; and so miTolaAqN↓; (Aboo-Naṣr, Ḳ, TA;) of which latter she pl. is maTaAliyqu: (TA:) or that is left a day and a night and then milked: (Ḳ:) pl. TawaAliqu and OaTolaAqN and TalaqapN; which last is expl. by AA as meaning she-camels that are milked in the place of pasturing. (TA.) See also TuluqN, first sentence: and for an explanation of the pl. TawaAliqu applied to camels, see TalaqN, second sentence. Also (O), TaAliqN, (Ṣ, O,) or TaAliqapN, (Ḳ,) signifies A she-camel which the pastor leaves for himself, not milking her at the water: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) the former is expl. by Esh-Sheybánee as meaning one which the pastor leaves [with her udder bound] with her SiraAr, not milking her in the place where she lies down to rest: (TA:) or the latter signifies, (Lth, O, Ḳ,) and the former also, (Lth, O,) a she-camel that is set loose among the tribe to pasture where she will in any part of the tract adjacent to their place of alighting or abode, (Lth, O, Ḳ, [mn jinAnihimo in the CK being erroneously put for mino janaAbihimo,]) that has not her fore shank and her arm bound together when she returns in the afternoon or evening, nor is turned away [from the others] in the place of pasturage: (Lth, O:) or TaAliqN signifies a she-camel, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and a ewe, (Ṣ,) that is set loose, or dismissed, to pasture where she will: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and also as first expl. in this sentence: (Ṣ:) it is mentioned by El-Fárábee as signifying a ewe left to pasture by herself, alone. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] TaAliqN and TaAliqapN, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former, without p, used by all, (Mṣb,) the latter occurring in a verse of El-Aạshà, (Ṣ, Mgh,* O, Mṣb,) ending a hemistich, and pronounced TaAliqapN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, [which cite the verse somewhat differently,]) ‡ A woman [divorced, or] left to go her way, (Ṣ,* Mgh,* O, Mṣb,*) or separated from her husband [by a sentence of divorce]: (Ṣ,* Mgh,* Mgh,* Ḳ, TA:) both mentioned by Akh: (O, TA:) accord. to IAmb, one says TaAliqN only, because it applies only to a female: accord. to Lth and IF, TaAliqapN means TaAliqapN gadFA [divorced,, &c., to-morrow]; and Lth adds that it is thus to accord with its verb, Talaqato: some, however, say that the h is affixed in the verse of El-Aạshà by poetic license, to complete the hemistich; but an Arab of the desert, in reciting this verse to Aṣ, is related to have said TaAliqN [which equally completes the hemistich]: and the Basrees hold that the sign of the fem. gender is elided in TaAliqN because it is a possessive epithet, meaning caAtu TalaAqK [having divorce]. (Mṣb.)
OuwojuhN TawaAliqu:
and layolapN TaAliqapN and layaAlK TawaAliqu: see TaloqN, latter half.
TutayoliyqN dim. of AiT-ilaAqN. (Ṣ, O.) See 8.
tuTayoliyqN dim. of AisotiTolaAqN. (Ṣ, O.) See 10.

hom.sense: muTolaqN: see TaloqN, first sentence.
[Hence,] yaduhu muTolaqapN: see TaloqN again, former half.

See also maMCN muTolaqN TiloqN. means † Water that is unrestricted. (TA.) And HukomN muTolaqN means † [A judicial decision, or an ordinance or the like, or a rule, that is unrestricted, or absolute, or] in which is no exception. (TA.)
muTolaqu Alyadi AlyumonaI: and muTolaqa Alyadayoni: each applied to a horse: see TuluqN.

[Golius, as on the authority of Meyd, explains it as signifying also A place where horses meet to be sent forth to run, or race: but what here next follows inclines me to think that it may be correctly muTal-aqN.]

entry.sense: muTal-iqN One desiring to outstrip with his horse in a race. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: miTolaAqN: see TaAliqN.

Also, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and miToliyqN↓, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and TulaqapN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and Til-iyqN↓, (Ḳ,) and Tal-aAqN↓, this last mentioned by Z, (TA,) ‡ One who oftentimes divorces, or dismisses, wives. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: miToliyqN: see what next precedes.
maToluwqapN: see TaloqN.
AimoraOapN maToluwqapN † A woman taken with the pains of parturition. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
muTayoliqN and muTayoliyqN dims. of munoTaliqN. (Ṣ.)
mutaTal-iqu All-isaAni: see TaloqN, former half.
munoTaliqu All-isaAni: see TaloqN, former half.
nuTayoliyqN: dim. of AinoTilaAqN. (Ṣ, O.) See 7.
1. Talama Alxubozapa, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaTolumu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. TalomN, (TA,) He made the cake of bread even, or equable. (Ḳ.)

2. Tl-m, inf. n. taToliymN, He beat a cake of bread baked in hot ashes with his hand, (Ḳ, TA) in order that it might become cool. (TA.) Hence the saying of Hassán.
taZal-u jiyaAdunaA mutamaT-iraAtK
yuTal-imuhun-a biAlxumuri Aln-isaMCu : (Ḳ,* TA:) or, as some relate it, yulaT-imuhun-a; but this is weak, or repudiated: (Ḳ:) or this is the correct reading, and the more obviously appropriate in meaning, accord. to MF; and accord. to IAth, it is the reading commonly known, and the same as the former in meaning: (TA:) the meaning is, [Our coursers passing the day running like the pouring of rain,] the women wiping the sweat from them with the mufflers: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as some say, [the women with the mufflers] beating them with the hands in removing the dust that was upon them. (TA.)
TulomN A table upon which the bread is expanded [previously to the baking]. (Ḳ.)
TalamN Dirt of the teeth in consequence of neglect [of the use] of the siwaAk [or tooth-stick]. (Ḳ.)

TulomapN A xubozap, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) [i. e. a cake of bread, or lump of dough,] baked in hot ashes in a hollow in the ground; what people [now] call a mal-ap; but this is the name of the hollow itself: what is baked in this is [properly called] the Tulomap and xubozap and maliyl: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. TulamN. (L, TA.)
It is said in a prov., Uin-a duwna AlT-alomapi xaroTa qataAdi huwobara (Meyd, TA) [i. e. Before the attainment of the cake of bread baked in hot ashes is the stripping of the leaves, by grasping each branch and drawing the hand down it, of the tragacanth of Howbar]: the Tulomap is the cake of bread that is put in hot ashes; and Howbar is a place abounding with the tragacanth: the prov. is applied in relation to a thing that is unattainable. (Meyd.)
Tul-aAmN The [tree called] tan-uwm [q. v.]; which is [erroneously said to be] hemp-seed (Hab-u AlX-ahodaAniji). (Ḳ.)
miTolamapN The implement with which bread is expanded. (KL.)

hom.sense: 1. Talawotu AlT-laA, (Ṣ, TA,) or AlT-aliI-a, aor. OaToluw; (TA;) and Talayotuhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) aor. OaToliI, inf. n. TaloIN; (TA;) I tied the young lamb or kid, (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) by its leg, (Ṣ, TA,) to a peg, or stake; (TA;) and confined, restrained, or withheld, it. (Ṣ.) And Talayotu AlX-aIoCa I confined, restrained, or withheld, the thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.)

Talayotuhu bihi, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. OaToliI, (Mṣb,) inf. n. TaloIN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) I daubed, bedaubed, smeared, or besmeared, it; (Mgh;) [rubbed, or did, it over; anointed, painted, varnished, plastered, coated, overspread, or overlaid, it; with it; i. e. with any fluid, semifluid, liniment, unguent, or the like; as, for instance,] with oil, (Ṣ,) or tar, (Mgh,) or clay, or mud, (Mṣb,), &c. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.) You say, TalaI AlbaEiyra AlhinaMCa, and biAlhinaMCi, [the latter of which is the more common,] aor. yaToliI, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He daubed, bedaubed, smeared, or besmeared, the camel with tar; as also Tl-Ahu↓, [but app. in an intensive sense, or relating to several objects,] (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. taToliyapN. (TA.) [And TalaAhu biAlc-ahabi He gilded it. And TalaAhu biAlfiD-api He silvered it.]
Hence, TalaI All-ayolu AlMfaAqa ‡ The night covered [with its darkness] the adjacent regions, or the tracts of the horizon; like as when a camel is daubed with tar. (TA.)

And TalaI, aor. yaToliI, † He reviled [another], or vilified [him]; (TA;) as also Tl-I↓, (Ḳ,* TA,) inf. n. taToliyapN; (Ḳ;) or taToliyapN signifies the reviling, or vilifying, in a foul manner. (IAạr, TA.)
And TalaI Albaqolu † The herbs, or leguminous plants, appeared upon the surface of the earth [as though they overspread it with a coating of colour]. (TA.)

TaliIa fuwhu, aor. yaTolaI, inf. n. TalFA, His mouth had a yellowness in the teeth. (Ṣ, TA.) TalFA [in relation to the mouth but in a somewhat different sense] is mentioned in the Ḳ in art. Tlw and not in art. TlI; but it belongs to both of these. (TA.)
2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in two places.

Tal-ayotu fulaAnFA, (Ṣ,) inf. n. taToliyapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) signifies also I tended, or took care of, such a one in his sickness; undertook, or managed, or superintended, the treatment of him therein. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.)
And Alt-aToliyapu also signifies The act of singing. (AA, Ḳ.)
4. ATlt She (a wild animal) had with her a young one, which is termed TalFA. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

ATlI (said of a man, Ṣ, TA, and of a camel, TA) He had an inclining of the neck (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) towards one side when said of a man, (TA,) on the occasion of death, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or on some other occasion. (Ṣ, TA.)

Hence, (IAth, TA,) maA OaTolaI nabiI-N qaT-u, (Ḳ, TA,) occurring in a trad., (TA,) means maA maAla UilaI hawaAhu [i. e. † No prophet ever inclined to his natural desire]: (Ḳ, TA:) as some relate it, maA QT-alaI; but this is a mistake. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tTl-I: see 8.
Also, (said of a man, TA,) He kept to diversion, sport, or play, and mirth. (Ḳ, TA.)

8. AiT-alaI, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the measure AifotaEala, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) and tTl-I↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [He, or it, was, or became, daubed, bedaubed, smeared, or besmeared; rubbed, or done, over; anointed, painted, varnished, plastered, coated, overspread, or overlaid: or] he daubed,, &c., himself: (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) bihi [with it]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. [with any fluid, semifluid, liniment, unguent, or the like; as, for instance,] with oil, (Ṣ,) or tar, (Mgh, Ḳ,) or clay, or mud, (Mṣb,), &c. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 12. AiTolawolaI He was good in speech:
and He was defeated, or put to flight. (IAạr, TA in art. xlI.)

TalFA The young one of any of the cloven-hoofed animals: (Ṣ, TA: [in the latter of which is added, as from the Ṣ, waAlxuf-i; but this is app. a mistake:]) or the young one of the gazelle, when just born: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ: [see XaSarN:]) and the youngling, of any kind; as also TalowN↓; (Ḳ, TA;) which latter is mentioned by IDrd; but expl. by him as meaning the young one of a wild animal: (TA:) and TilowapN↓ has this last meaning (Ḳ, TA) likewise accord. to IDrd: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] of TalFA is OaTolaMCN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of mult.] TilaMCN (Ḳ) and Tuliy-N (Ḳ, TA, but omitted in the CK) and TiliI-N (Lth, TA) and TuloyaAnN (Ḳ) and TiloyaAnN. (Lth, Ḳ.) [See also TaliI-N.]
[And, accord. to Freytag (in art. TlI), An infant until a month old or more: but for this he has named no authority.]
And The person; syn. XaxoSN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the saying, Uin-ahu lajamiylu AlT-alaA [Verily he is goodly, or comely, in person]. (Ṣ.)
Also Daubed, or smeared, (maToliI-N↓,) with tar. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also TaloyaMCu.]
And A man having a severe disease: (Ḳ, TA:) having no dual nor pl., or, as some say, (TA,) the pl. is OaTolaMCN, and the dual is TalayaAni. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also muTal-FI.]

And Desire; syn. hawFI. (Ḳ, TA.) So in the saying, qaDaI TalaAhu mino HaAjatihi [He accomplished his desire of that which he wanted]. (Ḳ, TA.) [Or, as Freytag says, on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees, accord. to some it signifies Pleasure (voluptas): and accord. to others, thirst. But see TilFA.]
See also TulaAwapN, in two places.
And see also TilaMC, last sentence.
TilFA Pleasure, or delight. (Ḳ.)
See also TilaMCN.

entry.sense: TalowN: see TalFA, first sentence.

hom.sense: TilowN The wolf. (Ḳ.)

And A hunter, or pursuer of wild animals or the like, slender in body: (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, AlqAbiDu is erroneously put for AlqaAniSu:]) said to be [so called as being] likened to the wolf. (Aboo-Saʼeed, TA.) Et-Tirimmáh says,
SaAdafato TilowAF Tawiyla AlT-awaI
HaAfiZa AlEayoni qaliyla Als-aMmo
[She, or they, (app. referring to one or more of the objects of the chase,) encountered a hunter slender in body, a long endurer of hunger, one whom sleep did not overcome, little, or seldom, subject to disgust]. (Aboo-Saʼeed, TA.)
See also TilaMCN, last sentence.

entry.sense: TulaApN (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) accord. to AA and Fr, (Ṣ, TA,) and so says Sb on the authority of Abu-lKhattáb, (TA,) or TuloyapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) accord. to Aṣ, (Ṣ, TA,) each with damm, (TA,) is sing. of TulFA or TulFI; which signifies Necks: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the bases of the necks: (M, Ḳ:) or the broad part [or parts] beneath the protuberant bone behind the ear: or, accord. to ISk, the sides of the neck: Sb says that TulaApN and TulFA are of the class of ruTabapN, and ruTabN, not of the class of tamorapN and tamorN: (TA:) [but see art. rTb, in which it is said, as on the authority of Sb, that ruTabN is not a broken pl. of ruTabapN, being masc. like tamorN:] TulowapN↓, also, signifies the side of the neck, as a dial. var. of [TulaApN or of] TuloyapN. (TA.)

hom.sense: TulowapN The whiteness of the dawn, (Ḳ, TA,) and of blossoms, or flowers. (TA.)
See also TulaApN.
TilowapN: see TalFA:
and see also TilMCN, last sentence.

entry.sense: TaloyapN A single act of daubing or smearing or the like: pl. TalayaAtN. (Mgh.)
See also TilaMCN, last sentence.

hom.sense: TuloyapN: see TulaApN.
Also A portion, tuft, or wisp, of wool, with which mangy camels are daubed [with tar]; also called ribocapN: whence the saying, maA yusaAwiI TuloyapF [It is not worth a Tlyp]. (TA.)
See also TaloyaMCu.
And see TilaMCN, last sentence.

entry.sense: TaloyaMCu A she-camel daubed, or smeared, (maToliy-apN↓, Ḳ, TA,) with tar. (TA.) [See also TalFA.]
And A mangy she-camel: (Ḳ:) app. so called because the she-camel is not daubed, or smeared, [with tar] unless mangy. (TA.)
And The rag of a menstruous woman: (Ḳ, TA:) whence the prov., Oahowanu mina AlT-aloyaMCi [More despicable than the TlyAC]: or, accord. to IAạr, this is called TuloyapN↓. (TA.)
[In some copies of the Ḳ, this word is erroneously put for Taliy-aA, q. v.]

hom.sense: TulawaMCu: see TulowaAnN.

entry.sense: TalowaAnN: see TulaAwapN.

TulowaAnN and TalawaAnN↓ and TulawaMCu↓ [or app. the last only accord. to some copies of the Ḳ] Expectation: and slowness, or tardiness; as also TalaAwapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) with fet-ḥ. (TA.) See also TulaAwapN.
TalawaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph: and see also TulaAwapN.
TiloyaAnN: see TaliI-N.
TalayaAnN: see TulaAwapN.
TulaMCN The coat upon the surface of blood. (Ḳ.) [See also TulaAwapN. And see Tul-aMCN.]

hom.sense: TilaMCN Tar: and anything (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of the like kind (Mgh, Mṣb) with which one daubs or smears or the like; [i. e. any fluid, semifluid, liniment, unguent, oil, varnish, plaster, or the like, with which a thing is daubed, smeared, rubbed or done over, anointed, painted, varnished, plastered, coated, overspread, or overlaid;] (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also TulaAwapN↓, which by rule should be TulaAyapN↓, for it is from Talayotu. (TA, in which TulaAyapN is afterwards mentioned as having the same meaning.)

And, as being likened thereto, † Any thick beverage or wine: (Mgh:) expressed juice of grapes cooked until the quantity of two thirds has gone by evaporation; (Ṣ, A, Mgh;) called by the Persians mayobuxotaj [or maIo Puxotah]; called by the Arabs TilaMC as being likened to tar: (A, Mgh:*) or thick expressed juice, or wine, cooked until half of it has gone: (Ḳ:) in a verse of Ibn-Sukkarah, shortened to TilFA↓, for the sake of the metre. (Ḥar p. 302.)

And † Wine [in an absolute sense] (Ṣ, Ḳ) is thus called by some of the Arabs, for the purpose of euphemism. (Ṣ.) ʼObeyd Ibn-El-Abras said to El-Mundhir when he [the latter] desired to slay him, hiIa Alxamoru tukonaI AlT-ilaMCa kamaA Alc-iYobu yukonaI OabaA jEodapa [It is wine: it is surnamed AlTlMC like as the wolf is surnamed Abw jEdp]: i. e. thou pretendest to show honour to me while desiring to slay me; like the wolf, whose acting is not good though his surname is good: (Ṣ:) or, as cited by IḲt, Eani Alxamori takoniI AlT-ilaMCa: and in the M,
haIi Alxamoru yakonuwnahaA biAleT-ilaMCi
[forming a hemistich; the words kamaA Alc-iYobu Alx, cited above, completing the verse]. (TA.)
And † The ashes between the three stones upon which the cooking-pot is placed: so called by way of comparison [to tar]. (TA.)
And Pure silver. (TA.)
And † Revilement, or reproach. (Ḳ.)

Also The cord with which the leg of the lamb, or kid, is tied (Ṣ, Ḳ) to a peg, or stake; (Ṣ;) and so TilowN↓ and TilowapN↓: (TA:) or the string with which the leg of the kid is tied as long as he is little; (Lḥ, TA;) and so TuloyapN↓ and TaloyapN↓ and TalFI↓ [or TalFA]. (TA.)
TaliI-N Confined, restrained, or withheld; [and particularly tied by the leg, as is shown by what follows;] as also maToliI-N↓. (Ṣ.)

And A young lamb or kid: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called because it is tied by the leg for some days to a peg, or stake: (ISk, Ṣ:) pl. TuloyaAnN; like rugofaAnN, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) pl. of ragiyfN: (ISk, Ṣ:) it is thus pluralized like a subst. because it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant. (AAF, TA.) [See also TalFA.]
[Hence AlT-aliI-u meaning † The sign of Aries: see an ex. voce HamalN.]
Also A yellowness in the teeth; and so TiloyaAnN↓: like SabiI-N and SiboyaAnN [in form]. (Ṣ.) [See also TulaAwapN.]
TalaAwapN: see the next paragraph, in two places:
and see also TulowaAnN.

TulaAwapN, and TalaAwapN↓, (Az, Ṣ, ISd, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former preferred by Az, (TA, and this, only, mentioned in the Mgh,) and TilaAwapN↓, (Ḳ,) Beauty, goodliness, grace, comeliness, or pleasingness: (Az,* ISd,* Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) ISd says, it is in that which has growth and that which has not growth. (TA.) One says, Ealayohi TulaAwapN [Upon him, or it, is an appearance of beauty,, &c.]. (Mṣb.) And maA Ealayohi TulaAwapN [There is not upon him, or it,, &c.]. (Ṣ.) And Uin-a liloquroMni laTulaAwapF [Verily to the Ḳur-án pertains beauty,, &c.]. (Mgh, from a trad.) And maAEalaI wajohihi HalaAwapN walaA TulaAwapN [There is not upon his face an appearance of sweetness nor an appearance of beauty,, &c.]. (TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) or the first, with damm, (TA,) Enchantment, or fascination: (Ḳ:) a meaning mentioned by ISd. (TA.)
And (the first, TA) The thin skin that overspreads the surface of milk, (T, ISd, Ḳ, TA,) as also TulaAyapN↓, (Kr, TA,) or of blood. (ISd, Ḳ, TA. [See also TulaMCN.])
And Remains of food in the mouth. (Lḥ, Ḳ, TA.)

And Saliva becoming dry (Ḳ, TA) and thick (TA) in the mouth, by reason of some accident, (Ḳ, TA,) or, as in the M, from thirst, (TA,) or disease; (Ḳ, TA;) the first and ↓second have this meaning; (TA;) as also TalFA↓ (Ḳ) [and app. TulowaAnN↓ and TalawaAnN↓ also accord. to the copies of the Ḳ followed in the TA; but see TulowanN above]: it is also said that TalowaAnN↓, with fet-ḥ, signifies saliva becoming dry upon the teeth from hunger; and has no pl.: TalFA↓ is the inf. n. of TaliIa fuwhu: and signifies also a whiteness that comes upon the teeth from disease or thirst; and so TalayaAnN↓. (TA.) [See also TaliI-N.]
For other meanings of TulaAwapN, see TulawaMCu,
and TilaMCN.
It signifies also A small quantity of herbage or pasture. (TA.)

entry.sense: TilaAwapN: see TulaAwapN, first sentence.
TulaAyapN: see TilaMCN:
and see also TulaAwapN.

Taliy-aA, thus correctly, as written by Ṣgh in the TṢ, not, as in the copies of the Ḳ, TaloyaA [or TaloyaMC], (TA,) The mange, or scab. (Ḳ, TA.) And A certain purulent pustule, [or eruption,] resembling the quwbaMC [or ringworm], (Ḳ, TA,) that comes forth in a man's side; whereupon one says to him, “It is only qwbMC, and not Tly-A;” thus making light of it to him. (TA.)
Tul-aI A draught of milk: (Ḳ:) but this is of the measure fuEolaI, belonging to art. Tl. (TA. [See Tul-apN in that art.])
Tal-aMCN A seller of the thickened juice called TilaMC. (MA.)

Tul-aMCN Blood, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) itself; applied to that of a slain person: or, accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed, a thing [or fluid] that comes forth after the flow of the blood, differing from blood in colour, on the occasion of the exit of the soul of the slaughtered animal: and the blood with which one daubs, or smears. (TA.) [See also TulaMCN.]
TaAlK A water to which camels come to drink overspread with [the green substance called] TuHolub [and TulawaMC]. (Ḳ, TA.)
And ‡ A dark night: (AA, Ḳ, TA:) as though it smeared [with tar] the forms, or persons, of men, and obscured them. (AA, TA.)
miTolFI: see what next follows.

miTolaMCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and miTolFI↓ (Ḳ) A narrow tract of ground in which water flows: (Ḳ:) or soft ground that gives growth to the trees called EiDaAh, (as in the Ṣ and in some copies of the Ḳ,) or gaDFA: (so in other copies of the Ḳ and in copies of the T and M:) and AlmaTaAliI, which is the pl. [of the latter, or AlmaTaAliI-u pl. of the former], signifies the soft places: (TA:) or the places in which the wild animals feed their younglings: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) so it is said. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: maToliI-N: see TaliI-N:
see also TalFA; and see the fem., with p {maToliy-apN}, voce TaloyaMCu.
[Hence,] OamorN maToliI-N † A dubious and obscure affair, or case: as though it were smeared over with that which involved it. (TA.)
And EuwdN maToliI-N † A stick, or rod, or branch, not stript of the peel or bark. (TA.)

entry.sense: muTal-FI Having a constant, or chronic, disease, (Ḳ, TA,) and bent thereby. (TA.) [See also TalFA.]
And Imprisoned without hope of liberation. (Ḳ.)

1. Tam-a, (MA, Ḳ, TA,) aor. _u {yaTomumu}, (TA, [by rule it should be _i,]) inf. n. TumuwmN (MA, Ḳ, TA) and Tam-N, (Ḳ, TA,) said of water, It was, or became, abundant, (MA, Ḳ, TA,) and rose high, or to a high pitch. (TA.) [See also TamaI.] And Tam-a AlwaAdiI means [Tam-a sayolu AlwaAdiI i. e. The torrent of the valley or water-course] rose high, or to a high pitch, and predominated: whence the prov., jaraI AlwaAdiI faTam-a EalaI AlqariI-i; in explanation of which Meyd says, i. e., [The torrent of the valley or water-course (sayolu AlwaAdiI) flowed, (so in the Provs. of Meyd,)] and filled up, or choked up, meaning destroyed by filling up, or choking up, the channel by which the water ran into the meadow: and he says that the prov. is applied to the case in which evil exceeds the ordinary limit: (Ḥar p. 127:) [or, accord. to Z, it means a man's overcoming his adversary: (Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 278:) but it should be observed that Tam-a in this sense is trans. without a prep.:] one says of a torrent, (Ṣ, Meyd, and Ḥar ubi suprà,) Tam-a Alr-akiy-apa, (Ṣ, Meyd, Ḳ, Ḥar,)) aor. _u {yaTomumu} and _i {yaTomimu}, (Ḳ, TA,) the latter on the authority of IAạr, inf. n. Tam-N, (TA,) It filled up, or choked up, the well, syn. dafanahaA, (Ṣ, Meyd, Ḳ, Ḥar,) or kabasahaA, (IAạr, TA,) and made it even or level (saw-aAhaA) [with the ground around it]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and Tam-a AlX-aIoCa biAlt-uraAbi, inf. n. Tam-N, He covered over the thing with earth, or dust; syn. kabasahu: (TA:) and Tam-a AlUinaMCa, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. Tam-N, (TA,) He filled the vessel (Ḳ, TA) so that the contents overflowed its edges: (TA:) and Tam-a AlbiYora wagayorahaA biAlt-uraAbi, aor. _u {yaTomumu}, inf. n. Tam-N, He filled the well, &c. with earth, or dust, so that it became even with the ground: (Mgh,* Mṣb:) and Tam-ahaA Alt-uraAbu The earth, or dust, so filled it. (Mṣb.)

[Hence, i. e. from Tam-a AlwaAdiI meaning as expl. in the beginning of the next preceding sentence,] one says, Tam-a AlX-aIoCu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaTomumu}, (Ṣ, TA,) [inf. n. Tam-N and TumuwmN,] † The thing abounded so that it rose to a high pitch, or had ascendency, and overcame. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Tam-a AlOamoru, inf. n. Tam-N, † The affair, or event, rose to a high pitch, or had ascendency, and overcame: (Mṣb:) or was, or became, great, or formidable. (Ḥar p. 127.) And OamorN yTm- wlA ytm- [app. yaTim-u walaA yatim-u, agreeably with analogy, in order to assimilate the former verb with the latter, as is often done; meaning † An affair that is great, or formidable, and that will not become accomplished]. (TA.) And Tam-ati Alfitonapu † The sedition, or conflict and faction, or the like, was, or became, vehement, or severe. (TA.) And daAhiyapN tTm-u EalaI Ald-awaAhI [i. e. taTum-u or taTim-u], meaning † [A calamity] that predominates over [the other calamities]. (Ḥar p. 127.)
Tam-a Alfarasa and Tam-a EalayohaA He (the stallion) leaped the mare. (TA.) And Tam-a AlX-ajarapa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. Tam-N, (JM,) He (a bird) mounted upon the top of the tree. (Ḳ.)

Tam-a said of a man and of a horse, aor. _i {yaTomimu} and _u, inf. n. TamiymN and Tam-N, He was, or became, light, or active, (Ḳ, TA,) and quick: (TA:) or he went away upon the face of the earth: (Ḳ, TA:) or he went away in any way. (TA.) And He ran in an easy manner: (Ḳ:) or so Tam-a, aor. _i {yaTomimu}, inf. n. TamiymN: (TA:) and mar-ayaTim-u, with kesr, inf. n. TamiymN, He passed along running in an easy manner: (Ṣ:) and so, accord. to Aṣ, Tam-a, inf. n. TumuwmN. (TA.) [See also TamaI.]

Tam-a raOosahu, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaTomumu}, inf. n. Tam-N, (TA,) He took somewhat from [the hair of] his head; gD-a minohu. (Ḳ. [So in my MṢ. copy: in the CK and TA, erroneously, EaD-a, with the unpointed E; and thus in the TḲ, in which, however, the phrase is well expl., on the authority of the A, as meaning he shaved a portion of his head: see also the pass. part. n.]) And Tam-a XaEarahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaTomumu}, inf. n. Tam-N, (TA,) He cut his hair; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and he cut it off entirely. (TA.) And Tam-a XaEarahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. TumuwmN, (Ṣ,) i. q. EaqaSahu [i. e. He plaited his hair: or twisted it:, &c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
2. Tm-m, inf. n. taTomiymN, He (a bird) alighted upon a branch. (Aboo-Naṣr, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
7. AnTm-, said of a rivulet, [and in like manner of a well, &c.,] It became filled up with earth, or dust, so as to be even with the ground [around it]. (Mgh.)

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. TamoTama He swam in the midst of the sea. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
And It (the sea) became full. (TA.)
He had a barbarousness, or vitiousness, or an impotence, or impediment, in his speech, or utterance, not speaking clearly, or correctly. (TA.)

entry.sense: Tam-N [as an inf. n.: see 1.]
[As a subst.,] see the next paragraph.

Tim-N The sea: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) said to be so called because of its overwhelming what is in it (liOan-ahu Tam-a EalaI maA fiyhi): but in this sense the word is said to be Tam-N↓, and to be pronounced with kesr for the purpose of assimilating it to rim-N. (TA.) One says, jaMCa biAlT-im-i waAlr-im-i, meaning He brought much wealth: (Ṣ, TA:) or the meaning in this instance is AlAmr Alkvyr [app. a mistranscription for AlOamor Alkabiyr i. e. that which was a great event]: so says Aṣ: or much of everything: or much and little: thus accord. to Aboo-Tálib: or what was moist and what was dry: or the leaves of trees, and what had fallen off from them. (TA. [See more voce rim: and see also what here follows.])

And Water: (Ḳ, TA:) or much water; as also TaAm-N↓ [or maMCN TaAm-N]: (TA:) or the rubbish and scum, and the like, that is upon its surface; or that is driven along by it: (Ḳ,* TA:) and thus expl. as used in the saying above-mentioned. (TA.)
And A large number: (Ḳ:) and this also is said to be meant in the phrase above. (TA.)
And A wonderful thing; syn. EajabN and EajiybN [which here, as in many other instances, evidently signify the same]: (Ḳ:) and this too is said to be meant in the phrase above. (TA.)
And A male ostrich: (Ḳ:) because of the lightness of his pace. (TA.)

And A courser, or swift horse; as also TamiymN↓: (Ḳ,* TA: [see also TamuwmN:]) called Tim-N because of. his light and quick, or easy, running (liTamiymi Eadowihi); or as being likened to the sea, as a horse is termed baHorN and sakobN and garobN. (TA.)
And A large cakar: (Ḳ:) because its head is maTomuwm [as though this epithet meant “bare”]. (TA.)
AlT-im-u is also said in the Ḳ to signify Alkay-isu; but [SM says] I think that this is a mistranscription for AlT-am-u meaning Alkabosu [see Tam-a Alr-akiy-apa, in the first paragraph]. (TA.)

hom.sense: Tum-apN A company, or congregated body, of men: and the middle of them: one says, laqiytuhu fI Tum-api Alqawomi [I met him, or found him, in the company of people, or in the midst of the people]. (TA.)
Also Error; or deviation from the right course: and confusion, or perplexity, and inability to see the right course. (TA.)
And Dirt, or filth; syn. qacarN. (TA.)

And Human dung. (Ḳ.) AZ says, When thou givest good advice to a man and he refuses to do aught but follow his own opinion alone, daEohu yataram-aEu fiI Tum-atihi [leave him wallowing in his dung]. (TA.)
And A portion (Ḳ, TA) of herbage, mostly (TA) of what is dry, or dried up. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: TamimN Hardy, strong, or sturdy: occurring thus, without idghám, in a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd; applied to a beast such as is termed qaAriHN. (TA.)
farasN TamuwmN A swift horse. (TA. [See also Tim-N.])
TamiymN: see Tim-N.
Also A medley of men, or people: and a multitude thereof. (TA.)
TaAm-N [part. n. of 1]: see Tim-N:
and see the paragraph here following.

TaAm-apN A calamity that predominates over others: (Ḳ, and Ḥar p. 127:) or simply a calamity. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Bekr En-Nessábeh, maA mino TaAm-apK Uil-aA wafawoqahaA TaAm-apN (Ṣ,* TA) i. e. There is no calamity but above it is a calamity. (TA.)
And A great, or formidable, thing; as also TaAm-N↓. (TA.)
And A cry, or vehement cry, that overcomes everything. (TA.)
And AlT-aAm-apu signifies The resurrection: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so called because it surpasses, or predominates over, everything: (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* TA:) and also called AlT-aAm-apu AlkuboraI. (Ḥar p. 346.)

TimoTimN and TumoTumaAniI-N↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and TimoTimiI-N↓ (Ḳ) and TumaATimN↓ (TA) A man having a barbarousness, or vitiousness, or an impotence, or impediment, in his speech, or utterance, not speaking clearly, or correctly: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and Aboo-Turáb explains [the pl. of the first] TamaATimu as meaning foreigners (Eajam). (TA.) Hence the saying of the poet, (Ṣ,) 'Antarah, (TA,)
taOowiI lahu quluSu Aln-aEaAmi kamaA Oawato
xiraqN yamaAniy-apN liOaEojama TimoTimi ; (Ṣ, TA;) respecting which Fr relates his having heard El-Mufaddal say that one of the most learned of men explained to him Alxiraqu AlyamaAniy-apu as meaning the clouds [app. likened to rags of cloth of El-Yemen], and AlOaEojamu AlTimoTimu as meaning the sound of thunder: (TA:) or the latter hemistich is thus:
HizaqN yamaAniy-apN liOaEojama TimoTimi and the verse means, To whom (referring to a male ostrich) repair the young ostriches, like as herds of camels of El-Yemen repair to one who is impotent, and indistinct, or incorrect, in speech: he likens the male ostrich, in respect of blackness, and want of speech, to an Abyssinian pastor impotent, and indistinct, or incorrect, in speech. (EM p. 231.)
TimoTimN signifies also A sort of sheep, haring small ears, and OagobaAb [or what resemble dewlaps], like the AgbAb of oxen: they are in the region of El-Yemen. (IDrd, TA.)
TamoTamapN A barbarousness, or vitiousness, or an impotence, or impediment, in speech, or utterance, so that the speech is not clear, or correct. (TA. [See R. Q. 1, of which it is the inf. n.])
TimoTimiI-N: see TimoTimN.
TumoTumaAniI-N: see TimoTimN.
