Thus in a trad., (Ṣ, TA,) in which it is related that it was said to Aboo-Hureyreh, “Didst thou hear this from the Apostle of God?” and he replied wamaA kaAna TahowiI i. e. † And what was my deed, or performance? or, accord. to AʼObeyd, OanaA maA TahowiI [I, what is my deed, or performance?] (TA) or famaA TahowiI What then is my deed, or performance, (Ṣ,) if I have not made that relation to be soundly, or well, performed, (Ṣ,* TA,) like as the cook does the cooking of food? (TA.) See also TuhFI.

hom.sense: TahoIN: see TuhFI.
Also Thin clouds. (TA.) [See also TahaMCN.]

And it is said in the “Nawádir” that samiEotu TahoyahumN, as also dagoyahumo and Tagoyahumo, means I heard their sound, or voice: [or their sounds, or voices:] and one says, flAn fI ThI wnhI [app. fI TahoIK wanahoIi, as though meaning Such a one is engaged in clamour and prohibition]. (TA.)

entry.sense: TahFI Broken bits of straw. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: TuhFI Cooked flesh-meat. (IAạr, Ḳ.) [It is said in one place in the TA that AlTuhI, with damm, (as though it were AlT-uhoIu, but I suppose AlT-uhaI to be meant,) is the subst. from TahaA All-aHoma.]

Also A sin, crime, fault, misdemeanour, or misdeed; syn. canobN; (Ḳ, TA; [in some copies of the Ḳ, Alc-anabu is put (erroneously, as is said in the TA,) in the place of Alc-anobu; and in the CK, Alc-iYobu;]) as also TahoIN↓: and maA TahowiI↓ in the trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh [mentioned above] is expl. by some as meaning maA canobiI [What is my fault?]. (TA.)

entry.sense: TahaMCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) with the lengthened A, (Ṣ, TA,) is like TaxaMCN; (Ḳ, TA; [in some copies of the Ḳ, each of these is erroneously written with the shortened A, without C;]) i. e. it is a dial. var. of the latter word, signifying High, or elevated, clouds: (Ṣ, TA:) or thin clouds: (Ḥam p. 12: [see also TahoIN:]) [and TahaMCapN is the n. un.:] one says, maA fiI Als-amaMCi TahaMCapN, meaning There is not in the sky a portion of cloud. (Ṣ.)
TuhaAwapN The thin skin that is upon milk or blood. (ISd, Ḳ.)
maA OadoriI OaI-u AlT-ahoyaMCi huwa means I know not what one of mankind, or of the people, he is: (Ḳ, TA:) like AI- AlD-aHoyaMCi: mentioned by Az. (TA.)
TahayaAnN The top of a mountain. (Ḳ.)

And A bar-aAdap [meaning a stand, or shelf, upon which vessels of porous earth, containing water, are placed, in order that the water may become cool]. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, burAdap: as is said in the TA, and shown by what here follows, it is with teshdeed; and it is written in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ bar-aAdap.])

In the saying of El-Ahwal El-Kindee,
falayota lanaA mino maMCi zamozama XarobapF
mubar-adapF baAtato EalaI AlT-ahayaAni
[And would that there were for us, of the water of Zemzem, a cooled draught that had passed the night upon the TahayaAn], it has been expl. as having the former of these meaning, and as having the second thereof, and as meaning a certain mountain in El-Yemen. (TA.)

hom.sense: TaAhK A cook; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a roaster, broiler, or fryer: and a maker, or kneader and baker, of bread: (Ḳ:) and, (Ḳ, TA,) as some say, (TA,) any dresser, or preparer, of food, (Ḳ, TA,) &c., who qualifies it well, rightly, or properly: (TA:) pl. TuhaApN and TuhiI-N: (Ḳ, TA: [in the CK the latter is written TuhFI, which is evidently wrong; whereas TuhiI-N is agreeable with analogy, being originally TuhuwoIN:]) the fem. is TaAhiyapN, and its pl. is TawaAhK. (TA.)
layolN TaAhK A dark night. (TA.)

entry.sense: OamorN maTohuw-N ‡ An affair performed, or executed, firmly, soundly, or thoroughly; and matured. (TA.)

TuwbN Baked bricks; syn. Mjur-N: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) n. un. with p {TuwbapN}: so says Az, and El-Fárábee says the like; and accord. to them it seems to be [genuine] Arabic: accord. to IDrd, it is of the dial. of Syria; but [Fei adds] I think it to be of the dial. of Room: (Mṣb:) or it is of the dial. of Egypt: (Ṣ, O:) [probably of Coptic origin. It is mentioned in the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. Tyb.]

OawobapF waTawobapF, [the latter word] meaning AlT-iyba, [and both together A return and perfume,] is a phrase which one says to the person entering and to him coming [as though he who said this meant I experience a return that is to me like perfume]. (O.)
TuwbaI: see art. Tyb.
[Taw-aAbN A baker of bricks: from TuwbN: mentioned by Golius, in art. Tyb, as occurring in the Hist. Sar.: and it is used in this sense in the present day.]

hom.sense:
1. TaAHa, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) aor. yaTuwHu and yaTiyHu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. of the former TawoHN, and of the latter TayoHN, (L,) He, or it, perished, or came to nought; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also tTw-H↓: (A:)
or was, or became, at the point of perishing: (Ḳ:) and he, or it, (i. e. anything, TA,) went away; passed away; (Ḳ, TA;) came to nought. (TA.)
And (as some say, TA) He, or it, fell; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and so tTw-H↓, as in the phrase tTw-H fiI AlbiYori [It fell into the well], said of a bucket. (TA.)
And He lost his way, syn. taAha, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) in the land, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or in the desert; as also tT-wH↓ and tTy-H↓. (TA.) And, said of an arrow, It missed its aim. (Ḥar p. 126.)

And Oayona TiyHa bika Whither hast thou been taken, or carried, away? (A.) And TAH bihi farasuhu His horse went away with him [or carried him away] like an arrow. (A.) And maA kaAnato Uil-aA mazoHapF TaAHa bihaA lisaAniI [It was nought but a jest, or joke, which my tongue hastily uttered, or which my tongue let full]. (A.)
See also the next paragraph {2}.

2. Tw-Hhu He caused him, or it, to perish, or come to nought; as also Tw-H bihi, (A,) and Ty-Hhu; (A, and Ḳ in art. TyH;) and ATAHhu↓ signifies the same, (IAạr, Ḳ,) said of a thing, (Ḳ,) or of property, (IAạr, and Ḳ in art. TyH,) as is also Tw-Hhu, (IAạr,) and he made it pass away. (Ḳ.) And He sent him to a land from which he should not return. (Ḳ.) And Tw-H bivawobihi He cast his garment [app. meaning himself (see a verse of Esh-Shemmákh, or of Leylà, cited voce vwb)] into a place of destruction; as also Ty-H bh. (L, and Ḳ in art. TyH.) And Taw-aHatohu AlT-waAYiHu↓ i. q. qacafatohu AlqawaAcifu (Ṣ, Ḳ) i. e. Accidents, or events, that cast into places of perdition [cast him thereinto]: (MF,* TḲ:) one should not say AlmuTaw-iHaAtu: it is an extr. phrase, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like the phrase in the Ḳur [xv. 22], waOarosalonaA Alr-iyaAHa lawaAqiHa accord. to one of the two interpretations thereof: (Ṣ:) and OaTaAHatohu↓ AlmaTaAwiHu and AlT-awaAYiHu signify the same, i. e. qacafatohu AlqawaAcifu; (A;) or [rather] the former of these two phrases has a similar meaning [i. e. the places of perdition caused him to fall thereinto; unless maTaAwiHu have a signification which I do not find explained]. (TA.) And Tw-H bihi He incited him, induced him, or made him, to venture upon a desert in which perdition was to be feared. (Ḳ,* TA.)

Also He, or it, caused him to lose his way, syn. taw-ahahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and so TAH↓ bihi, (Ḥar p. 126,) and Ty-Hhu, (Ḳ in art. TyH,) and carried him away hither and thither, (Ṣ,) or so that he cast himself hither and thither, (Ḳ, TA,) and so Tw-H bihi. (TA.) And Tw-H nafosahu He made himself to be, or become, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; like tuw-ahahaA and tay-ahahaA. (Ṣ in art. tyh.)
Tw-H bihi also signifies He threw it, or cast it, in the air. (Ḳ, TA. [For AlhawaMC, Golius and Freytag have read AlhawaI. See 5.])
And Tw-Hhu He beat him, or struck him, with a staff, or stick. (Ḳ.)
Tw-H fiI AljibaAli He went round about much, or often, in the mountains; i. q. Taw-afa and Taw-ada. (Ṣ in art. Twd.)

entry.sense:
3. TAwHhu He contended with him in casting, or shooting. (L, Ḳ.) A poet says,
fOam-aA waAHidN fakafaAka min-iI
famano liyadK tuTaAwiHuhaA AlOayaAdiI
Now as for one, what would proceed from me would suffice thee: but who will be responsible for a hand with which several hands contend in casting, or shooting? (L.)
4: see 2, in two places.

One says also, TAH XaEarahu He, or it, caused his hair to fall off. (Ḳ.) [And ATAH qawaAYimahu is said of a horse, or of a man in relation to a horse, app. meaning He made his legs to fall in a particular manner: see misoEarN.]
maA OaTowaHahu and maA OaToyaHahu i. q. maA Oatowahahu and mA Oatoyahahu: see 4 in art. twh.
5. tTw-H: see 1, in four places.
Also [He lost his way, or was made to lose his way, and] he cast himself hither and thither (Ṣ, Ḳ) fiI AlbilaAdi in the countries. (Ṣ.)
And He, or it, went and came, or moved to and fro, in the air: and he moved to and fro in sleep, upon the back of a camel. (L.)
6. taTaAwuHN signifies The casting, or throwing, a thing [to and fro,] one with another; or one to, or at, another. (KL.)
[Hence,] taTaAwaHato bihimu Aln-awaI i. q. taraAmatN [i. e. † Distance cast them away, one from another]. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
And taTaAwaHuwhu biAlD-arobi, and biAlOamori, They contended with him [in beating, and in the affair]. (A.)
niy-apN TawaHN i. q. baEiydapN [app. meaning A distant, or remote, thing, or place, that is the object of an action or a journey]; (Ḳ, and O in art. DrH;) like TaraHN and TamaHN and DaraHN. (O.)

TawaAYiHu i. q. qawaAcifu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) i. e. Accidents, or events, that cast into places of perdition: (MF,* TḲ:) said in the 'Ináyeh to be an anomalous pl. of muTiyHapN↓, from OaTaAHa meaning “he, or it, caused to pass away,” and “to perish, or come to nought.” (MF.) See 2.
[Taw-aAHN is expl. by Freytag as signifying Evilaffecting: but he names no authority.]
Tuw-aHapN A child's swing, of rope. (TA voce ruj-aAHapN.)
TaAYiHN [part. n. of 1] Perishing [&c.]. (L.)
See also art. TyH.
[TAyiHap, correctly TaAYiHapN, is expl. by Freytag, on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees, as meaning An army.]
muTiyHapN: see TawaAYiHu.
miTowaAHN A staff, or stick, (Ḳ, TA,) [as being] an instrument of destruction. (TA.)
maTaAwiHu i. q. maqaAcifu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which means Places of perdition; (TA in art. qcf;) like maTaAwidu [pl. of maTaAdapN]. (Ṣ and TA in art. Twd.)

[mutaTaAwiHN, app. a mistranscription for mutaTaAwaHN, which lit. means A place of casting, or throwing, to and fro, is expl. by Freytag, on the authority of the Deewán of Jereer, as meaning the intermediate part between the top and bottom of a well.]

1. TaAxahu, (Ḳ,) aor. yaTuwxuhu, (TA,) inf. n. TawoxN; (Ḳ;) as also TaAxahu, aor. yaTiyxuhu, inf. n. TayoxN; which is the more common; (TA;) He charged, reproached, or upbraided, him with something bad, evil, abominable, or foul, either said or done. (Ḳ.) [See also art. Tyx.]
1. TaAda, (aor. yaTuwdu, inf. n. TawodN, TḲ,) It (a thing, TḲ) was, or became, firm, or steadfast. (Fr, L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: Tw-dhu, inf. n. taTowiydN, He (God) made it high, or tall. (A.)

entry.sense: [4. ATAd He made, or rendered, firm, or steadfast: so accord. to Freytag; but he names no authority.]
5: see 2.
7. AnTAd It rose, or ascended, in the air. (Ḳ.)
TaAdN Heavy: (Ḳ:) and TaAdiI-N↓ firm, or steadfast: (L:) or both signify heavy and firm or steadfast. (TA.)
Also the former, A stallion excited by lust. (Ḳ.)

TawodN A mountain: (Ḳ:) or a great mountain (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ) rising high into the sky: (A:) or i. q. haDobapN [either as denoting a hill or mountain or a tract of sand: see the next sentence]: (IAạr:) pl. OaTowaAdN (A, L, Ḳ) and TiwadapN. (Ḳ.)
And An elevated, or overlooking, tract of sand; (Ḳ, TA;) as also haDobapN. (TA.)
And the pl. OaTowaAd is applied by a poet to signify ‡ Camels' humps; as being likened to mountains because of their height. (IAạr, L.)

Aibonu AlT-awodi means † The mass of rock (Aljulomuwdu) that falls from the upper part of a mountain: (A, L,* Ḳ:*) or the echo. (A.) One says, OasoraEu mini Qboni AlT-awodi † Quicker, or swifter, than the mass of rock that falls, &c.: or than the echo. (A.)
TaAdiI-N: see TaAdN.
maTaAdapN A desert, or waterless desert, far-extending: (Ḳ:) pl. maTaAwidu. (TA.) And the latter (i. e. the pl.), Places of perdition; (Ḳ, TA;) it is like maTaAwiHu. (Ṣ, TA.)
muTaw-idN Remote, or distant. (Ḳ.)
binaMCN munoTaAdN A lofty building, (Ḳ, TA,) rising high in the air. (TA.)
1. TaAra Hawolahu, aor. yaTuwru, (TA,) inf. n. TaworN and TawaraAnN, (Ḳ,) He went, or hovered, (HaAma,) round about it. (Ḳ,* TA.)

Hence, laA yaTuwruniI He will not approach my immediate vicinage. (TA.) And laA taTuro HaraAnaA Approach thou not our environs. (Ṣ, O, TA.) And laA OaTuwru bihi I will not approach him, or it: (Ṣ, O, TA:) occurring in a trad. (TA.) And fulaAnN yaTuwru bifulaAnK Such a one as it were hovers round about such a one, and draws near to him. (TA.)
maA OaboEada TaAraka for mA AbEd daAraka: see the remarks on letter T.

TaworN A time; one time; like the French “fois;” syn. taArapN: (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. OaTowaArN. (Ṣ, Ḳ, A.) You say, Oatayotuhu TaworFA baEoda TaworK I came to him time after time. (A.) faEala celika TaworFA baEoda TaworK He did that time after time. (Mṣb.) And jiYotuhu OaTowaArFA I came to him several times. (A.)

And State; condition; quality, mode, or manner; form, or appearance: pl. OaTowaArN. (Mṣb.) You say, Aln-aAsu OaTowaArN Mankind are of divers sorts and conditions. (Ṣ, A.*) It is said in the Ḳur [lxxi. 13], waqado xalaqakumo OaTowaArFA And He hath created you of divers sorts and conditions: (TA:) or of different forms, every one of his proper form: (Th, TA:) or of various aspects and dispositions: (TA:) or one time, a clot of blood; and one time, a lump of flesh: (Akh, Ṣ:) or [one time,] seed; then, a clot of blood; then, a lump of flesh; then, bone. (Fr, TA.)

And Quantity; measure; extent: (Ḳ:) limit: (Ṣ, A:) a limit between two things. (O, Ḳ.) You say, EadaA fulaAnN Taworahu Such a one exceeded his proper measure, or extent: (TA:) or his proper limit: (Ṣ, A, O, TA:) and taEad-aI Taworahu he transgressed the limits of his proper state, or condition. (Mṣb, TA.)

A thing that is commensurate, (L, Ḳ, TA,) or equal in length [and breadth (see EadaMCN)], (TA,) or correspondent, to a thing; (L, Ḳ, TA;) as also TuwrN↓ and TawaArN↓. (Ḳ.) You say of anything that is the equal of another thing, huwa Tuwruhu↓, and TawaAruhu↓ It is the equal of it. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) You say also, raOayotu HabolFA biTawaAri↓ hecaA AlHaAYiTi I saw a rope of the length of this wall. (TA.) And hecihi Ald-aAru biTawaAri↓ hecihi Ald-aAri This house has its wall contiguous to the wall of this [other] house, in one rank, or series. (TA.) And TawaAru↓ daArK, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and TiwaAru↓ dAr, (Ḳ,) and TaworuhaA, and TuwaratuhaA↓, (O,) The part of the finaMC [or exterior court, or yard], of a house, that is coextensive with the house; (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ;*) i. q. jawaAruhu. (Ḳ in art. jwr.) [See also the next paragraph.]

hom.sense: TuwrN: see TaworN, latter part, in two places.
The yard (finaMC) of house; (Ḳ;) as also TuwarapN↓. (TA.) [See also TawaAr, voce TaworN, last signification.]

A mountain: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or any mountain that produces trees, otherwise a mountain is not so called. (R, TA.) [Hence AlT-uwru is applied to Mount Sinai, which is also called Tuwru siynaMCa, and Tuwru siyniyna; and to the Mount of Olives, and to several other mountains; as is said in the Ḳ, &c.]

entry.sense: TuwarapN: see TaworN, last signification: and also TuwrN.
TiwarapN i. q. TiyarapN [q. v.]; (Ḳ;) a dial. var. of the latter word. (O.)

TawriI-N Wild; that estranges himself, or itself, from mankind; (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ;) applied to a bird, (Ṣ, O,) and to a man; (Ṣ, A, O;) as also TuwraAniI-N↓. (O.) You say, HamaAmN TuwriI-N, and TuwraAniI-N↓, Wild pigeons: (Ṣ, TA:) so called in relation to AlT-uwru, a certain mountain; or the mountain is called Tur-aAn, and [if so] it is an irreg. rel. n.: or that have come from a distant country. (TA.) [See also EuzofN.] And OaEaAriybu Tuwriy-uwna Wild Arabs of the desert, that avoid the towns and villages, from fear of epidemic disease, and of perdition: as though they were thus called in relation to the mountain named AlT-uwr, in Syria. (TA.) And rajulN TuwriI-N A stranger. (O, TA.)
maA bihaA TuwriI-N, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) and TuwraAniI-N↓, (Lth, O, Ḳ,) There is not in it (i. e. biAld-aAri in the house, A, TA) any one: (Lth, Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ:) as also duwriI-N. (TA.)
TuwraAniI-N: see TuwriI-N, in three places.
TawaArN and TiwaArN: see TaworN, latter part, in six places.

Such a one attained the two extremes of science, or learning; (Ṣ, O;) the beginning and the end thereof; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also OaTowariyhi: (Ḳ:) or the latter, which is the form mentioned by AZ, (Ṣ, O,) and by IAạr, (Sh, TA,) signifies the utmost point thereof; accord. to AZ, as related by AʼObeyd: (Ṣ, O:) or he attained, in science, or learning, his utmost, and his ambition; accord. to IAạr: (Sh, TA:) or balaga OaTowarayohi he attained the utmost of his endeavour. (L.)
balagotu mino fulaAnK OaTowarayohi I did the utmost in the case of such a one. (ISk, TA.)
rakiba fulaAnN Ald-ahora waOaTowarayohi [Such a one encountered fortune and] its two extremes. (Aṣ, TA.)
laqiIa minohu AlOaTowariyna, with kesr to the r, He experienced from him, or it, calamity. (Aṣ, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. TaAsa, aor. yaTuwsu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. TawosN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) He was, or became, beautiful, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) and bright, or fresh, (Ḳ, TA,) in face, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) after illness: (Ḳ, TA:) from AlT-awosu signifying “the moon:” so in the T: ascribed by Ṣgh to AA. (TA.) [In one copy of the Ṣ, this verb is omitted.]

TAs AlX-aIoCa, (M, O,) aor. as above, (O,) inf. n. TawosN, (M, A, O, Ḳ,) He trod, or trod upon, the thing; (M, A,* O, Ḳ;*) [like daAsahu;] and broke it: (M, O:) so says IDrd: (O:) and AlwaTosu is like AlT-awosu. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. maA OadoriI Oayona Taw-asa I know not whither he has gone (T, O, Ḳ) bihi [with him, or it]. (Ḳ.)
5. taTaw-asato She (a woman, A, Ḳ, or a girl, M) adorned herself: (M, A, Ṣgh, Ḳ:) [as though she made herself like a TaAWuws, or peacock.]

tTw-s He (a pigeon) shook, or ruffled, his feathers: you say, AlHamaAmu yakosaHu bicanabihi Hawola AlHamaAmapi wayataTaw-asu lahaA The male pigeon sweeps with his tail around the female pigeon, and shakes, or ruffles, his feathers to her. (A, TA.)
TaAsN [A drinking-cup; also vulgarly called TaAsap;] a certain thing in which one drinks; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or with which one drinks; accord. to AḤn, also called qaAquz-apN. (M.)
TawosN The moon: (IAạr, T, Ṣ, Ḳ: but omitted in one copy of the Ṣ:) or the moon a little after, or before, the change; i. q. hilaAlN: pl. OaTowaAsN. (M.)

TuwaAsN, (M, TA,) thus correctly, as written by El-Urmawee, with damm; not with fet-ḥ, as in the Ḳ and as written by Ṣgh; (TA;) [in the O, TawaAsu;] One of the nights of the last part of the [lunar] month; (M;) one of the nights called layaAliI AlmuHaAqi. (O, Ḳ.)

TaAWuwsN, (Ṣ, M, A, &c.,) of the measure faAEuwlN, (Mṣb,) the hemzeh being a substitute for w, (M,) [The peacock;] a certain bird, (Ṣ, M, A, O, Ḳ,) beautiful, (M, TA,) and well known: (O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) dim. TuwayosN, formed after the rejection of the augmentative letters: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. TawaAwiysu (M, A, Ḳ) and (sometimes, M) OaTowaAsN, (M, O, Ḳ,) by the rejection of what is augmentative: (M:) the former pl. is the more known. (TA.)
† A goodly, or beautiful, man; (El-Muärrij, O, Ḳ;) in the dial. of Syria. (El-Muärrij, O.)
† Silver; (A, O, Ḳ;) in the dial. of El-Yemen. (A, O.)
† Verdant land, wherein, (O, Ḳ,) or whereon, (T, O,) is every kind of plant, (O, Ḳ,) or of flowers, in the days of spring. (T, O.)
muTaw-asN Goodly, or beautiful; (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) applied to a face, (A, TA,) or other thing. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

1. TaAEa lahu, (T, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and TaAEahu, (Mṣb,) first pers. TuEotu, (Zj, O, Mṣb,*) aor. yaTuwEu, (T, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. TawoEN; (T, Mṣb, TA;) and, first pers. TiEotu, (Zj, O, Mṣb,*) aor. yaTaAEu, (T, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a good dial. var., (T, TA,) and yaTiyEu, (Mṣb, and Ḳ in art. TyE,) inf. n. TayoEN; (TA in art. TyE;)
three dial. vars., coordinate to qaAla and xaAfa and baAEa; (Mṣb;) He was, or became, submissive to him; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AnTAE↓ lh; (AO, Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) and ATAEhu↓, inf. n. UiTaAEapN, and subst. [i. e. quasi-inf. n.] TaAEapN↓: (Mṣb:) or i. q. ATAE↓; (T, TA;) which is expl. by ISd as meaning he was, or became, gentle, and submissive; as also TaAEa, aor. yaTaAEu: (TA:) [or each of these two verbs may be rendered he was, or became, obedient; or he obeyed; when by this is meant compliance with another's will or wish, not with a command: but] one says, Oamarahu faOTaAEahu↓ [He commanded him and he obeyed him], with A, not otherwise; (Ṣ;) or Oamarahu qaOaTaAEa [he commanded him and he obeyed]; for it is said that AlT-aAEapu↓ is never otherwise than a consequence of a command; and IF says that when one goes by command of another you say of him ATAEhu: (Mṣb:) Er-Rághib says that AlT-aAEapu↓ is like AlT-awoEu; but is mostly used as meaning obedience to a command [or the like; whence the saying, Aall-ahum-a laA tuTiyEan-a liI XaAmitFA, expl. in art. Xmt]: (TA:) and TAwEhu↓, also, signifies he obeyed him; like ATAEhu↓: you say, TAwEhu↓ EalaI Oamori kacaA he obeyed him in respect of such an affair. (MA. [But see 3 below.])
[Hence,] lisaAnuhu laA yaTuwEu bikacaA † His tongue will not aid, or assist, him with such a thing. (Ṣ, O.) See also 2. [And see 3.]

And sometimes (Ṣ) one says, TaAEa lahu AlmarotaEu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) like ATAE↓ lh, (ISk, Ṣ, O,) or like ATAEhu, (Ḳ,) meaning ‡ The pasturage enabled him to pasture his cattle upon it (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,* TA) wheresoever he would, (TA,) and was ample to him; (O, TA;) and it was not inaccessible to him. (TA.)
2. taTowiyEN [primarily] signifies The making obedient; or the causing to obey. (KL.)

faTaw-aEato lahu nafosuhu qatola Oaxiyhi, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,* Ḳ,*) in the Ḳur [v. 33], means ‡ And his soul, or mind, facilitated to him [the slaying of his brother]; (Akh, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA;) like Taw-aqatohu; (Akh, Ṣ, O, TA;) and like TaAwaEatohu↓, [which is one of the explanations in the O and Ḳ, and] which means the same; (Mṣb;) and accord. to this explanation it is tropical: Mbr says that it is an instance of faE-alato from AlT-awoEu; and TaAEato↓ and Taw-aEato are said to signify alike: (TA:) or the meaning is, aided him, or assisted him; (Fr, O, Ḳ;) accord. to which explanation, and that of Mbr, fiI is said by Az to be suppressed; the meaning being, fiI qatoli Oaxiyhi; or liqatoli Oaxiyhi; and he prefers the explanation of Akh: (TA:) or the meaning is, (O, Ḳ,) accord. to Mujáhid, (O,) encouraged him, and (O, Ḳ) AʼObeyd says that by this Mujáhid meant (TA) aided him, and complied with his wish. (O, Ḳ, TA,)

3. TAwEhu, (IF, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. muTaAwaEapN, (Ṣ, O, TA,) and quasi-inf. n. TawaAEiyapN, (TA,) i. q. waAfaqahu [as meaning He complied with him]. (IF, Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA.) You say, TAwEt AlmaroOapu zawojahaA, quasi-inf. n. TawaAEiyapN, The woman complied with her husband. (TA.) It is said that TAwEhu differs from OaTaAEahu. (Mṣb, TA.) But see 1, latter half, in two places.
See also 2.
One says also, TAwE lahu AlmuraAdu ‡ The thing wished, or desired, or sought after, [was, or became, easy of attainment to him; or] came to him easily. (TA.)
4. ATAE, inf. n. UiTaAEapN, and quasi-inf. n. TaAEapN: see 1, in four places. It also signifies He consented; or complied with what was desired of him; and so AstTAE↓. (TA.)

[Hence,] ATAE lahu AlmarotaEu: see 1, last sentence. One says also, ATAE Aln-axolu, (Ṣ, O,) and AlX-ajaru, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) ‡ The palm-trees, (Ṣ, O, TA,) and the trees, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) had ripe fruit, that might be gathered. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.) And ATAE Alt-amoru † The dates attained, or were near, to the time, or season, for their being cut off. (TA.)

5. tTw-E lilX-aIoCi and tTw-Ehu He desired the thing; or sought it; or sought it by artful, or skilful, management: or he constrained himself to do it: or he took it, or imposed it, upon himself submissively. (TA.) You say, taTaw-aEo lihecaA AlOamori Hat-aI tasotaTiyEahu, (Ṣ,) and taTaAwaEo↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) Constrain thyself to acquire ability to perform this affair until thou shalt be able to perform it. (Ṣ.) And tTw-E biAlX-aIoCi He did the thing without its being incumbent, or obligatory, on him; syn. tabar-aEa bihi. (Ṣ, O,* Mṣb.) mano taTaw-aEa xayorFA, in the Ḳur ii. 153 [and 180], means Whoso does good that is not obligatory on him: (Jel:) or does good in obedience, whether obligatory or supererogatory: or does good beyond what is obligatory on him: (Bḍ:) xayorFA being for bixayorK: (Bḍ,* Jel:) or it is an epithet qualifying an inf. n. suppressed: or the verb is made trans. as implying the meaning of OataI or faEalaI: (Bḍ:) and the Koofees, except 'Ásim, read yaT-aw-aEo, for yataTaw-aEo. (Az,* O, TA.*) [Hence,] TalaApu Alt-aTaw-uEi The supererogatory prayer; syn. Aln-aAfilapu. (O, Ḳ.) And Az says that taTaw-uEN signifies A thing that one does spontaneously, not made obligatory on him by an ordinance of God; as though it were made a subst. (TA.)
6: see the next preceding paragraph {5}.
7: see 1, first sentence.

10. AstTAE, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. AisotiTaAEapN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) originally AisotiTowaAEN, (O, B, TA,) i. q. OaTaAqa [meaning He was able; and he was able to do, or accomplish, a thing, and to acquire or obtain it, and to have it, &c.]; (Ḳ, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, OaTaAEa, which, however, correctly explains one meaning of AstTAE, as will be seen by what follows;]) the inf. n. being syn. with UiTaAqapN, (Ṣ, O, TA,) or TaAqapN, (Mṣb,) and qudorapN: (Mṣb, TA:) but it is said peculiarly of a human being [or a rational creature], whereas ATAq is used in a general manner: (IB, TA:) and the application of the former requires a peculiar constitution of the agent, and the conception of the act, and the fitness of the object to be acted upon or effected, and the possession of an instrument when the action is instrumental as in the case of writing: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and one says also, (Ḳ,) or sometimes they said, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) AisoTaAEa (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yasoTiyEu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) with fet-ḥ [to the first letter]; (Mṣb;) rejecting the t, deeming it difficult of utterance with the T, and disliking to incorporate it into the T because the s would then become movent, which it never is: Hamzeh (i. e. Ez-Zeiyát, TA, not Khallád, O, Ḳ, TA) read, [in the Ḳur xviii. 96,] famaA QsoT-aAEuwA, with idghám, combining two quiescent letters: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) this reading is said by Zj, as on the authority of Kh and Yoo and Sb and others, to be incorrect; but Abu-l-ʼAbbás Aḥmad Ibn Moḥammad Ibn-ʼAbd-El-Ghanee Ed-Dimyátee, who died in the year [of the Flight] 1116, and Ibn-El-Jezeree, and El-Háfidh Aboo-ʼAmr, contradict him, affirming it to be allowable: (TA:) and Akh says, (Ṣ, O,) and some of the Arabs say AisotaAEa, aor. yasotiyEu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) rejecting the T; (Ṣ, O;) which Zj holds to be not allowable in reading [the Ḳur-án]: (TA:) and some of the Arabs say OasoTaAEa, aor. yusoTiyEu, [in the CK, erroneously, yasoTiyEu,] with the disjunctive A [in the former], meaning OaTaAEa, aor. yuTiyEu, (Akh, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) making the s to be a substitute for the suppressed vowel of the medial radical letter of the verb [ATAE], (Akh, Ṣ, O,) for, as is said by Kh and Sb, OaTaAEa is originally OaTowaEa; (TA;) or, as AZ says, the verb in this case, with damm to the aor., is likened to OafoEala, aor. yufoEilu, inf. n. UifoEaAlN: (Mṣb:) but Zj says that he who reads famaA QsaT-aAEuwA errs; for the s of AisotafoEala is never movent: and Sb mentions maA OasotatiyEu; holding it to be an instance of substitution. (TA.)

See also 4. Some say that halo yasotaTiyEu rab-uka Oano yunaz-ila EalayonaA maAYidapF mina Als-amaMCi, in the Ḳur [v. 112], means halo yujiybu [i. e. Will thy Lord consent, or comply with the desire, that He should send down to us a table with food upon it from Heaven?]: (Er-Rághib, TA:)

and Ks read halo tasotaTiyEu rab-aka, meaning Wilt thou demand of thy Lord that He consent, or comply with the desire? (O, TA:) for AstTAEhu signifies also He demanded his obedience, and his consent, or compliance with what he desired of him. (TA.)
TaAEN accord. to the copies of the O and Ḳ; but some say TaAEK accord. to the O: see TaAYiEN, in three places.
TawoEN: see TaAYiEN, in seven places.

hom.sense: TaAEapN [quasi-inf. n. of 4: as a simple subst., sometimes meaning Submission, or submissiveness: but mostly, obedience to a command]: see 1, in three places; and see also TawaAEiyapN.
[See also TaAYiEN, of which it is a pl.]

entry.sense: TawaAEapN: see what next follows.

TawaAEiyapN i. q. TaAEapN↓: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) so in the saying fulaAnN Hasanu AlT-awaAEiyapi laka [Such a one is good in obedience to thee]: (Ṣ, O, TA:)
or it is a subst. from 3 [q. v.]; and so TwaAEap↓ [app. TawaAEapN]. (L, TA.)

TaAYiEN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TaAEN↓, (O, Ḳ,) and some say TaAEK↓, formed from TaAYiEN by transposition, (O,) and Tay-iEN↓, signify the same, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e. Being, or becoming, submissive; [or, simply, submissive; and obeying; or obedient;] (Mṣb;) and TawoEN↓, originally an inf. n., is likewise used as syn. with TaAYiEN: (Ḥam p. 408:) the pl. is Tuw-aEN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) i. e. pl. of TaAYiEN, (Ṣ, O,) and TaAEapN is [also a pl. of TaAYiEN, like as baAEapN is of baAYiEN; or] syn. with muTiyEuwna: (TA in art. swE:) [whence one says, daxala fiI TaAEatihi, and xaraja mino TaAEatihi, He entered among, and he quitted, his obeyers, or those who obeyed him; i. e. he became obedient, and he became disobedient, to him:] and miTowaAEN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) pl. maTaAwiyEu, (TA,) is [app., agreeably with analogy, an intensive epithet, meaning very submissive or obedient, but is said to be, in like manner,] syn. with muTiyEN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) applied to a man: (Ṣ, O:) and miTowaAEapN↓, applied to a man, [is app. a doubly intensive epithet; or] is syn. with miTowaAEN: (TA:) and is applied to a pl. number, as meaning compliant and submissive. (Ḥar p. 237.) One says, jaMCa fulaAnN TaAYiEFA Such a one came [submissively, or obediently, or willingly,] not being compelled against his will. (Ṣ, O.) And a poet says,
Halafotu biAlbayoti wamaA Hawolahu
mino EaAYicK biAlbayoti OawoTaAEi↓
[I swore, or have sworn, by the House of God (i. e. the Kaabeh), and what are around it, of such as betakes himself for refuge to the House or of such as renders obedience by visiting it]. (O.) And one says also, jaMCa Tay-iEFA↓ [He came of his own accord, or willingly]. (M and TA voce cuw.) And Tay-iEu↓ All-isaAni ‡ A man chaste, or eloquent, in speech. (TA.) And naAqapN Tay-iEapu↓ AlqiyaAdi and TawoEu↓ AlqiyaAdi † A she-camel that is gentle; [or tractable;] that does not contend with her leader. (TA.) And farasN TawoEu↓ AlEinaAni ‡ A traciable horse. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.) And fulaAnN TawoEu↓ yadika ‡ Such a one is submissive to thy hand. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.) And AimoraOapN TawoEu↓ AlD-ajiyEi A woman submissive to the bedfellow. (TA.) And fulaAnN TawoEu↓ AlmakaArihi † Such a one is submissive to misfortunes, [being] subject thereto. (T, TA.) [See also an ex. of TawoE↓ in a verse cited in art. Xmt voce XaAmitapN.] huwa OaTowaEu↓ Als-inaAni means † He is one to whom the spear-head is subservient, howsoever he will. (Ḳ in art. sn.)
Tay-iEN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

OaTowaEu [as signifying More, and most, submissive or obedient is regularly formed from TaAEa; or] is from AlT-aAEapu [i. e. from OaTaAEa], and similar to Oajowabu [from OajaAba, and therefore anomalous]. (M and L in art. jwb.) OaTowaEu mino farasK, and mino kalobK, [More submissive, or obedient, that a horse, and than a dog,] are provs. (Meyd.)
[It app. signifies also Very submissive or obedient: see an ex. in a verse cited voce tabad-aEa.]
[And it is also a simple epithet, like Oahowanu, &c.:] see TaAYiEN, last sentence.

XuH-N muTaAEN means A niggardliness that is obeyed by him who is characterized thereby, by the refusing rights, or dues, (O, Ḳ,) which God has rendered obligatory on him, in respect of his property: occurring in a trad. of the Prophet. (O.) And AlmuTaAEu, as a name of the Prophet, means He whose prayer is answered; whose intercession for his people is accepted. (TA.)
miTowaAEN: see TaAYiEN, first sentence.
miTowaAEapN [an epithet of a very rare form, like miEozaAbapN, q. v.]: see TaAYiEN.

muTaAwiEN an epithet applied by the grammarians to ‡ A verb that is intransitive [such as I term quasi-passive; expl. as meaning a verb whose (grammatical) agent receives the effect of the action of the agent of another verb (fiEolN yaqobalu faAEiluhu Oavara fiEoli faAEili fiEolK Mxara)]. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
AlmuT-aw-iEapu and AlmuT-aw-iEiyna: see what follows.

mutaTaw-iEN A supererogator in any good act. (O, Ḳ.) One says, faEalahu mutaTaw-iEFA [He did it without its being incumbent, or obligatory, on him; supererogatorily: or gratuitously, unasked, or unbidden: or disinterestedly; not seeking, or desiring, a compensation: syn. mutabar-iEFA]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. brE.) And AlmuT-aw-iEapu↓ means Those who exceed what is obligatory on them in fighting, or warring, against unbelievers or the like; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) originally AlmutaTaw-iEapu: (Mṣb:) hence AlmuT-aw-iEiyna↓ in the Ḳur ix. 80; originally AlmutaTaw-iEiyna. (Ṣ, O.)

hom.sense: 1. The inf. n. TawaAfN primarily signifies, accord. to Er-Rághib, The act of going, or walking, in an absolute sense: or the going, or walking, around, or otherwise. (MF, TA.) [Hence,] TaAfa Hawola AlX-aIoCi, (Ṣ,) or biAlX-aIoCi, (Mṣb,) or Hawola AlkaEobapi, (O, Ḳ,) and bihaA, (Ḳ,) aor. yaTuwfu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) inf. n. TawofN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TawaAfN (O, Mṣb, Ḳ, and mentioned also in the Ṣ but not there said to be an inf. n.) and TawafaAnN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) [and perhaps TuwfaAnN, q. v.,] He went round or round about, circuited, or circuited around, or compassed, (Mṣb, TA,) the thing, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or the Kaabeh; (O, Ḳ;) and so TaAfa, aor. yaTiyfu; (Mṣb; [but this I think doubtful;]) and tTw-f↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AiT-aw-afa↓, a variation of that next preceding, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. AiT-iw-aAfN; (TA;) and AstTAf↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as also AstTAfhu↓; (TA;) and ATAf↓ bihi, (Mṣb,) or Ealayohi; (TA;) and Tw-f↓, inf. n. taTowiyfN↓; (Ḳ;) or this last signifies he did so much, or often. (Ṣ, TA.) And TAf biAlqawomi, aor. yaTuwfu, inf. n. TawofN and TawafaAnN and maTaAfN, He went round about [or round about among] the people, or party; as also ATAf↓: the aor. of the former verb occurs in the Ḳur lvi. 17 and lxxvi. 19, trans. by means of EalaI. (TA.) And Tufotu bihi EalaI Albayoti [I went round the House of God, i. e. the Kaabeh, with him; or] I made him to go round, or to circuit, or compass, the House. (Mṣb. [The vulgar in the present day say Taw-afotuhu↓: and they apply the appellation muTaw-if↓ to One who makes the circuits round the Kaabeh with a pilgrim, and serves to conduct him round about to the other sacred objects, or places.]) You say also, TAf fiI AlbilaAdi, inf. n. TawofN and taTowaAfN, He journeyed [or journeyed round about] in the countries, or tracts of country; and so [or as meaning he did so much or often] Tw-f↓, inf. n. taTowiyfN and taTowaAfN. (TA. [In one place in the TA, the latter inf. n. is said to be with kesr, so that it is like tiboyaAnN; but see this latter, which is very extr.: see also tiTowaAfN below.]) laOaTuwfan-a↓ Tawofahu means the same as laOasoEaran-a saEorahu [app. I will assuredly practise circumvention like his practising thereof]. (Fr, O and Ḳ in art. sEr, q. v.)
See also 4, in two places.

TaAfa, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) inf. n. TawofN, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb,) from TawofN signifying gaAYiTN; (Ṣ, O;) as also AiT-aAfa↓, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AT-aOafa,]) He voided his excrement, or ordure; (Mgh, Mṣb;*) or he went away (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) to the field, or open tract, (Ṣ, O,) to void his excrement, or ordure. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in three places.
You say also, Tw-f Aln-aAsu, and AljaraAdu, The men, or people, and the locusts, filled the land like the TuwfaAn [or flood]. (TA.)
4: see 1, in two places.
ATAf biAlX-aIoCi signifies also He, or it, surrounded, or encompassed, the thing. (Mṣb.)

And ATAf bihi He came to him; visited him; or alighted at his abode as a guest; syn. Oalam-a bihi: and he approached him; or drew, or was, or became, near to him; syn. qaArabahu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [And] TaAfa↓ biAln-isaMCi, aor. yaTuwfu; and ATAf; He came to women, or the women; visited them; or alighted at their abodes as a guest; syn. Oalam-a (Mṣb.) And ATAf bihi and Ealayohi He came to him by night: and sometimes improperly used as meaning by day:
a poet says,
OaTafotu bihaA nahaArFA gayora layolK
waOalohaI rab-ahaA Talabu Alr-iHaAli
[I came to her by day, not by night, while the seeking for the camels' saddles, or for the things necessary for his journey, or for the places of alighting, diverted her lord, or husband, from attending to her]. (TA.) And TAf↓ bihi AlxayaAlu, aor. yaTuwfu, inf. n. TawofN; and, as Aṣ used to say, TAf, aor. yaTiyfu, inf. n. TayofN; The xyAl [i. e. apparition, or phantom,] came to him, or visited him, (Oalam-a bihi,) in sleep. (TA.)
5. tTw-f and AiT-aw-afa: see 1, first sentence.
8. AiT-aAfN: see 1, last sentence.
10: see 1, first sentence, in two places.

hom.sense: TaAfN A man who goes round, or round about, much, or often; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) [and] so Taw-aAfN↓: and Taw-aAfapN↓ a woman who goes round, or round about, much, or often, to the tents, or houses, of her female neighbours. (Mṣb.)
See also Tuwf.
TawofN in the phrase OaSaAbahu mina AlX-ayoTaAni TawofN, i. q. TaAYifN. (TA. See TaAYifN below, and in art. Tyf.)

[Also A kind of float composed of] inflated water-skins bound together, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with wood [or planks] laid upon them, (Mṣb,) so as to have the form of a flat roof, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) upon the water; (Mṣb;) used for embarking thereon upon the water and for carriage thereon (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) of wheat or other provisions and of men, and for the crossing [of rivers] thereon: (TA:) i. q. ramavN: and sometimes it is of wood, or timber: (Ṣ, O:) accord. to Az, a thing upon which large rivers are crossed, made of canes and of pieces of wood bound together, one upon another, and then bound round with ropes of the fibres or leaves of the palm-tree so as to be secure from its becoming unbound; after which it is used for embarking thereon and crossing, and sometimes it is laden with a load proportionate to its strength and its thickness: and it is also called EaAmapN, without teshdeed to the m: (TA:) pl. OaTowaAfN. (Mṣb, TA.)
And The bull (vawor) around which turn the oxen in the treading [of corn]. (TA.) [See TaAYifN.]
And i. q. qilodN [app. as meaning A portion of water for irrigation: for it is immediately added], and Tawofu AlqaSabi signifies the quantity of water with which the canes are irrigated. (TA.)

Also The foul matter that comes forth from the child after suckling: (El-Aḥmar, Mṣb, TA:) and by a secondary application, (Mṣb,) human excrement, or ordure, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in an absolute sense: (Mṣb:) what Er-Rághib says respecting it indicates that this is metonymical. (TA.)

entry.sense: Oaxacahu biTuwfi raqabatihi and biTaAfi↓ rqbth i. q. biSuwfi rqbth (Ṣ, Ḳ) and biSaAfihaA. (Ḳ.)

TuwfaAnN An overpowering rain: and overpowering water, [a meaning erroneously assigned in the CK to Taw-aAf instead of TuwfaAn,] that covers [or overwhelms] everything; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) in the common conventional acceptation, water abounding to the utmost degree; [i. e. a flood, or deluge;] such as befell the people of Noah; (TA;) or TuwfaAnu AlmaMCi signifies the water that covers [or overwhelms] everything: (Mṣb:) and a drowning torrent: (Ḳ:) and † much of anything, [like as we say a flood of anything,] such as includes the generality of persons, or things, within its compass: (Ḳ, TA:) and particularly † death; or quick, or quick and wide-spreading, death; or death commonly, or generally, prevailing; (TA;) or quick, or quick and wide-spreading, death, commonly, or generally, prevailing: and † quick [and extensive] slaughter: (Ḳ:) and † any accident [or evil accident] that besets a man: and † trial, or affliction: (TA:) and El-ʼAjjáj likens to the rain, or water, thus called, the darkness of night; using the phrase TuwfaAnu AlZ-alaAmi; (Kh, Ṣ;) by which he means † the intensity of the darkness of the night: (TA:) TuwfaAnN is said to be a pl. [or coll. gen. n.]; (Mṣb, TA;) and its sing. [or n. un.] is TuwfaAnapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) accord. to analogy: (Ṣ:) thus says Akh: (Ṣ, TA:) or it is an inf. n., like rujoHaAnN and nuqoSaAnN; and is from TaAfa, aor. yaTuwfu: (Mṣb, TA:) thus says Abu-l- ʼAbbás; and he says that there is no need of seeking for it a sing.: some say that it is of the measure fuloEaAnN, from TafaA AlmaMCu, aor. yaTofuw, meaning “the water rose,” or “became high;” the l being transposed to the place of the E; but this is strange. (TA.)
TawaAfN [is an inf. n. of 1, q. v., sometimes used as a simple subst., and] has for its pl. OaTowaAfN [which is regularly pl. of TawofN]. (TA.)

hom.sense: Taw-aAfN and its fem. with p {Taw-aAfapN}: see TaAfN.

The former signifies also A servant who serves one with gentleness and carefulness: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. Taw-aAfuwna: so says AHeyth: IDrd explains the pl. as meaning servants, and male slaves. (TA.) It is said in a trad., respecting the she-cat, that it is not unclean, but is mina AlT-aw-aAfiyna Ealayokumo, or AlT-aw-aAfaAti; [i. e. of those that go round about waiting upon you;] she being thus put it. the predicament of the slaves: whence the saying of En-Nakha'ee, that the she-cat is like some of the people of the house, or tent. (TA.) [In the CK, a meaning belonging to TuwfaAn is erroneously assigned to Taw-aAf.]
Also A maker of the Tawof that is composed of [inflated] water-skins [&c.] upon which one crosses [rivers, &c.]. (TA.)
TaAYifN part. n. of TaAfa, signifying Going round or round about,, &c. (Mṣb.)

[And hence,] The Easas [quasi-pl. n. of EaAs-N]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) [i. e.] the patrol, or watch that go the round of the houses; thus expl. by Er-Rághib; and said to mean particularly those who do so by night. (TA.)
And The bull that is next to the extremity, or side, of the kudos [or wheat collected together in the place where it is trodden out]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) [See TawofN.]

The TaAYif of the bow is The part between the siYap [or curved portion of the extremity] and the Oabohar [q. v.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or near [the length of a cubit or] the bone of the fore arm from its [middle portion called the] kabid [thus I render qariybN mino EaZomi Alc-iraAEi mino kabidihaA, which, I think, can have no other meaning]: or the TaAYifaAni are [two parts] exclusive of the two curved ends (duwna Als-iYatayoni): (Ḳ: [this last explanation seems to leave one of the limits of each TAYf undefined:]) or, accord. to AḤn, the TAYf of the bow is the part beyond its kuloyap [q. v.], above and below, [extending] to the place of the curving of the end of the bow: the pl. is TawaAYifu. (TA.)

laOaqoTaEan-a minohu TaAYifFA occurs in a trad. respecting a runaway slave, as meaning [I will assuredly cut off] some one, or more, of his OaToraAf [app. meaning fingers]: or, as some relate it, the word is TaAbaqFA. (TA.) And Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhalee says,
taqaEu Als-uyuwfu EalaI TawaAYifa minohumu
meaning, it is said, [The swords fall upon] arms and legs or hands and feet [of them: but in this case, TawaAYif may be pl. of TaAYifapN↓]. (TA.)

entry.sense: TaAYifapN A detached, or distinct, part or portion; a piece, or bit; [or somewhat;] of a thing: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and a firoqap of men [i. e. a party, portion, division, or class, thereof; as those of one profession or trade: a body, or distinct community: a sect: a corps: and sometimes a people, or nation]: (Mṣb:) and a company, or congregated body, (Mṣb, KL,) of men, at least consisting of three; and sometimes applied to one; and two: (Mṣb:) or one: and more than one: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so, accord. to I’Ab, in the Ḳur xxiv. 2: (Ṣ:) or up to a thousand: (Mujáhid, Ḳ:) or at least two men: (ʼAṭà, Ḳ:) or one man; (Ḳ;) as is said also on the authority of Mujáhid; (TA;) so that it is syn. with nafosN [as meaning a single person, or an individual]: (Ḳ:) [and sometimes it is applied to a distinct number, or herd, &c., of animals:] Er-Rághib says that when a plural or collective number is meant thereby, it is [what lexicologists term] a pl. of TaAYifN; and when one is meant thereby, it may be a pl. metonymically used as a sing., or it may be considered as of the class of raAwiyapN and Eal-aAmapN and the like: (TA:) [pl. TawaAYifu.]
See also TaAYifN, last sentence but one.
TaAYifiI-N A sort of raisins, of which the bunches are composed of closely-compacted berries: app. so called in relation to [the district of] Et-Táïf. (AḤn, TA.)

tiTowaAfN, (JM, TA,) with kesr, (TA,) [and app. taTowaAfN also, as it is sometimes written,] for cuw tTwAfK, (JM,) A garment in which one goes round, or curcuits, (JM, TA,) the House [of God, i. e. the Kaabeh]. (JM.)
maTaAfN A place of TawaAf (O, Mṣb, Ḳ *) i. e. of going round or round about, or circuiting. (Mṣb.)
muTaw-ifN: see 1, latter half.
1. TaAqahu, inf. n. TawoqN: see 4.

hom.sense: 2. Tw-qh, (Ṣ, TA,) or Tw-qhu TawoqFA, (O, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. taTowiyqN, (TA,) He attired him with a Tawoq [or neck-ring]. (Ṣ, TA.)

[Hence,] Taw-aqotuhu AlX-aIoCa means † I made the thing to be [as though it were] his Tawoq [or neck-ring]: and thereby is expressed the imposing [upon one] a thing that is difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient: (Mṣb:) [i. e.] Taw-aqotuka AlX-aIoCa means † I imposed, or have imposed, upon thee the thing as one that is difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.*) sayuTaw-aquwna maA baxiluwA bihi, in the Ḳur [iii. 176], means † They shall have that whereof they were niggardly made to cleave to their necks [like the neck-ring]: (O, TA:) as is said in a trad., it shall be made a biting snake upon the neck. (Jel.) And [in the Ḳur ii. 180] some read, waEalaI Ql-aciyna yuTaw-aquwnahu, [in the CK, erroneously, yuTaw-iquwnahu,] meaning, † And upon those who shall have it put [upon them] like the Tawoq upon their necks [shall be incumbent, &c.]: (Ḳ, TA:) which is like the saying yujaX-amuwnahu and yukal-afuwnahu [i. e. shall have it imposed upon them as a thing that is difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient]: (TA:) another reading is yaT-aw-aquwnahu↓, [in the CK, erroneously, yuT-aw-aquwnahu,] originally yataTaw-aquwnahu [meaning the same as the former reading]: and another, yuTay-aquwnahu↓, originally yuTayowaquwnahu [also meaning the same; in the CK, erroneously, yuTayoquwnahu]: and another, yaT-ay-aquwnahu↓, [in the CK, erroneously, with damm to the first letter, and so in what follows,] originally yataTayowaquwnahu [also meaning the same]. (Ḳ, TA.) One says also, Tw-qhu bihi and Tw-qhu Uiy-aAhu, meaning † He made it, namely, a sword, &c., to be to him a Tawoq [or thing encircling, or going round, his neck]. (TA.) And Taw-aqaniI niEomapF ‡ [He conferred upon me a permanent badge of favour]: and Tuw-iqotu minohu OayaAdiIa ‡ [I had permanent badges of favours from him conferred upon me]: and the verb is also used [in like manner] to denote dispraise, to which it has been erroneously said by some to be restricted. (TA. [See also 2 in art. qld: and see TawoqN.])
Tw-qt AlHay-apu: see 5.

Taw-aqaniIa Qll-ehu OadaMCa Haq-ka, (Ṣ, O,) or Haq-ihi, (Ḳ,) means God strengthened me, or empowered me, sufficiently for the giving, or paying, of thy due, or of his due: syn. qaw-aAniI (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) Ealayohi. (Ḳ.) And Tuw-iqahu He was enabled to do it. (TA.)
Taw-aqato lahu nafosuhu (Akh, Ṣ, O, Ḳ) is syn. with Taw-aEato, (Akh, Ṣ, O,) meaning His soul, or mind, facilitated to him [the doing of a thing]. (Akh, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. ATAq AlX-aIoCa, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and ATAq Ealayohi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UiTaAqapN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and TaAqapN is the subst. (Az, Mṣb, Ḳ) used in the place of the inf. n. like TaAEapN in the place of UiTaAEapN, (Az, TA,) He was, or became, able to do, or accomplish, or to bear, the thing; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also TaAqahu↓, (Az,* Ḳ,) aor. yaTuwqu, (Az, TA,) inf. n. TawoqN. (Az, Ḳ.) It is not used exclusively of a human being, as some assert it to be; but is used in a general manner. (TA.) [One says laA yuTalqu meaning He will not be, or is not to be, coped with: and also as meaning it is not to be done, or to be borne, endured, or tolerated: and so maA yuTaAqu: see an ex. voce HamoDa.]
5. tTw-q He put on, or attired himself with, a Tawoq [or neck-ring]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

[Hence, tTw-qhu, and tTw-q bihi, † He had it put upon him, and he bore it, and he took it upon himself, like the Tawoq upon the neck: and he had it imposed upon him, and he imposed it upon himself, as a thing that was difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient]. See 2. [See also Ḥar p. 310. And see 5 in art. qld.]
Q. Q. 1. yuTay-aquwnahu, originally yuTayowaquwnahu: see 2.
Q. Q. 2. yaT-ay-aquwnahu, originally yataTayowaquwnahu: see 2.

hom.sense: TaAqN A curved construction or structure; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) [said to be] a Pers. word arabicized; (Ṣ, O;) and its pl. is TaAqaAtN and TiyqaAnN: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or an arch of a building, wherever it is; and the pl. is OaTowaAqN and TiyqaAnN: (JK, TA:) and as signifying [thus, or] an arch constructed with bricks, it is [said to be] originally TaAYiqN↓; and therefore to have for its pl. TawaAYiqu: so says Az. (TA.) [It is often applied to An arched gateway or doorway: and to a vault. And] i. q. kuw-apN [i. e. A mural aperture; a hole, or an aperture, in a wall; a meaning also assigned to UiforiyzN, by which TaAqN will be found to be expl. in what follows: or a niche in a wall; which, as also a window, is now often called TaAqapN↓]. (So in the Munjid of Kr.) [And app. A kind of arched construction with a flat top which forms a shelf, against a wall. (See raf-N and sahowapN.)] And i. q. UiforiyzN [which is expl. as meaning a projecting roof or covering of a wall: and a projecting coping, or ledge, or cornice, surrounding the upper part of a wall: and in the KL as meaning a hole, or an aperture, of a wall; (as mentioned above;) but its author adds “so we have heard”]: (MA voce UiforiyzN:) or so OaTowaAqN. (JK, and O on the authority of Ibn-ʼAbbád. [But this I think doubtful, and the more so as it will be seen in what follows that another meaning assigned in these same lexicons to OaTowaAqN is said by IB to be a meaning of TaAqN.])
See also TaAYiqN, in two places.

[Also A layer, stratum, lamina, or the like; or any flat piece, or portion, of a thing, such as is in some cases placed over, or under, a similar piece or portion: and anything such as is in some cases lined, or faced, or otherwise combined, with another similar thing: pl. TaAqaAtN.] You say TaAqu naEolK [A single piece of leather of a sole that consists of two or more of such pieces]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and TaAqapu↓ nEolK [which means the same]. (Ḳ.) And naEolN TaAqN waAHidN A single sole; i. e. a sole of a single piece; not made of two pieces sewed together, one upon the other. (TA in art. nEl.) And [in like manner] a garment is said to be TaAqN waAHidN [i. e. Single, not double, not lined nor faced nor stuffed]. (Az, in TA in art. smT, [where this meaning is clearly indicated,] and Th, in M, same art.) Thus one says saraAwiylu TaAqN waAHidN [Trousers, or drawers, of single cloth]. (Th, M and Ḳ in art. smT.) [See also what is said of the phrase Als-araAwiylu AlT-aAqu voce rijolN.] One says also gazolN TaAqN waAHidN [Spun thread that is a single yarn]: and gazolN mafotuwlN TaAqayoni [Spun thread twisted of two yarns]. (Ṣ and TA in art. sHl.) See also TaAqapN, which has a similar meaning. [And see an ex. of the pl. TaAqaAt voce raboEapN.]
Also A certain sort of garment, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) having sleeves. (Ṣ, O.) [And] accord. to Esh-Shereeshee, A garment worn by a new-born child, or young infant, without an opening at the bosom. (Ḥar p. 502.)

And (O, Ḳ) accord. to IAạr, (O,) A [garment of the kind called] TayolasaAn [q. v.]: (O, Ḳ:) or such as is OaxoDar [properly meaning green; but when applied to a garment commonly meaning, as used by the Arabs, of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour; or a dingy ashcolour]: (Kr, Ḳ:) pl. TiyqaAnN, like siyjaAnN pl. of saAjN. (TA.)
And A [garment of the kind called] kisaMCi: (IB, TA:) and (TA) so OaTowaAqN. (JK, and O and TA on the authority of Ibn-ʼAbbád. [But this, as I have shown above, I think doubtful.])
And A [woman's muffler, or head-covering, such as is called] ximaAr. (IAạr, TA.)
And one says, raOayotu OaroDFA kaOan-ahaA AlT-iyqaAnu ‡ [I saw a land as though it were spread with the garments called TyqAn]; meaning, whereof the herbage was abundant. (TA.)

TawoqN [A neck-ring;] a certain ornament for the neck; (Ḳ;) a thing well known: (Mṣb:) [its most usual from is figured in my work on the Modern Egyptians, Appendix A:] pl. OaTowaAqN. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in a prov., kabira EamorNw Eani AlT-awoqi [ʼAmr has become too much advanced in age for the neck-ring]: (AʼObeyd, O, Ḳ, TA: in some copies of the Ḳ [erroneously] kabura:) or Xab-a EamorNw Eani AlT-awoqi, [which has the like meaning,] as in most of the books of proverbs: (TA:) applied to him who occupies himself with a thing that is beneath his ability. (Ḳ. [For the story of the origin of this prov., see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 319-21, or Ḥar pp. 502-3; as it is too long to be quoted here.])
And Anything that surrounds another thing (Mṣb, Ḳ) is called its Tawoq. (Mṣb.)
Hence caAtu AlT-awoqi as an appel-lation of The [ringed] pigeon [or ring-dove]. (Mṣb.)

[And hence] one says, taqal-adotu Aln-iEomapa Tawoqa AlHamaAmapi ‡ [I bore the favour as the ring of the pigeon; meaning, as a permanent badge or decoration]:
and fiI EunuqiI TawoqN maA liI biOadaMCi Xukorihi TawoqN ‡ [Upon my neck is a permanent badge or decoration, for which I have not ability to render due acknowledgment]: so in the A: hence also the saying of El-Mutanebbee,
OaqaAmato fiI Alr-iqaAbi lahu OayaAdK
hiIa AlOaTowaAqu waAln-aAsu AlHamaAmu
[Favours of his have remained upon the necks: they are the neck-rings, and the men are the pigeons]. (TA. [See, for this verse, p. 164 of Dieterici's ed. of the Deewán of El-Mutanebbee.])
AlT-awoqu signifies also The neck [itself]. (TA.)
And The kar-, (O,) or HaAbuwl, (Ḳ,) [i. e. the rope in the form of a loop] by means of which one ascends the palm-tree. (O, Ḳ.*)
See also the next paragraph, first and second sentences.

TaAqapN is the subst. from OaTaAqa, (Az, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and is used in the place of the inf. n., (Az, TA,) and [when used as a simple subst.] signifies Ability, or power; (Ṣ, O,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so TawoqN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) which is [originally] an inf. n., (Az, Ḳ,) and is also expl. as meaning the utmost that one can do, with difficulty, trouble, or inconvenience. (TA.) One says, [laA TaAqapa liI bihi I have not ability, or power, to do it, or to bear or endure or tolerate it: and, to cope with him: (see Ḳur ii. last verse: and verse 250:) and] huwa fiI TawoqiI↓ It is within my ability, or power. (Ṣ.) In the phrase Talabotahu TaAqataka, [as meaning Thou soughtest him, or it, in thy state of ability, or power,] Sb says, the [quasi-] inf. n. is prefixed [to the pronoun, and thus rendered determinate], though occupying the place of a denotative of state; in like manner as the article Al is prefixed [to ErAk] in the phrase OarosalahaA. (TA.)

[Also A slender and small bundle or fascicle of fibres or filaments or the like, one of those whereof two or more, twisted together, compose a rope; a strand, a yarn, a single twist, or single thread, of a rope or cord or fringe, &c.] You say TaAqapN mino HabolK A strand, yarn, or single twist, of a rope; syn. quw-apN; (Ṣ voce quw-apN;) and so TaAqN↓ mino HabolK, pl. OaTowaAqN: (JK voce quw-apN:) [the pl. of TaAqapN in this sense is TaAqaAtN:] TaAqaAtu AlHaboli means quwaAhu, as is said in the A. (TA.)

And A XuEobap [i. e. spring, spray, bunch, or branchlet,] of sweet basil, or of sweet-smelling plants: and likewise [a lock, or flock,] of hair: (JK, TA:) [and so of wool, and the like;] you say TaAqapu rayoHaAnK, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) [or mino rayoHaAnK, &c.,] meaning XuEobapN minohu, as in the A. (TA.)
TaAqapu naEolK: see TaAqN, latter half.
See also another meaning of TaAqapN voce TaAqN, first quarter.

entry.sense: TawoqapN A round, and plain, or soft, piece of ground, amid rugged tracts of ground: (O, Ḳ:) mentioned by IDrd as occurring in some poem of the Time of Ignorance but not heard by him from his companions. (O.)

TaAYiqN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and TaAqN↓ (O, Ḳ) A prominence [app. meaning a ledge or ridge] projecting from a mountain: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and the former, (Ṣ,) or the latter, (Ḳ,) or each, (O,) also the like thereof in a well; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ; [in the CK, Aln-iyri is erroneously put for AlbiYori;]) i. e., in the wall that surrounds the interior of a well; and its pl. is TawaAYiqu: (TA:) and between any two pieces of wood [or planks] of a ship, or boat: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or TaAYiqN signifies one of the pieces of wood [or planks] of the interior of a zaworaq [or skiff]: accord. to Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee, it is the middle. or in the middle, of a ship or boat: and accord. to Aṣ, a prominence projecting from a ship, or boat, like a ledge swelling out from a mountain: and also, he says, a ridge, or ledge, in a [mountain, or portion of a mountain, such as is termed] qun-ap: accord. to Lth, TaAYiqu kul-i XaIoCK signifies any mountain, or [hill such as is termed] Oakamap, that surrounds anything: and its pl. is OaTowaAqN [like OaSoHaAbN pl. of SaAHibN]. (TA.)
TaAYiqN also signifies, accord. to Ibn-Hamzeh, The curved extremity of a bow; which is said to be called its TaAq↓; but this he disallows. (TA.)
See also TaAqN, first sentence.

hom.sense: OaTowaAqN [a pl. of TaAqN: and of TawoqN: and of TaAYiqN.]

[Also] The milk of the cocoa-nut: (O, Ḳ, TA:) AḤn says, (O, TA,) it is very intoxicating; (O, Ḳ, TA;) moderately as long as its drinker does not go forth to the wind; but if he does so, his intoxication becomes excessive; (Ḳ, TA;) and when he who is not accustomed to it, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and is not suited to it, (O, TA,) continues constantly the drinking of it, it vitiates his intellect, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and confuses his understanding: (O, TA:) when it remains until the morrow, it becomes most acid vinegar. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: HamaAmN muTaw-aqN, (O,) and HamaAmapN muTaw-aqapN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) [Pigeons, and a pigeon,] having [i. e. marked with] a ring upon the neck. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And muTaw-aqapN signifies A large qaAruwrap [i. e. flask, or bottle,] having a ringed neck: (O, Ḳ:) thus called by the people of El-'Irák. (O.)

hom.sense: 1. TaAla, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said by some to be of the class of qaruba, being made by them to accord in from with its contr., which is qaSura, and by others said to be of the class of qaAla, (Mṣb,) first pers. Tulotu, [said to be] originally Tawulotu, because one says TawiylN, [not TaAYilN, when using it as an intrans. v.,] (Ṣ, O,) aor. yaTuwlu, (TA,) inf. n. TuwlN, (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) It (a thing, Ṣ, O, Mṣb) was, or became, elongated, or extended; [i. e. it was, or became, long; and it was, or became, tall, or high; which meanings are sometimes more explicitly denoted in order to avoid ambiguity, as when one says TaAla EalaI wajohi AlOaroDi it was, or became, elongated, or extended, upon the surface of the earth or ground; and TaAla fiI Als-amaMCi it was, or became, elongated, or extended, towards (lit. into) the sky;] (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AstTAl↓ signifies the same. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) It is also said of any time that is extended; and of anxiety that cleaves to one continually; and the like: [see TuwlN, below:] thus one says TaAla All-ayolu [The night became long, or protracted]: (TA:) [and thus TaAla Ealayohimu AlOamadu, in the Ḳur lvii. 15, means The time became extended, or prolonged, unto them:] and taTaAwala↓ Ealayohimu AlEumuru, in the Ḳur xxviii. 45, means, in like manner, [Life was prolonged unto them; or] their lives became long, or prolonged: (Jel:) and TAl Almajolisu The time of the assembly was, or became, extended, or prolonged: (Mṣb:) and TAl Alham-u [Anxiety became protracted]. (TA.) [One says also TaAlamaA faEala kacaA Long time did he thus; and the like; with the restrictive mA: see Ḥar p. 17.]

When trans. [without a particle] it is of the class faEala; not faEula, because this is not trans.: (TA:) one says Tulotuhu meaning I exceeded him, or surpassed him, in AlT-uwl [i. e. tallness; or I overtopped him]: and also in AlT-awol [i. e. beneficence, and excellence,, &c.]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) See 3. A poet says,
Uin-a Alfarazodaqa SaxorapN EaAriyapN
TaAlato falayosa tanaAluhaA AlOawoEaAlu
[Verily El-Farezdaḳ is a bare rock that has exceeded in height the mountain-goats so that the mountain-goats do not reach it]: he means TaAlati AlOawoEaAla. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., faTaAla AlEab-aAsu Eumara i. e. And El-ʼAbbás exceeded ʼOmar in tallness of stature. (TA.) And you say, TaAlahu fiI AlHasabi [He excelled him in the grounds of pretension to respect or honour]. (Ḳ and TA in explanation of Xarafahu: in the CK [erroneously] TAwalahu.)

One says also, TAl Ealayohi, (Ṣ,) or Ealayohimo, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) the verb in this case being of the class of qaAla, aor. yaTuwlu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. TawolN; (Ṣ,* Mṣb;) and tTw-l↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and ATAl↓; (Mṣb;) He bestowed, or conferred, a benefit or benefits, or a favour or favours, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) upon him, (Ṣ,) or upon them. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) And tTw-l↓ EalayonaA biXaIoCK He gave to us a thing; like tanaw-ala; but the latter is said by Aboo-Mihjen to be used only in relation to good; and the former, sometimes, in relation to good and to evil. (TA in art. nwl.)

entry.sense:
2. Tw-lhu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taTowiylN; (O;) and ATAlhu↓, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and OaTowalahu↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiTaAlapN; (O;) both signify the same; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He elongated it; extended it; lengthened it; or made it long, or tall or high; (Ṣ,* O, Mṣb;) syn. mad-ahu, (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb,) and jaEalahu TawiylFA. (O, TA.) You say, Taw-alotu AlHadiydapa I elongated, or lengthened, the piece of iron. (Mṣb.) And ATAl↓ Qll-ehu baqaMCahu God extended, or prolonged, his continuance [in life]; or may God extend,, &c. (Mṣb.)
And ATAl↓ Almajolisa He extended, or prolonged, the time of the assembly. (Mṣb.) And Tw-al lilofarasi, (Ṣ, O,) or lild-aAb-api, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He slackened [or lengthened] (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) the tether, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or rope, (Mṣb,) of the horse, (Ṣ, O,) or of the beast, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) in the place of pasture, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or that it might pasture [more largely]: (Mṣb:) and ATAl↓ lahaA AlT-iwala and AlT-iyala [signify the same]. (TA, from a trad.) And [hence] Tw-l lahu (inf. n. as above, Ṣ) He granted him a delay, or respite; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) said of God: (Ṣ:) and AlmuTaAwalapu↓ fiI AlOamori means Alt-aTowiylu fiyhi; (Mṣb;) [i. e.] TAwlhu signifies he delayed, or deferred, with him, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) fiI AlOamori [in the affair], (Ṣ, O,) or fiI Ald-ayoni [in the case of the debt] and AlEidapi [the promise]. (TA.) [And Tw-l Ealayohi and tTw-l↓ He was prolix, or tedious, to him: see 2 in art. bsq; and see an ex. of the former voce HawozN.]

3. TaAwalaniI faTulotuhu↓ He contended with me for superiority (Ks, O, TA) in AlT-uwl [i. e. tallness], and also in AlT-awol [i. e. beneficence, and excellence,, &c.], and I exceeded him, or surpassed him, therein. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) bika OuTaAwilu occurs in a prayer of the Prophet, and is from AlT-awolu, meaning [By means of Thee I contend for] superiority over the enemies. (O.) One says also, TaAwalahu biAlkibari waqaAla OanaA Oakobaru minoka [He contended, or disputed, with him for superiority in greatness, and said, I am greater than thou]. (A in art. kbr.) [And AlmuTaAwalapu fiI AlHuZowapi, occurring in the TA in art. smw, means The contending, or vying, or competing, for superiority, in highness of rank.]
See also 2, last sentence but one.

hom.sense: 4. ATAl and ATwl, as trans.: see 2, in five places.

ATAlt AlmaroOapu The woman brought forth tall children, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) or a tall child. (Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., (Ṣ,) or in a prov., not a trad., (Ḳ,) but IAth declares it to be a trad., and in the trads. of the Prophet are many celebrated provs., (MF,) Uin-a AlqaSiyrapa qado tuTiylu [Verily the short woman sometimes brings forth tall children], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) waUin-a AlT-awiylapa↓ qado tuqoSiru [and verily the tall woman sometimes brings forth short children]. (O.)
See also 1, last sentence but one.
One says also, ATAl lifarasihi He tied his horse with the rope [or tether, called Tiwal]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 2, last sentence:
and see also 1, last two sentences.
6. tTAwl: see 1, former half.
Also It became high by degrees; said of a building. (L in art. Xyd.)

And i. q. taTaAl-a or taTaAlala, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) meaning He (a man, Ṣ, TA) stood upon his toes, and stretched his stature, to look at a thing: (TA:) or taTaAwalotu fiI qiyaAmiI I stretched my legs, in my standing, to look. (O.) One says, yataTaAwalu liloOafonaAni wayajotacibuhaA biAlmiHojani [He stretches himself up towards the branches, and draws them to him with the hooked-headed stick]. (Ṣ in art. Hrq.) And it is said in a trad., tTAwl Ealayohimu Alr-ab-u bifaDolihi The Lord looked down upon them, or regarded them compassionately, (OaXorafa,) with his favour (O.)
Also He made a show of AlT-uwl [i. e. tallness], or AlT-awol [i. e. beneficence, and excellence,, &c.]. (TA.)

tTAwl Ealayohi and AstTAl↓ signify the same; (Az, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) He held up his head with a show of superiority over him; (Az, TA;) [i. e. he behaved haughtily, arrogantly, overweeningly, overbearingly, domineeringly, or proudly, towards him; domineered over him; or exalted himself above him;] or he overbore, overpowered, subdued, or oppressed, him: (Mṣb:) AstTAl↓ Elyh is also expl. as meaning he arrogated to himself excellence over him, syn. tafaD-ala; (Ḳ, TA;) and exalted himself above him: (TA:) and AstTAlwA↓ Ealayohimo as meaning they slew of them more than they [the latter] had slain (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) of them [the former]: (O:) and AlAisotiTaAlapu↓ fiI EiroDi Aln-aAsi occurs in a trad. as meaning the contemning of men, and exalting oneself above them, and reviling them, vilifying them, or detracting from their reputation. (TA.) One says also tTAwl bimaA Einodahu He exalted, or magnified, or boasted, himself in, or he boasted of, what he possessed. (TA in art. ftH.) And AlfaHolu yataTaAwalu EalaI Uibilihi The stallion [overbears, or] drives as he pleases, and repels the other stallions from, his she-camels. (O.)
And taTaAwalaA They vied, competed, or contended for superiority, each with the other [in AlT-uwl i. e. tallness, or in AlT-awol i. e. beneficence, and excel-lence,, &c.: see 3]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 10. AstTAl: see 1, first sentence.

Also It extended and rose; (Ḳ, TA;) said of a crack [in a wall]; like AstTAr: mentioned by Th. (TA.) [And likewise said, in the same sense, of the dawn, i. e., of the false dawn; in which case it is opposed to AstTAr: see musotaTiylN.]
See also 6, in four places.

This verb is also used, by Z and Bḍ, in a trans. sense; and AstTAlhu, occurring in the “Mufassal” [of Z] is expl. as meaning Ead-ahu TawiylFA [He reckoned it long,, &c.]; and in like manner it is used by Es-Saạd in the “Mutowwal:” but this usage is on the ground of analogy [only]; for, accord. to the genuine lexical usage, it is intransitive. (TA.)

entry.sense: TawolN [is originally an inf. n.: (see TaAla Ealayohi:) and, used as a simple subst.,] signifies Beneficence; and bounty: (Ṣ, TA:) and [a benefit, a favour, a boon, or] a gift. (Ḥar p. 58.)

And, (O, Ḳ, TA,) as also TaAYilN↓ and TaAYilapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) Excellence, excess, or superabundance: and power, or ability: and wealth, or competence: and ampleness of circumstances: (O, Ḳ, TA:) and superiority, or ascendancy. (O, TA.) One says, lifulaAnK EalaI fulaAnK TawolN To such a one belongs excellence, or superabundance, above such a one. (O. [And the like is said in the Mgh.]) And it is said in the Ḳur [iv. 29], wamano lamo yasotaTiEo minokumo TawolFA Oano yanokiHa QlmuHoSanaAti, meaning And such of you as is not able to obtain superabundance so that he may marry the free women, let him marry a female slave; (Mgh;) i. e. such as is not able to give the dowry of the free woman, (Mgh, O, TA,) as expl. by Zj. (Mgh, TA.) In the phrase Tawolu AlHur-api, the former word is originally the inf. n. of the verb in TaAla EalayohaA meaning “he benefited her;” because, when one is able to give the dowry of the free woman, and pays it, he benefits her: or, as some of the lawyers says, this phrase means The superabundance of the means of sustenance that suffices for the marrying of the free woman, agreeably with a saying of Az: or, as some say, Twl means wealth, or competence; and the phrase is originally TawolN UilaI AlHur-api, i. e. ampleness of wealth such as supplies the means of attaining to the free woman: or originally TawolN EalaI AlHur-api, meaning power, or ability, for the marrying of the free woman: (Mṣb:) Esh-Shaabee is related to have used the phrase AlT-awolu UilaI AlHur-api; and in like manner are I’Ab and Jábir and Saʼeed Ibn-Jubeyr. (Mgh.) ciI AlT-awoli in the Ḳur xl. 3 means The Possessor of all-sufficiency, and of superabundance, or of bounty: (O:) or the Possessor of power: or of bounty, and beneficence. (TA.) And Ouwluw AlT-awoli minohumo in the Ḳur ix. 87 means Those, of them, who are possessors of superabundance, and of opulence. (Bḍ.)
See also TiwalN, latter half, in two places.

TuwlN [is originally an inf. n.: (see 1, first sentence:) and, used as a simple subst.,] signifies Length; and tallness, or height; contr. of EaroDN; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) or of qiSarN: (M, TA:) pl. OaTowaAlN: (Mṣb:) it is in man and other animals, and in inanimate things: (TA:) in real things, or substances; and also in ideal things, or attributes, as time and the like. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [One says, qaTaEahu TuwlFA and biAlT-uwli He cut it lengthwise.]

And The utmost extent of time. (TA.) You say, laA Oukal-imuhu Tuwla Ald-ahori (Ṣ, O, TA) and TawaAla↓ Ald-ahori, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,* TA,) both meaning the same, (Ṣ, O, TA,) i. e. [I will not speak to him] during the utmost extent of time. (Ḳ,* TA.)
[In geography, The longitude of a place: pl. as above.]
See also TiwalN, in two places.
TawalN Length in the upper lip of the camel, (M, Ḳ, TA,) beyond the lower. (M, TA.)

hom.sense: TuwalN: see TiwalN.
Also pl. of TuwlaI, fem. of OaTowalu [q. v.].

entry.sense:
TiwalN, for which Tiwal-N↓ occurs in poetry, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and TiyalN↓, for which also Tiyal-N↓ occurs in poetry, (Ḳ) and TawiylapN↓, (Lth, O, Ḳ,) but this is disapproved by Az, (TA,) and tiTowalN↓, (Ḳ,) A tether; i. e. the rope that is extended for a horse or similar beast, and attached to which he pastures: (Ṣ, O:)
a rope with which the leg of such a beast is bound: (Ḳ:) a long rope thus used: (TA:) or with which one binds him, holding its extremity, and letting the beast pasture: (Ḳ, TA:) or of which one of the two ends is bound to a stake, and the other to the fore leg of a horse, in order that he may go round about bound thereby, and pasture, and not go away at random. (TA.) An ex. of the first of these words occurs in a verse of Tarafeh cited voce vinoIN. (Ṣ, O.) And it is said in a trad. that when a man of an army alights in a place, he may debar others from the extent of the Tiwal of his horse. (TA.)
OaroxaI lahu AlT-iwala [lit. meaning He relaxed, or slackened, to him the tether] means [also] ‡ he left him to his own affair. (A and TA in art. rxw.)

And one says, TaAla Tiwaluka and Tiyaluka↓ and Tiyluka↓ and Tuwluka↓ and Tuwaluka↓ and TawaAluka↓ and TiyaAluka↓ (ISk, Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and Tawoluka↓ (Ḳ) meaning † Thy life [has become long; or may thy life become long]: (ISk, Ṣ, O, Ḳ: [see also TiylapN:]) or thine absence: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or ‡ thy tarrying, (A, Ḳ, TA,) and thy flagging in an affair. (A, TA.) Tufeyl says,
OataAnaA falamo nadofaEohu Uico jaMCa TaAriqFA
waqulonaA lahu TaAla Tawoluka↓ faQnozili
meaning [He came to us, and we did not repel him since he came as a nightly visiter, and we said to him,] Thy case in respect of the length of the journey and the endurance of travel [has been long, therefore alight thou: or the right reading may be Tuwluka↓, which is better known]: or, as some relate it, Tiyluka↓. (TA.) [It is also said that] TiwalN is a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is TiwalapN↓; and in like manner, TiyalN↓, of TiyalapN↓. (TA.)
TiylN: see the next preceding paragraph, latter half, in two places.
[In the phrases TiylN yawomN and TiylN layolapN, it app. means A tedious period, or length of time.]
TiyalN: see TiwalN, in three places.
TaAlapN A she-ass: (O, Ḳ:) said to occur [as meaning a wild she-ass] in a poem of Dhu-rRummeh, who likens thereto his she-camel: but unknown to Az. (TA.)
TiylapN Life; the period of life. (Ḳ, TA.) One says, OaTaAla Qll-ehu Tiylatahu [God prolonged, or may God prolong, his life]. (TA.) [See also TiwalN.]
TiwalapN: see TiwalN, last sentence.
TiyalapN: see TiwalN, last sentence.
TuwlaI [fem. of OaTowalu: used as a subst.,] A high, or an elevated, state or condition: pl. TuwalN. (Ḳ.)
TuwlaAniI-N: see Tuw-aAlN.
Tiwal-N: see TiwalN, first sentence.
Tiyal-N: see TiwalN, first sentence.
TawaAlN: see TuwlN:
and see also TiwalN.
TuwaAlN: see TawiylN:
and see also Tuw-aAlN.
TiyaAlN: see TiwalN.

TawiylN Elongated, or extended; [i. e. long; and tall, or high;] (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also TuwaAlN↓; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ; but see Tuw-aAlN;) and musotaTiylN↓: and OaTowalu↓ is used in the sense of TawiylapN, [being syn. sometimes with TawiylN and TawiylapN,] in a verse of El-Farezdaḳ cited voce EaziyzN: (O, TA:) [it seems, from a comparison of explanations of suroHuwbN and salohabN, &c. in the Ṣ and Ḳ, that TawiylN applied to a horse or the like generally signifies long-bodied:] TawiylN is the only epithet, known to IJ, of the measure faEiylN having the f and l sound and having w for its E, except SawiybN and qawiymN; for EawiySN is [held by him to be only] used as a subst.: (M in art. Swb:) the pl. (of TawiylN and TuwaAlN, TA) is TiwaAlN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TiyaAlN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) the latter anomalous, and said by IJ to occur only in one verse: (TA:) the fem. is TawiylapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and TuwaAlapN; (Ḳ,* TA;) and the pl. of the former of these is TawiylaAtN. (Mṣb.)

They said, Uin-a All-ayola TawiylN walaA yaTulo Uil-aA bixayorK [Verily the night is long, and may it not be long save with good fortune]: mentioned by Lḥ, as expressing a prayer. (TA.) And qaSiyrapN mino TawiylapK [A short thing from a tall thing]; meaning a date from a palm-tree: a prov., alluding to the abridging of speech, or language. (IAạr, Meyd, Ḳ.) See also 4.

AlT-awiylu is also the name of A certain kind of metre of verse; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) [namely, the first;] consisting of faEuwluno mafaAEiyluno eight [a mistake for four] times: (O, TA:) so called because it is the longest of all the metres of verse; originally comprising forty-eight letters: (TA:) a post-classical term. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
TawiylapN as a subst.: see TiwalN.
Tuw-alN A certain bird, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) of the aquatic kind, having long legs. (O, Ḳ.)
Tay-ilapu Alr-iyHi The wind's counterwind. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

Tuw-aAlN Very, or exceedingly, tall; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) applied to a man; as also, in the same sense, TuwaAlN↓, (TA,) the latter having a stronger signification than TawiylN, [with which it is mentioned above as syn.,] (TA voce rakiykN,) or it denotes less than Tuw-aAlN; (O in art. Zrf;) and so TuwlaAniI-N↓ and muTaAwilN↓, in the dial. of the vulgar: Tuw-aAlN has no broken pl., its pl. being only Tuw-aAluwna: its fem. is with p {Tuw-aAlapN}, and so is that of TuwaAlN {TuwaAlapN}; each applied to a woman. (TA.)
TaAYilN Benefiting; bestowing, or conferring, a benefit or benefits, or a favour or favours. (Mṣb.)

[Hence its usage in the following exs.] One says of that which is vile, or contemptible, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) huwa gayora TaAYilK, (Mṣb,) or maA huwa biTaAYilK, (Ḳ, TA,) [It is not good for anything; it is unprofitable, useless, or worthless]; and in this manner it is used alike as masc. and fem. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., Darabotuhu bisayofK gayori TaAYilK, meaning I smote him with a sword that was not sharp. (TA.) And in another trad., kuf-ina fiI kafanK gayori TaAYilK i. e. [He was shrouded in grave-clothing] not of delicate texture, and not of a goodly kind. (TA.)

And [hence] it signifies [also] Benefit, profit, utility, or avail; and excellence: thus in the saying, hecaA OamorN laA TaAYila fiyhi [This is an affair in which is no benefit,, &c.]: (Ṣ, O, TA:) and lamo yaHola minohu biTaAYilK [He did not find or experience, or get or obtain, from it, or him, any benefit,, &c.]: it is only used in negative phrases [in this sense]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) and [thus] one says also, naTaqa bimaA laA TaAYila taHotahu [He spoke that in which was no profit]. (TA in art. bwq.) See also TawolN, second sentence.
TaAYilapN: see TawolN, second sentence.

Also Enmity: and blood-revenge: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) pl. TawaAYilu. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN yaTolubu baniI fulaAnK biTaAYilapK i. e. Such a one seeks to obtain of the sons of such a one blood-revenge. (TA.) [See also an ex. in art. Eql, conj. 8.]

OaTowalu Exceeding, or surpassing, in AlT-uwl [i. e. length, and tallness or height]: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) and also in AlT-awol [i. e. beneficence, and excellence,, &c.]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) fem. TuwlaI: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. of the former, applied to men, OaTaAwilu; (Ṣ, O;) and of the latter TuwalN. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.*) Als-aboEu AlT-uwalu, i. e. The seven longer chapters of the Ḳur-án, (O, TA,) are the chapter of Albaqarap and the next five chapters of which the last is AlOaEoraAf, and one other, which is the chapter of yuwnus, or AlOanofaAl and baraMCap together, these being regarded as one chapter, (O, Ḳ, TA,) or, as some say, Alkahof, and some say Alt-awobap [which is the same as baraMCap]; and some say [the chapters vulgarly called] the HawaAmiym [which are the fortieth and six following chapters]: but the first of all these sayings is the right. (TA.) And TuwlaI AlT-uwlayayoni [The longer of the two longer chapters of the Ḳur-án], occurring in a trad. of Umm-Selemeh, was expl. by her as meaning the chapter of AlOaEoraAf: (O:) AlT-uwlayaAni meaning AlOanoEaAm and AlOaEoraAf. (TA.) OasoraEukun-a luHuwqFA biI OaTowalukun-a yadFA, or, as some relate it laHaAqFA, as saying of the Prophet to his wives, means [The quickest of you in attaining to me is, or will be,] the most extensive of you in giving. (O.)
See also TawiylN.
Also A camel whose upper lip is long, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) extending beyond the lower. (TA.)
tiTowalN: see TiwalN, first sentence.
miTowalN The penis. (O, Ḳ.)
And A halter; syn. rasanN: (Ḳ:) pl. maTaAwilu, signifying the halters (OarosaAn) of horses. (O, Ḳ.)
muTaAwilN: see Tuw-aAlN. [And see also its verb.]
madFI mutaTaAwilN A distant limit, or far-extending space. (W p. 50.)
musotaTaAlN is used by Z and Bḍ as meaning Reckoned long, on the ground of analogy. (TA. [See its verb.])

musotaTiylN: see TawiylN. Alfajoru AlmusotaTiylu is The first dawn; also called the false; and termed canabu Als-iroHaAni [the tail of the wolf], because it appears rising without extending laterally: (Mṣb:) opposed to AlmusotaTiyru. (TA in art. Tyr.)

hom.sense: 1. TawaI AlX-aIoCi, (Ṣ, Mṣb,*) or AlS-aHiyfapa, (Ḳ,) aor. yaTowiI, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. TaI-N, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [He folded, folded up, or folded together, and he rolled up, the thing, such as a garment, or piece of cloth, or the like, or the written piece of paper:] TawaI AlS-aHiyfapa meaning the contr. of naXarahaA. (TA.) And one says also, TawaI Alv-awoba, inf. n. Tiy-apN, with kesr, and TiyapN, like EidapN, this latter on the authority of Lḥ, and extr., [meaning He folded,, &c., the garment, or piece of cloth:] and the phrase SaHiyfapN jaAfiyapu AlT-iyapi has been mentioned as meaning AlT-aI-i [i. e. A written piece of paper thick, or rude, in respect of the folding,, &c.]. (TA.) [And Tawayotu Als-iqaMCa EalaI bululatihi, and bulalatihi, or balalatihi, I folded the skin while it was moist: whence the phrases Tawayotu fulaAnFA EalaI bululatihi, and bulalatihi, &c., and TawaAhu EalaI bilaAlihi, and buluwlihi, expl. voce balalN; and a similar phrase in a verse cited voce cariba, q. v.: see also a similar phrase in art. dml, conj. 3: and see TawiIa.]
