[Hence, TawaI signifies also † He, or it, made a thing compact, as though folded; or round, like a scroll.] One says, TuwiIa jisomuhu Tay-FA Hat-aI Qkotanaza laHomuhu † [His body was, or became, compacted, or rounded, so that his, or its, flesh was firm, or hard]. (Lḥ, TA in art. dmlj.) And saAqN Hasanapu AlT-aI-i † [A shank goodly in respect of the compacture, or rounding; well compacted, well rounded, or well turned]. (Ḳ in art. jdl, &c.) And [hence likewise,] TawaAhu means also † It rendered him lean, lank, light of flesh, slender, or lank in the belly. (L in art. msd.) One says, TawaAhu Als-ayoru † Journeying, or travel, rendered him lean, or emaciated him. (TA.)
TawaI Eunuqahu wanaAma MminFA is said of a gazelle [as meaning He folded, or bent, his neck, and slept free from fear]. (TA.)

TawaI kaXoHahu [lit. He folded, or bent, his flank,] means ‡ he turned away his love, or affection: (Ṣ, TA:) or, as in the M, ‡ he withdrew his countenance: and the following ex. is cited:
waSaAHibK qado TawaI kaXoHFA faqulotu lahu
Uin-a QnoTiwaMCaka↓ hecaA Eanoka yaTowiyniI
‡ [Many a companion has withdrawn countenance, and I have said to him, Verily this thy withdrawing withdraws me from thee]: (TA:) or TawaI kaXoHahu Ean-iI means ‡ he turned away from me, forsaking, or abandoning. (Ḳ, TA. [See also art. kXH.])

And TawaI kaXoHahu EalaI OamorK ‡ He concealed an affair, or a case: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as in the M, † he determined, or resolved, upon an affair: (TA:) or, as in the L, and other lexicons, † he persevered in an affair. (TA in art. kXH.)
And TawaI, [for TawaI OaHoXaMCahu,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yaTowiI, inf. n. TaI-N, (Ṣ,) † He suffered hunger intentionally, or purposely. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [See also TawiIa.])
And TawaI Ean-iI AlHadiyva, (Ḳ,* TA,) and Als-ir-a, (TA,) ‡ He concealed from me the story, (Ḳ,* TA,) and the secret. (TA.) One says, AiTowi hecaA AlHadiyva ‡ Conceal thou this story. (TA.)

And TawaI HadiyvFA UilaI HadiyvK † He concealed in his mind a story and passed on from it to another story; like as is said of the traveller in the sentence next following: and similar to this is the phrase TaI-u AlS-awomi † [the passing on from the fasting to the next fasting]. (TA.) One says of the traveller, yaTowiI manozilFA UilaI manozilK falaA yanozilu † [He passes on from one place of alighting to another so that he does not alight]. (TA.) And TawaI AlmakaAna UilaI AlmakaAni † He passed on from the place to the place. (TA.) And TawaI AlbilaAda, (Ḳ, Ta,) inf. n. TaI-N, (TA,) ‡ He traversed the countries, (Ḳ, TA,) country after country. (TA.)
TawaI Alqawoma means † He came to the people, or party: or he passed by them: (IAạr, Ḳ, TA:) or he sat by them, or at their place of abode. (Ḳ, TA.)
TawaI Qll-ehu AlbuEoda lanaA, accord. to the Ḳ, means ‡ May God contract (lit. make near) the distance to us: but accord. to the T, AlbaEiyda [i. e., make near the remote]. (TA.)

AlT-aI-u also denotes the passing away of life: [or rather the making life to pass away:] one says, TawaI Qll-ehu Eumuraha † [God made, or may God make, his life to pass away]: and a poet says,
Tawatoka xuTuwbu dahorika baEoda naXorK
† [Thy misfortunes have exanimated thee after vivifying, or reviving]: TuwiIa fulaAnN wahuwa manoXuwrN ‡ [Such a one has been exanimated but he is revived] is said of a person when [he has died and] a good reputation of him remains, or a good memorial. (TA.) [It is also implied in the TA that, in accordance with this usage of the verb, TawaAhu may be rendered † He caused it to pass away, or come to nought or to an end; destroyed it; or annihilated it: (see the pass. part. n.:) and, accord. to Bḍ, yawoma naTowiI Qls-amaMCa, in the Ḳur xxi. 104, may mean On the day when we shall efface the heaven: but this phrase is better rendered on the day when we shall fold, or roll up, the heaven.]
One says also, TawaI Algazola EalaI AlmiTowaI [He wound the spun thread upon the winder]. (TA.)

And TawaI Alr-akiy-apa, (TA,) or AlbiYora, (Mṣb,) inf. n. TaI-N, He cased the well with stones, and with baked bricks: and in like manner, TawaI All-abina fiI AlbinaMCi [He cased the bricks, or crude bricks, in the building]. (TA.)

TawiIa Als-iqaMCu, [aor. yaTowaI,] inf. n. TawFI, The skin was folded having in it moisture, or some remains of milk, in consequence of which it became altered, and stinking, and dissundered by putrefaction. (TA. [See also the third sentence of this paragraph.])
And TawiIa, aor. yaTowaI, inf. n. TawFI (Ṣ, Ḳ) and TiwFI also, on the authority of Sb, (TA,) † He was hungry; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) as also OaTowaI↓. (Ḳ. [See also TawaI, above.])
And Tawiyato Tiy-atuhu The place to which, or towards which, he would repair, or betake himself, was, or became, remote. (Lḥ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Taw-ayotuhu [I folded it with several, or many, foldings; or wound it, or coiled it: see the quasi-pass., tTw-I]. (TA.)
4: see 1, last sentence but one.

5. tTw-I [It became folded with several, or many, foldings; or wound, or coiled;] quasi-pass. of 2. (TA.) You say, taTaw-ati AlHay-apu The serpent wound, or coiled, itself. (Ṣ, TA.) And Sb mentions the phrase taTaw-aI QnoTiwaMCF↓; citing, as an ex.,
waqado taTaw-ayotu QnoTiwaMCa AlHaDobaho
[And I had writhed with the winding of the HDbp], meaning [by this last word] a species of serpent, or the bow-string. (TA.)

6. taTaAowaIa [This verb, said of several agents, (i. e., app. taTaAwawoA said of several persons, or taTaAwato said of several things,) accord. to Freytag on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees signifies They mutually folded together.]

7. AnTwI [It was, or became, folded, folded up, or folded together, and rolled up,] quasi-pass. of TawaI (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) as signifying the contr. of naXara; (TA;) as also AiT-awaI↓, (Ḳ, TA,) of the measure AifotaEala, mentioned by Az and ISd. (TA.) See also 5.

[Hence,] AnTwI baTonuhu † [His belly became lean, or lank]; said of a camel, and of a sheep or goat. (JK voce AirotaqaI.) And AinoTiwaMCu AlHaXaA † [The state of being lean, or lank, in the belly]. (Ṣ and TA voce OaxoTafa, q. v.)
See also a verse cited in the first paragraph.

[Hence also,] AnTwI EalaI AlHiqodi, and Alwud-i, † He conceived [as though he infolded] in the heart rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, and love, or affection. (MA.) And AnTwI qalobuhu EalaI gil-K † [His heart conceived, as though it infolded, rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite]. (TA.)
8: see the next preceding paragraph {7}.
Taw-N: see TawFI.

TaI-N [originally an inf. n., of TawaI, q. v.,] and TiI-N↓ and TiwaI↓, [said in one place in the TA to be like UilaI, but I think that this is only said to show that its first vowel is kesr and the second fet-ḥ, and that it is correctly TiwFI, for there is no reason for its being imperfectly decl.,] accord. to the M, are sings. of OaTowaMCN, which it explains as signifying The lines, or streaks, and creases, of the folding of a garment, or piece of cloth, and of a written piece of paper, and of the belly, and of fat, and of the guts, and of a serpent, and of other things;
and it is said in the T and Ḳ that maTaAwK↓, of which the sing. is maTowFI↓, signifies the OaTowaMC of the serpent, and of the guts, and of fat, and of the belly, and of a garment, or piece of cloth: (TA:) one says, maA baqiyato fiI maTaAwiI↓ OamaEaAYihaA vamiylapN [There remained not in the creases of her, or their, guts any relic of food]: (A, TA:) and maTaAwiI↓ Ald-iroEi signifies the creases of the coat of mail when it is drawn together, or contracted. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, EalaI jabiynihaA OaTowaMCu Aln-ajomi i. e. TaraAYiquhu [app. meaning Upon her forehead (for so jabiyn sometimes signifies) are the wrinkles indicative of the time for the payment of the debt of nature]. (TA.) The OaTowaMC in the she-camel are The TaraAYiq [i. e. lines, or streaks, or perhaps creases, or wrinkles,] of the fat (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) of the hump: (Ḳ, TA:) [or the creases, or wrinkles, one above another, of the side and of the hump; for] Lth says, TaraAYiqu janobihaA wasanaAmhaA TaI-N fawoqa TaI-K [the creases, or wrinkles, of her side and of her hump are, or consist of, TaI- above TaI-]. (TA.) And AḤn says that OaTowaMCN signifies The bending [or rather he should have said, or perhaps he did say, the places of bending] in the tail of the locust, [which are] like Euqad [or articulations]: and the pl. [of mult.] is TiwaI↓ [said to be like UilaI, but I think that it is correctly TiwFI, as I have observed above]. (TA.)

One says also, wajadotu fiI TaI-i AlkitaAbi kacaA [lit. I found within the folding of the writing, or letter, such a thing; meaning, infolded, or enclosed, or included, in it; or among the contents, or implications, of it]: and fiI OaTowaMCi Alkutubi and maTaAwiyhaA↓ [lit. within the folds, or places of folding, of the writings, or letters]. (A, TA.) And Algil-u fiI TaI-i qalobihi ‡ [Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, is conceived, as though it were infolded, in his heart]. (TA. [See 7.]) And OadorajaniI fiI TaI-i Aln-isoyaAni ‡ [He, or it, infolded me within the folding of oblivion]. (TA.)
See also TawFI.
And see TawiI-N.
[Also A casing of stones or of baked bricks; and particularly such a casing of a well; an inf. n. used as a subst. properly so called; and often occurring in the lexicons, &c. in this sense.]
TiI-N: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence.
Tay-apN [inf. n. of un. of TawaI]. You say, TawaAhu Tay-apF waAHidapF [He folded it,, &c., with one folding, &c.]. (TA.)

Tiy-apN, (Ṣ, TA,) from Tawayotu AlX-aIoCa, (Ṣ,) is like jilosapN (Ṣ, TA) and rikobapN (Ṣ) and miXoyapN, signifying A mode, or manner, of folding, &c.; and a mode, or manner, of being folded, &c. (TA.) One says, Uin-ahu laHasanu AlT-iy-api [Verily he is good in respect of the mode, or manner, of folding,, &c.]. (Ḳ, TA.) And TawaAhu Tiy-apF jay-idapF [He folded it,, &c., in a good mode, or manner, of doing so]. (TA.) And hence the saying of Dhu-rRummeh,
kamaA tunaX-aru baEoda AlT-iy-api Alkutubu
[Like as the writings, or letters, are unfolded after the folding in a particular manner]: (Ṣ, TA:) he said Tiy-ap, with kesr, because he did not mean a single time [of folding]. (TA.)
[See also 1, second sentence, where it is mentioned as a simple inf. n., and sometimes pronounced TiyapN, without teshdeed.]

Also i. q. niy-apN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so Tawiy-apN↓; (Ḳ;) and [agreeably with this explanation] Kh says that it may mean A place of alighting or abode [to which one purposes repairing, or betaking himself], and it may mean an object of aim or purpose or intention [whatever it be]: (Ṣ:) and in the A it is expl. as meaning the direction towards which countries are traversed: (TA:) one says Tiy-apN baEiydapN i. e. [A place of alighting or abode, &c.] that is distant, or remote: and baEudato Ean-aA Tiy-atuhu i. e. The place of alighting, or of abode, to which he purposed repairing [was distant, or remote]: and maDaI liTiy-atihi i. e. [He went] to his niy-ap [meaning either place of alighting, &c. or object of aim, &c.] that he purposed: (Ṣ:) and laqiytuhu biTiy-aAti AlEiraAqi i. e. [I met him in] the regions, or quarters, or directions, of El-'Irak: and sometimes it is pronounced TiyapN, without teshdeed. (TA.)
Also An object of want or need. (TA.) [Therefore maDaI liTiy-atihi may be rendered He went to accomplish his object of want or need.]
Mxira Tiy-apK is syn. with Mxira maxoTarK [expl. voce xaTorapN, q. v.]. (TA in art. xTr.)

hom.sense: TawFI A skin for water or milk; syn. siqaMCN; (Ḳ;) as also TaI-N↓: or the former signifies a skin (sqMC) that has been folded having in it its moisture, and has consequently become dissundered; app. an inf. n. [of TawiIa] used as a subst. [properly so called]: and siqaMCN TawK↓ signifies [the same, or] a skin that has been folded having in it moisture, or some remains of milk, in consequence of which it has become altered, and stinking, and dissundered by putrefaction. (TA.)
Also Hunger; (Ṣ;) [and] so Taw-N↓ [if not a mistranscription]. (TA. [See TawiIa, of which the former is an inf. n., as also TiwFI.])

entry.sense: TuwFI is said by some to be like TiwFI↓, meaning A thing twice done [as though folded]; and to be thus in the Ḳur [xx. 12 and lxxix. 16]; meaning twice sanctified [referring to the valley there mentioned]; (Ṣ, TA; [and thus expl., and said to be like vinFI, in the Ksh and by Bḍ;]) or, as El-Ḥasan says, twice blest and sanctified: (Ṣ, TA:) or meaning twice called [referring to the calling of Moses mentioned in the context]. (Ksh and Bḍ in xx. 12, and in like manner says Er-Rághib.) [But TuwaI (as most pronounce it) or TuwFI, in the Ḳur, is generally held to be the name of a certain valley. Golius explains TuwFI and TiwFI as meaning “Plicata, plicabilis, res;” which is a mistake: and he adds, “Ambulatio, incessus reciprocatus, ultro citroque in se rediens:” for the latter of these explanations, both of which he gives as on the authority of J and the Ḳ, I am quite unable to account.]
TiwFI: see the next preceding paragraph:
and see also TaI-N, in two places.

TawaI AlbaToni A man lean, or lank, in the belly; (Ṣ, TA; [in the Ḥam, p. 708, erroneously written TiwaI AlbaToni, and there expl. as meaning naturally small in the belly;]) as also munoTawK↓ [or rather munoTawiI AlbaToni]; (TA;) and so Tay-aAnu↓. (Ḥam p. 495.)

And [hence], (Ḳ, TA,) as also TaAwK↓, and Tay-aAnu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) † Hungry: (Ṣ, TA:) or having eaten nothing: fem. [of the second] TaAwiyapN (Ḳ) and [of the third] Tay-aA or Tay-aMCu [like HayoraI and HayoraMCu pls. of HayoraAnu]. (Ḳ accord. to different copies.)
See also TawFI.

hom.sense: TawiI-N A bundle of baz- [meaning cloths or stuffs or garments, or a kind, or kinds, thereof: so called as being folded together]: thus in the Tekmileh [and in copies of the Ḳ]: in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, mina Alburodi in the place of mn Albaz-i. (TA.)

And A well that is cased (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,* TA) with stones, or with baked bricks; as also TaI-N↓: (TA:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Mṣb:) it is masc., but may be made fem. to accord. with the meaning [i. e. biYorN]: (M, TA:) pl. OaTowaMCN: accord. to the Ḳ, Tawiy-apN↓ signifies a well; but [SM says] I have not seen that any one has mentioned this. (TA.)
And A saAEap [meaning short portion] of the night: (Ḳ:) one says, Oatayotuhu baEoda TawiI-K mina All-ayoli [I came to him after a short portion of the night]: mentioned by ISd. (TA.)

entry.sense: Tawiy-apN † The Damiyr [meaning heart, or mind]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) so called because it is [as though it were] folded upon the secret, or because the secret is [as though it were] infolded in it. (TA.)
See also Tiy-apN.
And see TawiI-N.
maA biAld-aAri TuwawiI-N [like duwowiI-N or dawawiI-N, if not a mistranscription for TuwriI-N,] means [There is not in the house] any one. (TA.)
Tay-aAnu: see the paragraph commencing with TawiI AlbaToni, in two places. [Tay-aAnN, perfectly decl., belongs to art. Tyn, q. v.]
TaMCN: see art. TI.

hom.sense: TaAyapN A saToH [or flat top or roof of a house] (Az, Ṣ, Ḳ) upon which one sleeps. (Az, TA.)
And A place in which dates are put to dry in the sun. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And A great rock in land containing sand, (Ḳ, TA,) or in which 9are no stones: mentioned by ISd. (TA.)
jaMCati AlUibilu TaAyaAtK means [The camels came] in herds; syn. quToEaAnFA: the sing. is TaAyapN. (TA.)

entry.sense: TaAwK A gazelle that bends, [or is bending,] or has bent, his neck, on the occasion of lying down, and then lies down, or has [lain down and] slept free from fear. (TA.)
And TaAwiI AlkaXoHi Rendered lean or lank; not large in the sides. (Ḥam p. 495.)
See also the paragraph commencing with TawiI AlbaToni.
XiEorN TaAwiI-N Verse of which the [fundamental] rhyme-letter is T: [but] Kh says that its A is originally I. (TA.)

maTowFI; and its pl. maTaAwK, and as a prefixed n. maTaAwiI: see TaI-N, in five places. maTowFI may be used as an inf. n., meaning The folding of a garment, or piece of cloth: and as meaning the place of folding thereof: and signifies also the inside thereof. (Ḥar p. 160.)
miTowFI [A winder for thread;] a thing upon which spun thread is wound. (TA.)
And, as a word used by the vulgar, [but by them generally pronounced maTowaI, with fet-ḥ, and without tenween,] A small [clasp-] knife. (TA.)
maTowiI-N [Folded, folded up, or folded together, and rolled up: see 1, first sentence.]

[And hence, † Made compact, as though folded; and round, like a scroll]. You say AimoraOapN maTowiy-apu Alxaloqi (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. mkr) [meaning, accord. to the PṢ in that art., † A plump woman; and the same seems to be indicated by what immediately follows it in the Ṣ itself: but it is more correctly rendered † a woman compacted, or rounded, in make: see TuwiIa jisomuhu. It may, however, signify also † A woman lean, lank, or slender, in make; lit., rendered lean,, &c.: see TawaAhu].
biYorN maTowiy-apN (Ṣ, TA) A well cased with stones [or with baked bricks]. (TA.)

waQls-amewaAtu maTowiy-aAtN biyamiynihi, in the Ḳur [xxxix. 67, generally understood to mean And the heavens shall be folded together, or rolled up, by his right hand], has been expl. as meaning [that they shall be] destroyed: so says Er-Rághib. (TA.)
munoTawK, or munoTawiI AlbaToni: see the paragraph commencing with TawiI AlbaToni.
2. Tay-ayotu TaMCF I wrote a T. (TA.)

hom.sense: TaMCN, also pronounced TaA, One of the letters of the alphabet [i. e. the letter T]: masc. and fem.: Kh says that its A is originally I. (TA.) [See art. T.]
It is also an epithet applied to a man, meaning Multum coiens. (KL, TA.)

entry.sense: TaI-a: and TiI-N: and Tay-apN: and Tiy-apN (also pronounced TiyapN): and Tay-aAnu, fem. Tay-aA or Tay-aMCN: see in art. TwI.

hom.sense: 1. TaAba, aor. yaTiybu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. TiybN (Ṣ [but there mentioned app. as a subst.], O, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TiybapN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and TaAbN (Ḳ) and TuwbaI [q. v. infrà] (Ksh and Bḍ in xiii. 28) and taToyaAbN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [the last of which is of a measure denoting intensiveness, and is said in the TA to be with fet-ḥ because it is unsound, whereas the inf. n. of a sound verb, if of the measure tfEAl, is with kesr, but this is a strange mistake, (see 2 in art. byn,)] It was, or became, the contr. of xabiyv, (Ṣ, Mgh,) in two senses: (Mgh:) [i. e.] it was, or became, [good,] pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury; syn. lac-a; (A, Ḳ;) or kaAna laciycFA; (Mṣb;) or it was esteemed [good,] pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury, in taste, and in odour: (Mgh:) and it was, or became, pure, (Mgh, Ḳ,) or clean. (Mgh.) [See also Tay-ibN.]

[Hence,] TaAbato nafosuhu † His mind [or he himself] was, or became, [cheerful, happy, pleased,] dilated, or free from straitness. (Mṣb.) And Tibotu bihi nafosFA i. q. TaAbato bihi nafosiI † [i. e. I, or my mind, was, or became, cheerful, happy, pleased, or dilated, by means of it; agreeably with what next precedes: or pleased, content, or willing, to grant, concede, give, or do, it]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) [for] TaAbato nafosuhu biAlX-aIoCi [often] signifies ‡ He granted, conceded, or gave, the thing, liberally, [willingly, or of his own good pleasure,] without constraint, and without anger. (TA.) And faEalotu celika biTiybapinafosK † I did that [of my own free will; willingly;] not being constrained by any one. (Ṣ, O.) And TaAbato nafosiI Ealayohi † [My mind was agreeable to it]; said when a thing is agreeable, or suitable, to one's mind; and [in like manner] Tibotu nafosFA Ealayohi. (TA.) And TaAbato nafosuhu liloEamali wagayorihi [He was cheerful, happy, pleased, or willing, to do work, &c.]. (Ḳ in art. nXT.) And TaAbato nafosiI Eano celika tarokFA † [I was pleased, willing, or content, to leave, give up, relinquish, or be without, that]; and [in like manner] Tibotu nafosFA Eanohu: whence, in the Ḳur [iv. 3], faUino Tibona lakumo Eano XaIoCK minohu nafosFA † [But if they be pleased, or willing, or content, to give up, or relinquish, or remit, unto you somewhat thereof]. (TA.)

And TAb, (A, O, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. TiybN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and TiybapN, (Ḳ,) ‡ It was, or became, lawful, allowable, or free. (A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA.) [In the Ḳ, AlT-iybu and AlT-iybapu are expl. as meaning AlHil-u, which Golius has supposed to mean in this case “quod licitum, legitimum;” and which Freytag has in like manner expl. as meaning “res licita,” and “licitum:” but it is here an inf. n., of Hal-a; not syn. with the epithet AlHalaAlu, which is given as an explanation of AlT-ay-ibu.] You say, TaAba liI kacaA ‡ Such a thing became, or has become, lawful,, &c., to me. (A.) Hence the saying of Aboo-Hureyreh, AaloMna TaAba AlD-iraAbu, (TA,) or TaAba QmoDarobu, (O, TA,) as some relate it, accord. to the dial. of Himyer, (TA,) meaning TaAb QlD-arobu, i. e. † Now fighting has become lawful. (O, TA.) faQnokiHuwA maA TaAba lakumo mina Qln-isaMCi, in the Ḳur [iv. 3], means † [Then take ye in marriage] such as are lawful to you [of women]. (Mgh.)
And TaAbati AlOaroDu, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. TiybN, (TA,) † The land became abundant in herbage. (Ḳ, TA.)
See also 2, in two places:
and see 10.

entry.sense: 2. Ty-bhu, (Ṣ, M, A, MA, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taToyiybN; (KL;) and ATAbhu↓; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and TaAbahu↓; (IAạr, M, Ḳ;) He, or it, made it, or rendered it, good, pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury: perfumed, or rendered fragrant, him, or it: (Ṣ, MA, O,* Ḳ,* KL:) [and made it or rendered it, pure, or clean: (see 1, first sentence:)] you say, Ty-b julasaMCahu He perfumed his companions with whom he was sitting: (A:) and Ty-b Alv-awoba and TaAbahu↓ [He perfumed the garment]: (IAạr, M, TA:) or Tay-abotuhu I daubed, or smeared, him, or it, with perfume, or some odoriferous or fragrant substance: (Mṣb:) and Tay-abahu biAlT-iybi [He perfumed him, or daubed him, or smeared him, with some odoriferous or fragrant substance]. (TA.)

[Hence,] Ty-b binafosihi [and Ty-b nafosahu, which latter is a phrase of frequent occurrence, † He placated, or soothed, his mind;] he spoke to him pleasantly, sweetly, or blandly. (TA.) And Tay-abota nafosiI Eanoka † [Thou hast made me to be pleased, or happy, or content, without thee]. (Ṣ in art. slw.)

And Ty-bhu † He made it lawful, allowable, or free. (TA, from a trad.) [Hence,] Tay-aba ligariymihi niSofa AlmaAli ‡ He acquitted his debtor of the half of the property; gave up, resigned, or remitted, it to him. (A.)
See also 10.
3. TAybhu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. muTaAyabapN, (KL,) He jested, or joked, with him; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) indulged in pleasantry with him. (KL.)

hom.sense: 4: see 2:
and see also 10, in four places.
ATAb signifies also He brought, brought forward, offered, or proffered, good, pleasant, delicious, or savoury, food. (O, Ḳ.)
† He spoke good, pleasant, or sweet, words. (O, Ḳ.)
† He begat good children. (Ḳ.)
And † He wedded lawfully. (O, Ḳ.)

maA OaToyabahu, and maA OayoTabahu, the latter formed by transposition, (Ṣ, TA,) or a dial. var. of the former, (TA in art. yTb,) and OaToyibo bihi, and OayoTibo bihi, are all allowable [as meaning How good, pleasant, delightful, delicious, or sweet, is he, or it! or how pure, or clean,, &c.!]. (TA.)
And one says, maA OaToyaba nafosahu Eanoka [How pleased, or happy, or content is he to be without thee, or to give thee up, or to relinquish thee!]. (IAạr, Ḳ in art. sfT.)

entry.sense: 5. tTy-b [quasi-pass. of 2, as such signifying It became, or was made or rendered, good, pleasant,, &c.: and] he perfumed himself, or made himself fragrant, (A, Mṣb, TA,) biAlT-iybi [with perfume], (Mṣb,) or biAlX-iIoCi [with the thing]. (TA.)

10. AstTAbhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AisotaToyabahu, (Sb, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and ATAbhu↓, (TA,) and OaToyabahu↓, and Ty-bhu↓, (Ḳ,) and TaAbahu↓, (TA, [but this last I think doubtful,]) He found it, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or saw it, (Mṣb,) to be Tay-ib [i. e. good, pleasant,, &c.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One says, AstTAb fulaAnN Ald-iymapa [Such a one found, or saw, to be good, or pleasant, the lasting and still rain]. (A.)

And AstTAb, (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or AstTAb nafosahu, (TA,) and ATAb↓, (A, O, Ḳ,) or ATAb↓ nafosahu, (TA,) i. q. AisotanojaI [i. e. He washed, or wiped with a stone, or a piece of dry clay, the place of exit of his excrement]. (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [This signification is said in the TA to be tropical; but it is not so accord. to the A.]
And AstTAb He shaved his pubes. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

And He asked people for sweet water. (Ḳ.) Thus, accord. to IAạr, the saying [of a poet]
falam-aA QsotaTaAbuwA Sub-a fiI AlS-aHoni niSofuhu
means And when they asked for sweet water [the half of it was poured forth into the bowl]: but it is also expl. agreeably with what here follows. (TA.)
He (a man) drank TaAbap [i. e. wine]: so in the M. (TA.)

TaAbN is an inf. n. of TaAba, (Ḳ,) and syn. with TiybN and also with Tay-ibN, q. v.: a poet says, praising ʼOmar Ibn-ʼAbd-El-'Azeez,
muqaAbalu AlUiEoraAqi fiI AlT-aAbi AlT-aAbo
bayona OabiI AlEaASiI waMli AlxaT-aAbo [i. e. Rooted by the father's and the mother's side in unsullied goodness, or the like, between Abu-l- 'Ásee on the one side and the family of El-Khattáb on the other: for it is evidently cited as an ex. of AlTAb used as a subst. and as an epithet; so that by fI AlTAb AlTAb is meant fI AlT-iybi AlT-ay-ibi: otherwise it might be supposed that the literal repetition is meant to denote simply corroboration, as appears to be the case in an instance which will be mentioned in what follows:] the object of praise being the son of ʼAbd-El-'Azeez the son of Marwán the son of El-Hakam the son of Abu-l-'Ás [or 'Ásee], and his mother being Umm-'Ásim the daughter of 'Ásim the son of ʼOmar the son of El-Khattáb. (Ṣ, O.)

Eacoqu Qboni TaAbK is the name of A sort of palm-trees in El-Medeeneh [app. so called because of the sweetness of their fruit, or TAb may in this instance be for TaAbap, a name of El-Medeeneh]: (Ḳ:) or, as also ruTabu Qboni TaAbK, a sort of dates of El-Medeeneh: (Ṣ, O:) or Aibonu TaAbK is a name of a sort of fresh ripe dates: (Ḳ:) and Eacoqu Qboni TaAbK and Eacoqu Qboni zayodK are two sorts of dates: (Ṣ:) accord. to IAth, ruTabu Qboni TaAbK is the name of a sort of dates of El-Medeeneh so called in relation to Ibn-Táb, a man of its inhabitants. (TA.)
TuwbN, mentioned in this art. in the Ṣ and Ḳ, [as though it were originally TuyobN,] see in art. Twb.

TiybN an inf. n. of TaAba. (O, Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ.) [Used as a simple subst., Goodness, pleasantness,, &c.] You say, maA bihi mina AlT-iybi [There is not in him aught of goodness,, &c.]: you should not say, mn AlT-iybapi. (Ṣ, O.) [See also TaAbN: and TuwbaI.]

[Also] a word of well-known meaning; (Ḳ;) [A perfume; a fragrant, or an odoriferous, substance;] a substance with which one perfumes himself, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) of what is termed EiTor. (Mṣb.) [The pl. accord. to Golius and Freytag is OaToyaAbN. Hence, jawozu AlT-iybi The nutmeg: see jwz.]
Also The most excellent of any sort of thing. (Ḳ.) [See also OaToyabu: and Tay-ibapN.]

hom.sense: TaAbapN Wine: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) as though meaning Tay-ibapN; and originally TayabapN: (AM, TA:) or i. q. EaSiyrN [i. e. expressed juice]. (TA, from an explanation of a trad.)
TaAbapu: see what next follows.

entry.sense: Tayobapu a name of The city of the Prophet; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also TaAbapu↓, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AlT-ay-ibapu↓, and AlmuTay-abapu↓, (Ḳ,) which last may be also written AlmuTay-ibapu↓. (TA.)

hom.sense: TiybapN an inf. n. of TaAba. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
Also The clearest of wine: (Ḳ:) and the choicest of herbage. (TA.)
Tiybapu is a name of The well Zemzem. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: saboIN TiyabapN ‡ Persons (Aṣ, TA) made captive lawfully, (Aṣ, Ṣ,* A, O,* Ḳ,* TA,) without perfidy and breach of covenant, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) not made so when a covenant is existing with them, (Aṣ, TA,) nor when there is any doubt respecting their state of slavery: (O:) TiyabapN, in the sense of Tay-ibN, is [said to be] the only instance among nouns, (TA,) or rather among epithets, (MF, TA,) of fiEalapN, with kesr and then fet-ḥ, (TA,) i. e. with only fet-ḥ to the E. (MF, TA.)

TuwbaI, of the measure fuEolaI from AlT-iybu, originally TuyobaI, (Zj, Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) an inf. n. of TaAbN, (Ksh and Bḍ in xiii. 28,) syn. with TiybN: (Seer, Ḳ: [in my MṢ copy of the Ḳ Tay-ib, a manifest mistake:]) and fem. of OaToyabu: (ISd, Ḳ:) and pl. of Tay-ibapN, (Ḳ,) accord. to Kr, who says that there is no word like it except kuwsaI pl. of kay-isapN, and DuwqaI pl. of Day-iqapN; but ISd says that, in his opinion, TuwbaI and kuwsaI and DuwqaI are fems. of OaToyabu and Oakoyasu and OaDoyaqu, because fuEolaI is not a pl. measure: Kr also adds that they did not say TiybaI↓, like as they said kiysaI and DiyqaI; (TA; [see DuwqaI, in art. Dyq;]) [but Ṣgh says that] TiybaI↓ is a dial. var. of TuwbaI: (O:) Aboo-Ḥátim Sahl Ibn-Moḥammad Es-Sijistánee relates that an Arab of the desert, reciting as a pupil to him, persisted in pronouncing TuyobaI for TuwbaI: (TA:) it signifies HusonaI [as meaning A good final, or ultimate, state or condition]: and (some say, O, Mṣb) xayorN [meaning good, good fortune, and the like]: (O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and xiyrapN [meaning God's blessing or favour,, &c.]; (Ḳ;) as some say: (TA:) or eternal life: (Zj, TA:) or a pleasant life: (Mṣb:) and (O, Ḳ) a certain tree in Paradise; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) thus the Prophet is related to have said; and MF says that it is a proper name thereof, not admitting the article Al, and the like is said in the M: (TA:) or it signifies Paradise in the Indian language; (O, Ḳ;) or, accord. to Saʼeed Ibn-Jubeyr, in the Abyssinian language: (O:) as also TiybaI↓. (Ḳ.) These different significations are assigned by different persons to this word in the phrase in the Ḳur [xiii. 28] TuwbaI lahumo [which seems to be best rendered as an announcement, meaning A good final state,, &c., shall be to them, or be their lot]: (Mṣb, TA:) Sb holds that it is an invocation of good, or a prayer, [as though qulo i. e. “say thou” were understood before it,] and that TwbI is virtually in the nom. case, i. e. marofuwE, as is shown by the words immediately following waHusonu maMbK: but Th, who makes TwbI to be an inf. n. like rujoEaI, says that one reading is TuwbaI lahumo waHusona maMbK, like the phrase saqoyFA lahu: MF, however, [supposing Th to have said TuwbFI, though I think it indubitable that he said TuwbaI, and only meant that it was used as virtually, not literally, with tenween,] observes that rujoEFI, with tenween, is not known to have been transmitted from any one of the leading authorities on the Arabic language. (TA.) Ḳatádeh says that TuwbaI lahumo is a phrase of the Arabs; who say, TuwbaI laka Uino faEalota kacaA wakacaA [A good final state, &c., be to thee, or be thy lot, or shall be to thee, if thou do such and such things]: and it is said in a trad., TuwbaI lilX-aOomi [May good,, &c., betide Syria]; in which case, TwbI is of the measure fuEolaI from AlT-iybu, and does not mean “Paradise,” nor “the tree.” (L, TA.) One says, TuwbaI laka and TuwbaAka; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) but not Tuwabyoka: (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, O: [in one of my copies of the Ṣ Tuwbiyka:]) or TuwbaAka is a barbarism: (O, Ḳ:) it is disallowed by the T, and by most of the grammarians: but Akh says that it is used by some of the Arabs; and Ibn-El-Moatezz uses it in the following verse:
mar-ato binaA saHarFA TayorN faqulotu lahaA
TuwbaAki yaA layotanaA Uiy-aAki TuwbaAki
[A flock of birds passed by us a little before daybreak, and I said to them, Good betide you: would that we were you: good betide you]:
Esh-Shiháb El-Khafájee says that l is understood [before the k] in TwbAk; but MF has argued well against this assertion. (TA.)
TiybaI: see the next preceding paragraph, former half, in three places.

TiyaAbN A sort of palm-trees of El-Basrah, (L, Ḳ, TA,) the dates of which, when the gathering has been delayed beyond the usual time, fall, one after another, from their stones, so that the raceme remains with nothing upon it but the stones hanging to the bases of the dates; though they are large; and if the fruit is gathered when fully ripe, the stone does not come off with it. (L, TA.)

Tay-ibN (Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TaAbN↓, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) the latter originally TaAYibN and deprived of its medial radical letter, or of the measure faEalN, (M, TA,) Contr. of xabiyvN, (Ṣ, Mgh, O,) in two senses: (Mgh:) [i. e. good,] pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury; syn. laciycN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;*) or esteemed [good,] pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury, (musotalac-N,) in taste, and in odour: (Mgh:) and pure, (Mgh, Ḳ,) or clean. (Mgh.) You say TaEaAmN Tay-ibN Food [pleasant in taste; or] that descends easily [and agreeably] down the throat. (TA.) And maMCN Tay-ibN Sweet water; (O, TA;) or pure water. (TA.) [And raAYiHapN Tay-ibapN A pleasant, sweet, or fragrant, odour.] And baladN Tay-ibN A country that has no salsuginous places in it: (O, TA:) or a land of good and fertile soil. (Mgh.) And SaEiydN Tay-ibN Pure ground. (Zj, Mgh, O.) And Alkalimu AlT-ay-ibu † [The good saying] i. e. laA Uileha Uil-aA Qll-ehu [There is no deity but God]. (TA.) And fulaAnN fiI bayotK Tay-ibK i. e. ‡ [Such a one is of a good house, or family; meaning,] of high, or noble, birth. (TA.) And fulaAnN Tay-ibu AlUizaAri † Such a one is continent, or chaste. (O.) And fulaAnN Tay-ibu AlOaxolaAqi † Such a one is [of good, or pleasant, dispositions;] easy in converse, conversable, or affable. (O, TA.) [And Tay-ibu Aln-afosi † Cheerful, happy, pleased, or dilated, in mind. (See TaAbato nafosuhu.) And nafosN Tay-ibapN biXaIoCK † A mind cheerful, happy, pleased, or dilated, by means of a thing: or pleased, content, or willing, to grant, concede, give, or do, a thing: and Tay-ibapN Eano XaIoCK † pleased, willing, or content, to leave, give up, relinquish, or be without, a thing. (See, again, 1.)]

Also † Lawful; allowable; allowable by, or agreeable to, law; legitimate; legal; or free. (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) laA yasotawiI Qloxabiyvu waQlT-ay-ibu, in the Ḳur [v. 100], means † The unlawful and the lawful of property and the unrighteous and the righteous of deeds and the sound and the unsound of tenets or the like and the good and the bad of mankind [shall not be equal in your estimation]. (Mgh.) [See also the next paragraph.]

Tay-ibapN [fem. of Tay-ibN: and also a subst., made so by the affix p; meaning A good, pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet or savoury, thing: and a pure, or clean, thing: pl. Tay-ibaAtN]. waQlT-ay-ibaAti mina Alr-izqi, in the Ḳur [vii. 30], means And what are esteemed [good,] pleasant, delicious, sweet, or savoury, of foods and beverages. (Mgh.) And OanofiquwA mino Tay-ibaAti maA kasabotumo, in the same [ii. 269], Expend ye of the good things that ye have gained: (Mgh:) or † of your lawful gains. (Mgh, O.) And kuluwA mina QlT-ay-ibaAti, in the same [xxiii. 53], † Eat ye of the things that are lawful; of any such lawful things as are esteemed good, or pleasant. (TA.) AlT-ay-ibaAtu mina AlkalaAmi means † The most excellent of words, or speech; (Mṣb, TA;) the best thereof: (Mṣb:) and is meant by AlT-ay-ibaAtu in [the words of] the taXah-ud, [commencing with] Alt-aHiy-aAtu lil-ehi waAlS-alawaAtu waAlT-ay-ibaAtu: [see taHiy-apN, in art. HI:] and likewise in the Ḳur [xxiv. 26], where it is said, AlT-ay-ibaAtu lilT-ay-ibiyna; by the Ty-byn being meant the pure of men; accord. to Fr.: but these words of the Ḳur are otherwise expl., as meaning the good women are for the good men. (O.)
See also Tayobapu.

Tuy-aAbN, with damm, means Tay-ibN jid-FA [i. e. Very good, pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury]. (Ṣ, O, TA. [In the Ḳ it is implied that it is simply syn. with Tay-ibN; like as many other intensive epithets are confounded therein with those that are not intensive.]) A poet says,
Uin-aA wajadonaA maMCahaA Tuy-aAbaA
[Verily we found its water to be very good, pleasant, or sweet]. (Ṣ, O.)

OaToyabu [Better, and best; more, and most, pleasant, delightful, delicious, sweet, or savoury]: its fem. is TuwbaI: (ISd, Ḳ:) and OaTaAyibu is its pl.: (Ṣ:) and OayoTabu is a dial. var. of OaToyabu, or is formed from the latter by transposition. (TA in art. yTb.)

AlOaToyabaAni [The two best, or most pleasant,, &c., of things,] means † Eating and coïtus: (IAạr, Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ:) or sleep and coïtus: (ISk, O, TA:) or the mouth and the vulva of a woman: (Yaạḳoob, A, O, Ḳ:) or fat and youthfulness: (A, Ḳ:) or strength and appetence: or youthfulness and briskness or liveliness or sprightliness: (Ḥar p. 88:) or fresh ripe dates and the xirbiz [or water-melon]: or milk and dates. (TA.)

And OaTaAyibu signifies The best, or best parts, of a thing, (Ḳ, TA,) as of flesh-meat, &c.; (TA;) as also maTaAyibu↓, a pl. which has no sing., (Ḳ, TA,) of the same class as maHaAsinu and malaAmiHu, (TA,) or its pl. is maToyabN↓, (Ks, O, Ḳ,) or maTaAbN↓ and maTaAbapN↓: (M, Ḳ:) or you say, OaToEamanaA mino OaTaAyibi Aljazuwri [He fed us from the best parts of the slaughtered camel], but not mn maTaAyibi↓ Aljzwr; (Ṣ, O;) or you say, mino OaTaAyibihaA and maTaAyibihaA↓; (Aṣ, A, O;) or the latter, but not the former; (Yaạḳoob, TA;) or you say OaTaAyibu Aljazuwri, and maTaAyibu↓ Alr-uTabi [the best of fresh ripe dates]; (IAạr, Ḳ;) and AḤn uses the phrase OaTaAyibu AlkalaOi [the best portions of the herbage]. (TA.)
OayoTab-apu AlEanozi and OayoTabatuhaA [mentioned in this art. because held to be formed by transposition (in Freytag's Lex. with Tu in each case)] The she-goat's lusting for the male. (AZ, O, Ḳ.)
maTaAbN: see OaToyabu.
maToyabN: see OaToyabu.

muTiybN [part. n. of 4: as such signifying] A lawful wedder: a woman said to her beloved,
walaA zurotanaA Uil-aA waOanota muTiybu
[Nor didst thou visit us save when thou wast a lawful wedder]: because, in the estimation of excessive lovers, what is unlawful is more sweet. (TA.)
maTaAbapN: see OaToyabu.

maToyabapN [A cause of pleasure or delight]. One says, hecaA XaraAbN maToyabapN liln-afosi This is a beverage [which is a cause of pleasure to the soul, or] with which the soul is pleased when drinking it. (Ṣ, O.) And in like manner one says of food. (TA.)

muTay-abN pass. part. n. of 2. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) Hilofu AlmuTay-abiyna [The covenant of the perfumed men]: (Ḳ, TA:) these were five tribes; Benoo-ʼAbd-Menáf and Benoo-Asad-Ibn-'AbdEl-'Ozzà and Benoo-Teym and Benoo-Zuhrah and Benu-l-Hárith and Benoo-Fihr: (TA:) and they were so called for the following reason: when Benoo-ʼAbd-Menáf desired to assume [the offices of] the HijaAbap and the rifaAdap and the liwaMC and the siqaAyap, [see arts. Hjb, &c.,] which belonged to Benoo-ʼAbd-ed-Dár, and these refused their consent, all of the above-mentioned, (Ḳ, TA,) having assembled in the house of Ibn-Jud'án, in the Time of Ignorance, (TA,) concluded a ratified covenant for the accomplishment of their affair, engaging not to fail in aiding one another: then they mixed some perfumes, and dipped their hands therein; after which they wiped their hands upon the Kaabeh in token of confirmation of the covenant: and Benoo-'Abded-Dár, also, and their confederates, (Ḳ, TA,) composing six tribes, Benoo-ʼAbd-ed-Dár and Jumah and Makhzoom and 'Adee and Kaab and Sahm, (TA,) concluded together another covenant, and were thence called AlOaHolaAf: (Ḳ, TA:) this is the account commonly known and received: another account is the following: there came a man of the Benoo-Zeyd to Mekkeh for the purpose of [the religious visit termed] the Eumorap, having with him merchandise, and a man of Sahm bought this of him, and refused to pay him for it; whereupon he called to them from the summit of Aboo-Kubeys, and they arose, and entered into a covenant together to do him justice: thus relates Eth-Tha'álibee: (TA:) Moḥammad was one of the muTay-abuwn, (Ḳ, TA,) being then twenty-five years old; and so was Aboo-Bekr: and ʼOmar was an OaHolafiI-. (TA.)
AlmuTay-abapu: see Tayobapu.
AlmuTay-ibapu: see Tayobapu.
maToyuwbN pass. part. n. of TaAbahu [as syn. with Tay-abahu]; like maxoyuwTN [from xaATahu]. (TA.)
maTaAyibu: see OaToyabu, in four places.

1. TaAHa, aor. yaTiyHu, inf. n. TayoHN: see 1 in art. TwH. Sb says that this verb is [originally TawiHa, aor. yaTowiHu, i. e.,] of the measure faEila, aor. yafoEilu; like waliIa, aor. yaliI; accord. to those who say Taw-aHahu, and not Tay-aHahu: but accord. to those who say Tay-aHahu, it is [originally TayaHa, aor. yaToyiHu, of the measure faEala, aor. yafoEilu,] like baAEa, aor. yabiyEu. (L, TA.)
2. Ty-H: see 2 in art. TwH.
4. maA OaToyaHahu: see 4 in arts. TwH and twh.
5. tTy-H, syn. with tTw-H: see 1 in art. TwH.
6. tTAyH It became scattered, or dispersed; or it flew away or about; syn. taTaAyara. (Ḥam p. 615.)
TayoHN A piece of wood that is in the OaSol [app. meaning lower part] of the plough. (Ḳ.)

OaSaAbatohumo TayoHapN (A, Ḳ) means Events that caused divisions between them, or that dispersed them, befell them: (Ḳ, TA:) so says Aboo-Saʼeed. (TA.) And one says, Taw-aHatohumo TayoHaAtN Calamities destroyed them. (TA.) And cahabato OamowaAluhumo TayoHaAtK Their possessions, or cattle, went away dispersed, or scattered, and remote. (TA.) [See also TayoxapN.]
TaAYiHN: see art. TwH.
kaf-N TaAYiHapN occurs in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh as meaning A hand flying from its wrist. (TA.)

muTay-aHN, accord. to the Ḳ, signifies Bad, corrupt, or vitious: but it may be a mistransscription, for muTab-aHN [or this is a mistranscription for muTay-axN, which is expl. as having this meaning]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. TaAxa, aor. yaTiyxu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. TayoxN; (L;) as also tTy-x↓; He became charged, reproached, or upbraided, with something bad, evil, abominable, or foul, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) either said or done. (L.)
And TAx, aor. as above, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (L,) He magnified himself, or was proud. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
And He exerted himself, or strove, and persisted, or persevered, in that which was vain. (Ḳ.)

TaAxahu, aor. yiTiyxuhu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. TayoxN; as also TAxhu, aor. yaTuwxuhu, inf. n. TawoxN; but the former is the more common; (TA in art. Twx;) and Ty-xhu↓; He charged, reproached, or upbraided, him with something bad, evil, abominable, or foul, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) either said or done. (L.) And Ty-x↓ OaSoHaAbahu He reviled and harassed his companions. (Aboo-Málik, TA.)
And TAx AlOamora, inf. n. as above, He corrupted, vitiated, or marred, the affair. (ISd, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see above {1}, in two places.
Ty-x AlEacaAbu Ealayohi, (Ḳ,) or rather (TA) Ty-xhu AlEacaAbu, (AZ, TA,) Punishment pressed severely, or persistently, upon him, so that it killed him. (AZ, Ḳ, TA.)
And Ty-xhu Als-imanu Fatness filled him with fat and flesh. (AZ, Ḳ, TA.)
5: see 1, first sentence.
TayoxN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: TiyxN a word imitative of the sound of laughing. (Sb, Ḳ.) qaAluwA Tiyxi Tiyxi, the word Tyx being in this case indecl., with kesr for its termination, means They uttered a reiterated laughing [like a repeating of Tiyx]. (Lth, Ḳ, TA.)
Also, and TayoxN↓, Ignorance. (TA.)

TayoxapN (L, Ḳ) and TaAYixN↓ and Tay-aAxapN↓ [which last is a doubly intensive epithet] (L) Stupid, in whom is little good: (L, Ḳ:) or stupid and dirty: pl. of the first TayoxaAtN: it has no known broken pl. (L.) [See also TaboxapN and TanaxapN.]
Also the first, Trial; sedition, or conflict and faction; or the like; syn. fitonapN; (Ḳ, TA;) and war. (TA.) [See also TayoHapN.]

entry.sense: TayuwxN A she-camel that goes to the right and left, and crops the extremities of the trees. (TA.)
Tay-aAxapN: see TayoxapN.
TaAYixN: see TayoxapN.
muTay-axN [app. applied to a camel] Smeared with tar. (Ḳ.)
And Bad, corrupt, or vitious. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. TaAra, aor. yaTiyru, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. TayaraAnN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TayoruwrapN (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and TayorN, (Ḳ,) He (a winged creature) moved in the air by means of his wings; flew; (A, Ḳ;) moved in the air as a beast does upon the ground. (Mṣb.)

It is also said of other things than those which have wings; as in the saying of El-'Amberee (Kureyt Ibn-Uneyf, Ḥam p. 3):
TaAruwA Uilayohi zaraAfaAtK wawuHodaAnaA
[They fly to it in companies and one by one]; (TA;) i. e. they hasten to it: for Tirotu UilaI kacaA means † I hastened to such a thing: and Tirotu bikacaA † I outstripped, or became foremost, with such a thing. (Ḥam p. 6.) And TAr EalaI matoni farasihi ‡ He fled upon the back of his horse. (TA, from a trad.) And TAr Alqawomu † The people took fright and ran away quickly. (Mṣb.) And TaAruwA siraAEFA † They went away quickly. (TA.)
[One says also, TAr Euqoluhu † His reason fled. And TAr fuWaAduhu ‡ His courage (lit. his heart) fled away: see also 10: and see XaEaAEN. (Both are phrases of frequent occurrence.)]
And TAr TaAYruhu: see TaAYirN.
[And see an ex. voce Xiq-apN.]

TAr qalobiI maTaArahu means † My heart inclined towards that which it loved, and clung to it. (TA, from a trad.) And TiyriI bihi, addressed to a woman, is expl. by IAạr as meaning † Love thou, or become attached, to him. (TA.)
TArt Eayonuhu (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. xlj) † His eye throbbed. (PṢ and TḲ in that art.)

TAr lahu SiytN fiI Aln-aAsi ‡ [He became famous among the people; lit. means fame among the people became, or came to be, (SaAra,) his]. (A.) [And in like manner one says,] TAr lahu mino naSiybihi kacaA ‡ Such a thing became his, or came to him, of his lot, or portion; syn. SaAra, and HaSala. (Mgh.) And TAr lanaA ‡ It came to our lot, or portion. (TA.) And TAr likul-K minohumo sahomuhu ‡ The share of each came to him. (TA.)
See also 6, in two places.
TaAra bihi is also syn. with Tay-arahu, q. v. (TA.)
[Hence the metaphorical phrase TaArato bihaA AlEarabu expl. voce EarabapN.]
TArt AlUibilu biMcaAnihaA, (TA,) or biOaconaAbihaA, (O, TA,) thus [correctly] in the TṢ, (TA,) [like XaAlato biOaconaAbihaA,] means † The she-camels conceived. (O, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Ty-rhu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Ty-r bihi, (Ḳ,) and ATArhu↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and TAyrhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and TaAra↓ bihi, (TA,) He made him to fly. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See also 10.]
Tay-ara AlEaSaAfiyra Eani Alz-aroEi He made the sparrows to fly away, [scared them, or dispersed them,] from the seedproduce. (A.)

humo fiI XaIoCK laA yuTay-aru guraAbuhu [They are in that whereof the crow is not made to fly away, because of its abundance]: a prov. alluding to a state of plenty. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also guraAbN.] One says also OuTiyra AlguraAbu [The crow was made to fly away]. (Ṣ.) [See muTaArN.]
Ty-r fuWaAdahu ‡ [He, or it, made his courage (lit. his heart) to fly away]. (Ṣ in art. fz, &c.)

Ty-r AlmaAla bayona Alqawomi, and ATArhu↓, He divided the property into lots, or shares, among the people: (O, Ḳ,* TA:) OaTarotu, signifying I divided into lots, or shares, occurs in a trad.; but some say that the O is a radical letter. (IAth, TA.)
Ty-r AlfaHolu AlUibila means † The stallion made all the she-camels to conceive: (Ḳ, TA:) or, to conceive quickly. (TA.) And Tay-arato hiIa [or Tuy-irato?] They conceived quickly. (TA.)
3: see 2, first sentence.

hom.sense: 4: see 2, in two places.
ATArt OaroDunaA Our land abounded, or became abundant, in birds. (TA.)

entry.sense:
5. tTy-r minohu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and bihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) sometimes changed to AiT-ay-ara, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) as in the Ḳur xxvii. 48, the t being incorporated into the T, and this requiring a conjunctive A that the word may begin with it [and not with a quiescent letter], (Ṣ,) inf. n. [or rather quasi-inf. n.] TiyarapN, the only instance of the kind except xiyarapN, which is the same in relation to taxay-ara, (IAth,) He augured evil from it; regarded it as an evil omen. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
The Arabs, when they desired to set about an affair, passed by the places where birds lay upon the ground, and roused them, in order to learn thence whether they should proceed or refrain: but the law forbade this. (Mṣb.) They augured evil from the croaking of the crow, and from the birds' going towards the left; and in like manner, from the motions of gazelles. (TA.) tafaMCala signifies the contr. of tTy-r. (TA.)
6. tTAyr † It became scattered, or dispersed; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) flew away or about; went away; became reduced to fragments; (TA;) as also AstTAr↓, (Ḳ, TA,) and TaAra↓. (TA.)

‡ It became long, or tall; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also TaAra↓, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) which is said of hair, (TA,) as is also the former, (Ṣ, TA,) and of a camel's hump. (Ṣgh, TA.) It is said in a trad., xuco maA taTaAyara mino XaEarika (Ṣ, TA) [Clip thou] what has become long and dishevelled [of thy hair]. (TA.)
tTAyr Als-aHaAbu fiI Als-amaMCi † The clouds became spread throughout the sky. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also 10.]
7. AnTAr It became split, slit, or cracked. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also 10, latter part.]

hom.sense: 10. AstTAr [He made a thing to fly. See also 2.]
[Hence,] † He drew forth a sword quickly from its scabbard. (Ḳ,* TA.)

AusotuTiyra † It (for ex., dust, Ṣ) was made to fly. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, kaAda yusotaTaAru mino Xid-api Eadowihi ‡ [He was almost made to fly by reason of the vehemence of his running]. (A.) And AusotuTiyra fuWaAduhu mina AlfazaEi ‡ [His courage (lit. his heart) was made to fly away by reason of fright]. (A.)
† He was taken away quickly, as though the birds carried him away. (TA.)
† He hastened, or was quick, in running; (Ḳ;) he ran quickly; (O, L;) said of a horse. (O, L, Ḳ.) [A signification of the pass. form; as though meaning he was made to fly.]
† He was [flurried, or] frightened. (O, Ḳ.) [As though meaning originally he was made to fly by reason of fright.]

AstTAr ‡ It (the dawn) spread; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) its light spread in the horizon: (TA:) [see musotaTiyrN:] and the verb is used in the same sense in relation to other things: (Ṣ:) said of lightning, it spread in the horizon: and of dust, it spread in the air: and of evil, it spread. (TA.) See also 6.

‡ It (a crack in a wall) appeared and spread. (A. [See also AstTAl.]) It (a slit, or crack, for Als-uwqu in the Ḳ is a mistake for AlX-aq-u, or, accord. to the L, a crack in a wall, TA) rose, (Ḳ,) and appeared. (TA.) † It (a crack in a glass vessel, and wear in a garment,) became apparent in the parts thereof. (TA.)
‡ It (a wall) cracked (Ḳ, TA) from the beginning thereof to the end. (TA.) † It (a glass vessel) showed a crack in it from beginning to end. (TA.) [See also 7.]
AstTArt said of a bitch, She desired the male. (O, Ḳ.)
TayorN: see TaAYirN, in seven places:
and see also TayorapN, in two places.
Tayoru Tayoru, (O,) or Tayori Tayori, (TA,) is a cry by which a sheep or goat is called. (O, TA.)

entry.sense: TayorapN and TayoruwrapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and TayorN↓ (Ṣ) ‡ Levity; inconstancy. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) You say, fiI fulaAnK TayorapN and TayoruwrapN↓, ‡ In such a one is levity, or inconstancy. (Ṣ.) And Auzojuro OaHonaMCa Tayorika↓ ‡ [alluding to the original signification of TayorN, namely, “birds,”] means jawaAniba xif-atika waTayoXika [agreeing with an explanation of the same saying voce HinowN, q. v.]. (Ṣ.)
Also TayorapN † A slip; a stumble: hence the trad., Uiy-aAka waTayoraAti AlX-abaAbi † Beware thou of the slips and stumbles of youth. (TA.)
TiyorapN and TiyarapN and TiwarapN; see TaAYirN; the second, in four places.
TayoruwrapN: see TayorapN, in two places.

hom.sense: Tay-aArN ‡ A sharp, spirited, vigorous, horse, (Ḳ, TA,) that is almost made to fly by reason of the vehemence of his running; (TA;) as also muTaArN↓. (Ḳ, TA. [The latter word in the CK written maTAr; but said in the TA to be with damm, and so written in a copy of the A.]) [See also Tay-uwrN.]
See also musotaTiyrN.
Also A company of men. (O.)

As applied to A balance, it is not of the language of the Arabs: (O:) [i. e., it is post-classical:] it means an assay-balance (miyzaAnN and maEoyaArN) for gold; so called because of the form of a bird, or because of its lightness: or the balance for dirhems [or moneys] that is known among them [who use it] by the appellation of the qArsTwn [meaning the χαριστίων of Archimedes, (as is observed in a note in p. 178 of vol. ii. of the sec. ed. of Ḥar,) i. e. the hydrostatic balance]: or, accord. to El-Fenjedeehee, the tongue (lisaAt) of the balance. (Ḥar pp. 549-50.)

entry.sense: huwa Tay-uwrN fay-uwrN † He is sharp, and quick in returning [to a good state], or recovering [from his anger]. (Ḳ.) [See also Tay-aArN.]

hom.sense: TaAYirN A flying thing [whether bird or insect]: (Mṣb,* TA:) pl. TayorN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as SaHobN is pl. of SaAHibN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or TayorN is originally an inf. n. of TaAra: or an epithet contracted from Tay-irN: (TA:) or a quasi-pl. n.; (Mgh, TA;) and this is the most correct opinion: (TA:) [but see, below, a reason for considering it originally an inf. n.:] and TaAYirN may also be quasi-pl. n., like jaAmilN and baAqirN: (TA:) TayorN↓ is also sometimes used as a sing.; (Ḳṭr, AO, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as in the Ḳur iii. 43 [and v. 110], accord. to one reading: (Ṣ:) but ISd says, I know not how this is, unless it be meant to be [originally] an inf. n.: (TA:) [for an inf. n. used as an epithet is employed as sing. and pl.:] or TaAYirN, only, is used as a sing., (Th, IAmb, Mṣb,) by general consent; and AO once said so in common with others: (Th:) but TayorN↓ has a collective, or pl., signification: (IAmb, Mṣb:) and is fem.: (Mgh:) or is more frequently fem. than masc.: (IAmb, Mṣb:) the pl. of TayorN is TuyuwrN [a pl. of mult.] and OaToyaArN [a pl. of pauc.]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or TuyuwrN may be pl. of TaAYirN, like as sujuwdN is pl. of saAjidN: (TA:) TaAYirapN is seldom applied to the female. (IAmb, Mṣb.)
[AlT-aAYir is a name of † The constellation Cygnus; also called Ald-ajaAjapu.]

huwa saAkinu AlT-aAYiri means ‡ He is grave, staid, sedate, (Ḳ,) or motionless; so that if a bird alighted upon him, it would be still; for if a bird alight upon a man, and he move in the least, the bird flies away. (TA.) Of the same kind also is the saying, ruziqa fulaAnN sukuwna AlT-aAYiri waxafoDa AljinaAHi ‡ [Such a one was endowed, or has been endowed, with gravity and gentleness]. (TA.) And Tuyuwruhumo sawaAkinu ‡ They are remaining fixed, settled, or at rest: and XaAlato naEaAmatuhumo signifies the contrary. (A, TA.) And kaOan-a EalaI ruWusihimu AlT-ayora↓ ‡ [As though birds were on their heads] is said of a people, meaning them to be motionless by reason of reverence: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it was said of the Companions of Moḥammad, describing them as quiet and grave [in his presence], without levity: and the origin of the saying is this: that birds alight only upon a thing that is still and inanimate: (TA:) or that the crow alights upon the head of the camel, and picks from it the ticks, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the young ones thereof, (Ṣ,) and the camel does not move (Ṣ, Ḳ) his head, (Ṣ,) lest the crow should take fright and fly away. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) In like manner, waqaEa TaAYiruhu means ‡ He became grave, or sedate. (Meyd.) And TaAra↓ TaAYiruhu ‡ He became light, or inconstant: (Meyd:) and he became angry; (O, Ḳ, TA;) like vaAra vaAYiruhu and faAra faAYiruhu: (TA:) or he hastened, and was light, or active, or agile. (Ḥar p. 561.)

And it is said in a trad., Alr-uWoyaA EalaI rijoli TaAYirK maA lamo tuEab-aro (O, TA) † A dream is unsettled as to its result, or final sequel, while it is not interpreted. (TA.) [The Arabs hold that the result of a dream is affected by its interpretation: wherefore it is added in this tradition, and said in others also, that the dreamer should not relate his dream, unless to a friend or to a person of understanding.]
Eay-avato Tayoruhu↓ see expl. in art. Eyv.

TaAYirN also signifies A thing from which one augurs either good or evil; an omen, a bodement, of good or of evil: (Ḳ:) and TiyarapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and TiyrapN↓ (Ḳ) and TiwarapN↓ (IDrd, Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA [in the CK, in this art., erroneously, TuwrapN, but in art. Twr it is Tiwarap,]) a thing from which one augurs evil; an evil omen or bodement; (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.;) contr. of faOolN: (TA:) and TaAYirN signifies fortune, (AʼObeyd, Ḳ, TA,) whether good or evil: (TA:) and especially evil fortune; ill luck; as also TayorN↓ and TiyarapN↓: for the Arabs used to augur evil from the croaking of the crow, and from birds going towards the left: [see 5:] (TA:) and TiyarapN↓ is an inf. n. [or rather a quasi-inf. n.] of taTay-ara, [q. v.,] (IAth,) and signifies auguration of evil. (Mṣb.)
The Arabs used to say, to a man or other thing from which they augured evil, (TA,) TaAYiru Qll-ehi laA TaAYiruka, (ISk, Ṣ, IAmb,) and TAYra Qll-eh lA TAYrak, meaning What God doth and decreeth, not what thou dost and causest to be feared: (IAmb:) accord. to ISk, one should not say Tayoru↓ Qll-ehi: (Ṣ:) but the Arabs are related to have said, also, laA Tayora Uil-aA Tayoru Qll-ehi [There is no evil fortune but that which is of God]; like as one says, laA Oamora Uil-aA Oamoru Qll-ehi. (Aṣ, Ṣ.) They also used to say, jaraI lahu AlT-aAYiru biOamori kacaA [Fortune brought to him such an event]: and hence fortune, whether good or evil, is called TAYr. (TA.) And it is said in the Ḳur [vii. 128], Uin-amaA TaAYiruhumo Einoda Qll-ehi, meaning Their evil fortune, which will overtake them, is only that which is threatened to befall them in the latter state, [with God,] and not that which befalls them in the present state of existence: (TA:) or the cause of their good and evil is only with God; i. e., it is his decree and will: or the cause of their evil fortune is only with God; i. e., it is their works, which are registered with Him. (Bḍ.) It is said in a trad., that Moḥammad liked what is termed faOol, and disliked what is termed Tiyarap↓: (Ṣ:) and in another, that he denied there being any such thing as the latter. (TA.)

Also The means of subsistence; syn. rizoqN. (Ḳ:) or misery: or happiness: every one of these three significations has been assigned to it in the Ḳur xvii. 14: in which, accord. to AM, it is meant that God has decreed to every man happiness or misery, according as He foresaw that he would be obedient or disobedient. (TA.) [See also what immediately follows.]

Also The actions of a man which are [as it were] attached as a necklace to his neck. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And this is [also said by some to be] its signification in the Ḳur xvii. 14. (Jel.) [The actions of a man are the cause of his happiness or misery.]
AlT-aAYiru signifies also The brain. (AAF, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: OaToyaru mino EuqaAbK [More swift of flight than an eagle] is a prov. said of an EqAb because it may be in the morning in El-'Irák and in the evening in El-Yemen. (Meyd.)

hom.sense: maTaArN [A place to or from which a bird or other thing flies: in the phrase TaAra qalobiI maTaArahu, (see 1,) it lit. signifies a place to which one would fly:] a place of flying. (TA.)
OaroDN maTaArapN [and muTiyrapN↓ (see 4)] A land abounding with birds. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
HaforN maTaArN, (O,) and biYorN maTaArapN, (O, Ḳ,) [A pit, or cavity, and a well,] wide in the mouth. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense:
muTaArN Made to fly away: En-Nábighah says,
walirahoTi Har-aAbK waqad-K suwrapN
fiI Almajodi layosa guraAbuhu bimuTaAri
[And to the family of Harráb and Kadd belongs an eminence in glory of which they fear not any diminution: lit., of which the crow is not made to fly away; the greatness of their glory being likened to abundant seed-produce, as has been shown above: see 2]: (Ṣ:) AʼObeyd says that Harráb and Kadd were two men of the BenooAsad. (TA in art. qd.)
See also Tay-aArN.
muTiyrapN: see maTaArN.

hom.sense: muTay-arN A sort of [garment of the kind called] burod (O, Ḳ) having upon it the forms of birds. (O.)

And Aloes-wood: (Ḳ:) or a certain preparation thereof: (AḤn, TA:) or such as is muTar-FI [i. e. mixed with some other odoriferous substance]; formed by transposition from the latter word; (O, Ḳ;) but this pleased not ISd: (TA:) or aloes-wood split and broken in pieces. (O, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: musotaTaArN [Made to fly.]

[And hence,] † A horse that hastens, or is quick, in running: (Ḳ:) that runs quickly. (TṢ, L.) It is contracted by the poet 'Adee into musoTaAr, or muSoTaAr. (TA.) And musoTaArN for musotaTaArN is applied as an epithet to wine. (TA. [No ex. is there given to indicate the meaning.])

musotaTiyrN ‡ Spreading; applied to dust; as also Tay-aArN↓; (TA;) and to hoariness; and to evil: (L:) rising and spreading; (Ḳ;) whereof the light spreads in the horizon; applied to the true dawn, which renders it unlawful to the faster to eat or drink or indulge in other carnal pleasure, and on the appearance of which the prayer of daybreak may be performed, and which is termed AlxiyoTu AlOaboyaDu: that to which the epithet musotaTiyl is applied is [the false dawn,] that which is likened to the tail of the wolf (canabu Als-iroHaAni), and is termed AlxiyoTu AlOasowadu; and this does not render anything unlawful to the faster. (TA.)
Also A dog excited by lust; (Lth, O, Ḳ;) and so a camel; (Ḳ;) or the epithet applied in this sense to the latter is haAYijN. (Lth, O, TA.)

1. TaAXa, aor. yaTiyXu, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. TayoXN (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TayaXaAnN, (TA, [there only said to be syn. with TayoXN, but it is well known, and often occurring, as an inf. n. of TAX in the first of the senses here explained,]) He was, or became, light, inconstant, unsteady, irresolute, or fickle, syn. of the inf. n. xif-apN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or contr. of HilomN, (IDrd, O,) and i. q. nazaqN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) after gravity, or sedateness: (TA:) or light of intellect; lightwitted: (TA:) and he became bereft of his reason, or intellect, (Sh, A, O, Ḳ,) so as to be ignorant of that which he would endeavour to do. (Sh, O.) [And, said of a beast, He was, or became, restless, or unsteady.]
TaAXato yaduhu fiI AlS-aHofapi His hand was light, or active, in the bowl, and took from every side. (TA.)
TaAXato rijolaAhu His legs were in a state of commotion. (TA.)
TaAXa Als-ahomu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. TayoXN, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) The arrow passed beyond the butt: (A, Ḳ:) or declined, or turned aside, Eani Alhadafi from the butt; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and did not hit it. (Mṣb.)
TaAXato Eani AlOum-i rijoluhu His leg turned aside [from the root thereof]: a phrase used by Aboo-Sahm El-Hudhalee, whose leg had been cut off. (TA.)
4. ATAXhu [He, or it, rendered him light, inconstant, unsteady,, &c.]. (TA in art. sfh.)
ATAX Als-ahoma He made the arrow to decline, or turn aside, Eani Alhadafi from the butt. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[TayoXapN A fit of TayoX, i. e. lightness, or levity, inconstancy, unsteadiness, irresoluteness, or fickleness;, &c. See 1.]
Tay-aAXN: see TaAYiXN, in three places.

TaAYiXN (A, O, Ḳ) and Tay-aAXN↓, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) [but the latter has an intensive signification,] applied to a man, (Ṣ, O,) Light, inconstant, unsteady, irresolute, or fickle, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) after gravity, or sedateness: (TA:) or light of intellect; lightwitted: [&c.: see 1:] (TA:) and [so] TaAYiXu All-ub-i: (A:) and for the pl. you say qawomN TaAXapN, (A, TA,) and Tay-aAXapN↓: (TA:) and Tay-aAXN↓ signifies one who does not pursue one course, (A, O, Ḳ,) in consequence of the lightness of his intellect. (TA.)
[Also, applied to a beast, Restless, or unsteady.]
Also, both epithets, but the latter has an intensive signification, An arrow that declines, or turns aside, Eani Alhadafi from the butt; and does not hit it. (Mṣb.)
AlOaToyaXu A certain bird: (Aboo-Málik, Ḳ:) app. because of its lightness, or activity, and frequent state of commotion. (TA.)
1. TaAEa, aor. yaTiyEu, inf. n. TayoEN: see 1 in art. TwE.

1. TaAfa AlxayaAlu, aor. yaTiyfu, inf. n. TayofN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maTaAfN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) thus says Aṣ: (TA:) and TaAfa, aor. yaTuwfu, inf. n. TawofN; (O, Ḳ;) thus says El-Mufaddal: (O, TA:) The xyAl [i. e. apparition, or phantom,] came (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) in sleep. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And TAf bihi AlxayaAlu The xyAl came to him, or visited him, (Oalam-a bihi,) in sleep. (TA in art. Twf,)

2. Ty-f, inf. n. taToyiyfN, He went round or round about, or circuited, much, or often; as also Tw-f: (Ḳ:) but, (TA,) IDrd says, ATAf↓ and Ty-f and tTy-f↓ are the same in meaning: (O, TA:) therefore what is said in the Ḳ requires consideration: tTy-f↓ signifies as above. (TA.)
4. ATAf: see the next preceding paragraph: and see also art. Twf.
5: see 2, in two places.

TayofN An apparition, a phantom, a spectre, or an imaginary form, (xayaAlN,) coming in sleep; (IDrd, O, Ḳ;) one says Tayofu xayaAlK and TaAYifu↓ xayaAlK [meaning thus]: (IDrd, O:) or anything that obscures the sight, [arising] from a vain suggestion of the Devil: (Lth, TA:) or a jinnee, and a human being, and a xayaAl, that comes to, or visits, a man [generally in sleep];
as also TaAYifN↓; so says IF in art. Twf: (Mṣb:) both of these words signify alike; i. e. a thing like the xayaAl; and a thing that comes to one, or visits one: (Fr, TA:) and TiyfN↓, with kesr, signifies a xayaAl itself: (Kr, TA:) or [TayofN is properly, or originally, an inf. n.; and] Tayofu AlxayaAli signifies the coming of the xyAl in sleep: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:*) accord. to El-Mufaddal, (O,) one says TayofN as meaning TaAYifu xayaAlK because it is originally [TayowifN, and then] Tay-ifN; like may-itN and mayotN from maAta, aor. yamuwtu. (O, Ḳ.) Tayofu AlX-ayoTaAni and TaAYifuhu↓ signify The Devil's visitation, by touch, or madness or insanity, (biQlomas-i,) or by vain prompting or suggestion: (Mṣb:) or TayofN mina AlX-ayoTaAni signifies A touch, or slight degree, or somewhat [of a taint or an infection], of insanity or possession, from the Devil; syn. lamamN; occurring in the Ḳur vii. 200, accord. to one reading; another reading being TaAYifN↓ mina AlX-ayoTaAni, which signifies the same. (Ṣ, O. [See also TawofN.]) One says also Tayofu junuwnK [A touch, or slight degree, of insanity, or diabolical possession]. (Ṣ, O.) And TayofN [alone] signifies Insanity, or diabolical possession: (O, Ḳ:) so says AʼObeyd, on the authority of El-Ahmar: (TA:) and this is said by Az to be the meaning of the word in the language of the Arabs. (O, TA.)

And † Anger: (I’Ab, Mujáhid, O, Ḳ:) because the intellect of the angry departs [for a time] so that he assumes the the likeness of the insane, or possessed: (O, TA:) said by I’Ab to mean thus in the Ḳur vii. 200. (TA.)
TiyfN: see the next preceding paragraph.
TiyaAfN The blackness of night: or this is [TinaAfN,] with n. (TA.)
TaAYifN: see TayofN, in four places: and see art. Twf.
TiylN: TiylN: TiylapN: TiyalapN: Tiyal-N: TiyaAlN: and Tay-ilapN: see in art. Twl.

1. TaAnahu, aor. yaTiynu, (Ṣ,* Mṣb,) inf. n. TayonN; (Mṣb;) or Ty-nhu↓, (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ,) but some disapprove this, (Ṣ,) or this denotes intensiveness and muchness; (Mṣb;) He plastered it, or coated it, with Tiyn [i. e. clay, or mud], (Ṣ,* MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) namely, a roof, or flat housetop, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and a house, or chamber, (Mṣb,) or a wall. (MA.)
And the former, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and ↓the latter also, (TA,) He sealed it with Tiyn [i. e. clay], namely, a writing; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and so OaTaAnahu↓. (TA in art. EnI.)

And [hence,] TaAnahu Qll-ehu EalaI Alxayori † God created him with an adaptation, or a disposition, to that which is good; adapted him, or disposed him, by creation, or nature, thereto; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also TaAmahu: so says ISk, and he cites as an ex.,
OalaA tiloka nafosN Tiyna fiyhaA HayaAWuhaA . (Ṣ) meaning [Verily that is a soul] of which the sense of shame is the natural quality. (TA.)

And TAn, said of a man, signifies also Has-ana Eamalahu [i. e. He made his work, or deed, good; he performed, or executed, his deed, or work, well]; as also TaAma: thus expl. by IAạr: in the Ḳ, the former is erroneously expl. as meaning Has-ana Eamala AlT-iyni. (TA.)
2: see the foregoing paragraph {1}, in two places.
4: see the first paragraph {1}.
5. tTy-n He (a man, TA) became defiled, or besmeared, with Tiyn [i. e. clay, earth, or mud]. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: yawomN TaAnN, (Ṣ,) and makaAnN TaAnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and OaroDN TaAnapN, (Ṣ,) [A day, and a place, and a land,] in which is much Tiyn [meaning mud]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also what next follows.

entry.sense: TiynN a word of well-known meaning, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) of which TaAnN↓ is a dial. var.; (TA;) Clay, earth, mould, soil, or mud: (MA, KL, &c.:) it differs in different layers, or strata, of the earth; the best is the pure, unmixed with sand, remaining after the subsiding of the waters; and the best of this is that of Egypt, which has a peculiar property of preventing plague, or pestilence, and the corruption of water into which it is thrown: it is of several sorts; among which are AlT-iynu Almaxotuwmu [Terra sigillata, or Lemnian earth], and AlT-iynu AlOaromaniI-u [Armenian bole], &c.: (TA:) TiynapN↓ has a more particular signification, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) meaning a piece, or portion, thereof, (Ḳ, TA,) [as a piece of clay] with which a [writing of the kind termed] Sak- and the like are sealed. (TA.) [Hence,] Xahowapu AlT-iyni [The longing for clay; a sort of malacia]. (TA voce Hum-aADN.) And Aibonu AlT-iyni Adam. (T in art. bnI.)
TiynapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Also [† A material substance considered as that of which a thing having form consists.]

[And hence,] ‡ The natural, or native, constitution or disposition. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One says, huwa mina AlT-iynapi AlOuwlaI ‡ [app. meaning He is of the primitive kind of natural constitution or disposition]. (Ṣ, TA.) And Uin-ahu layaAbisu AlT-iynapi ‡ [Verily he is tough in respect of natural constitution or disposition;] meaning he is not easy [in disposition]. (TA.)
[TiyniI-N Of, or relating to, AlT-iyn i. e. clay, &c.; clayey, earthy,, &c.]
[And † Of, or relating to AlT-iynap i. e. the natural, or native, constitution or disposition; natural, or native.]
TiyaAnapN The art of working in, or with, Tiyn [or clay, &c.; and particularly the art of plastering with clay, or mud]. (Ḳ.)
Tay-aAnN A worker in, or with, Tiyn [or clay, &c.; and particularly a plasterer with clay or mud]. (TA.) [Tay-aAnu, imperfectly decl., belongs to art. TwI.]
maTiynN A roof, or flat house-top, [&c.,] plastered, or coated, with Tiyn [i. e. clay, or mud]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
